EDITED, FROM NUMEROUS MANUSCRIPTS BY THE REV. WALTER W. SKEAT, LITT.D., D.C.L., LL.D., PH.D. ELRINGTON AND BOSWORTH PROFESSOR OF ANGLO-SAXON AND FELLOW OF CHRIST'S COLLEGE, CAMBRIDGE
BEING A SUPPLEMENT TO THE COMPLETE WORKS OF GEOFFREY CHAUCER (OXFORD, IN SIX VOLUMES, 1894)

Q.L: 'And yit ye shul han better loos,
Right in dispyt of alle your foos,
Than worthy is; and that anoon.'

DIV1.P: Oxford AT THE CLARENDON PRESS MDCCCXCVII

DIV1.HEAD: THE TESTAMENT OF LOVE.

DIV2.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV2.P: MANY men there ben that, with eeres openly sprad, so moche swalowen the deliciousnesse of jestes and of ryme, 2. delyciousness; (and elsewhere, y is often replaced by i). by queynt knitting coloures, that of the goodnesse or of the badnesse of the sentence take they litel hede or els non. 4. none.

Soothly, dul wit and a thoughtful soule so sore have myned 5. Sothely. wytte. and graffed in my spirites, that suche craft of endyting wol not ben of myn acqueyntaunce. And, for rude wordes and boystous percen the herte of the herer to the in[ne]rest point, and planten 8. inrest poynte. there the sentence of thinges, so that with litel helpe it is able to springe; this book, that nothing hath of the greet flode of 10. spring. boke. great floode. wit ne of semelich colours, is dolven with rude wordes and boystous, and so drawe togider, to maken the cacchers therof 12. catchers. ben the more redy to hente sentence. 13. hent.

Some men there ben that peynten with colours riche, and some with vers, as with red inke, and some with coles and chalke; and yet is there good matere to the leude people of thilke chalky purtreyture, as hem thinketh for the tyme; and afterward the sight of the better colours yeven to hem more 18. afterwarde. joye for the first leudnesse. So, sothly, this leude clowdy occu∣pacion 19. leudenesse. is not to prayse but by the leude; for comunly leude 20. comenly. leudnesse commendeth. Eke it shal yeve sight, that other 21. leudenesse. precious thinges shal be the more in reverence. In Latin and French hath many soverayne wittes had greet delyt to 23. gret delyte.
endyte, and have many noble thinges fulfild; but certes, there 24. fulfylde. ben some that speken their poysye-mater in Frenche, of whiche speche the Frenche men have as good a fantasye as we have in hering of Frenche mennes English. And many termes there 27. englysshe. ben in English, [of] whiche unneth we Englishmen connen declare 28. englysshe; supply of. englyssh-. the knowleginge. How shulde than a Frenche man born suche 29. Howe. borne. termes conne jumpere in his mater, but as the jay chatereth English? Right so, trewly, the understanding of Englishmen 31. englyssh. englyssh-. wol not strecche to the privy termes in Frenche, what-so-ever we 32. stretche. bosten of straunge langage. Let than clerkes endyten in Latin, for they have the propertee of science, and the knowinge in that 34. propertie. facultee; and let Frenchmen in their Frenche also endyten their 35. facultie. lette. queynt termes, for it is kyndely to their mouthes; and let us shewe our fantasyes in suche wordes as we lerneden of our dames tonge.

And although this book be litel thank-worthy for the leudnesse 39. boke. thanke worthy. in travaile, yet suche wrytinges excyten men to thilke thinges that ben necessarie; for every man therby may, as by a perpetual mirrour, seen the vyces or vertues of other, in which thing 42. sene. lightly may be conceyved to eschewe perils, and necessaries to cacche, after as aventures have fallen to other people or persons. 44. catche.

Certes, [perfeccion is] the soveraynest thing of desyre, and 45. I supply perfeccion is; to make sense. soueraynst. moste †creatures resonable have, or els shulde have, ful appetyte 46. creature (sic). reasonable. to their perfeccion; unresonable beestes mowen not, sith reson 47. sythe reason. hath in hem no werking. Than resonable that wol not is com∣parisoned to unresonable, and made lyke hem. For-sothe, the most soverayne and fynal perfeccion of man is in knowing of 47,50. perfection. a sothe, withouten any entent disceyvable, and in love of oon 51. one. very god that is inchaungeable; that is, to knowe and love his creatour.

¶ Now, principally, the mene to bringe in knowleging and 54. Nowe. meane. loving his creatour is the consideracion of thinges made by the creatour, wherthrough, by thilke thinges that ben made under∣stonding 56. be (for by). stonding here to our wittes, arn the unsene privitees of god 57. arne. made to us sightful and knowing, in our contemplacion and understonding. These thinges than, forsoth, moche bringen us
to the ful knowleginge [of] sothe, and to the parfit love of the 60. I supply of. parfyte. maker of hevenly thinges. Lo, David sayth, 'thou hast delyted 61. haste. me in makinge,' as who sayth, to have delyt in the tune, how god 62. delyte (this sentence is corrupt). hath lent me in consideracion of thy makinge.

Wherof Aristotle, in the boke de Animalibus, saith to naturel 64. saythe. philosophers: 'it is a greet lyking in love of knowinge their 65. great. creatour; and also in knowinge of causes in kyndely thinges.' Considred, forsoth, the formes of kyndly thinges and the shap, 66,67. thynges consydred. Forsoth (sic). a greet kindely love me shulde have to the werkman that 68. great. me (sic); for men. hem made. The crafte of a werkman is shewed in the werke. Herfore, truly, the philosophers, with a lyvely studie, many noble thinges right precious and worthy to memory writen; and by a greet swetande travayle to us leften of causes [of] the 72. great. Supply of. propertees in natures of thinges. To whiche (therfore) philo∣sophers 73. propertyes. it was more joy, more lykinge, more herty lust, in kyndely vertues and maters of reson, the perfeccion by busy 75. matters of reason. perfection. study to knowe, than to have had al the tresour, al the richesse, 76. treasour. al the vainglory that the passed emperours, princes, or kinges hadden. Therfore the names of hem, in the boke of perpetual memory, in vertue and pees arn writen; and in the contrarye, 79. peace. that is to sayne, in Styx, the foule pitte of helle, arn thilke pressed 80. stixe. that suche goodnesse hated. And bycause this book shal be of 81. boke. love, and the pryme causes of steringe in that doinge, with passions and diseses for wantinge of desyre, I wil that this book be cleped 83. dyseases. boke. THE TESTAMENT OF LOVE.

But now, thou reder, who is thilke that wil not in scorne 85. nowe. laughe, to here a dwarfe, or els halfe a man, say he wil rende out the swerde of Hercules handes, and also he shuld sette 87. set. Hercules Gades a myle yet ferther; and over that, he had power of strengthe to pulle up the spere, that Alisander the 89. pul. noble might never wagge? And that, passing al thinge, to ben mayster of Fraunce by might, there-as the noble gracious Edward the thirde, for al his greet prowesse in victories, ne might al yet 92. great. conquere?

Certes, I wot wel, ther shal be mad more scorne and jape 94. wote. made. of me, that I, so unworthily clothed al-togider in the cloudy cloude 95. vnworthely.
of unconninge, wil putten me in prees to speke of love, or els of the causes in that matter, sithen al the grettest clerkes han had ynough to don, and (as who sayth) †gadered up clene toforn 98. gathered. toforne. hem, and with their sharpe sythes of conning al mowen, and mad therof grete rekes and noble, ful of al plentees, to fede me 100. made. great. plentyes. and many another. Envye, forsothe, commendeth nought his reson that he hath in hayne, be it never so trusty. And al-though 102. reason. hayn (sic). 102. -thoughe. these noble repers, as good workmen and worthy their hyre, 103. hyer. han al drawe and bounde up in the sheves, and mad many 104. made. shockes, yet have I ensample to gadere the smale crommes, 105. gader. and fullen my walet of tho that fallen from the borde among 106. fullyn. amonge. the smale houndes, notwithstandinge the travayle of the almoigner, that hath drawe up in the cloth al the remissailes, 108. remyssayles. as trenchours, and the relief, to bere to the almesse. 109. relyef.

Yet also have I leve of the noble husbande Boëce, al-though I be a straunger of conninge, to come after his doctrine, and these grete workmen, and glene my handfuls of the shedinge 112. great. after their handes; and, if me faile ought of my ful, to encrese 113. encrease. my porcion with that I shal drawe by privitees out of the shocke. 114. priuytyes. A slye servaunt in his owne helpe is often moche commended; knowing of trouth in causes of thinges was more hardyer in the 116. knoweyng. first sechers (and so sayth Aristotle), and lighter in us that han folowed after. For their passing †studies han fresshed our wittes, 118. study (sic). and our understandinge han excyted, in consideracion of trouth, by sharpnesse of their resons. Utterly these thinges be no 120. reasons. dremes ne japes, to throwe to hogges; it is lyflich mete for 121. lyfelyche meate. children of trouthe; and as they me betiden, whan I pilgrimaged 122. betiden (sic); past tense. out of my kith in winter; whan the †weder out of mesure was 123. wether. measure. boystous, and the wylde wind Boreas, as his kind asketh, with 124. wynde Borias. kynde. dryinge coldes maked the wawes of the occian-see so to aryse 125. dryenge. unkyndely over the commune bankes, that it was in poynte to spille al the erthe. 127. spyl. (rubric) boke.
DIV2.TRAILER: Thus endeth the Prologue; and here-after foloweth the first book of the Testament of Love.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER I.
DIV3.P: ALAS! Fortune! alas! I that som-tyme in delicious houres was wont to enjoye blisful stoundes, am now drive by CH. I. 2. enjoy. unhappy hevinesse to bewaile my sondry yvels in tene! 3. sondrye.

Trewly, I leve, in myn herte is writte, of perdurable letters, al the entencions of lamentacion that now ben y-nempned! For any 5. nowe. maner disese outward, in sobbing maner, sheweth sorowful yexinge 6. disease outwarde. from within. Thus from my comfort I ginne to spille, sith she 7. comforte. that shulde me solace is fer fro my presence. Certes, her 8. ferre. absence is to me an helle; my sterving deth thus in wo it myneth, 9. hell. dethe. that endeles care is throughout myne herte clenched; blisse of 10. endelesse. my joye, that ofte me murthed, is turned in-to galle, to thinke on thing that may not, at my wil, in armes me hente! Mirth is 12. hent. chaunged in-to tene, whan swink is there continually that reste was 13. swynke. wont to sojourne and have dwelling-place. Thus witless, thought∣ful, 14. dwellynge-. wytlesse. sightles lokinge, I endure my penaunce in this derke prison, 15. syghtlesse. prisone. †caitived fro frendshippe and acquaintaunce, and forsaken of al 16. caytisned (for caytifued). that any †word dare speke. Straunge hath by waye of intrucioun 17. wode (!); for worde; read word. mad his home, there me shulde be, if reson were herd as he 18. made. reason. herde. shulde. Never-the-later yet hertly, lady precious Margarit, have mynde on thy servaunt; and thinke on his disese, how lightles he 20. disease. liveth, sithe the bemes brennende in love of thyn eyen are so 21. beames. bewent, that worldes and cloudes atwene us twey wol nat suffre 22. For be-went, Th. has be-went. my thoughtes of hem to be enlumined! Thinke that oon vertue 23. one. of a Margarite precious is, amonges many other, the sorouful to comforte; yet †whyles that, me sorouful to comforte, is my lust 25. wyl of; apparently an error for whyles (which I adopt). luste. to have nought els at this tyme, d[r]ede ne deth ne no maner 26. dede (for drede). traveyle hath no power, myn herte so moche to fade, as shulde 27. myne. to here of a twinkling in your disese! Ah! god forbede that; 28. twynckelynge. disease. but yet let me deye, let me sterve withouten any mesure of 29. lette (twice). dey. measure. penaunce, rather than myn hertely thinking comfort in ought 30. myne. comforte. were disesed! What may my service avayle, in absence of her 31. diseased. maye. aueyle. that my service shulde accepte? Is this nat endeles sorowe to 32. endlesse.
thinke? Yes, yes, god wot; myn herte breketh nigh a-sonder. 33. wote; myne hert breaketh. How shulde the ground, without kyndly noriture, bringen forth 34. howe. grounde. forthe. any frutes? How shulde a ship, withouten a sterne, in the grete see 35. howe. shippe. great. be governed? How shulde I, withouten my blisse, my herte, my 36. Howe. desyre, my joye, my goodnesse, endure in this contrarious prison, that thinke every hour in the day an hundred winter? Wel may now Eve sayn to me, 'Adam, in sorowe fallen from welth, driven 39. nowe. sayne. art thou out of paradise, with swete thy sustenaunce to be∣swinke!' 40. arte. weate. Depe in this pyninge pitte with wo I ligge y-stocked, with chaynes linked of care and of tene. It is so hye from thens I lye and the commune erth, there ne is cable in no lande maked, that might strecche to me, to drawe me in-to blisse; ne steyers 44. stretche. to steye on is none; so that, without recover, endeles here to 45. stey. endlesse. endure, I wot wel, I [am] purveyed. O, where art thou now, 46. wotte. I supply am. spurveyde. arte. nowe. frendship, that som-tyme, with laughande chere, madest bothe 47. frenshyppe (sic). face and countenaunce to me-wardes? Truely, now art thou 48. nowe arte. went out of towne. But ever, me thinketh, he wereth his olde 49. weareth. clothes, and that the soule in the whiche the lyfe of frendship was in, is drawen out from his other spirites. Now than, farewel, 51. Nowe. frendship! and farewel, felawes! Me thinketh, ye al han taken your leve; no force of you al at ones. But, lady of love, ye wote 53. leaue. what I mene; yet thinke on thy servaunt that for thy love spilleth; al thinges have I forsake to folowen thyn hestes; rewarde me with a thought, though ye do naught els. Remem∣braunce of love lyth so sore under my brest, that other thought 57. lythe. cometh not in my mynde but gladnesse, to thinke on your goodnesse and your mery chere; †ferdnes and sorowe, to thinke on your 59. frendes (sic); for ferdnes; cf. p. 9, l. 9. wreche and your daunger; from whiche Christ me save! My 60. Christe. greet joye it is to have in meditacion the bountees, the vertues, 61. great. bounties. the nobley in you printed; sorowe and helle comen at ones, to 62. hel. suppose that I be †weyved. Thus with care, sorowe, and tene 63. veyned (sic); for weyued. am I shapt, myn ende with dethe to make. Now, good goodly, 64. shapte. Nowe. thinke on this. O wrecched foole that I am, fallen in-to so lowe, 65. wretched. the hete of my brenning tene hath me al defased. How shulde 66. heate. ye, lady, sette prise on so foule fylthe? My conninge is thinne, my wit is exiled; lyke to a foole naturel am I comparisoned. 68. wytte.
Trewly, lady, but your mercy the more were, I wot wel al my 69. wote. labour were in ydel; your mercy than passeth right. God graunt that proposicion to be verifyed in me; so that, by truste of good hope, I mowe come to the haven of ese. And sith it is impos∣sible, 72. ease. sythe. the colours of your qualitees to chaunge: and forsothe I 73. qualyties. wot wel, wem ne spot may not abyde there so noble vertue 74. wote. wemme ne spotte maye. haboundeth, so that the defasing to you is verily [un]imaginable, 75. Read unimaginable. as countenaunce of goodnesse with encresinge vertue is so in you knit, to abyde by necessary maner: yet, if the revers mighte falle 77. knytte. fal. (which is ayenst kynde), I †wot wel myn herte ne shulde therfore 78. wol wel (for wot wel). naught flitte, by the leste poynt of gemetrye; so sadly is it †souded, that away from your service in love may he not departe. 80. sonded; read souded. maye. O love, whan shal I ben plesed? O charitee, whan shal I ben 81. pleased. charyte. esed? O good goodly, whan shal the dyce turne? O ful of 82. eased. vertue, do the chaunce of comfort upwarde to falle! O love, 83. comforte. fal. whan wolt thou thinke on thy servaunt? I can no more but here, out-cast of al welfare, abyde the day of my dethe, or els to see the 85. out caste. daye. se. sight that might al my wellinge sorowes voyde, and of the flode 86. flodde. make an ebbe. These diseses mowen wel, by duresse of sorowe, 87. diseases. make my lyfe to unbodye, and so for to dye; but certes ye, lady, in a ful perfeccion of love ben so knit with my soule, that deth 89. perfectyon. knytte. dethe. may not thilke knotte unbynde ne departe; so that ye and my soule togider †in endeles blisse shulde dwelle; and there shal 91. togyther is endelesse in blysse (!). dwel. my soule at the ful ben esed, that he may have your presence, to 92. eased. shewe th'entent of his desyres. Ah, dere god! that shal be a 93. thentent. greet joye! Now, erthely goddesse, take regarde of thy servant, 94. great. Nowe. though I be feble; for thou art wont to prayse them better that 95. arte wonte. wolde conne serve in love, al be he ful mener than kinges or princes that wol not have that vertue in mynde.

Now, precious Margaryte, that with thy noble vertue hast 98. Nowe. haste. drawen me in-to love first, me weninge therof to have blisse, [ther]-as galle and aloes are so moche spronge, that savour of 100. I supply ther. swetnesse may I not ataste. Alas! that your benigne eyen, in whiche that mercy semeth to have al his noriture, nil by no waye tourne the clerenesse of mercy to me-wardes! Alas! that your brennande vertues, shyning amonges al folk, and enlumininge 104. folke.
al other people by habundaunce of encresing, sheweth to me 105. encreasing. but smoke and no light! These thinges to thinke in myn herte maketh every day weping in myn eyen to renne. These liggen on my backe so sore, that importable burthen me semeth on my backe to be charged; it maketh me backwarde to meve, whan my steppes by comune course even-forth pretende. These 110. forthe. thinges also, on right syde and lift, have me so envolved with care, that wanhope of helpe is throughout me ronne; trewly, †I leve, that graceles is my fortune, whiche that ever sheweth it 112, 113. trewly and leue; read trewly I leve. 113. gracelesse. me-wardes by a cloudy disese, al redy to make stormes of tene; 114. disease. and the blisful syde halt stil awayward, and wol it not suffre to 115. halte. me-wardes to turne; no force, yet wol I not ben conquered.

O, alas! that your nobley, so moche among al other creatures 117. (The sentence be∣ginning O, alas seems hopelessly corrupt; there are pause-marks after vertues and wonderful.) commended by †flowinge streme †of al maner vertues, but 118. folowynge; read flowinge. by; read of. ther ben wonderful, I not whiche that let the flood to come 119. flode. in-to my soule; wherefore, purely mated with sorowe thorough-sought, my-selfe I crye on your goodnesse to have pitè on this caytif, that in the in[ne]rest degree of sorowe and disese is left, 122. caytife. inrest. disease. lefte. and, without your goodly wil, from any helpe and recovery. These sorowes may I not sustene, but-if my sorowe shulde be 124. maye. told and to you-wardes shewed; although moche space is bitwene 125. tolde. us twayne, yet me thinketh that by suche †joleyvinge wordes my 126. ioleynynge (sic). disese ginneth ebbe. Trewly, me thinketh that the sowne of my 127. disease. lamentacious weping is right now flowe in-to your presence, and 128. nowe. there cryeth after mercy and grace, to which thing (me semeth) thee list non answere to yeve, but with a deynous chere ye 130. the lyst none. commaunden it to avoide; but god forbid that any word shuld of 131. worde. you springe, to have so litel routh! Pardè, pitè and mercy in every Margarite is closed by kynde amonges many other vertues, by qualitees of comfort; but comfort is to me right naught worth, 134. qualites of comforte. worthe. withouten mercy and pitè of you alone; whiche thinges hastely god me graunt for his mercy!

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER II.
DIV3.P:
REHERSINGE these thinges and many other, without tyme or moment of rest, me semed, for anguisshe of disese, that CH. II. 2. disease. al-togider I was ravisshed, I can not telle how; but hoolly all my 3. tel howe. holy. passions and felinges weren lost, as it semed, for the tyme; and 4. loste. sodainly a maner of drede lighte in me al at ones; nought suche 5. light. fere as folk have of an enemy, that were mighty and wolde hem 6. feare. folke. greve or don hem disese. For I trowe, this is wel knowe to many 7. done. disease. persones, that otherwhyle, if a man be in his soveraignes presence, a maner of ferdnesse crepeth in his herte, not for harme, but of 9. ferdenesse. goodly subjeccion; namely, as men reden that aungels ben aferde 10. subiection. of our saviour in heven. And pardè, there ne is, ne may no 11. maye. passion of disese be; but it is to mene, that angels ben adradde, 12. disease. meane. not by †ferdnes of drede, sithen they ben perfitly blissed, [but] 13. frendes; read ferdnes; see l. 16. perfytely. I supply but and by. as [by] affeccion of wonderfulnesse and by service of obedience. 14. affection. Suche ferde also han these lovers in presence of their loves, and subjectes aforn their soveraynes. Right so with ferdnesse myn 16. aforne. ferdenesse. herte was caught. And I sodainly astonied, there entred in-to the place there I was logged a lady, the semeliest and most 18. lodged. moste. goodly to my sight that ever to-forn apered to any creature; and 19. to-forne. trewly, in the blustringe of her looke, she yave gladnesse and comfort sodaynly to al my wittes; and right so she doth to 21. comforte sodaynely. dothe. every wight that cometh in her presence. And for she was so goodly, as me thought, myn herte began somdele to be enbolded, 23. myne. beganne. and wexte a litel hardy to speke; but yet, with a quakinge voyce, as I durste, I salued her, and enquired what she was; and why she, so worthy to sight, dayned to entre in-to so foule a dongeon, and namely a prison, without leve of my kepers. 27. prisone. leaue. For certes, al-though the vertue of dedes of mercy strecchen to 28. al-thoughe. stretchen. visiten the poore prisoners, and hem, after that facultees ben had, 29. faculties. to comforte, me semed that I was so fer fallen in-to miserye and 30. ferre. wrecched hid caytifnesse, that me shulde no precious thing 31. wretched hyd. thynge. neighe; and also, that for my sorowe every wight shulde ben hevy, and wisshe my recovery. But whan this lady had somdele 33. heauy.
apperceyved, as wel by my wordes as by my chere, what thought besied me within, with a good womanly countenance she sayde these wordes:—

'O my nory, wenest thou that my maner be, to foryete my 37. wenyst. foryet. frendes or my servauntes? Nay,' quod she, 'it is my ful entente 38. naye. to visyte and comforte al my frendshippes and allyes, as wel in 39. frenshippes. alyes. tyme of perturbacion as of moost propertee of blisse; in me shal 40. propertye. unkyndnesse never be founden: and also, sithen I have so fewe especial trewe now in these dayes. Wherefore I may wel at more 42. nowe. leysar come to hem that me deserven; and if my cominge may 42, 43. maye. in any thinge avayle, wete wel, I wol come often.'

'Now, good lady,' quod I, 'that art so fayre on to loke, 45. Nowe. reyninge hony by thy wordes, blisse of paradys arn thy lokinges, 46. honny. paradise. joye and comfort are thy movinges. What is thy name? How 47. comforte. howe. is it that in you is so mokel werkinge vertues enpight, as me semeth, and in none other creature that ever saw I with myne 49. sawe. eyen?'

'My disciple,' quod she, 'me wondreth of thy wordes and on thee, that for a litel disese hast foryeten my name. Wost thou 52. the. disease haste. Woste. not wel that I am LOVE, that first thee brought to thy service?' 53. the.

'O good lady,' quod I, 'is this worship to thee or to thyn 54. worshyppe. the thyne. excellence, for to come in-to so foule a place? Pardè, somtyme, tho I was in prosperitè and with forayne goodes envolved, I had mokil to done to drawe thee to myn hostel; and yet many 57. the. werninges thou madest er thou liste fully to graunte, thyn home 58. graunt thyne. to make at my dwelling-place; and now thou comest goodly by 59. nowe. thyn owne vyse, to comforte me with wordes; and so there∣thorough 60. thyne. I ginne remembre on passed gladnesse. Trewly, lady, 61. thoroughe. I ne wot whether I shal say welcome or non, sithen thy coming 62. wotte. none. wol as moche do me tene and sorowe, as gladnesse and mirthe. See why: for that me comforteth to thinke on passed gladnesse, 64. se. that me anoyeth efte to be in doinge. Thus thy cominge bothe gladdeth and teneth, and that is cause of moche sorowe. Lo, lady, how than I am comforted by your comminge'; and with that 67. howe. I gan in teeres to distille, and tenderly wepe.

'Now, certes,' quod Love, 'I see wel, and that me over∣thinketh, 69. Nowe. se.
that wit is thee fayleth, and [thou] art in pointe 70. wytte in the. I supply thou. arte. to dote.'
'Trewly,' quod I, 'that have ye maked, and that ever wol I rue.'

'Wottest thou not wel,' quod she, 'that every shepherde ought 74. shepeherde. by reson to seke his sperkelande sheep, that arn ronne in-to 75. shepe. arne. wildernesse among busshes and perils, and hem to their pasture 76. amonge. ayen-bringe, and take on hem privy besy cure of keping? And though the unconninge sheep scattred wolde ben lost, renning to 78. tho. shepe. loste. wildernesse, and to desertes drawe, or els wolden putte hem-selfe 79. put. to the swalowinge wolfe, yet shal the shepherde, by businesse and 80. shepeherde. travayle, so putte him forth, that he shal not lete hem be lost by 81. put. forthe. let. loste. no waye. A good shepherde putteth rather his lyf to ben lost for his sheep. But for thou shalt not wene me being of werse condicion, trewly, for everich of my folke, and for al tho that to me-ward be knit in any condicion, I wol rather dye than suffre 85. mewarde. hem through errour to ben spilte. For me liste, and it me lyketh, 86. throughe. of al myne a shepherdesse to be cleped. Wost thou not wel, I fayled never wight, but he me refused and wolde negligently go with unkyndenesse? And yet, pardè, have I many such holpe and releved, and they have ofte me begyled; but ever, at the ende, it discendeth in their owne nekkes. Hast thou not rad how kinde 91. Haste. radde howe. I was to Paris, Priamus sone of Troy? How Jason me falsed, 92. sonne. for al his false behest? How Cesars †swink, I lefte it for no tene 93. For false read faire. howe Sesars sonke (sic); corrupt. til he was troned in my blisse for his service? What!' quod she, 'most of al, maked I not a loveday bytwene god and mankynde, 95. louedaye. and chees a mayde to be nompere, to putte the quarel at ende? 96. chese. put. Lo! how I have travayled to have thank on al sydes, and yet list 97. howe. thanke. me not to reste, and I might fynde on †whom I shulde werche. 98. rest. home; read whom. But trewly, myn owne disciple, bycause I have thee founde, at al 99. the. assayes, in thy wil to be redy myn hestes to have folowed and hast ben trewe to that Margarite-perle that ones I thee shewed; 101. haste. the. and she alwaye, ayenward, hath mad but daungerous chere; 102. ayenwarde. made. I am come, in propre person, to putte thee out of errours, and 103. put the. make thee gladde by wayes of reson; so that sorow ne disese shal 104. the. reason. disease.
no more hereafter thee amaistry. Wherthrought I hope thou 105. the. shalt lightly come to the grace, that thou longe hast desyred, of 106. shalte. haste. thilke jewel. Hast thou not herd many ensamples, how I have 107. Haste. herde. howe. comforted and releved the scholers of my lore? Who hath worthyed kinges in the felde? Who hath honoured ladyes in boure by a perpetuel mirrour of their tr[o]uthe in my service? Who hath caused worthy folk to voyde vyce and shame? Who 111. folke. hath holde cytees and realmes in prosperitè? If thee liste clepe 112. cyties. the. cleape. ayen thyn olde remembraunce, thou coudest every point of this 113. poynte. declare in especial; and say that I, thy maistresse, have be cause, causing these thinges and many mo other.'

'Now, y-wis, madame,' quod I, 'al these thinges I knowe wel 116. Nowe. my-selfe, and that thyn excellence passeth the understanding of us beestes; and that no mannes wit erthely may comprehende thy 118. wytte. vertues.'

'Wel than,' quod she, 'for I see thee in disese and sorowe, 120. se the in disease. I wot wel thou art oon of my nories; I may not suffre thee so to 121. wote. arte one. maye. the. make sorowe, thyn owne selfe to shende. But I my-selfe come to be thy fere, thyn hevy charge to make to seme the lesse. For wo 123. thyne. is him that is alone; and to the sorye, to ben moned by a sorouful wight, it is greet gladnesse. Right so, with my sicke frendes I am 125. great. sicke; and with sorie I can not els but sorowe make, til whan I have hem releved in suche wyse, that gladnesse, in a maner of counterpaysing, shal restore as mokil in joye as the passed hevi∣nesse biforn did in tene. And also,' quod she, 'whan any of my 129. byforne. servauntes ben alone in solitary place, I have yet ever besied me to be with hem, in comfort of their hertes, and taught hem to 131. comforte. make songes of playnte and of blisse, and to endyten letters of rethorike in queynt understondinges, and to bethinke hem in what wyse they might best their ladies in good service plese; and 134. please. also to lerne maner in countenaunce, in wordes, and in bering, 135. bearyng. and to ben meke and lowly to every wight, his name and fame to encrese; and to yeve gret yeftes and large, that his renomè may 137. encrease. maye. springen. But thee therof have I excused; for thy losse and thy 138. the. grete costages, wherthrough thou art nedy, arn nothing to me 139. great. wherthroughe. arte. arne no-thinge. unknowen; but I hope to god somtyme it shal ben amended, as
thus I sayd. In norture have I taught al myne; and in curtesye 141. thus as I; om. as. made hem expert, their ladies hertes to winne; and if any wolde [b]en deynous or proude, or be envious or of wrecches acqueyn∣taunce, 143. endeynous; read ben deynous. wretches. hasteliche have I suche voyded out of my scole. For 144. schole. al vyces trewly I hate; vertues and worthinesse in al my power I avaunce.'

'Ah! worthy creature,' quod I, 'and by juste cause the name of goddesse dignely ye mowe bere! In thee lyth the grace 148. beare. the lythe. thorough whiche any creature in this worlde hath any goodnesse. Trewly, al maner of blisse and preciousnesse in vertue out of thee springen and wellen, as brokes and rivers proceden from 151. the. their springes. And lyke as al waters by kynde drawen to the see, so al kyndely thinges thresten, by ful appetyte of desyre, to drawe after thy steppes, and to thy presence aproche as to their kyndely perfeccion. How dare than beestes in this worlde aught forfete 155. perfection. Howe. ayenst thy devyne purveyaunce? Also, lady, ye knowen al the privy thoughtes; in hertes no counsayl may ben hid from your 157. counsayle maye. hydde. knowing. Wherfore I wot wel, lady, that ye knowe your-selfe that 158. wote. I in my conscience am and have ben willinge to your service, al coude I never do as I shulde; yet, forsothe, fayned I never to love otherwyse than was in myn herte; and if I coude have made chere to one and y-thought another, as many other doon alday 162. doone aldaye. afore myn eyen, I trowe it wolde not me have vayled.'
'Certes,' quod she, 'haddest thou so don, I wolde not now 164. done. nowe. have thee here visited.' 165. the.

'Ye wete wel, lady, eke,' quod I, 'that I have not played raket, 166. playde. "nettil in, docke out," and with the wethercocke waved; and trewly, there ye me sette, by acorde of my conscience I wolde not flye, til ye and reson, by apert strength, maden myn herte to 169. reason. aperte. tourne.'

'In good fayth,' quod she, 'I have knowe thee ever of tho 171. faythe. the. condicions; and sithen thou woldest (in as moch as in thee was) 172. the. a made me privy of thy counsayl and juge of thy conscience 173. counsayle. (though I forsook it in tho dayes til I saw better my tyme), wolde 174. forsoke. never god that I shuld now fayle; but ever I wol be redy 175. nowe. witnessing thy sothe, in what place that ever I shal, ayenst al tho that wol the contrary susteyne. And for as moche as to me is
naught unknowen ne hid of thy privy herte, but al hast thou tho 178. hert. thinges mad to me open at the ful, that hath caused my cominge 179. made. in-to this prison, to voyde the webbes of thyne eyen, to make thee 180. the. clerely to see the errours thou hast ben in. And bycause that 181. se. men ben of dyvers condicions, some adradde to saye a sothe, and some for a sothe anon redy to fighte, and also that I may not my∣selfe 183. anone. fyght. maye. ben in place to withsaye thilke men that of thee speken 184. withsay. the. otherwyse than the sothe, I wol and I charge thee, in vertue of 185. the. obedience that thou to me owest, to wryten my wordes and sette hem in wrytinges, that they mowe, as my witnessinge, ben noted among the people. For bookes written neyther dreden ne 188. amonge. shamen, ne stryve conne; but only shewen the entente of the 189. onely. wryter, and yeve remembraunce to the herer; and if any wol in thy presence saye any-thing to tho wryters, loke boldely; truste on 191. -thynge. Mars to answere at the ful. For certes, I shal him enfourme of al the trouthe in thy love, with thy conscience; so that of his helpe thou shalt not varye at thy nede. I trowe the strongest and 194. shalte. the beste that may be founde wol not transverse thy wordes; 195. maye. transuers. wherof than woldest thou drede?'

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER III.
DIV3.P: GRETLY was I tho gladded of these wordes, and (as who, CH. III. 1. gladed; see l. 5. saith) wexen somdel light in herte; both for the auctoritè 2. somdele. of witnesse, and also for sikernesse of helpe of the forsayd beheste, and sayd:—

'Trewly, lady, now am I wel gladded through comfort of 5. nowe. comforte. your wordes. Be it now lykinge unto your nobley to shewe 6. nowe. whiche folk diffame your servauntes, sithe your service ought 7. folke. above al other thinges to ben commended.'

'Yet,' quod she, 'I see wel thy soule is not al out of the 9. se. amased cloude. Thee were better to here thing that thee might 10. the (twice). lighte out of thyn hevy charge and after knowing of thyn owne 11. light. helpe, than to stirre swete wordes and such resons to here; for in a thoughtful soule (and namely suche oon as thou art) 13. one. arte. wol not yet suche thinges sinken. Come of, therfore, and let
me seen thy hevy charge, that I may the lightlier for thy comfort 15. sene. comforte. purveye.' 16. puruey.

'Now, certes, lady,' quod I, 'the moste comfort I might have 17. Nowe. comforte. were utterly to wete me be sure in herte of that Margaryte I serve; and so I thinke to don with al mightes, whyle my lyfe dureth.'
'Than,' quod she, 'mayst thou therafter, in suche wyse that 21. mayste. misplesaunce ne entre?'
'In good fayth,' quod I, 'there shal no misplesaunce be caused through trespace on my syde.'
'And I do thee to weten,' quod she, 'I sette never yet person 25. the. set. to serve in no place (but-if he caused the contrary in defautes and trespaces) that he ne spedde of his service.'

'Myn owne erthly lady,' quod I tho, 'and yet remembre to your worthinesse how long sithen, by many revolving of yeres, 29. howe. in tyme whan Octobre his leve ginneth take and Novembre 30. leaue. sheweth him to sight, whan bernes ben ful of goodes as is the nutte on every halke; and than good lond-tillers ginne shape 32. londe-. for the erthe with greet travayle, to bringe forth more corn to 33. great. forthe. corne. mannes sustenaunce, ayenst the nexte yeres folowing. In suche tyme of plentee he that hath an home and is wyse, list not to 35. plentie. lyste. wander mervayles to seche, but he be constrayned or excited. Oft the lothe thing is doon, by excitacion of other mannes 37. doone. opinion, whiche wolden fayne have myn abydinge. [Tho gan I] 38. I supply Tho gan I. take in herte of luste to travayle and see the wynding of the erthe 39. se. in that tyme of winter. By woodes that large stretes wern in, 40. werne. by smale pathes that swyn and hogges hadden made, as lanes 41. swyne. with ladels their maste to seche, I walked thinkinge alone a wonder greet whyle; and the grete beestes that the woode 43. great. great. haunten and adorneth al maner forestes, and heerdes gonne to 44. gone; read gonne. wilde. Than, er I was war, I neyghed to a see-banke; and for 45. ware. ferde of the beestes "shipcraft" I cryde. For, lady, I trowe ye 46. shypcrafte. wete wel your-selfe, nothing is werse than the beestes that shulden ben tame, if they cacche her wildenesse, and ginne ayen 48. catche. waxe ramage. Thus forsothe was I a-ferd, and to shippe me 49. a-ferde. hyed.

Than were there y-nowe to lacche myn handes, and drawe me 51. lache.
to shippe, of whiche many I knew wel the names. Sight was 52. many; read meynee. knewe. the first, Lust was another, Thought was the thirde; and Wil eke was there a mayster; these broughten me within-borde of this shippe of Traveyle. So whan the sayl was sprad, and this ship 55. sayle. shyppe. gan to move, the wind and water gan for to ryse, and overthwartly 56. wynde. to turne the welken. The wawes semeden as they kiste togider; but often under colour of kissinge is mokel old hate prively 58. olde. closed and kept. The storm so straungely and in a devouring 59. kepte. storme. maner gan so faste us assayle, that I supposed the date of my deth shulde have mad there his ginning. Now up, now downe, 61. made. nowe under the wawe and now aboven was my ship a greet 61, 62. nowe. 62. shyppe. whyle. And so by mokel duresse of †weders and of stormes, 63. wethers; read weders. and with greet avowing [of] pilgrimages, I was driven to an yle, 62, 64. great. 64. I supply of. where utterly I wende first to have be rescowed; but trewly, †at 65. as; read at. the first ginning, it semed me so perillous the haven to cacche, 66. catche. that but thorow grace I had ben comforted, of lyfe I was ful 67. thorowe. dispayred. Trewly, lady, if ye remembre a-right of al maner thinges, your-selfe cam hastely to sene us see-driven, and to 69. came. weten what we weren. But first ye were deynous of chere, after whiche ye gonne better a-lighte; and ever, as me thought, ye 71. a-lyght. lived in greet drede of disese; it semed so by your chere. 72. great. disease. And whan I was certifyed of your name, the lenger I loked in you, the more I you goodly dradde; and ever myn herte on you opened the more; and so in a litel tyme my ship was out of 75. shyppe. mynde. But, lady, as ye me ladde, I was war bothe of beestes 76. lad. ware. and of fisshes, a greet nombre thronging togider; among whiche 77. great. amonge. a muskel, in a blewe shel, had enclosed a Margaryte-perle, the moste precious and best that ever to-forn cam in my sight. 79. to-forne came. And ye tolden your-selfe, that ilke jewel in his kinde was so good and so vertuous, that her better shulde I never finde, al sought I ther-after to the worldes ende. And with that I held 82. helde. my pees a greet whyle; and ever sithen I have me bethought on 83. peace. great. the man that sought the precious Margarytes; and whan he had founden oon to his lyking, he solde al his good to bye that jewel. 85. one. Y-wis, thought I, (and yet so I thinke), now have I founden the 86. nowe. jewel that myn herte desyreth; wherto shulde I seche further? 87. myne.
Trewly, now wol I stinte, and on this Margaryte I sette me for 88. nowe. ever: now than also, sithen I wiste wel it was your wil that 89. Nowe. I shulde so suche a service me take; and so to desyre that thing, of whiche I never have blisse. There liveth non but he hath 91. none. disese; your might than that brought me to suche service, that to 92. disease. me is cause of sorowe and of joye. I wonder of your worde that ye sayn, "to bringen men in-to joye"; and, pardè, ye wete wel 94. sayne. that defaut ne trespace may not resonably ben put to me-wardes, 95. reasonably. as fer as my conscience knoweth. 96. ferre.

But of my disese me list now a whyle to speke, and to enforme 97. disease. you in what maner of blisse ye have me thronge. For truly I wene, that al gladnesse, al joye, and al mirthe is beshet under locke, and the keye throwe in suche place that it may not be founde. My brenning wo hath altred al my hewe. Whan I shulde slepe, I walowe and I thinke, and me disporte. Thus combred, I seme that al folk had me mased. Also, lady myne, 103. folke. desyre hath longe dured, some speking to have; or els at the lest have ben enmoysed with sight; and for wantinge of these thinges my mouth wolde, and he durst, pleyne right sore, sithen yvels 106. mouthe. for my goodnesse arn manyfolde to me yolden. I wonder, lady, 107. arne. trewly, save evermore your reverence, how ye mowe, for shame, 108. howe. suche thinges suffre on your servaunt to be so multiplied. Wherfore, kneling with a lowe herte, I pray you to rue on this caytif, that of nothing now may serve. Good lady, if ye liste, 111. caytife. now your help to me shewe, that am of your privyest servantes 112. nowe. helpe. at al assayes in this tyme, and under your winges of proteccion. 113. protection. No help to me-wardes is shapen; how shal than straungers in 114. helpe. howe. any wyse after socour loke, whan I, that am so privy, yet of helpe 115. socoure. I do fayle? Further may I not, but thus in this prison abyde; 116. maye. what bondes and chaynes me holden, lady, ye see wel your-selfe. 117. se. A renyant forjuged hath not halfe the care. But thus, syghing and sobbing, I wayle here alone; and nere it for comfort of your 119. comforte. presence, right here wolde I sterve. And yet a litel am I gladded, 120. gladed. that so goodly suche grace and non hap have I hent, graciously 121. none. hente. to fynde the precious Margarite, that (al other left) men shulde 122. lefte. bye, if they shulde therfore selle al her substaunce. Wo is me, 123. sel.
that so many let-games and purpose-brekers ben maked wayters, suche prisoners as I am to overloke and to hinder; and, for suche lettours, it is hard any suche jewel to winne. Is this, lady, 126. harde. an honour to thy deitee? Me thinketh, by right, suche people 127. deytie. shulde have no maistrye, ne ben overlokers over none of thy servauntes. Trewly, were it leful unto you, to al the goddes wolde I playne, that ye rule your devyne purveyaunce amonges your servantes nothing as ye shulde. Also, lady, my moeble is insuffysaunt to countervayle the price of this jewel, or els to make th'eschange. Eke no wight is worthy suche perles to were 133. weare. but kinges or princes or els their peres. This jewel, for vertue, wold adorne and make fayre al a realme; the nobley of vertue is so moche, that her goodnesse overal is commended. Who is it that wolde not wayle, but he might suche richesse have at his wil? The vertue therof out of this prison may me deliver, and naught els. And if I be not ther-thorow holpen, I see my-selfe 139. ther-thorowe. se. withouten recovery. Although I might hence voyde, yet wolde I not; I wolde abyde the day that destence hath me ordeyned, 141. daye. destenye. whiche I suppose is without amendement; so sore is my herte bounden, that I may thinken non other. Thus strayte, lady, 143. maye. none. hath sir Daunger laced me in stockes, I leve it be not your wil; and for I see you taken so litel hede, as me thinketh, and wol 145. se. not maken by your might the vertue in mercy of the Margaryte on me for to strecche, so as ye mowe wel in case that you liste, 147. stretche. my blisse and my mirthe arn feld; sicknesse and sorowe ben 148. arne. alwaye redy. The cope of tene is wounde aboute al my body, that stonding is me best; unneth may I ligge for pure misesy 150. miseasy. sorowe. And yet al this is litel ynough to be the ernest-silver in 151. ynoughe. forwarde of this bargayne; for treble-folde so mokel muste I suffer er tyme come of myn ese. For he is worthy no welthe, that may 153. ease. maye. no wo suffer. And certes, I am hevy to thinke on these thinges; but who shal yeve me water ynough to drinke, lest myn eyen drye, for renning stremes of teres? Who shal waylen with me 156. teares. myn owne happy hevinesse? Who shal counsaile me now in 157. myne. nowe. my lyking tene, and in my goodly harse? I not. For ever the 158. harse (sic); for harme? more I brenne, the more I coveyte; the more that I sorow, the more thrist I in gladnesse. Who shal than yeve me a contrarious
drink, to stanche the thurste of my blisful bitternesse? Lo, thus 161. drinke. I brenne and I drenche; I shiver and I swete. To this reversed 162. sweate. yvel was never yet ordeyned salve; forsoth al †leches ben uncon∣ning, 163. lyches (for leches). save the Margaryte alone, any suche remedye to purveye.' 164. puruey.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER IV.
DIV3.P: AND with these wordes I brast out to wepe, that every teere of myne eyen, for greetnesse semed they boren out the bal of CH. IV. 2. great-. my sight, and that al the water had ben out-ronne. Than thought me that Love gan a litel to hevye for miscomfort of my chere; 4. heauy. and gan soberly and in esy maner speke, wel avysinge what 5. easy. she sayd. Comenly the wyse speken esily and softe for many 6. easyly. skilles. Oon is, their wordes are the better bileved; and also, in 7. One. esy spekinge, avysement men may cacche, what to putte forth 8. easy speakynge. catche. put forthe. and what to holden in. And also, the auctoritè of esy wordes is 9. easy. the more; and eke, they yeven the more understandinge to other intencion of the mater. Right so this lady esely and in a softe 11. ladye easely. maner gan say these wordes.

¶ 'Mervayle,' quod she, 'greet it is, that by no maner of sem∣blaunt, 13. great. as fer as I can espye, thou list not to have any recour; 14. ferre. but ever thou playnest and sorowest, and wayes of remedye, for folisshe wilfulnesse, thee list not to seche. But enquyre of thy 16. the lyste. next frendes, that is, thyne inwit and me that have ben thy 17. inwytte. maystresse, and the recour and fyne of thy disese; [f]or of disese is 18. disease (twice). gladnesse and joy, with a ful †vessel so helded, that it quencheth 19. nessel; misprint for uessel. the felinge of the firste tenes. But thou that were wont not only 20. wonte. onely. these thinges remembre in thyne herte, but also fooles therof to enfourmen, in adnullinge of their errours and distroying of their 22. distroyeng. derke opinions, and in comfort of their sere thoughtes; now canst 23. comforte. seare. thou not ben comfort of thyn owne soule, in thinking of these 24. comforte. thinges. O where hast thou be so longe commensal, that hast so 25. haste. mikel eeten of the potages of foryetfulnesse, and dronken so of ignorance, that the olde souking[es] whiche thou haddest of me 27. soukyng. arn amaystred and lorn fro al maner of knowing? O, this is 28. arne.
a worthy person to helpe other, that can not counsayle him-selfe!' And with these wordes, for pure and stronge shame, I wox al 30. woxe. reed.

And she than, seing me so astonyed by dyvers stoundes, sodainly (which thing kynde hateth) gan deliciously me comforte 33. thynge. with sugred wordes, putting me in ful hope that I shulde the Margarite getten, if I folowed her hestes; and gan with a fayre clothe to wypen the teres that hingen on my chekes; and than 36. teares. sayd I in this wyse.

'Now, wel of wysdom and of al welthe, withouten thee may 38. Nowe. wysedom. the. nothing ben lerned; thou berest the keyes of al privy thinges. 39. bearest. In vayne travayle men to cacche any stedship, but-if ye, lady, 40. catche. first the locke unshet. Ye, lady, lerne us the wayes and the by-pathes to heven. Ye, lady, maken al the hevenly bodyes goodly and benignely to don her cours, that governen us beestes 43. done her course. here on erthe. Ye armen your servauntes ayenst al debates with imperciable harneys; ye setten in her hertes insuperable blood of 45. blode. hardinesse; ye leden hem to the parfit good. Yet al thing 46. leaden. parfyte. thynge. desyreth ye werne no man of helpe, that †wol don your 47. wern. wele; read wol. done. lore. Graunt me now a litel of your grace, al my sorowes 48. nowe. to cese.' 49. cease.

'Myne owne servaunt,' quod she, 'trewly thou sittest nye myne herte; and thy badde chere gan sorily me greve. But amonge thy playning wordes, me thought, thou allegest thinges to be letting of thyne helpinge and thy grace to hinder; wherthrough, 53. wherthroughe. me thinketh, that wanhope is crope thorough thyn hert. God forbid that nyse unthrifty thought shulde come in thy mynde, thy wittes to trouble; sithen every thing in coming is contingent. Wherfore make no more thy proposicion by an impossible. But now, I praye thee reherse me ayen tho thinges that 58. nowe. the. thy mistrust causen; and thilke thinges I thinke by reson to 59. reason. distroyen, and putte ful hope in thyn herte. What understondest 60. put. thou there,' quod she, 'by that thou saydest, "many let-games 61. lette-games. are thyn overlokers?" And also by "that thy moeble is in∣suffysaunt"? I not what thou therof menest.' 63. meanest.

'Trewly,' quod I, 'by the first I say, that janglers evermore arn spekinge rather of yvel than of good; for every age of man 65. arne.
rather enclyneth to wickednesse, than any goodnesse to avaunce. Also false wordes springen so wyde, by the stering of false lying 67. steeryng. lyeng. tonges, that fame als swiftely flyeth to her eres and sayth many 68. eares. wicked tales; and as soone shal falsenesse ben leved as tr[o]uthe, for al his gret sothnesse.

Now by that other,' quod I, 'me thinketh thilke jewel so precious, that to no suche wrecche as I am wolde vertue therof 72. wretche. extende; and also I am to feble in worldly joyes, any suche jewel to countrevayle. For suche people that worldly joyes han at her wil ben sette at the highest degree, and most in reverence ben accepted. For false wening maketh felicitè therin to be supposed; but suche caytives as I am evermore ben hindred.'

'Certes,' quod she, 'take good hede, and I shal by reson to 78. reason. thee shewen, that al these thinges mowe nat lette thy purpos 79. the. let. purpose. by the leest point that any wight coude pricke.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER V.
DIV3.P: REMEMBREST nat,' quod she, 'ensample is oon of the CH. V. 1. one. strongest maner[es], as for to preve a mannes purpos? 2. maner; read maneres. purpose. Than if I now, by ensample, enduce thee to any proposicion, is 3. nowe. the. it nat preved by strength?' 4. proued.
'Yes, forsothe,' quod I.

'Wel,' quod she, 'raddest thou never how Paris of Troye and 6. howe. Heleyne loved togider, and yet had they not entrecomuned of speche? Also Acrisius shette Dane his doughter in a tour, for suertee that no wight shulde of her have no maistry in my 9. suertie. service; and yet Jupiter by signes, without any speche, had al his purpose ayenst her fathers wil. And many suche mo have ben knitte in trouthe, and yet spake they never togider; for that is a thing enclosed under secretnesse of privytè, why twey persons entremellen hertes after a sight. The power in knowing, of such thinges †to preven, shal nat al utterly be yeven to you 15. so; read to. beestes; for many thinges, in suche precious maters, ben reserved to jugement of devyne purveyaunce; for among lyving 17. lyueng. people, by mannes consideracion, moun they nat be determined.
Wherfore I saye, al the envy, al the janglinge, that wel ny [al] 19. I supply al. people upon my servauntes maken †ofte, is rather cause of esployte 20. efte; read ofte. than of any hindringe.'
'Why, than,' quod I, 'suffre ye such wrong; and moun, whan ye list, lightly al such yvels abate? Me semeth, to you it is a greet unworship.' 24. great.

'O,' quod she, 'hold now thy pees. I have founden to many 25. holde nowe thy peace. that han ben to me unkynde, that trewly I wol suffre every wight in that wyse to have disese; and who that continueth to the ende 27. disease. wel and trewly, hem wol I helpen, and as for oon of myne in-to blisse [don] to wende. As [in] marcial doing in Grece, who 29. one. I supply don. I supply in. was y-crowned? By god, nat the strongest; but he that rathest com and lengest abood and continued in the journey, and spared 31. come. abode. nat to traveyle as long as the play leste. But thilke person, that 32. lest. profred him now to my service, [and] therin is a while, and anon 33. nowe. I supply and. voideth and [is] redy to another; and so now oon he thinketh 34. I supply is. nowe one. and now another; and in-to water entreth and anon respireth: 35. nowe. such oon list me nat in-to perfit blisse of my service bringe. 36. one. perfyte. A tree ofte set in dyvers places wol nat by kynde endure to bringe forth frutes. Loke now, I pray thee, how myne olde servauntes 38. nowe. the howe. of tyme passed continued in her service, and folowe thou after their steppes; and than might thou not fayle, in case thou worche in this wyse.'

'Certes,' quod I, 'it is nothing lich, this world, to tyme 42. worlde. passed; eke this countrè hath oon maner, and another countrè 43. one. hath another. And so may nat a man alway putte to his eye the 44. alwaye put. salve that he heled with his hele. For this is sothe: betwixe 45. healed. two thinges liche, ofte dyversitè is required.'

'Now,' quod she, 'that is sothe; dyversitè of nation, dyversitè of 47. Nowe. lawe, as was maked by many resons; for that dyversitè cometh in 48. reasons. by the contrarious malice of wicked people, that han envyous hertes ayenst other. But trewly, my lawe to my servauntes ever hath ben in general, whiche may nat fayle. For right as mannes †lawe 51. lawes; read lawe. that is ordained by many determinacions, may nat be knowe for 52. determinatiōs. good or badde, til assay of the people han proved it and [founden] 53. I supply founden. to what ende it draweth; and than it sheweth the necessitè
therof, or els the impossibilitè: right so the lawe of my servauntes so wel hath ben proved in general, that hitherto hath it not fayled.

Wiste thou not wel that al the lawe of kynde is my lawe, and by god ordayned and stablisshed to dure by kynde resoun? 58. reasoun. Wherfore al lawe by mannes witte purveyed ought to be underput 59. purueyde. vnderputte. to lawe of kynde, whiche yet hath be commune to every kyndely creature; that my statutes and my lawe that ben kyndely arn 61. arne. general to al peoples. Olde doinges and by many turninges of yeres used, and with the peoples maner proved, mowen nat so lightly ben defased; but newe doinges, contrariauntes suche olde, ofte causen diseses and breken many purposes. Yet saye I nat 65. diseases. breaken. therfore that ayen newe mischeef men shulde nat ordaynen 66. mischefe. a newe remedye; but alwaye looke it contrary not the olde no ferther than the malice streccheth. Than foloweth it, the olde 68. stretcheth. doinges in love han ben universal, as for most exployte[s] forth 69. exployte forthe. used; wherfore I wol not yet that of my lawes nothing be adnulled. 70. nothynge. But thanne to thy purpos: suche jangelers and lokers, and 71. purpose. wayters of games, if thee thinke in aught they mowe dere, yet 72. the. love wel alwaye, and sette hem at naught; and let thy port ben 73. lette. porte. lowe in every wightes presence, and redy in thyne herte to maynteyne that thou hast begonne; and a litel thee fayne with 75. the. mekenesse in wordes; and thus with sleyght shalt thou surmount and dequace the yvel in their hertes. And wysdom yet is to seme 77. wysdome. flye otherwhyle, there a man wol fighte. Thus with suche thinges 78. fyght. the tonges of yvel shal ben stilled; els fully to graunte thy ful 79. graunt. meninge, for-sothe ever was and ever it shal be, that myn enemyes 80. meanynge. ben aferde to truste to any fightinge. And therfore have thou no cowardes herte in my service, no more than somtyme thou haddest in the contrarye. For if thou drede suche jangleres, thy viage to make, understand wel, that he that dredeth any rayn, to 84. vnder∣stande. rayne. sowe his cornes, he shal have than [bare] bernes. Also he that 85. I supply bare. is aferd of his clothes, let him daunce naked! Who nothing 86. aferde. undertaketh, and namely in my service, nothing acheveth. After grete stormes the †weder is often mery and smothe. After 88. great. wether; read weder. moche clatering, there is mokil rowning. Thus, after jangling wordes, cometh "huissht! pees! and be stille!"' 90. huysshte. peace. styl.

'O good lady!' quod I than, 'see now how, seven yere passed 91. se nowe howe.
and more, have I graffed and †grobbed a vyne; and with al the 92. groubed. wayes that I coude I sought to a fed me of the grape; but frute have I non founde. Also I have this seven yere served Laban, to 94. none. a wedded Rachel his doughter; but blere-eyed Lya is brought to my bedde, which alway engendreth my tene, and is ful of children in tribulacion and in care. And although the clippinges and kissinges of Rachel shulde seme to me swete, yet is she so barayne that gladnesse ne joye by no way wol springe; so that I may wepe with Rachel. I may not ben counsayled with solace, sithen issue of myn hertely desyre is fayled. Now than I pray that 101. Nowe. to me [come] sone fredom and grace in this eight[eth] yere; this 102. I supply come. eighteth mowe to me bothe be kinrest and masseday, after the 103. kynrest (sic). seven werkedays of travayle, to folowe the Christen lawe; and, what ever ye do els, that thilke Margaryte be holden so, lady, in your privy chambre, that she in this case to none other person be committed.'

'Loke than,' quod she, 'thou persever in my service, in whiche I have thee grounded; that thilke scorn in thyn enemyes mowe 109. skorne. this on thy person be not sothed: "lo! this man began to edefye, 110. this; read thus? but, for his foundement is bad, to the ende may he it not bringe." For mekenesse in countenaunce, with a manly hert in dedes and in longe continuaunce, is the conisance of my livery to al my retinue delivered. What wenest thou, that me list avaunce suche persons as loven the first sittinges at feestes, the highest stoles in churches and in hal, loutinges of peoples in markettes and fayres; unstedfaste to byde in one place any whyle togider; wening his owne wit more excellent than other; scorning al maner devyse but his own? Nay, nay, god wot, these shul nothing parten of my blisse. Truly, my maner here-toforn hath ben [to] worship[pe] 120. toforne. with my blisse lyons in the felde and lambes in chambre; 121. worship; read worshippe (verb). egles at assaute and maydens in halle; foxes in counsayle, stil[le] 122. styl. in their dedes; and their proteccioun is graunted, redy to ben 123. protection. a bridge; and their baner is arered, like wolves in the felde. Thus, by these wayes, shul men ben avaunced; ensample of David, that from keping of shepe was drawen up in-to the order of kingly governaunce; and Jupiter, from a bole, to ben Europes fere; and Julius Cesar, from the lowest degrè in Rome, to be mayster of al erthly princes; and Eneas from hel, to be king of
the countrè there Rome is now stonding. And so to thee I say; 130. nowe. the. thy grace, by bering ther-after, may sette thee in suche plight, 131. set the. that no jangling may greve the leest tucke of thy hemmes; that 132. lest. [suche] are their †jangles, is nought to counte at a cresse in thy 133. ianghes; read jangles. disavauntage.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER VI.
DIV3.P: EVER,' quod she, 'hath the people in this worlde desyred to have had greet name in worthinesse, and hated foule CH. VI. 2. great. beare. to bere any [en]fame; and that is oon of the objeccions thou 3. read enfame; see l. alegest to be ayen thyne hertely desyre.'
'Ye, forsothe,' quod I; 'and that, so comenly, the people wol lye, and bringe aboute suche enfame.' 6. one. obiections.

'Now,' quod she, 'if men with lesinges putte on thee enfame, 7. Nowe. leasynges put on the. wenest thy-selfe therby ben enpeyred? That wening is wrong; 8. wronge. see why; for as moche as they lyen, thy meryte encreseth, and 9. se. encreaseth. make[th] thee ben more worthy, to hem that knowen of the soth; 10. the. by what thing thou art apeyred, that in so mokil thou art encresed 11. arte encreased. of thy beloved frendes. And sothly, a wounde of thy frende [is] 12. I supply is. to thee lasse harm, ye, sir, and better than a fals kissing in disceyv∣able 13. the. harme. false. glosing of thyne enemy; above that than, to be wel with thy frende maketh [voyd] suche enfame. Ergo, thou art encresed 15. I supply voyd. arte. and not apeyred.'

'Lady,' quod I, 'somtyme yet, if a man be in disese, th'estima∣cion 17. disease. of the envyous people ne loketh nothing to desertes of men, ne to the merytes of their doinges, but only to the aventure of fortune; and therafter they yeven their sentence. And some loken the voluntary wil in his herte, and therafter telleth his jugement; not taking hede to reson ne to the qualitè of the 22. reason. doing; as thus. If a man be riche and fulfild with worldly 23. fulfylde. welfulnesse, some commenden it, and sayn it is so lent by juste 24. sayne. lente. cause; and he that hath adversitè, they sayn he is weked; and 25. sayne. weaked; read wikked? hath deserved thilke anoy. The contrarye of these thinges some 26. anoye.
men holden also; and sayn that to the riche prosperitè is pur∣vayed 27. sayne. in-to his confusion; and upon this mater many autoritès of many and greet-witted clerkes they alegen. And some men 29. great. sayn, though al good estimacion forsake folk that han adversitè, 30. forsaken; read forsake. yet is it meryte and encrees of his blisse; so that these purposes 31. encrease. arn so wonderful in understanding, that trewly, for myn adversitè 32. arne. now, I not how the sentence of the indifferent people wil jugen 33. nowe. howe. my fame.'

'Therfore,' quod she, 'if any wight shulde yeve a trewe sen∣tence on suche maters, the cause of the disese maist thou see 36. disease. se. wel. Understand ther-upon after what ende it draweth, that is to 37. vnderstande. sayne, good or badde; so ought it to have his fame †by goodnesse 38. fame or by goodnesse enfame; read fame by goodnesse or enfame. or enfame by badnesse. For [of] every resonable person, and 39. Supply of. reasonable. namely of a wyse man, his wit ought not, without reson to-forn 40. wytte. reason to-forne. herd, sodainly in a mater to juge. After the sawes of the wyse, 41. herde. "thou shalt not juge ne deme toforn thou knowe."' 42. toforne.

'Lady,' quod I, 'ye remembre wel, that in moste laude and praysing of certayne seyntes in holy churche, is to rehersen their conuersion from badde in-to good; and that is so rehersed, as 45. conuercion. by a perpetual mirrour of remembraunce, in worshippinge of tho sayntes, and good ensample to other misdoers in amende∣ment. How turned the Romayne Zedeoreys fro the Romaynes, 48. Howe. zedeoreys or ȝedeoreys. to be with Hanibal ayenst his kynde nacion; and afterwardes, him seming the Romayns to be at the next degrè of confusion, turned to his olde alyes; by whose witte after was Hanibal dis∣comfited. Wherfore, to enfourme you, lady, the maner-why I mene, see now. In my youth I was drawe to ben assentaunt 53. meane se nowe. and (in my mightes) helping to certain conjuracions and other grete maters of ruling of citizins; and thilke thinges ben my 55. great. drawers in; and ex[c]itours to tho maters wern so paynted and 56. exitours. werne. coloured that (at the prime face) me semed them noble and glorious to al the people. I than, wening mikel meryte have deserved in furthering and mayntenaunce of tho thinges, besyed and laboured, with al my diligence, in werkinge of thilke maters to the ende. And trewly, lady, to telle you the sothe, me rought 61. tel. litel of any hate of the mighty senatours in thilke citè, ne of
comunes malice; for two skilles. Oon was, I had comfort to ben 63. One. comforte. in suche plyte, that bothe profit were to me and to my frendes. 64. profyte. Another was, for commen profit in cominaltee is not but pees and 65. profyte. comynaltie. peace. tranquilitè, with just governaunce, proceden from thilke profit; 66. profyte. sithen, by counsayle of myne inwitte, me thought the firste painted thinges malice and yvel meninge, withouten any good avayling to 68. meanynge. any people, and of tyrannye purposed. And so, for pure sorowe, and of my medlinge and badde infame that I was in ronne, tho [the] teres [that] lasshed out of myne eyen were thus awaye 71. I supply the and that. wasshe, than the under-hidde malice and the rancour of purposing 72. rancoure. envye, forncast and imagined in distruccion of mokil people, 73. fornecaste. distruction. shewed so openly, that, had I ben blind, with myne hondes al the 74. blynde. circumstaunce I might wel have feled.

Now than tho persones that suche thinges have cast to redresse, 76. Nowe. caste. for wrathe of my first medlinge, shopen me to dwelle in this pyn∣ande 77. dwel. prison, til Lachases my threed no lenger wolde twyne. And 78. threde. ever I was sought, if me liste to have grace of my lyfe and frenesse of that prison, I shulde openly confesse how pees might 80. howe peace. ben enduced to enden al the firste rancours. It was fully 81. endused. supposed my knowing to be ful in tho maters. Than, lady, I thought that every man that, by any waye of right, rightfully don, may helpe any comune †wele to ben saved; whiche thing to 84. done. maye. helpe (repeated after comen); read wele. thynge. kepe above al thinges I am holde to mayntayne, and namely in distroying of a wrong; al shulde I therthrough enpeche myn 86. distroyeng. owne fere, if he were gilty and to do misdeed assentaunt. And 87. misdede. mayster ne frend may nought avayle to the soule of him that 88. frende maye. in falsnesse deyeth; and also that I nere desyred wrathe of the people ne indignacion of the worthy, for nothinge that ever I wrought or did, in any doing my-selfe els, but in the mayntenaunce of these foresayd errours and in hydinge of the privitees therof. And that al the peoples hertes, holdinge on the errours syde, weren blinde and of elde so ferforth begyled, that debat and 94. -forthe. debate. stryf they maynteyned, and in distruccion on that other syde; 95. stryfe. distruction. by whiche cause the pees, that moste in comunaltee shulde be 96. peace. comunaltie. desyred, was in poynte to be broken and adnulled. Also the citee 97. cytie. of London, that is to me so dere and swete, in whiche I was forth 98. forthe.
growen; (and more kyndely love have I to that place than to any other in erthe, as every kyndely creature hath ful appetyte to that place of his kyndly engendrure, and to wilne reste and pees in that stede to abyde); thilke pees shulde thus there have ben broken, and of al wyse it is commended and desyred. For knowe thing it is, al men that desyren to comen to the perfit pees ever∣lasting 104. thynge. perfyte. lasting must the pees by god commended bothe mayntayne and kepe. This pees by angels voyce was confirmed, our god entringe 101-6. peace (five times). in this worlde. This, as for his Testament, he lefte to al his 107. left. frendes, whanne he retourned to the place from whence he cam; 108. came. this his apostel amonesteth to holden, without whiche man perfitly 109. perfytely. may have non insight. Also this god, by his coming, made not 110. none. pees alone betwene hevenly and erthly bodyes, but also amonge us on erthe so he pees confirmed, that in one heed of love oon 111-2. peace (twice). 112. one (twice). body we shulde perfourme. Also I remembre me wel how the 113. howe. name of Athenes was rather after the god of pees than of batayle, shewinge that pees moste is necessarie to comunaltees and citees. 114-5. peace (twice). 115. comunalties and cytes. I than, so styred by al these wayes toforn nempned, declared 116. toforne. certayne poyntes in this wyse. Firste, that thilke persones that hadden me drawen to their purposes, and me not weting the privy entent of their meninge, drawen also the feeble-witted 119. meanynge. feoble. people, that have non insight of gubernatif prudence, to clamure 120. none. gubernatyfe. and to crye on maters that they styred; and under poyntes for comune avauntage they enbolded the passif to take in the 122. passyfe. actives doinge; and also styred innocentes of conning to crye after thinges, whiche (quod they) may not stande but we ben executours of tho maters, and auctoritè of execucion by comen eleccion to us be delivered. And that muste entre by strength of 126. election. your mayntenaunce. For we out of suche degree put, oppression of these olde hindrers shal agayn surmounten, and putten you in 128. agayne. such subjeccion, that in endelesse wo ye shul complayne. 129. subiection.

The governementes (quod they) of your citè, lefte in the handes of torcencious citezins, shal bringe in pestilence and distruccion 131. dis∣truction. to you, good men; and therfore let us have the comune ad∣ministracion to abate suche yvels. Also (quod they) it is worthy the good to commende, and the gilty desertes to chastice. There ben citezens many, for-ferde of execucion that shal be doon; for 135. doone.
extorcions by hem committed ben evermore ayenst these purposes and al other good mevinges. Never-the-latter, lady, trewly the meninge under these wordes was, fully to have apeched the 138. meanynge. mighty senatoures, whiche hadden hevy herte for the misgover∣naunce 139. heauy. that they seen. And so, lady, whan it fel that free eleccion [was mad], by greet clamour of moche people, [that] for 141. election. Supply was mad. great (twice). Supply that. greet disese of misgovernaunce so fervently stoden in her eleccion 142. disease. election. that they hem submitted to every maner †fate rather than have 143. face; read fate. suffred the maner and the rule of the hated governours; not∣withstandinge that in the contrary helden moche comune meyny, that have no consideracion but only to voluntary lustes withouten 146. onely. reson. But than thilke governour so forsaken, fayninge to-forn 147. reason. to-forne. his undoinge for misrule in his tyme, shoop to have letted thilke 148. shope. eleccion, and have made a newe, him-selfe to have ben chosen; 149. electyon. and under that, mokil rore [to] have arered. These thinges, lady, knowen among the princes, and made open to the people, 151. amonge. draweth in amendement, that every degree shal ben ordayned to stande there-as he shulde; and that of errours coming herafter men may lightly to-forn-hand purvaye remedye; in this wyse pees 154. to forne hande. peace. and rest to be furthered and holde. Of the whiche thinges, lady, thilke persones broughten in answere to-forn their moste soverayne 156. to forne. juge, not coarted by payninge dures, openly knowlegeden, and asked therof grace; so that apertly it preveth my wordes ben 158. apertely. sothe, without forginge of lesinges. 159. leasynges.

But now it greveth me to remembre these dyvers sentences, in 160. nowe. janglinge of these shepy people; certes, me thinketh, they oughten to maken joye that a sothe may be knowe. For my trouthe and 162. maye. my conscience ben witnesse to me bothe, that this (knowinge sothe) have I sayd, for no harme ne malice of tho persones, but 164. sayde. only for trouthe of my sacrament in my ligeaunce, by whiche 165. onely. leigeaunce. I was charged on my kinges behalfe. But see ye not now, lady, 166. se. nowe. how the felonous thoughtes of this people and covins of wicked men conspyren ayen my sothfast trouth! See ye not every wight 168. Se. that to these erroneous opinions were assentaunt, and helpes to the noyse, and knewen al these thinges better than I my-selven, apparaylen to fynden newe frendes, and clepen me fals, and 171. cleapen. false.
studyen how they mowen in her mouthes werse plyte nempne? 172. howe. O god, what may this be, that thilke folk whiche that in tyme of 173. maye. folke. my mayntenaunce, and whan my might avayled to strecche to 174. stretch. the forsayd maters, tho me commended, and yave me name of trouth, in so manyfolde maners that it was nyghe in every wightes eere, there-as any of thilke people weren; and on the other syde, thilke company somtyme passed, yevinge me name of badde loos: now bothe tho peoples turned the good in-to 179. Nowe. badde, and badde in-to good? Whiche thing is wonder, that they knowing me saying but sothe, arn now tempted to reply her 181. knowyuge (sic). sayng. arne nowe. olde praysinges; and knowen me wel in al doinges to ben trewe, and sayn openly that I false have sayd many thinges! And they 183. sayne. aleged nothing me to ben false or untrewe, save thilke mater 184. nothynge. knowleged by the parties hem-selfe; and god wot, other mater 185. wote. is non. Ye also, lady, knowe these thinges for trewe; I avaunte 186. none. not in praysing of my-selfe; therby shulde I lese the precious secrè of my conscience. But ye see wel that false opinion of the 188. se. people for my trouthe, in telling out of false conspyred maters; and after the jugement of these clerkes, I shulde not hyde the sothe of no maner person, mayster ne other. Wherfore I wolde not drede, were it put in the consideracion of trewe and of wyse. And for comers hereafter shullen fully, out of denwere, al the sothe knowe of these thinges in acte, but as they wern, I have 194. werne. put it in scripture, in perpetuel remembraunce of true meninge. 195. meanynge. For trewly, lady, me semeth that I ought to bere the name of 196. beare. trouthe, that for the love of rightwysnesse have thus me †sub∣mitted. 197. submytten (!). But now than the false fame, which that (clerkes sayn) 198. nowe. sayne. flyeth as faste as doth the fame of trouthe, shal so wyde sprede 199. dothe. til it be brought to the jewel that I of mene; and so shal I ben 200. meane. hindred, withouten any mesure of trouthe.' 201. measure.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER VII.
DIV3.P: THAN gan Love sadly me beholde, and sayd in a changed voyce, lower than she had spoken in any tyme: 'Fayn CH. VII. 2. Fayne. wolde I,' quod she, 'that thou were holpen; but hast thou sayd 3. haste. any-thing whiche thou might not proven?' 4. -thynge.
'Pardè,' quod I, 'the persones, every thing as I have sayd, han knowleged hem-selfe.'
'Ye,' quod she, 'but what if they hadden nayed? How 7. Yea. Howe. woldest thou have maynteyned it?'

'Sothely,' quod I, 'it is wel wist, bothe amonges the greetest 9. wyste. amongest. greatest. and other of the realme, that I profered my body so largely in-to provinge of tho thinges, that Mars shulde have juged the ende; but, for sothnesse of my wordes, they durste not to thilke juge truste.'

'Now, certes,' quod she, 'above al fames in this worlde, the 14. Nowe. name of marcial doinges most plesen to ladyes of my lore; but 15. moste pleasen. sithen thou were redy, and thyne adversaryes in thy presence refused thilke doing; thy fame ought to be so born as if in dede 17. borne. it had take to the ende. And therfore every wight that any droppe of reson hath, and hereth of thee infame for these thinges, 19. reason. the. hath this answere to saye: "trewly thou saydest; for thyne adversaryes thy wordes affirmed." And if thou haddest lyed, yet are they discomfited, the prise leved on thy syde; so that fame 22. leaued. shal holde down infame; he shal bringe [it in] upon none 23. Supply it in. halfe. What greveth thee thyne enemye[s] to sayn their owne 24. the. enemye (sic). sayne. shame, as thus: "we arn discomfited, and yet our quarel is 25. arne. trewe?" Shal not the loos of thy frendes ayenward dequace thilke enfame, and saye they graunted a sothe without a stroke or fight∣ing? Many men in batayle ben discomfited and overcome in a rightful quarel, that is goddes privy jugement in heven; but yet, although the party be yolden, he may with wordes saye his 30. partie. quarel is trewe, and to yelde him, in the contrarye, for drede of dethe he is compelled; and he that graunteth and no stroke hath feled, he may not crepe away in this wyse by none excusacion. 33. maye.
Indifferent folk wil say: "ye, who is trewe, who is fals, him-selfe 34. folke. false. knowlegeth tho thinges." Thus in every syde fame sheweth to thee good and no badde.' 36. the.

'But yet,' quod I, 'some wil say, I ne shulde, for no dethe, have discovered my maistresse; and so by unkyndnesse they wol knette infame, to pursue me aboute. Thus enemyes of wil, in manyfolde maner, wol seche privy serpentynes queintyses, to quenche and distroye, by venim of many besinesses, the light of tr[o]uthe; to make hertes to murmure ayenst my persone, to have me in hayne withouten any cause.'

'Now,' quod she, 'here me a fewe wordes, and thou shalt fully 44. Nowe. shalte. ben answered, I trowe. Me thinketh (quod she) right now, by 45. answerde. nowe. thy wordes, that sacrament of swering, that is to say, charging by 46. swearyng. othe, was oon of the causes to make thee discover the malicious 47. one. the. imaginacions tofore nempned. Every ooth, by knittinge of copu∣lacion, 48. othe. copulation. muste have these lawes, that is, trewe jugement and right∣wysenesse; in whiche thinge if any of these lacke, the ooth is 50. othe. y-tourned in-to the name of perjury. Than to make a trewe serment, most nedes these thinges folowe. For ofte tymes, a man to saye sothe, but jugement and justice folowe, he is forsworn; 53. forsworne. ensample of Herodes, for holdinge of his serment was [he] 54. Supply he. dampned.

Also, to saye tr[o]uthe rightfulliche (but in jugement) other-while is forboden, by that al sothes be nat to sayne. Therfore in jugement, in tr[o]uthe, and rightwisenesse, is every creature bounden, up payne of perjury, ful knowing to make, tho[ugh] it were of his owne persone, for drede of sinne; after that worde, "better is it to dey than live false." And, al wolde perverted people 61. false. fals report make in unkyndnesse, in that entent thy [en]fame to 62. reporte. reyse, whan light of tr[o]uthe in these maters is forth sprongen 63. forthe. and openly publisshed among commens, than shal nat suche derke enfame dare appere, for pure shame of his falsnesse. As some men ther ben that their owne enfame can none otherwyse voide or els excuse, but †by hindringe of other mennes fame; which 67. be; for by. that by non other cause clepen other men false, but for [that] 68. cleapen. Supply that. with their owne falsnesse mowen they nat ben avaunsed; or els by false sklaund[r]inge wordes other men shenden, their owne 70. sklaundynge. shendyn.
trewe sklaunder to make seme the lasse. For if such men wolden their eyen of their conscience revolven, [they] shulden seen the 72. I supply they. sene. same sentence they legen on other springe out of their sydes, with 73. legen [for aleggen]. so many braunches, it were impossible to nombre. To whiche therefore may it be sayd in that thinge, "this man thou demest, 75. maye. therein thy-selfe thou condempnest."

But (quod she) understand nat by these wordes, that thou 77. vnder∣stande. wene me saye thee to be worthy sclaunder, for any mater tofore 78. the. written; truely I wolde witnesse the contrary; but I saye that the bemes of sclaundring wordes may not be don awaye til the 80. beames. done. daye of dome. For how shulde it nat yet, amonges so greet 81. howe. great. plentee of people, ben many shrewes, sithen whan no mo but 82. plentie. eight persons in Noes shippe were closed, yet oon was a shrewe 83. one. and skorned his father?
