These thinges (quod she) I trowe, shewen that fals fame is nat to drede, ne of wyse persons to accepte, and 85. false. namely nat of thy Margarite, whose wysdom here-after I thinke to 86. wysedom. declare; wherfore I wot wel suche thing shal nat her asterte; 87. wotte. thynge. than of unkyndnesse thyn ooth hath thee excused at the fulle. 88. thyne othe. the. But now, if thou woldest nat greve, me list a fewe thinges to 89. nowe. shewe.'
'Say on,' quod I, 'what ye wol; I trowe ye mene but trouthe 91. meane. and my profit in tyme cominge.' 92. profyte.

'Trewly,' quod she, 'that is sothe, so thou con wel kepe these wordes, and in the in[ne]rest secrè chambre of thyne herte so 94. inrest. faste hem close that they never flitte; than shalt thou fynde hem 95. shalte. avayling. Loke now what people hast thou served; whiche of 96. nowe. haste. hem al in tyme of thyne exile ever thee refresshed, by the valewe 97. the. of the leste coyned plate that walketh in money? Who was sory, 98. sorye. or made any rewth for thy disese? If they hadden getten their 99. disease. purpose, of thy misaventure sette they nat an hawe. Lo, whan thou were emprisonned, how faste they hyed in helpe of thy 101. howe. deliveraunce! I wene of thy dethe they yeve but lyte. They loked after no thing but after their owne lustes. And if thou liste 103. -thynge. say the sothe, al that meyny that in this †brige thee broughten, 104. brigge; read brige. lokeden rather after thyne helpes than thee to have releved. 104,105. the.

Owen nat yet some of hem money for his commens? Paydest
nat thou for some of her dispences, til they were tourned out of Selande? Who yave thee ever ought for any rydinge thou madest? 108. the. Yet, pardè, some of hem token money for thy chambre, and 109. pardye. putte tho pens in his purse, unwetinge of the renter.

Lo for which a company thou medlest, that neither thee ne 111. the. them-selfe mighten helpe of unkyndnesse; now they bere the 112. nowe. beare. name that thou supposest of hem for to have. What might thou more have don than thou diddest, but-if thou woldest in a fals 114. done. false. quarel have been a stinkinge martyr? I wene thou fleddest, as longe as thou might, their privitè to counsayle; which thing thou hele[de]st lenger than thou shuldest. And thilke that ought thee 117. helest; read heledest. the. money no penny wolde paye; they wende thy returne hadde ben an impossible. How might thou better have hem proved, but thus 119. Howe. in thy nedy diseses? Now hast thou ensaumple for whom thou 120. diseases. Nowe haste. shalt meddle; trewly, this lore is worth many goodes.' 121. shalte. worthe.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER VIII.
DIV3.P: †EFT gan Love to †steren me [with] these wordes: 'thinke CH. VIII. 1. Ofte; read Eft. sterne; read steren. I supply with. on my speche; for trewly here-after it wol do thee lykinge; 2. the. and how-so-ever thou see Fortune shape her wheele to tourne, 3. howe. se. this meditacion [shal] by no waye revolve. For certes, Fortune 4. meditation. I supply shal. sheweth her fayrest, whan she thinketh to begyle. And as me thought, here-toforn thou saydest, thy loos in love, for thy right∣wysenesse 6. toforne. ought to be raysed, shulde be a-lowed in tyme cominge. Thou might in love so thee have, that loos and fame shul so ben 8. the. raysed, that to thy frendes comfort, and sorowe to thyne enemys, 9. comforte. endlesse shul endure.

But if thou were the oon sheep, amonges the hundred, were lost 11. one shepe. in deserte and out of the way hadde erred, and now to the flocke 12. loste. nowe. art restoored, the shepherd hath in thee no joye and thou ayen 13. arte. shepeherd. the. to the forrest tourne. But that right as the sorowe and an∣guisshe was greet in tyme of thyne out-waye goinge, right so 15. great. joye and gladnesse shal be doubled to sene thee converted; and 16. the.
nat as Lothes wyf ayen-lokinge, but [in] hool counsayle with the 17. wyfe. I supply in. hoole. shepe folowinge, and with them grasse and herbes gadre. Never-the-later (quod she) I saye nat these thinges for no wantrust that I have in supposinge of thee otherwyse than I shulde. For 20. the. trewly, I wot wel that now thou art set in suche a purpose, out of 21. wotte. nowe. arte sette. whiche thee liste nat to parte. But I saye it for many men there 22. the. been, that to knowinge of other mennes doinges setten al their 23. bene. cure, and lightly desyren the badde to clatter rather than the good, and have no wil their owne maner to amende. They also hate of olde rancours lightly haven; and there that suche thing 26. thynge. abydeth, sodaynly in their mouthes procedeth the habundaunce of the herte, and wordes as stones out-throwe. Wherfore my 28. stones repeated in Th. counsayl is ever-more openly and apertly, in what place thou sitte, 29. counsayle. apertely. counterplete th'errours and meninges in as fer as thou hem 30. therrours. meanynges. ferre. wistest false, and leve for no wight to make hem be knowe in 31. wystyst. leaue. every bodyes ere; and be alway pacient and use Jacobes wordes, 32. eare. what-so-ever men of thee clappen: "I shal sustayne my ladyes 33. menne. the. wrathe which I have deserved, so longe as my Margarite hath rightwysed my cause." And certes (quod she) I witnesse my-selfe, if thou, thus converted, sorowest in good meninge in thyne herte, 36. meanynge. [and] wolt from al vanitè parfitly departe, in consolacioun of al 37. I supply and. wolte. parfytely. 37. consolatyoun. good plesaunce of that Margaryte, whiche that thou desyrest after 38. pleasaunce. wil of thyn herte, in a maner of a †moders pitè, [she] shul fully 39. hert. mothers; read moders. I supply she. accepte thee in-to grace. For right as thou rentest clothes in 40. the. open sighte, so openly to sowe hem at his worshippe withouten reprofe [is] commended. Also, right as thou were ensample of 42. I supply is. moche-folde errour, right so thou must be ensample of manyfolde correccioun; so good savour to forgoing †of errour causeth diligent 44. correctioun. al; read of. After errour I omit distroyeng (gloss upon for∣going). love, with many playted praisinges to folowe; and than shal al the firste errours make the folowinge worshippes to seme hugely encresed. Blacke and white, set togider, every for other more 47. encreased. sette. semeth; and so doth every thinges contrary in kynde. But 48. dothe. infame, that goth alwaye tofore, and praysinge worship by any 49. gothe. worshippe. cause folowinge after, maketh to ryse the ilke honour in double of welth; and that quencheth the spotte of the first enfame. Why
wenest, I saye, these thinges in hindringe of thy name? Nay, 52. wenyste. Naye nay god wotte. nay, god wot, but for pure encresing worship, thy rightwysenesse to 53. encreasyng. commende, and thy trouthe to seme the more. Wost nat wel thy-selfe, that thou in fourme of making †passest nat Adam that eet of the apple? Thou †passest nat the stedfastnesse of Noe, that eetinge of the grape becom dronke. Thou passest nat the 55-7. passeth (twice); passyst (third time). ete. 57. eatynge. become. chastitè of Lothe, that lay by his doughter; eke the nobley of Abraham, whom god reproved by his pryde; also Davides mekenesse, whiche for a woman made Urye be slawe. What? also Hector of Troye, in whom no defaute might be founde, yet 61. whome. is he reproved that he ne hadde with manhode nat suffred the warre begonne, ne Paris to have went in-to Grece, by whom gan 63. begon. ganne. al the sorowe. For trewly, him lacketh no venim of privè consenting, whiche that openly leveth a wrong to withsaye. 65. leaueth. wronge. withsay.
Lo eke an olde proverbe amonges many other: "He that is stille semeth as he graunted."

Now by these ensamples thou might fully understonde, that 68. Nowe. these thinges ben writte to your lerning, and in rightwysenesse of tho persones, as thus: To every wight his defaute committed made goodnesse afterwardes don be the more in reverence and in 71. done. open shewing; for ensample, is it nat songe in holy churche, 72. song. "Lo, how necessary was Adams synne!" David the king gat 73. howe. gate. Salomon the king of her that was Uryes wyf. Truly, for reprofe 74. wyfe. is non of these thinges writte. Right so, tho I reherce thy 75. none. before-dede, I repreve thee never the more; ne for no villany of thee are they rehersed, but for worshippe, so thou continewe wel 76-7. the (twice). here-after: and for profit of thy-selfe I rede thou on hem thinke.' 78. profyte.

Than sayde I right thus: 'Lady of unitè and accorde, envy and wrathe lurken there thou comest in place; ye weten wel your-selve, and so don many other, that whyle I administred the 81. done. office of commen doinge, as in rulinge of the stablisshmentes amonges the people, I defouled never my conscience for no maner dede; but ever, by witte and by counsayle of the wysest, the maters weren drawen to their right endes. And thus trewly for you, lady, I have desyred suche cure; and certes, in your service was I nat ydel, as fer as suche doinge of my cure 87. ferre. streccheth.' 88. stretcheth.

'That is a thing,' quod she, 'that may drawe many hertes of noble, and voice of commune in-to glory; and fame is nat but wrecched and fickle. Alas! that mankynde coveyteth in so leude 91. wretched. a wyse to be rewarded of any good dede, sithe glorie of fame, in this worlde, is nat but hindringe of glorie in tyme comminge! And certes (quod she) yet at the hardest suche fame, in-to heven, is nat the erthe but a centre to the cercle of heven? A pricke is wonder litel in respect of al the cercle; and yet, in al this pricke, 96. respecte. may no name be born, in maner of peersing, for many obstacles, 97. borne. as waters, and wildernesse, and straunge langages. And nat only 98. onely. names of men ben stilled and holden out of knowleginge by these obstacles, but also citees and realmes of prosperitè ben letted to be knowe, and their reson hindred; so that they mowe nat ben 101. reason. parfitly in mennes propre understandinge. How shulde than the 102. parfitely. Howe. name of a singuler Londenoys passe the glorious name of London, whiche by many it is commended, and by many it is lacked, and in many mo places in erthe nat knowen than knowen? For in many countrees litel is London in knowing or in spech; and yet among oon maner of people may nat such fame in goodnes 107. one. come; for as many as praysen, commenly as many lacken. Fy 108. Fye. than on such maner fame! Slepe, and suffre him that knoweth previtè of hertes to dele suche fame in thilke place there nothing 110. nothynge. ayenst a sothe shal neither speke ne dare apere, by attourney ne by other maner. How many greet-named, and many greet 112. Howe. great (twice). in worthinesse losed, han be tofore this tyme, that now out 113. nowe. of memorie are slidden, and clenely forgeten, for defaute of wrytinges! And yet scriptures for greet elde so ben defased, that 115. great. no perpetualtè may in hem ben juged. But if thou wolt make 116. maye. wolte. comparisoun to ever, what joye mayst thou have in erthly name? It is a fayr lykenesse, a pees or oon grayn of whete, to a thou∣sand 118. fayre. one grayne of wheate. thousande. shippes ful of corne charged! What nombre is betwene the oon and th'other? And yet mowe bothe they be nombred, and 120. one. thother. ende in rekening have. But trewly, al that may be nombred is nothing to recken, as to thilke that may nat be nombred. For 121-2. maye. †of the thinges ended is mad comparison; as, oon litel, another 123. ofte; read of the. made. one. greet; but in thinges to have an ende, and another no ende, 124. great. suche comparisoun may nat be founden. Wherfore in heven to
ben losed with god hath non ende, but endlesse endureth; and 126. none. thou canst nothing don aright, but thou desyre the rumour therof 127. canste nothynge done. rumoure. be heled and in every wightes ere; and that dureth but a pricke 128. healed; read deled? eare. in respecte of the other. And so thou sekest reward of folkes 129. rewarde. smale wordes, and of vayne praysinges. Trewly, therin thou lesest the guerdon of vertue; and lesest the grettest valour of 131. valoure. consyence. conscience, and uphap thy renomè everlasting. Therfore boldely renomè of fame of the erthe shulde be hated, and fame after deth shulde be desyred of werkes of vertue. [Trewly, vertue] asketh 134. Supply Trewly, vertue. guerdoning, and the soule causeth al vertue. Than the soule, delivered out of prison of erthe, is most worthy suche guerdon 136. prisone. guerdone. among to have in the everlastinge fame; and nat the body, that causeth al mannes yvels.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER IX.
DIV3.P: OF twey thinges art thou answered, as me thinketh (quod CH. IX. 1. arte. Love); and if any thing be in doute in thy soule, shewe 2. thynge. it forth, thyn ignoraunce to clere, and leve it for no shame.' 3. thyne. leaue.

'Certes,' quod I, 'there is no body in this worlde, that aught coude saye by reson ayenst any of your skilles, as I leve; and by 5. reason. my witte now fele I wel, that yvel-spekers or berers of enfame 6. nowe. bearers. may litel greve or lette my purpos, but rather by suche thinge my 7. purpose, quarel to be forthered.'
'Ye,' quod she, 'and it is proved also, that the ilke jewel in 9. Yea. my kepinge shal nat there-thorow be stered, of the lest moment 10. -thorowe. steered. that might be imagined.'
'That is soth,' quod I.

'Wel,' quod she, 'than †leveth there, to declare that thy in∣suffisance 13. leneth; read leueth. is no maner letting, as thus: for that she is so worthy, thou shuldest not clymbe so highe; for thy moebles and thyn 15. thyne. estate arn voyded, thou thinkest [thee] fallen in suche miserie, 16. arne. I supply thee. that gladnesse of thy pursute wol nat on thee discende.' 17. the.

'Certes,' quod I, 'that is sothe; right suche thought is in myn 18. myne hert. herte; for commenly it is spoken, and for an olde proverbe it is
leged: "He that heweth to hye, with chippes he may lese 20. maye. his sight." Wherfore I have ben about, in al that ever I might, to studye wayes of remedye by one syde or by another.'

'Now,' quod she, 'god forbede †that thou seke any other 23. Nowe. are; read that. doinges but suche as I have lerned thee in our restinge-whyles, 24. the. and suche herbes as ben planted in oure gardins. Thou shalt 25. shalte. wel understande that above man is but oon god alone.' 26. one.

'How,' quod I, 'han men to-forn this tyme trusted in writtes 27. Howe. to forne. and chauntements, and in helpes of spirites that dwellen in the ayre, and therby they han getten their desyres, where-as first, for al his manly power, he daunced behynde?'

'O,' quod she, 'fy on suche maters! For trewly, that is 31. fye. sacrilege; and that shal have no sort with any of my servauntes; in myne eyen shal suche thing nat be loked after. How often is it commaunded by these passed wyse, that "to one god shal men serve, and not to goddes?" And who that liste to have myne helpes, shal aske none helpe of foule spirites. Alas! is nat man maked semblable to god? Wost thou nat wel, that al vertue of lyvelich werkinge, by goddes purveyaunce, is underput to reson∣able 38. vnderputte. creature in erthe? Is nat every thing, a this halfe god, mad 39. thynge. made. buxom to mannes contemplation, understandinge in heven and 40. buxome. in erthe and in helle? Hath not man beinge with stones, soule of 41. manne. wexing with trees and herbes? Hath he nat soule of felinge, with beestes, fisshes, and foules? And he hath soule of reson and 43. reason. understanding with aungels; so that in him is knit al maner 44. knytte. of lyvinges by a resonable proporcioun. Also man is mad of 45. lyuenges. reasonable. made. al the foure elementes. Al universitee is rekened in him alone; he hath, under god, principalitè above al thinges. Now is his 47. Nowe. soule here, now a thousand myle hence; now fer, now nygh; 48. nowe. nowe ferre nowe. thousande. now hye, now lowe; as fer in a moment as in mountenaunce of 49. nowe (twice). ferre. momente. ten winter; and al this is in mannes governaunce and disposicion. 50. tenne. disposytion. Than sheweth it that men ben liche unto goddes, and children of moost heyght. But now, sithen al thinges [arn] underput to the 52. nowe. I supply arn. vnderputte. wil of resonable creatures, god forbede any man to winne that lord∣ship, 53. reasonable. and aske helpe of any-thing lower than him-selfe; and than, 54. lordshippe. thynge. namely, of foule thinges innominable. Now than, why shuldest
thou wene to love to highe, sithen nothing is thee above but god 56. nothynge. the. alone? Trewly, I wot wel that thilke jewel is in a maner even in 57. wote. euyn. lyne of degree there thou art thy-selfe, and nought above, save 58. arte. thus: aungel upon angel, man upon man, and devil upon devil 59. manne (twice). han a maner of soveraigntee; and that shal cese at the daye 60. soueraygntie. cease. of dome. And so I say: though thou be put to serve the 61. thoughe putte. ilke jewel duringe thy lyfe, yet is that no servage of under∣puttinge, but a maner of travayling plesaunce, to conquere and gette that thou hast not. I sette now the hardest: in my service 64. haste. now thou deydest, for sorowe of wantinge in thy desyres; trewly, 64-5. nowe. al hevenly bodyes with one voyce shul come and make melody in thy cominge, and say—"Welcome, our fere, and worthy to entre into Jupiters joye! For thou with might hast overcome deth; 68. haste. dethe. thou woldest never flitte out of thy service; and we al shul now praye to the goddes, rowe by rowe, to make thilk Margarite, 70. nowe pray. that no routh had in this persone, but unkyndely without comfort 71. For in read on? comforte. let thee deye, shal besette her-selfe in suche wyse, that in erthe, 72. lette the. for parte of vengeaunce, shal she no joye have in loves service; and whan she is deed, than shal her soule ben brought up in-to thy presence; and whider thou wilt chese, thilke soule shal ben 75. wylte. committed." Or els, after thy deth, anon al the foresayd hevenly 76. dethe anone. bodyes, by one accorde, shal †benimen from thilke perle al the 77. benommen; read benimen. vertues that firste her were taken; for she hath hem forfeyted by that on thee, my servaunt, in thy lyve, she wolde not suffre 79. the. to worche al vertues, withdrawen by might of the hygh bodyes. Why than shuldest thou wene so any more? And if thee liste 81. the. to loke upon the lawe of kynde, and with order whiche to me was ordayned, sothely, non age, non overtourninge tyme but 83. none (twice). †hiderto had no tyme ne power to chaunge the wedding, ne 84. hytherto. the knotte to unbynde of two hertes [that] thorow oon assent, in 85. Supply that. thorowe one. my presence, †togider accorden to enduren til deth hem departe. 86. togyther. dethe. What? trowest thou, every ideot wot the meninge and the privy 87. ydeot wotte. entent of these thinges? They wene, forsothe, that suche accord 88. accorde. may not be, but the rose of maydenhede be plucked. Do way, 89. waye (twice). do way; they knowe nothing of this. For consent of two hertes 90. consente.
alone maketh the fasteninge of the knotte; neither lawe of kynde ne mannes lawe determineth neither the age ne the qualitè of persones, but only accord bitwene thilke twaye. And trewly, 93. onely. after tyme that suche accord, by their consent in hert, is enseled, 93-4. accorde. 94. ensealed. and put in my tresorye amonges my privy thinges, than ginneth the name of spousayle; and although they breken forward bothe, 96. breaken forwarde. yet suche mater enseled is kept in remembrance for ever. And 97. ensealed. kepte. see now that spouses have the name anon after accord, though 98. se nowe. accorde. the rose be not take. The aungel bad Joseph take Marye his 99. bade. spouse, and to Egypte wende. Lo! she was cleped "spouse," and yet, toforn ne after, neither of hem bothe mente no flesshly 101. toforne. lust knowe. Wherfore the wordes of trouthe acorden that my 102. luste. servauntes shulden forsake bothe †fader and moder, and be ad∣herand 103. father and mother; rather, fader and moder. adherande. to his spouse; and they two in unitè of one flesshe shulden accorde. And this wyse, two that wern firste in a litel 105. werne. maner discordaunt, hygher that oon and lower that other, ben 106. one. mad evenliche in gree to stonde. But now to enfourme thee 107. made. nowe. the. that ye ben liche to goddes, these clerkes sayn, and in deter∣minacion 108. sayne. shewen, that "three thinges haven [by] the names 109. thre. I supply by. of goddes ben cleped; that is to sayn: man, divel, and images"; 110. cleaped. but yet is there but oon god, of whom al goodnesse, al grace, and 111. one. al vertue cometh; and he †is loving and trewe, and everlasting, 112. his; read is. and pryme cause of al being thinges. But men ben goddes lovinge and trewe, but not everlasting; and that is by adop∣cioun of the everlastinge god. Divels ben goddes, stirringe by a maner of lyving; but neither ben they trewe ne everlastinge; 116. lyueng. and their name of godliheed th[e]y han by usurpacion, as the 117. thy; read they. prophete sayth: "Al goddes of gentyles (that is to say, paynims) 118. saythe. are divels." But images ben goddes by nuncupacion; and they ben neither livinge ne trewe, ne everlastinge. After these wordes they clepen "goddes" images wrought with mennes handes. 121. cleapen. But now [art thou a] resonable creature, that by adopcion alone 122. nowe. I supply art thou a. reasonable. art to the grete god everlastinge, and therby thou art "god" 123. arte (twice). great. cleped: let thy †faders maners so entre thy wittes that thou might 124. lette. folowe, in-as-moche as longeth to thee, thy †faders worship, so 124-5. fathers; read faders. 125. the. worshyppe.
that in nothinge thy kynde from his wil declyne, ne from his nobley perverte. In this wyse if thou werche, thou art above 127. arte. al other thinges save god alone; and so say no more "thyn herte to serve in to hye a place."

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER X.
DIV3.P: FULLY have I now declared thyn estate to be good, so thou CH. X. 1. nowe. folow therafter, and that the †objeccion first †by thee 2. abiection; read objeccion. be; read by. the. aleged, in worthinesse of thy Margaryte, shal not thee lette, as 3. the. it shal forther thee, and encrese thee. It is now to declare, the 4. the. encrease the. nowe. last objeccion in nothing may greve.' 5. obiection.

'Yes, certes,' quod I, 'bothe greve and lette muste it nedes; 6. let. the contrarye may not ben proved; and see now why. Whyle 7. maye. se nowe. I was glorious in worldly welfulnesse, and had suche goodes in welth as maken men riche, tho was I drawe in-to companyes that loos, prise, and name yeven. Tho louteden blasours; tho curreyden glosours; tho welcomeden flatterers; tho worshipped thilke that now deynen nat to loke. Every wight, in such erthly 12. nowe. wele habundant, is holde noble, precious, benigne, and wyse to do what he shal, in any degree that men him sette; al-be-it that 14. set. the sothe be in the contrarye of al tho thinges. But he that can 15. can ne never; omit ne. never so wel him behave, and hath vertue habundaunt in manyfolde maners, and be nat welthed with suche erthly goodes, is holde for a folle, and sayd, his wit is but sotted. Lo! how fals for 18. wytte. false. aver is holde trewe! Lo! how trewe is cleped fals for wanting 19. auer (sic); for aueir (avoir). howe. cleaped. false. of goodes! Also, lady, dignitees of office maken men mikel comended, as thus: "he is so good, were he out, his pere shulde men not fynde." Trewly, I trowe of some suche that are so praysed, were they out ones, another shulde make him so be knowe, he shulde of no wyse no more ben loked after: but only 24. onely. fooles, wel I wot, desyren suche newe thinges. Wherfore I wonder 25. wotte. new. that thilke governour, out of whom alone the causes proceden 26. whome. that governen al thinges, whiche that hath ordeyned this world 27. worlde. in workes of the kyndely bodyes so be governed, not with
unstedfast or happyous thing, but with rules of reson, whiche 29. reason. shewen the course of certayne thinges: why suffreth he suche slydinge chaunges, that misturnen suche noble thinges as ben we men, that arn a fayr parcel of the erthe, and holden the upperest 32. arne a fayre parsel. degree, under god, of benigne thinges, as ye sayden right now 33. nowe. your-selfe; shulde never man have ben set in so worthy a place but-if his degrè were ordayned noble. Alas! thou that knittest the purveyaunce of al thinges, why lokest thou not to amenden these defautes? I see shrewes that han wicked maners sitten in 37. se. chayres of domes, lambes to punisshen, there wolves shulden ben punisshed. Lo! vertue, shynende naturelly, for povertee lurketh, 39. pouertie. and is hid under cloude; but the moone false, forsworn (as 40. hydde. forsworne. I knowe my-selfe) for aver and yeftes, hath usurped to shyne by day-light, with peynture of other mens praysinges; and trewly, thilke forged light fouly shulde fade, were the trouth away of colours feyned. Thus is night turned in-to day, and day in-to 44. daye (twice). night; winter in-to sommer, and sommer in-to winter; not in dede, but in misclepinge of foliche people.' 46. miscleapynge.
'Now,' quod she, 'what wenest thou of these thinges? How felest thou in thyn hert, by what governaunce that this cometh aboute?'
'Certes,' quod I, 'that wot I never; but-if it be that Fortune 50. wotte. hath graunt from above, to lede the ende of man as her lyketh.'

'Ah! now I see,' quod she, 'th'entent of thy mening! Lo, 52. nowe I se. thentent. meanyng. bycause thy worldly goodes ben fulliche dispent, thou beraft out 53. berafte. of dignitè of office, in whiche thou madest the †gaderinge of thilke 54. gatherynge. goodes, and yet diddest in that office by counsaile of wyse [before 55. I supply before that. that] any thing were ended; and true were unto hem whos profit 56. whose profyte. thou shuldest loke; and seest now many that in thilke hervest 57. nowe. made of thee mokel, and now, for glosing of other, deyneth thee 58. the (twice). nowe. nought to forther, but enhaunsen false shrewes by witnessinge of trouthe! These thinges greveth thyn herte, to sene thy-selfe thus abated; and than, frayltè of mankynde ne setteth but litel by the lesers of suche richesse, have he never so moche vertue; and so thou wenest of thy jewel to renne in dispyt, and not ben accepted 63. dispyte. in-to grace. Al this shal thee nothing hinder. Now (quod she) 64. the. Nowe. first thou wost wel, thou lostest nothing that ever mightest thou 65. woste.
chalenge for thyn owne. Whan nature brought thee forth, come 66. the forthe. thou not naked out of thy †moders wombe? Thou haddest no 67. mothers; read moders. richesse; and whan thou shalt entre in-to the ende of every flesshly body, what shalt thou have with thee than? So, every 69. the. richesse thou hast in tyme of thy livinge, nis but lent; thou 70. haste. lente. might therin chalenge no propertee. And see now; every thing 71. propertie. se nowe. that is a mannes own, he may do therwith what him lyketh, to 72. owne. yeve or to kepe; but richesse thou playnest from thee lost; if thy 73. the. might had strecched so ferforth, fayn thou woldest have hem kept, 74. stretched. fayne. multiplyed with mo other; and so, ayenst thy wil, ben they departed from thee; wherfore they were never thyn. And if thou laudest 76. the. and joyest any wight, for he is stuffed with suche maner richesse, thou art in that beleve begyled; for thou wenest thilke joye to be 78. arte. selinesse or els ese; and he that hath lost suche happes to ben 79. ease. loste. unsely.'
'Ye, forsoth,' quod I.
'Wel,' quod she, 'than wol I prove that unsely in that wise is to preise; and so the tother is, the contrary, to be lacked.'
'How so?' quod I. 84. Howe.

'For Unsely,' quod she, 'begyleth nat, but sheweth th'entent 85. thentent. of her working. Et e contra: Selinesse begyleth. For in prosperitè she maketh a jape in blyndnesse; that is, she wyndeth him to make sorowe whan she withdraweth. Wolt thou nat (quod she) 88. Wolte. preise him better that sheweth to thee his herte, tho[ugh] it be 89. the. with bytande wordes and dispitous, than him that gloseth and thinketh in †his absence to do thee many harmes?' 91. their; read his. the.
'Certes,' quod I, 'the oon is to commende; and the other to 92. one. lacke and dispice.'

'A! ha!' quod she, 'right so Ese, while †she lasteth, gloseth 94. ease. he; read she. and flatereth; and lightly voydeth whan she most plesauntly sheweth; and ever, in hir absence, she is aboute to do thee tene and sorowe in herte. But Unsely, al-be-it with bytande chere, sheweth what she is, and so doth not that other; wherfore Unsely doth not begyle. Selinesse disceyveth; Unsely put away 99. dothe. awaye. doute. That oon maketh men blynde; that other openeth their eyen in shewinge of wrecchidnesse. The oon is ful of drede to 100-1. one (twice). 101. wretchydnesse.
lese that is not his owne; that other is sobre, and maketh men discharged of mokel hevinesse in burthen. The oon draweth 103. one. a man from very good; the other haleth him to vertue by the hookes of thoughtes. And wenist thou nat that thy disese hath 105. disease. don thee mokel more to winne than ever yet thou lostest, and 106. done the. more than ever the contrary made thee winne? Is nat a greet 107. the. great. good, to thy thinking, for to knowe the hertes of thy sothfast frendes? Pardè, they ben proved to the ful, and the trewe have 109. Pardy. discevered fro the false. Trewly, at the goinge of the ilke brotel joye, ther yede no more away than the ilke that was nat thyn 111. awaye. proper. He was never from that lightly departed; thyn owne 111-2. thyne. good therfore leveth it stille with thee. Now good (quod she); 113. leaueth. the. Nowe. for how moche woldest thou somtyme have bought this verry 114. howe. knowing of thy frendes from the flatteringe flyes that thee glosed, 115. the. whan thou thought thy-selfe sely? But thou that playnest of losse in richesse, hast founden the most dere-worthy thing; that thou 117. thynge. clepest unsely hath made thee moche thing to winnen. And 118. cleapest. the. thynge. also, for conclusioun of al, he is frende that now leveth nat his 119. nowe leaueth. herte from thyne helpes. And if that Margarite denyeth now nat 120. hert. nowe. to suffre her vertues shyne to thee-wardes with spredinge bemes, 121. the. spreadynge beames. as far or farther than if thou were sely in worldly joye, trewly, 122. farre. I saye nat els but she is somdel to blame.' 123. somdele.
'Ah! pees,' quod I, 'and speke no more of this; myn herte 124. peace. myne. breketh, now thou touchest any suche wordes!' 125. breaketh nowe.
'A! wel!' quod she, 'thanne let us singen; thou herest no 126. lette. more of these thinges at this tyme.'

DIV2.TRAILER: Thus endeth the firste book of the Testament of Love; and herafter foloweth the seconde.

DIV2.HEAD: BOOK II.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER I.
DIV3.P: VERY welth may not be founden in al this worlde; and that is wel sene. Lo! how in my mooste comfort, as I wende CH. I. 2. howe. comforte. and moost supposed to have had ful answere of my contrary 3. hadde. thoughtes, sodaynly it was vanisshed. And al the workes of man faren in the same wyse; whan folk wenen best her entent for to 5. folke. have and willes to perfourme, anon chaunging of the lift syde to 6. anone. the right halve tourneth it so clene in-to another kynde, that never shal it come to the first plyte in doinge.

O this wonderful steering so soone otherwysed out of knowinge! But for my purpos was at the beginninge, and so dureth yet, if god 10. purpose. of his grace tyme wol me graunt, I thinke to perfourme this worke, as I have begonne, in love; after as my thinne wit, with 12. wytte. inspiracion of him that hildeth al grace, wol suffre. Grevously, god wot, have I suffred a greet throwe that the Romayne 14. wotte. great. emperour, which in unitè of love shulde acorde, and every with other * * * * in cause of other to avaunce; and namely, sithe 16. (Something seems to be lost here). this empyre [nedeth] to be corrected of so many sectes in heresie 17. I supply nedeth. of faith, of service, o[f] rule in loves religion. Trewly, al were 18. o; read of. it but to shende erroneous opinions, I may it no lenger suffre. 19. erronyous. maye. For many men there ben that sayn love to be in gravel and sande, 20. menne. sayne. that with see ebbinge and flowinge woweth, as riches that sodaynly vanissheth. And some sayn that love shulde be in windy blastes, that stoundmele turneth as a phane, and glorie of renomè, which after lustes of the varyaunt people is areysed or stilled.

Many also wenen that in the sonne and the moone and other sterres love shulde ben founden; for among al other planettes 26. amonge. moste soveraynly they shynen, as dignitees in reverence of estates rather than good han and occupyen. Ful many also there ben that in okes and in huge postes supposen love to ben grounded, as in strength and in might, whiche mowen not helpen their owne
wrecchidnesse, whan they ginne to falle. But [of] suche diversitè 31. wretchydnesse. fal. I supply of. of sectes, ayenst the rightful beleve of love, these errours ben forth 32. forthe. spredde, that loves servantes in trewe rule and stedfast fayth in 33. stedfaste faythe. no place daren apere. Thus irrecuperable joy is went, and anoy 34. darne. endless is entred. For no man aright reproveth suche errours, 35. endlesse. but [men] confirmen their wordes, and sayn, that badde is noble 36. I supply men. good, and goodnesse is badde; to which folk the prophete biddeth 37. folke. wo without ende.

Also manye tonges of greet false techinges in gylinge maner, 39. great. principally in my tymes, not only with wordes but also with armes, 40. onely. loves servauntes and professe in his religion of trewe rule pursewen, to confounden and to distroyen. And for as moche as holy †faders, 42. fathers; read faders. that of our Christen fayth aproved and strengthed to the Jewes, as to men resonable and of divinitè lerned, proved thilke fayth with 44. faythe. resones, and with auctoritès of the olde testament and of the newe, her pertinacie to distroy: but to paynims, that for beestes and houndes were holde, to putte hem out of their errour, was †miracle 47. put. miracles; read miracle. of god shewed. These thinges were figured by cominge of th'angel 48. thangel. to the shepherdes, and by the sterre to paynims kinges; as who sayth: angel resonable to resonable creature, and sterre of miracle 50. saythe. to people bestial not lerned, wern sent to enforme. But I, lovers 51. werne. clerk, in al my conning and with al my mightes, trewly I have no suche grace in vertue of miracles, ne for no discomfit falsheedes suffyseth not auctoritès alone; sithen that suche [arn] heretikes and maintaynours of falsitès. Wherfore I wot wel, sithen that they ben men, and reson is approved in hem, the clowde of errour hath her reson beyond probable resons, whiche that cacchende 57. reason. bewonde (sic). catchende wytte. wit rightfully may not with-sitte. By my travaylinge studie I have ordeyned hem, †whiche that auctoritè, misglosed by mannes 59. with; read whiche. reson, to graunt shal ben enduced. 60. reason.

Now ginneth my penne to quake, to thinken on the sentences 61. Nowe. of the envyous people, whiche alway ben redy, both ryder and 62. alwaye. goer, to scorne and to jape this leude book; and me, for rancour 63. booke. rancoure. and hate in their hertes, they shullen so dispyse, that although 64. althoughe. my book be leude, yet shal it ben more leude holden, and by 65. booke. wicked wordes in many maner apayred. Certes, me thinketh,
[of] the sowne of their badde speche right now is ful bothe myne 67. I supply of. nowe. eeres. O good precious Margaryte, myne herte shulde wepe if I wiste ye token hede of suche maner speche; but trewly, I wot 69. wotte. wel, in that your wysdom shal not asterte. For of god, maker of 70. wysdome. kynde, witnesse I took, that for none envy ne yvel have I drawe 71. toke. this mater togider; but only for goodnesse to maintayn, and errours in falsetees to distroy. Wherfore (as I sayd) with reson 73. reason. I thinke, thilke forsayd errours to distroye and dequace.

These resons and suche other, if they enduce men, in loves 75. reasons. service, trewe to beleve of parfit blisse, yet to ful faithe in cre∣dence 76. parfyte. of deserte fully mowe they nat suffyse; sithen 'faith hath no merite of mede, whan mannes reson sheweth experience in doing.' For utterly no reson the parfit blisse of love by no waye 78-9. reason (twice). 79. parfyte. may make to be comprehended. Lo! what is a parcel of lovers 80. maye. persel. joye? Parfit science, in good service, of their desyre to compre∣hende 81. parfyte. in bodily doinge the lykinge of the soule; not as by a glasse to have contemplacion of tyme cominge, but thilke first imagined and thought after face to face in beholding. What herte, what reson, what understandinge can make his heven to be 85. reason. feled and knowe, without assaye in doinge? Certes, noon. Sithen 86. none. thanne of love cometh suche fruite in blisse, and love in him-selfe is the most among other vertues, as clerkes sayn; the seed of 88. amonge. sayne. suche springinge in al places, in al countreys, in al worldes shulde ben sowe.

But o! welawaye! thilke seed is forsake, and †mowe not ben 88-91. sede. 91. mowen; read mowe. suffred, the lond-tillers to sette a-werke, without medlinge of 92. londe-tyllers. set. cockle; badde wedes whiche somtyme stonken †han caught the 93. hath; read han. name of love among idiotes and badde-meninge people. Never-the-later, 94. meanynge. yet how-so-it-be that men clepe thilke †thing preciousest 95. howe. menne cleape. kynge (sic); read thing. in kynde, with many eke-names, that other thinges that the soule yeven the ilke noble name, it sheweth wel that in a maner men have a greet lykinge in worshippinge of thilke name. Wherfore 98. great. this worke have I writte; and to thee, tytled of Loves name, 99. the. I have it avowed in a maner of sacrifyse; that, where-ever it be rad, it mowe in merite, by the excellence of thilke name, the 101. radde. more wexe in authoritè and worshippe of takinge in hede; and to
what entent it was ordayned, the inseëres mowen ben moved. Every thing to whom is owande occasion don as for his ende, 104. thynge. done. Aristotle supposeth that the actes of every thinge ben in a maner his final cause. A final cause is noblerer, or els even as noble, as thilke thing that is finally to thilke ende; wherfore accion of 107. thynge. thinge everlasting is demed to be eternal, and not temporal; sithen it is his final cause. Right so the actes of my boke 'Love,' and love is noble; wherfore, though my book be leude, the cause 110. boke. with which I am stered, and for whom I ought it doon, noble 111. done (sic). forsothe ben bothe. But bycause that in conninge I am yong, 112. yonge. and can yet but crepe, this leude A. b. c. have I set in-to lern∣ing; 113. canne. sette. for I can not passen the telling of three as yet. And if god 114. thre. wil, in shorte tyme, I shal amende this leudnesse in joininge syllables; whiche thing, for dulnesse of witte, I may not in three 116. thynge. maye. thre. letters declare. For trewly I saye, the goodnesse of my Margaryte∣perle wolde yeve mater in endyting to many clerkes; certes, her mercy is more to me swetter than any livinges; wherfore my lippes mowen not suffyse, in speking of her ful laude and wor∣shippe as they shulde. But who is that [wolde be wyse] in 121. that in knowyng (sic); supply wolde be wyse before in knowing. knowing of the orders of heven, and putteth his resones in the erthe? I forsothe may not, with blere eyen, the shyning sonne of vertue in bright whele of this Margaryte beholde; therfore as yet I may her not discryve in vertue as I wolde. In tyme cominge, 125. maye. in another tretyse, thorow goddes grace, this sonne in clerenesse 126. thorowe. of vertue to be-knowe, and how she enlumineth al this day, 127. howe. I thinke to declare.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER II.
DIV3.P: IN this mene whyle this comfortable lady gan singe a wonder CH. II. 1. meane. ganne. mater of endytinge in Latin; but trewly, the noble colours in rethorik wyse knitte were so craftely, that my conning wol not strecche to remembre; but the sentence, I trowe, somdel have 4. stretche. somdele. I in mynde. Certes, they were wonder swete of sowne, and they were touched al in lamentacion wyse, and by no werbles of myrthe. Lo! thus gan she singe in Latin, as I may constrewe it 7. ganne. in our Englisshe tonge.

'Alas! that these hevenly bodyes their light and course shewen, as nature yave hem in commaundement at the ginning of the first age; but these thinges in free choice of reson han non under∣stondinge. 11. none. But man that ought to passe al thing of doinge, of 12. thynge. right course in kynde, over-whelmed sothnesse by wrongful tytle, and hath drawen the sterre of envye to gon by his syde, that the clips of me, that shulde be his shynande sonne, so ofte is seye, 15. sey; read seye or seyen. that it wened thilke errour, thorow hem come in, shulde ben myn 16. thorowe. owne defaute. Trewly, therfore, I have me withdrawe, and mad 17. made. my dwellinge out of lande in an yle by my-selfe, in the occian closed; and yet sayn there many, they have me harberowed; but, 19. sayne. god wot, they faylen. These thinges me greven to thinke, and 20. wote. namely on passed gladnesse, that in this worlde was wont me 21. wonte. disporte of highe and lowe; and now it is fayled; they that 22. nowe. wolden maystries me have in thilke stoundes. In heven on highe, above Saturnes sphere, in sesonable tyme were they 24. seasonable. lodged; but now come queynte counsailours that in no house wol suffre me sojourne, wherof is pitè; and yet sayn some that 26. sayne. they me have in celler with wyne shed; in gernere, there corn is 27. corne. layd covered with whete; in sacke, sowed with wolle; in purse, 28. layde. with money faste knit; among pannes mouled in a †whicche; 29. knytte. amonge (twice). wyche; read whicche. in presse, among clothes layd, with riche pelure arayed; in stable, 30. layde. among hors and other beestes, as hogges, sheep, and neet; and 31. amonge horse. shepe. nete. in many other wyse. But thou, maker of light (in winking of thyn eye the sonne is queynt), wost right wel that I in trewe name 33. woste. was never thus herberowed.

Somtyme, toforn the sonne in the seventh partie was smiten, I bar both crosse and mytre, to yeve it where I wolde. With me 36. bare. the pope wente a-fote; and I tho was worshipped of al holy 37. went. church. Kinges baden me their crownes holden. The law was set as it shuld; tofore the juge, as wel the poore durste shewe his greef as the riche, for al his money. I defended tho taylages, 40. grefe. and was redy for the poore to paye. I made grete feestes in my 41. pay. great. tyme, and noble songes, and maryed damoselles of gentil feture, withouten golde or other richesse. Poore clerkes, for witte of schole, I sette in churches, and made suche persones to preche; 44. preache.
and tho was service in holy churche honest and devout, in 45. deuoute. plesaunce bothe of god and of the people. But now the leude 46. nowe. for symonye is avaunced, and shendeth al holy churche. Now is 47. Nowe. steward, for his achates; now †is courtiour, for his debates; now 48. stewarde. nowe. it; read is. nowe. is eschetour, for his wronges; now is losel, for his songes, per∣soner; 49. eschetoure. nowe. and [hath his] provendre alone, with whiche manye 50. I supply hath his. thrifty shulde encrese. And yet is this shrewe behynde; free herte is forsake; and losengeour is take. Lo! it acordeth; for suche there ben that voluntarie lustes haunten in courte with ribaudye, that til midnight and more wol playe and wake, but in the churche at matins he is behynde, for yvel disposicion of his stomake; therfore he shulde ete bene-breed (and so did his 56. eate beane-. syre) his estate ther-with to strengthen. His auter is broke, and lowe lyth, in poynte to gon to the erthe; but his hors muste ben 58. lythe. gone. horse. esy and hye, to bere him over grete waters. His chalice poore, 59. easy. beare. great. but he hath riche cuppes. No towayle but a shete, there god shal ben handled; and on his mete-borde there shal ben bord-clothes 61. meate-. borde-. and towelles many payre. At masse serveth but a cler∣gion; fyve squiers in hal. Poore chaunsel, open holes in every syde; beddes of silke, with tapites going al aboute his chambre. Poore masse-book and leud chapelayn, and broken surplice with 65. boke. leude chapelayne. many an hole; good houndes and many, to hunte after hart and 66. harte. hare, to fede in their feestes. Of poore men have they greet 67. great. care; for they ever crave and nothing offren, they wolden have 68. nothynge. hem dolven! But among legistres there dar I not come; my 69. amonge. dare. doinge[s], they sayn, maken hem nedy. They ne wolde for 70. sayne. nothing have me in town; for than were tort and †force nought 71. forthe; read force. worth an hawe about, and plesen no men, but thilk grevous and 72. worthe. pleasen. torcious ben in might and in doing. These thinges to-forn-sayd 73. to-forne-. mowe wel, if men liste, ryme; trewly, they acorde nothing. And 74. nothynge. for-as-moch as al thinges by me shulden of right ben governed, I am sory to see that governaunce fayleth, as thus: to sene smale 76. sorye. se. and lowe governe the hye and bodies above. Certes, that policye is naught; it is forbode by them that of governaunce 78. polesye. treten and enformen. And right as beestly wit shulde ben 79. treaten. wytte.
subject to reson, so erthly power in it-selfe, the lower shulde ben 80. subiecte, reason. subject to the hygher. What is worth thy body, but it be governed with thy soule? Right so litel or naught is worth 82. worthe. erthely power, but if reignatif prudence in heedes governe the 83. reignatyfe. smale; to whiche heedes the smale owen to obey and suffre in their governaunce. But soverainnesse ayenward shulde thinke in 85. ayenwarde. this wyse: "I am servaunt of these creatures to me delivered, not lord, but defendour; not mayster, but enfourmer; not 87. lorde. possessour, but in possession; and to hem liche a tree in whiche 88. possessoure. sparowes shullen stelen, her birdes to norisshe and forth bringe, 89. forthe bring. under suretee ayenst al raveynous foules and beestes, and not to 90. suretie. be tyraunt them-selfe." And than the smale, in reste and quiete, by the heedes wel disposed, owen for their soveraynes helth and prosperitè to pray, and in other doinges in maintenaunce therof performe, withouten other administracion in rule of any maner governaunce. And they wit have in hem, and grace to come to suche thinges, yet shulde they cese til their heedes them cleped, 96. cease. although profit and plesaunce shulde folowe. But trewly, other 97. profyte. pleasaunce. governaunce ne other medlinge ought they not to clayme, ne the heedes on hem to putte. Trewly, amonges cosinage dar 99. put. dare. I not come, but-if richesse be my mene; sothly, she and other 100. meane. bodily goodes maketh nigh cosinage, ther never propinquitè ne alyaunce in lyve was ne shulde have be, nere it for her medling maners; wherfore kindly am I not ther leged. Povert of kinred is behynde; richesse suffreth him to passe; truly he saith, he com never of Japhetes childre. Whereof I am sory that Japhetes children, for povert, in no linage ben rekened, and Caynes children, for riches, be maked Japhetes heires. Alas! this is a wonder chaunge bitwene tho two Noës children, sithen that of Japhetes ofspring comeden knightes, and of Cayn discended 109. comeden (sic); read comen? the lyne of servage to his brothers childre. Lo! how gentillesse 110. howe. and servage, as cosins, bothe discended out of two brethern of 111. bretherne. one body! Wherfore I saye in sothnesse, that gentilesse in kinrede †maketh not gentil linage in succession, without desert 113. maken; read maketh. deserte. of a mans own selfe. Where is now the lyne of Alisaundre the 114. nowe. noble, or els of Hector of Troye? Who is discended of right bloode of lyne fro king Artour? Pardè, sir Perdicas, whom that
Alisandre made to ben his heire in Grece, was of no kinges bloode; his dame was a tombestere. Of what kinred ben the 118. tombystere. gentiles in our dayes? I trow therfore, if any good be in gen∣tilesse, it is only that it semeth a maner of necessitè be input to gentilmen, that they shulden not varyen fro the vertues of their auncestres. Certes, al maner linage of men ben evenliche in birth; for oon †fader, maker of al goodnes, enformed hem al, 123. one. father; read fader. and al mortal folk of one sede arn greyned. Wherto avaunt men 124. folke. arne. of her linage, in cosinage or in †elde-faders? Loke now the gin∣ning, 125. -fathers; read -faders. and to god, maker of mans person; there is no clerk ne no 126. clerke. worthy in gentilesse; and he that norissheth his †corage with 127. corare; read corage. vyces and unresonable lustes, and leveth the kynde course, to 128. leaueth. whiche ende him brought forth his birthe, trewly, he is ungentil, 129. forthe. and among †cherles may ben nempned. And therfore, he that 130. amonge. clerkes (!); read cherles. wol ben gentil, he mot daunten his flesshe fro vyces that causen 131. mote. ungentilnesse, and leve also reignes of wicked lustes, and drawe 132. leaue. to him vertue, that in al places gentilnesse gentilmen maketh. And so speke I, in feminine gendre in general, of tho persones, at the reverence of one whom every wight honoureth; for her bountee and her noblesse y-made her to god so dere, that his 136. bountie. moder she became; and she me hath had so greet in worship, 137. great. that I nil for nothing in open declare, that in any thinge ayenst her secte may so wene. For al vertue and al worthinesse of plesaunce 139. maye. in hem haboundeth. And although I wolde any-thing speke, trewly I can not; I may fynde in yvel of hem no maner mater.'

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER III.
DIV3.P: RIGHT with these wordes she stinte of that lamentable melodye; and I gan with a lyvely herte to praye, if that CH. III. 2. ganne. it were lyking unto her noble grace, she wolde her deyne to declare me the mater that firste was begonne, in which she lefte and sainte to speke beforn she gan to singe. 5. beforne.
'O,' quod she, 'this is no newe thing to me, to sene you men 6. thynge. menne. desyren after mater, whiche your-selfe caused to voyde.'

'Ah, good lady,' quod I, 'in whom victorie of strength is proved above al other thing, after the jugement of Esdram, whos lordship 9. thynge. whose.
al lignes: who is, that right as emperour hem commaundeth, 10. lignes (sic). whether thilke ben not women, in whos lyknesse to me ye aperen? 11. whose lykenesse. For right as man halt the principaltè of al thing under his be∣inge, 12. halte. in the masculyne gender; and no mo genders ben there but masculyn and femenyne; al the remenaunt ben no gendres but of grace, in facultee of grammer: right so, in the femenyne, the 15. facultie. women holden the upperest degree of al thinges under thilke gendre conteyned. Who bringeth forth kinges, whiche that ben 17. forthe. lordes of see and of erthe; and al peoples of women ben born. 18. borne. They norisshe hem that graffen vynes; they maken men comfort 19. comforte. in their gladde cheres. Her sorowe is deth to mannes herte. 20. dethe. Without women, the being of men were impossible. They conne with their swetnesse the crewel herte ravisshe, and make it meke, buxom, and benigne, without violence mevinge. In beautee 23. buxome. beautie. of their eyen, or els of other maner fetures, is al mens desyres; ye, more than in golde, precious stones, either any richesse. And in this degree, lady, your-selfe many hertes of men have so bounden, that parfit blisse in womankynde to ben men wenen, 27. parfyte. and in nothinge els. Also, lady, the goodnesse, the vertue of women, by propertè of discrecion, is so wel knowen, by litelnesse of malice, that desyre to a good asker by no waye conne they warne. And ye thanne, that wol not passe the kynde werchinge of your sectes by general discrecion, I wot wel, ye wol so enclyne 32. wotte. to my prayere, that grace of my requeste shal fully ben graunted.'

'Certes,' quod she, 'thus for the more parte fareth al mankynde, to praye and to crye after womans grace, and fayne many fan∣tasyes to make hertes enclyne to your desyres. And whan these sely women, for freeltè of their kynde, beleven your wordes, and wenen al be gospel the promise of your behestes, than graunt[en] 38. graunt. they to you their hertes, and fulfillen your lustes, wherthrough their libertè in maystreship that they toforn had is thralled; and 40. toforne. so maked soverayn and to be prayed, that first was servaunt, and voice of prayer used. Anon as filled is your lust, many of you be so trewe, that litel hede take ye of suche kyndnesse; but with traysoun anon ye thinke hem begyle, and let light of that thing whiche firste ye maked to you wonders dere; so what thing to women it is to loven any wight er she him wel knowe, and have him proved in many halfe! For every glittring thing
is nat gold; and under colour of fayre speche many vices may 48. golde. be hid and conseled. Therfore I rede no wight to trust on you to rathe; mens chere and her speche right gyleful is ful ofte. Wherfore without good assay, it is nat worth on many †of you 51. worthe. on; read of. to truste. Trewly, it is right kyndely to every man that thinketh women betraye, and shewen outward al goodnesse, til he have 53. -warde. his wil performed. Lo! the bird is begyled with the mery voice 54. birde. of the foulers whistel. Whan a woman is closed in your nette, than wol ye causes fynden, and bere unkyndenesse her †on 56. beare. vnhande; read on hande. hande, or falsetè upon her putte, your owne malicious trayson with suche thinge to excuse. Lo! than han women non other 58. none. wreche in vengeaunce, but †blobere and wepe til hem list stint, 59. bloder; read blobere. and sorily her mishap complayne; and is put in-to wening that al men ben so untrewe. How often have men chaunged her 61. Howe. loves in a litel whyle, or els, for fayling their wil, in their places hem set! For fren[d]ship shal be oon, and fame with another 63. sette. frenship (sic). one. him list for to have, and a thirde for delyt; or els were he lost 64. lyste. delyte. bothe in packe and in clothes! Is this fair? Nay, god wot. 65. faire. I may nat telle, by thousande partes, the wronges in trechery 66. maye. tel. of suche false people; for make they never so good a bond, 67. bonde. al sette ye at a myte whan your hert tourneth. And they that wenen for sorowe of you deye, the pitè of your false herte is flowe 69. dey. out of towne. Alas! therfore, that ever any woman wolde take any wight in her grace, til she knowe, at the ful, on whom she might at al assayes truste! Women con no more craft in queynt 72. trust. crafte. knowinge, to understande the false disceyvable conjectementes of mannes begylinges. Lo! how it fareth; though ye men 74. howe. gronen and cryen, certes, it is but disceyt; and that preveth wel by th'endes in your werkinge. How many women have ben 76. thendes. Howe. lorn, and with shame foule shent by long-lastinge tyme, whiche 77. lorne. longe-. thorow mennes gyle have ben disceyved? Ever their fame shal 78. thorowe. dure, and their dedes [ben] rad and songe in many londes; that 79. I supply ben. radde. they han don, recoveren shal they never; but alway ben demed 80. done. lightly, in suche plyte a-yen shulde they falle. Of whiche slaunders 81. fal. and tenes ye false men and wicked ben the verey causes; on you by right ought these shames and these reproves al hoolly discende. 83. holy.
Thus arn ye al nighe untrewe; for al your fayre speche, your 84. arne. herte is ful fickel. What cause han ye women to dispyse? Better fruite than they ben, ne swetter spyces to your behove, mowe ye not fynde, as far as worldly bodyes strecchen. Loke to their 87. farre. stretchen. forminge, at the making of their persones by god in joye of paradyce! For goodnesse, of mans propre body were they maked, after the sawes of the bible, rehersing goddes wordes in this wyse: "It is good to mankynde that we make to him an helper." Lo! in paradyse, for your helpe, was this tree graffed, out of whiche al linage of man discendeth. If a man be noble frute, of noble frute it is sprongen; the blisse of paradyse, to mennes sory hertes, yet in this tree abydeth. O! noble helpes ben these trees, and gentil jewel to ben worshipped of every good creature! He that hem anoyeth doth his owne shame; it is 97. dothe. a comfortable perle ayenst al tenes. Every company is mirthed by their present being. Trewly, I wiste never vertue, but a woman 99. wyst. were therof the rote. What is heven the worse though Sarazins on it lyen? Is your fayth untrewe, though †renegates maken 101. faythe. thoughe rennogates. theron lesinges? If the fyr doth any wight brenne, blame his 102. leasynges. fyre (four times) owne wit that put him-selfe so far in the hete. Is not fyr gen∣tillest 103. wytte. farre. heate. and most comfortable element amonges al other? Fyr 104. element comfortable; read comfortable element. is cheef werker in fortheringe sustenaunce to mankynde. Shal 105. chefe. fyr ben blamed for it brende a foole naturelly, by his own stulty witte in steringe? Ah! wicked folkes! For your propre malice and shreudnesse of your-selfe, ye blame and dispyse the precious∣[es]t 108. precioust. thing of your kynde, and whiche thinges among other 109. amonge. moste ye desyren! Trewly, Nero and his children ben shrewes, that dispysen so their dames. The wickednesse and gyling of men, in disclaundring of thilke that most hath hem glad[d]ed 104,112. moste. and plesed, were impossible to wryte or to nempne. Never-the-later 112-3. gladed and pleased. yet I say, he that knoweth a way may it lightly passe; eke an herbe proved may safely to smertande sores ben layd. So 115. layde. I say, in him that is proved is nothing suche yvels to gesse. But these thinges have I rehersed, to warne you women al at ones, that to lightly, without good assaye, ye assenten not to mannes speche. The sonne in the day-light is to knowen from the moone that shyneth in the night. Now to thee thy-selfe 120. Nowe. the.
(quod she) as I have ofte sayd, I knowe wel thyne herte; thou art noon of al the tofore-nempned people. For I knowe wel the 122. arte none. continuaunce of thy service, that never sithen I sette thee 123. set the. a-werke, might thy Margaryte for plesaunce, frendship, ne fayrhede 124. frendeshyp. fayrehede. of none other, be in poynte moved from thyne herte; wherfore in-to myne housholde hastely I wol that thou entre, and al the parfit privitè of my werking, make it be knowe in thy understond∣ing, 127. parfyte. as oon of my privy familiers. Thou desyrest (quod she) 128. one. fayn to here of tho thinges there I lefte?' 129. fayne.
'Ye, forsothe,' quod I, 'that were to me a greet blisse.' 130. great.
'Now,' quod she, 'for thou shalt not wene that womans con∣dicions 131. Nowe. for fayre speche suche thing belongeth:—

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER IV.
DIV3.P: THOU shalt,' quod she, 'understonde' first among al other CH. IV. 1. shalte. amonge. thinges, that al the cure of my service to me in the parfit 2. parfyte. blisse in doing is desyred in every mannes herte, be he never so moche a wrecche; but every man travayleth by dyvers studye, 4. wretche. and seke[th] thilke blisse by dyvers wayes. But al the endes 5. seke; read seketh. are knit in selinesse of desyre in the parfit blisse, that is suche 6. parfyte. joye, whan men it have gotten, there †leveth no thing more to 7. lyueth; read leveth. thynge. ben coveyted. But how that desyre of suche perfeccion in 8. howe. perfection. my service be kindely set in lovers hertes, yet her erroneous 9. erronyous. opinions misturne it by falsenesse of wening. And although mannes understanding be misturned, to knowe whiche shuld ben the way unto my person, and whither it abydeth; yet wote they there is a love in every wight, [whiche] weneth by that thing that 13. I supply whiche. he coveyteth most, he shulde come to thilke love; and that 14. moste. is parfit blisse of my servauntes; but than fulle blisse may not 15. parfyte. maye. be, and there lacke any thing of that blisse in any syde. Eke it 16. thynge. foloweth than, that he that must have ful blisse lacke no blisse in love on no syde.'

'Therfore, lady,' quod I tho, 'thilke' blisse I have desyred, and †soghte toforn this my-selfe, by wayes of riches, of dignitè, 20. sothe; read soghte. toforne.
of power, and of renomè, wening me in tho †thinges had ben 21. thrages (sic); read thinges. thilke blisse; but ayenst the heer it turneth. Whan I supposed 22. heere. beste thilke blisse have †getten, and come to the ful purpose 23. get; read getten. of your service, sodaynly was I hindred, and throwen so fer abacke, that me thinketh an inpossible to come there I lefte.'

'I †wot wel,' quod she; 'and therfore hast thou fayled; for 26. wol; read wot. thou wentest not by the hye way. A litel misgoing in the ginning causeth mikil errour in the ende; wherfore of thilke blisse thou fayledest, for having of richesse; ne non of the other thinges thou nempnedest mowen nat make suche parfit blisse in love as I shal 30. parfite. shewe. Therfore they be nat worthy to thilke blisse; and yet somwhat must ben cause and way to thilke blisse. Ergo, there is som suche thing, and som way, but it is litel in usage and that 33. some (twice). is nat openly y-knowe. But what felest in thyne hert of the service, in whiche by me thou art entred? Wenest aught thy∣selfe yet be in the hye way to my blisse? I shal so shewe it to thee, thou shalt not conne saye the contrary.' 37. the. shalte. con.
'Good lady,' quod I, 'altho I suppose it in my herte, yet wolde I here thyn wordes, how ye menen in this mater.' 39. howe ye meanen.

Quod she, 'that I shal, with my good wil. Thilke blisse desyred, som-del ye knowen, altho it be nat parfitly. For kyndly 41. some deale. entencion ledeth you therto, but in three maner livinges is al suche 42. entention. thre. lyuenges. wayes shewed. Every wight in this world, to have this blisse, oon 43. one. of thilke three wayes of lyves must procede; whiche, after opinions 44. thre. of grete clerkes, are by names cleped bestiallich, resonablich, [and 45. great. cleaped. I supply and manlich. Resonablich. manlich. Resonablich] is vertuous. Manlich is worldlich. Bestial∣liche is lustes and delytable, nothing restrayned by bridel of reson. 47. nothynge. Al that joyeth and yeveth gladnesse to the hert, and it be ayenst reson, is lykened to bestial living, which thing foloweth lustes and 47-9. reason (twice). 49. lyueng. thynge. delytes; wherfore in suche thinge may nat that precious blisse, 50. maye. that is maister of al vertues, abyde. Your †faders toforn you have 51. fathers. toforne. cleped such lusty livinges after the flessh "passions of desyre," 52. lyuenges. which are innominable tofore god and man both. Than, after determinacion of suche wyse, we accorden that suche passions of 54. determination. desyre shul nat be nempned, but holden for absolute from al other livinges and provinges; and so †leveth in t[w]o livinges, manlich 56. lyuenges (twice). lyueth; read leveth. to; read two.
and resonable, to declare the maters begonne. But to make thee 57. the. fully have understanding in manlich livinges, whiche is holden 58. lyuenges. worldlich in these thinges, so that ignorance be mad no letter, 59. made. I wol (quod she) nempne these forsayd wayes †by names and 60. be; read by. conclusions. First riches, dignitè, renomè, and power shul in this worke be cleped bodily goodes; for in hem hath ben, a gret 62. cleaped. throw, mannes trust of selinesse in love: as in riches, suffisance to have maintayned that was begonne by worldly catel; in dignitè, 64. begon. honour and reverence of hem that wern underput by maistry 65. werne. therby to obeye. In renomè, glorie of peoples praising, after 66. obey. lustes in their hert, without hede-taking to qualitè and maner of doing; and in power, by trouth of lordships mayntenaunce, thing to procede forth in doing. In al whiche thinges a longe tyme mannes coveytise in commune hath ben greetly grounded, to come 70. greatly. to the blisse of my service; but trewly, they were begyled, and for the principal muste nedes fayle, and in helping mowe nat availe. See why. For holdest him not poore that is nedy?' 73. Se.
'Yes, pardè,' quod I.
'And him for dishonored, that moche folk deyne nat to 75. folke. reverence?'
'That is soth,' quod I.
'And what him, that his mightes faylen and mowe nat helpen?'
'Certes,' quod I, 'me semeth, of al men he shulde be holden a wrecche.' 80. wretch.
'And wenest nat,' quod she, 'that he that is litel in renomè, but rather is out of the praysinges of mo men than a fewe, be nat in shame?'
'For soth,' quod I, 'it is shame and villany, to him that coveyteth renomè, that more folk nat prayse in name than preise.'

'Soth,' quod she, 'thou sayst soth; but al these thinges are folowed of suche maner doinge, and wenden in riches suffisaunce, in power might, in dignitè worship, and in renomè glorie; wherfore they discended in-to disceyvable wening, and in that service disceit 89. disceite. is folowed. And thus, in general, thou and al suche other that so worchen, faylen of my blisse that ye long han desyred. Wherfore truly, in lyfe of reson is the hye way to this blisse; as I thinke 92. reason. more openly to declare herafter. Never-the-later yet, in a litel to comforte thy herte, in shewing of what waye thou art entred thy∣selfe, 94. arte.
and that thy Margarite may knowe thee set in the hye way, I wol enforme thee in this wyse. Thou hast fayled of thy first 95-6. the (twice). purpos, bicause thou wentest wronge and leftest the hye way on thy right syde, as thus: thou lokedest on worldly living, and that 98. lyueng. thing thee begyled; and lightly therfore, as a litel assay, thou 99. the. songedest; but whan I turned thy purpos, and shewed thee 97-100. purpose. a part of the hye waye, tho thou abode therin, and no deth ne 101. parte. dethe. ferdnesse of non enemy might thee out of thilk way reve; but 100-2. the. ever oon in thyn herte, to come to the ilke blisse, whan thou 103. one. were arested and firste tyme enprisoned, thou were loth to chaunge thy way, for in thy hert thou wendest to have ben there thou shuldest. And for I had routhe to sene thee miscaried, 106. the. and wiste wel thyn ablenesse my service to forther and encrese, 107. wyst. thyne. encrease. I com my-selfe, without other mene, to visit thy person in comfort 108. come. mean. For person read prison? comforte. of thy hert. And perdy, in my comming thou were greetly 109. greatly gladed. glad[d]ed; after whiche tyme no disese, no care, no tene, might 110. disease. move me out of thy hert. And yet am I glad and greetly enpited, 111. gladde. greatly. how continually thou haddest me in mynde, with good avysement 112. howe. of thy conscience, whan thy king and his princes by huge wordes and grete loked after variaunce in thy speche; and ever thou 114. great. were redy for my sake, in plesaunce of the Margarite-perle and 115. peerle. many mo other, thy body to oblige in-to Marces doing, if any contraried thy sawes. Stedfast way maketh stedfast hert, with good hope in the ende. Trewly, I wol that thou it wel knowe; for I see thee so set, and not chaunginge herte haddest in my 119. se the. service; and I made thou haddest grace of thy kinge, in foryeve∣nesse of mikel misdede. To the gracious king art thou mikel 121. arte. holden, of whos grace and goodnesse somtyme hereafter I thinke 122. whose. thee enforme, whan I shew the ground where-as moral vertue 123. the. grounde. groweth. Who brought thee to werke? Who brought this grace 124. the. aboute? Who made thy hert hardy? Trewly, it was I. For haddest thou of me fayled, than of this purpos had[dest thou] 126. purpose. had; read haddest thou. I supply hede. never taken [hede] in this wyse. And therfore I say, thou might wel truste to come to thy blisse, sithen thy ginninge hath ben hard, 128. harde. but ever graciously after thy hertes desyr hath proceded. Silver 129. desyre. fyned with many hetes men knowen for trew; and safely men 130. heates.
may trust to the alay in werkinge. This †disese hath proved what 131. diseases (sic). waye. -forwarde. way hence-forward thou thinkest to holde.'
'Now, in good fayth, lady,' quod I tho, 'I am now in; me semeth, it is the hye way and the right.'

'Ye, forsothe,' quod she, 'and now I wol disprove thy first wayes, by whiche many men wenen to gette thilke blisse. But for-as-moche as every herte that hath caught ful love, is tyed with queynt knittinges, thou shalt understande that love and thilke foresayd blisse toforn declared in this[e] provinges, shal hote the 139. toforne. knot in the hert.'
'Wel,' quod I, 'this inpossession I wol wel understande.'

'Now also,' quod she, 'for the knotte in the herte muste ben 133-142. Nowe (four times). from one to an-other, and I knowe thy desyr, I wol thou under∣stande 143. desyre. these maters to ben sayd of thy-selfe, in disproving of thy first service, and in strengthinge of thilke that thou hast undertake 145. strenghthynge. haste. to thy Margaryte-perle.'
'A goddes halfe,' quod I, 'right wel I fele that al this case is possible and trewe; and therfore I †admitte it altogither.' 148. admytted; read admytte it.
'†Understand wel,' quod she, 'these termes, and loke no con∣tradiccion 149. Vnderstanden (sic). thou graunt.'

'If god wol,' quod I, 'of al these thinges wol I not fayle; and if I graunt contradiccion, I shulde graunte an impossible; and 149-152. contradyction (twice). that were a foul inconvenience; for whiche thinges, lady, y-wis, 153. foule. ladye. herafter I thinke me to kepe.'

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER V.
DIV3.P:
'WEL,' quod she, 'thou knowest that every thing is a cause, CH. V. 1. thynge. wherthrough any thing hath being that is cleped "caused." 2. -throughe. Than, if richesse †causeth knot in herte, thilke richesse †is cause 3. causen; read causeth. arne; read is. of thilke precious thinge being. But after the sentence of Aristotle, every cause is more in dignitè than his thinge caused; wherthrough it foloweth richesse to ben more in dignitè than thilke knot. But richesses arn kyndely naughty, badde, and 7. arne. nedy; and thilke knotte is thing kyndely good, most praysed 8, 9. thynge (twice). moste. and desyred. Ergo, thing naughty, badde, and nedy in kyndely 9. thynge (twice). moste.
understandinge is more worthy than thing kyndely good, most 10. thynge. moste. desyred and praysed! The consequence is fals; nedes, the 11. false. antecedent mot ben of the same condicion. But that richesses 12. mote. ben bad, naughty, and nedy, that wol I prove; wherfore they mowe cause no suche thing that is so glorious and good. The more richesse thou hast, the more nede hast thou of helpe hem 15. haste. to kepe. Ergo, thou nedest in richesse, whiche nede thou shuldest not have, if thou hem wantest. Than muste richesse ben nedy, that in their having maken thee nedy to helpes, in 18. the. suretee thy richesse to kepen; wherthrough foloweth, richesse to 19. suretie. ben nedy. Everything causinge yvels is badde and naughty; but richesse in one causen misese, in another they mowen not evenly 21. misease. strecchen al about. Wherof cometh plee, debat, thefte, begylinges, 22. stretchen. debate. but richesse to winne; whiche thinges ben badde, and by richesse arn caused. Ergo, thilke richesse[s] ben badde; whiche badnesse 24. arne. richesse; read richesses. and nede ben knit in-to richesse by a maner of kyndely propertee; 25. propertie. and every cause and caused accorden; so that it foloweth, thilke richesse[s] to have the same accordaunce with badnesse and nede, that their cause asketh. Also, every thing hath his being by his cause; than, if the cause be distroyed, the being of caused is vanisshed. And, so, if richesse[s] causen love, and richesse[s] 27-30. richesse; read richesses (thrice). weren distroyed, the love shulde vanisshe; but thilke knotte, and it be trewe, may not vanisshe, for no going of richesse. Ergo, richesse is no cause of the knot. And many men, as I sayd, setten the cause of the knotte in richesse; thilke knitten the richesse, and nothing the yvel; thilke persons, what-ever they 35. nothynge. ben, wenen that riches is most worthy to be had; and that make they the cause; and so wene they thilke riches be better than the person. Commenly, suche asken rather after the quantitè than after the qualitè; and suche wenen, as wel by hem-selfe as by other, that conjunccion of his lyfe and of his soule is no more 40. coniunction. precious, but in as mikel as he hath of richesse. Alas! how may 41. howe maye. he holden suche thinges precious or noble, that neither han lyf ne 42. lyfe. soule, ne ordinaunce of werchinge limmes! Suche richesse[s] 43. richesse; read richesses. ben more worthy whan they ben in †gadering; in departing, ginneth his love of other mennes praysing. And avarice †gadering 44-5. gatheryng. maketh be hated, and nedy to many out-helpes; and whan leveth the possession of such goodes, and they ginne vanissh, than
entreth sorowe and tene in their hertes. O! badde and strayte ben thilke, that at their departinge maketh men teneful and sory, and in the †gadering of hem make men nedy! Moche folk at 50. gatheryng. folke. ones mowen not togider moche therof have. A good gest gladdeth his hoste and al his meyny; but he is a badde gest that maketh his hoste nedy and to be aferd of his gestes going.' 53. aferde.
'Certes,' quod I, 'me wondreth therfore that the comune opinion is thus: "He is worth no more than that he hath in 55. worthe. catel."'

'O!' quod she, 'loke thou be not of that opinion; for if gold or 57. golde. money, or other maner of riches shynen in thy sight, whos is that? 58. whose. Nat thyn. And tho[ugh] they have a litel beautee, they be nothing 59. beautie. in comparison of our kynde; and therfore, ye shulde nat sette 60. set. your worthinesse in thing lower than your-selfe. For the riches, the fairnesse, the worthinesse of thilke goodes, if ther be any suche preciousnesse in hem, are nat thyne; thou madest hem so never; from other they come to thee, and to other they shul from thee. Wherfore enbracest thou other wightes good, as 64-5. the (twice). tho[ugh] they were thyn? Kynde hath drawe hem by hem-selfe. It is sothe, the goodes of the erth ben ordayned in your fode and norisshinge; but if thou wolt holde thee apayd with that 68. wolte. the apayde. suffyseth to thy kynde, thou shalt nat be in daunger of no suche riches; to kynde suffyseth litel thing, who that taketh hede. And if thou wolt algates with superfluitè of riches be a-throted, thou shalt hastelich be anoyed, or els yvel at ese. And fairnesse 72. ease. of feldes ne of habitacions, ne multitude of meynè, may nat be 73. maye. rekened as riches that are thyn owne. For if they be badde, it is greet sclaunder and villany to the occupyer; and if they be good 75. great. or faire, the mater of the workman that hem made is to prayse. 76. workeman. How shulde other-wyse bountee be compted for thyne? Thilke 77. Howe. bountie. goodnesse and fairnesse be proper to tho thinges hem-selfe; than, if they be nat thyne, sorow nat whan they wende, ne glad thee 79. the. nat in pompe and in pride whan thou hem hast. For their bountee and their beautees cometh out of their owne kynde, and 81. bountie. beautes. nat of thyne owne person. As faire ben they in their not having as whan thou hast hem. They be nat faire for thou hast hem; but thou hast geten hem for the fairnesse of them-selfe. And 83-4. haste (thrice). there the vaylance of men is demed in richesse outforth, wenen
me[n] to have no proper good in them-selfe, but seche it in 86. me; read men. straunge thinges. Trewly, the condicion of good wening is to 87. condytion. thee mistourned, to wene, your noblesse be not in your-selfe, but 88. the. in the goodes and beautee of other thinges. Pardy, the beestes 89. beautie. that han but feling soules, have suffisaunce in their owne selfe; and ye, that ben lyke to god, seken encrese of suffisaunce from so 91. encrease. excellent a kynde of so lowe thinges; ye do greet wrong to him 92. great. that you made lordes over al erthly thinges; and ye putte your worthinesse under the nombre of the fete of lower thinges and foule. Whan ye juge thilke riches to be your worthinesse, than putte ye your-selfe, by estimacion, under thilke foule thinges; 93-6. put (twice). and than leve ye the knowing of your-selfe; so be ye viler than any dombe beest; that cometh of shrewde vice. Right so thilke persons that loven non yvel for dereworthinesse of the persone, but for straunge goodes, and saith, the adornement in the knot lyth in such thing; his errour is perilous and shrewd, and he 101. shreude. wryeth moche venim with moche welth; and that knot may 102. maye. nat be good whan he hath it getten.

Certes, thus hath riches with flickering sight anoyed many; and often, whan there is a throw-out shrewe, he coyneth al the 105. throwe out. gold, al the precious stones that mowen be founden, to have in 106. golde. his bandon; he weneth no wight be worthy to have suche thinges but he alone. How many hast thou knowe, now in late tyme, 108. Howe. haste. that in their richesse supposed suffisance have folowed, and now 108-9. nowe. it is al fayled!'
'Ye, lady,' quod I, 'that is for mis medling; and otherwyse 111. misse medlyng. governed [they] thilke richesse than they shulde.' 112. Supply they.

'Ye,' quod she tho, 'had not the flood greetly areysed, and 113. floode greatly. throwe to-hemward both gravel and sand, he had mad no med∣linge. 114. hemwarde. sande. made. And right as see yeveth flood, so draweth see ebbe, and 115. floode. pulleth ayen under wawe al the firste out-throwe, but-if good pyles 116. out throw. of noble governaunce in love, in wel-meninge maner, ben sadly 117. meanynge. grounded; †the whiche holde thilke gravel as for a tyme, that 118. to; read the. ayen lightly mowe not it turne; and if the pyles ben trewe, the gravel and sand wol abyde. And certes, ful warning in love shalt 120. sande. thou never thorow hem get ne cover, that lightly with an ebbe, er 121. shalte. thorowe.
thou be ware, it [ne] wol ayen meve. In richesse many men 122. beware. I supply ne. have had tenes and diseses, whiche they shulde not have had, if 123. diseases. therof they had fayled. Thorow whiche, now declared, partly it is 124. Thorowe. nowe. partely. shewed, that for richesse shulde the knotte in herte neither ben caused in one ne in other; trewly, knotte may ben knit, and 126. maye. knytte. I trowe more stedfast, in love, though richesse fayled; and els, in richesse is the knotte, and not in herte. And than suche a knotte is fals; whan the see ebbeth and withdraweth the 129. false. gravel, that such richesse voydeth, thilke knotte wol unknitte. Wherfore no trust, no way, no cause, no parfit being is in 131. parfyte. richesse, of no suche knotte. Therfore another way muste we have.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER VI.
DIV3.P: HONOUR in dignitè is wened to yeven a ful knot.'

'Ye, certes,' quod I, 'and of that opinion ben many; for they sayn, dignitè, with honour and reverence, causen hertes CH. VI. 3. sayne. to encheynen, and so abled to be knit togither, for the excellence 4. knytte. in soverayntè of such degrees.'
