'Now,' quod she, 'if dignitè, honour, and reverence causen 6. Nowe. thilke knotte in herte, this knot is good and profitable. For every cause of a cause is cause of thing caused. Than thus: good thinges and profitable ben by dignitè, honour, and rever∣ence caused. Ergo, they accorden; and dignites ben good with reverences and honour. But contraries mowen not accorden. Wherfore, by reson, there shulde no dignitee, no reverence, non 12. reason. none. honour acorde with shrewes. But that is fals; they have ben 13. false. cause to shrewes in many shreudnes; for with hem they accorden.

Ergo, from beginning to argue ayenward til it come to the laste 15. ayenwarde. conclusion, they are not cause of the knot. Lo, al day at eye arn 16. arne. shrewes not in reverence, in honour, and in dignitè? Yes, for∣sothe, rather than the good. Than foloweth it that shrewes rather than good shul ben cause of this knot. But of this [the] 19. Supply the. contrarie of al lovers is bileved, and for a sothe openly de∣termined to holde.'
'Now,' quod I, 'fayn wolde I here, how suche dignitees acorden 22. Nowe. fayne. howe. with shrewes.'

'O,' quod she, 'that wol I shewe in manifolde wyse. Ye wene (quod she) that dignites of office here in your citè is as the sonne; it shyneth bright withouten any cloude; [of] whiche thing, 26. I supply of. thynge. whan they comen in the handes of malicious tirauntes, there cometh moche harm, and more grevaunce therof than of the 28. harme. wilde fyre, though it brende al a strete. Certes, in dignitè of office, the werkes of the occupyer shewen the malice and the badnesse in the person; with shrewes they maken manyfolde harmes, and moche people shamen. How often han rancours, 32. Howe. for malice of the governour, shulde ben mainteyned? Hath not than suche dignitees caused debat, rumours, and yvels? Yes, 34. debate. god wot, by suche thinges have ben trusted to make mens under∣standing 35. wote. enclyne to many queynte thinges. Thou wottest wel what I mene.' 37. meane.
'Ye,' quod I, 'therfore, as dignitè suche thing in tene y-wrought, so ayenward, the substaunce in dignitè chaunged, relyed to bring 39. ayenwarde. ayen good plyte in doing.'

'Do way, do way,' quod she; 'if it so betyde, but that is selde, that suche dignitè is betake in a good mannes governaunce, what thing is to recken in the dignitees goodnesse? Pardè, the bountee and goodnesse is hers that usen it in good governaunce; 44. bountie. and therfore cometh it that honour and reverence shulde ben 45. honoure. don to dignitè bycause of encresinge vertue in the occupyer, 46. done. encreasynge. and not to the ruler bycause of soverayntee in dignitè. Sithen 47. soverayntie. dignitè may no vertue cause, who is worthy worship for suche goodnesse? Not dignitè, but person, that maketh goodnesse in dignitè to shyne.'

'This is wonder thing,' quod I; 'for me thinketh, as the person in dignitè is worthy honour for goodnesse, so, tho[ugh] a person for badnesse ma[u]gree hath deserved, yet the dignitè leneth to 53. magre. be commended.'

'Let be,' quod she, 'thou errest right foule; dignitè with badnesse is helper to performe the felonous doing. Pardy, were it kyndly good, or any propertè of kyndly vertue [that men] 57. Supply that. men and it. hadden in hem-selfe, shrewes shulde hem never have; with hem shulde they never accorde. Water and fyr, that ben contrarious, 59. fire.
mowen nat togider ben assembled; kynde wol nat suffre suche contraries to joyne. And sithen at eye, by experience in doing, 61. ioyn. we seen that shrewes have hem more often than good men, siker 62. sene. menne. mayst thou be, that kyndly good in suche thing is nat appropred. 63. mayste. Pardy, were they kyndly good, as wel oon as other shulden evenlich in vertue of governaunce ben worthe; but oon fayleth in 64-5. one (twice). goodnesse, another doth the contrary; and so it sheweth, kyndly 66. dothe. goodnesse in dignitè nat be grounded. And this same reson (quod she) may be mad, in general, on al the bodily goodes; 68. made. for they comen ofte to throw-out shrewes. After this, he is 69. throwe out. strong that hath might to have grete burthens, and he is light 70. great burthyns. and swifte, that hath soveraintè in ronning to passe other; right so he is a shrewe, on whom shreude thinges and badde han most werchinge. And right as philosophy maketh philosophers, and my service maketh lovers, right so, if dignites weren good or vertuous, they shulde maken shrewes good, and turne her malice, and make hem be vertuous. But that they do nat, as it is proved, but causen rancour and debat. Ergo, they be nat good, 77. debate. but utterly badde. Had Nero never ben Emperour, shulde never his dame have be slayn, to maken open the privitè of his engendrure. Herodes, for his dignitè, slew many children. The 80. slewe. dignitè of king John wolde have distroyed al England. Therfore 81. Englande. mokel wysdom and goodnesse both, nedeth in a person, the 82. wysedom. malice in dignitè slyly to brydel, and with a good bitte of arest to withdrawe, in case it wolde praunce otherwyse than it shulde. Trewly, ye yeve to dignites wrongful names in your cleping. They shulde hete, nat dignitè, but moustre of badnesse and mayntenour of shrewes. Pardy, shyne the sonne never so bright, and it bringe forth no hete, ne sesonably the herbes out-bringe of 88. bring forthe. heate. the erthe, but suffre frostes and cold, and the erthe barayne to 89. colde. ligge by tyme of his compas in circute about, ye wolde wonder, and dispreyse that sonne! If the mone be at ful, and sheweth 91. son. no light, but derke and dimme to your sight appereth, and make distruccion of the waters, wol ye nat suppose it be under cloude 93. distruction or in clips, and that som prevy thing, unknowen to your wittes, 94. some. is cause of suche contrarious doinge? Than, if clerkes, that han ful insight and knowing of suche impedimentes, enforme you of
the sothe, very idiottes ye ben, but-if ye yeven credence to thilk clerkes wordes. And yet it doth me tene, to sene many wrecches 98. wretches. rejoycen in such maner planettes. Trewly, litel con[ne] they on 99. con; read conne. philosophy, or els on my lore, that any desyr haven suche 100. desyre. lightinge planettes in that wyse any more to shewe.'

'Good lady,' quod I, 'tel me how ye mene in these thinges.' 102. howe. mean. 'Lo,' quod she, 'the dignites of your citè, sonne and mone, nothing in kynde shew their shyning as they shulde. For the sonne made no brenning hete in love, but freesed envye in mennes hertes, for feblenesse of shyning hete; and the moone was about, under an olde cloude, the livinges by waters to 107. lyuenges. distroye.'
'Lady,' quod I, 'it is supposed they had shyned as they shulde.'

'Ye,' quod she, 'but now it is proved at the ful, their beautè in 111. nowe. kyndly shyning fayled; wherfore dignitè of him-selven hath no beautee in fayrnesse, ne dryveth nat awaye vices, but encreseth; 113. beautie. encreaseth. and so be they no cause of the knotte. Now see, in good trouth; 114. Nowe se. holde ye nat such sonnes worthy of no reverence, and dignites worthy of no worship, that maketh men to do the more harmes?'
'I not,' quod I.
'No?' quod she; 'and thou see a wyse good man, for his 118. se. goodnesse and wysnesse wolt thou nat do him worship? Therof 119. wysenesse wolte. he is worthy.'
'That is good skil,' quod I; 'it is dewe to suche, both rever∣ence and worship to have.'

'Than,' quod she, 'a shrewe, for his shreudnesse, altho he be put forth toforn other for ferde, yet is he worthy, for shrewdnesse, 124. forthe toforne. to be unworshipped; of reverence no part is he worthy to have, 125. parte. [that] to contrarious doing belongeth: and that is good skil. 126. I supply that. For right as he besmyteth the dignites, thilke same thing ayen∣ward 127. ayenwarde. him smyteth, or els shulde smyte. And over this thou wost 128. woste. wel (quod she) that fyr in every place heteth where it be, and 129. fyre. heateth. water maketh wete. Why? For kyndely werking is so y-put in hem, to do suche thinges; for every kyndely in werking sheweth his kynde. But though a wight had ben mayre of your city 132. cytie. many winter togider, and come in a straunge place there he were
not knowen, he shulde for his dignitè have no reverence. Than neither worshippe ne reverence is kyndely propre in no dignitè, sithen they shulden don their kynde in suche doinge, if any were. And if reverence ne worshippe kyndely be not set in dignitees, and they more therein ben shewed than goodnesse, for that in dignitè is shewed, but it proveth that goodnesse kyndely in hem is not grounded. I-wis, neither worshippe, ne reverence, ne good∣nesse in dignitè don non office of kynde; for they have non 141. done none. none. suche propertee in nature of doinge but by false opinion of the 142. propertie. people. Lo! how somtyme thilke that in your city wern in 143. howe. cytie werne. dignitè noble, if thou liste hem nempne, they ben now over∣turned 144. nowe. bothe in worship, in name, and in reverence; wherfore such dignites have no kyndly werching of worshippe and of reverence. He that hath no worthinesse on it-selfe, now it ryseth 147. For He read That thing? and now it vanissheth, after the variaunt opinion in false hertes 147-8. nowe (twice). of unstable people. Wherfore, if thou desyre the knotte of this jewel, or els if unstable people. Wherfore, if thou desyre the knotte of this jewel, or els if thou woldest suppose she shulde sette the knotte on thee for suche maner dignitè, than thou wenest beautee or 151. the. beautie. goodnesse of thilke somwhat encreseth the goodnesse or vertue in 152. encreaseth. the body. But dignite[es] of hemself ben not good, ne yeven 153. dignite; read dignitees. reverence ne worshippe by their owne kynde. How shulde they 154. howe. than yeve to any other a thing, that by no waye mowe they have 155. thynge. hem-selfe? It is sene in dignitè of the emperour and of many mo other, that they mowe not of hem-selve kepe their worshippe ne their reverence; that, in a litel whyle, it is now up and now 158. that that; read that. nowe (twice). downe, by unstedfaste hertes of the people. What bountee mowe 159. bountie. they yeve that, with cloude, lightly leveth his shyninge? Certes, 160. leaueth. to the occupyer is mokel appeyred, sithen suche doinge doth 161. dothe. villanye to him that may it not mayntayne. Wherfore thilke way 162. maye. waye. to the knotte is croked; and if any desyre to come to the knot, he must leve this way on his lefte syde, or els shal he never come 164. leaue. waye. there.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER VII.
DIV3.P: AVAYLETH aught (quod she) power of might in maynten∣aunce of [men, to maken hem] worthy to come to this CH. VII. 2. I supply men, to maken hem. knot?'
'Pardè,' quod I, 'ye; for hertes ben ravisshed from suche maner thinges.'

'Certes,' quod she, 'though a fooles herte is with thing ravisshed, yet therfore is no general cause of the powers, ne of a siker parfit herte to be loked after. Was not Nero the moste 8. parfyte. shrewe oon of thilke that men rede, and yet had he power to 9. one. make senatours justices, and princes of many landes? Was not that greet power?' 11. great.
'Yes, certes,' quod I.

'Wel,' quod she, 'yet might he not helpe him-selfe out of disese, whan he gan falle. How many ensamples canst thou 14. disease. fal. Howe. canste. remembre of kinges grete and noble, and huge power †helden, and 15. great. holden; yet they might not kepe hem-selve from wrecchednesse? How wrecched was king Henry Curtmantil er he deyde? He had not so moche as to cover with his membres; and yet was he oon 18. one. of the grettest kinges of al the Normandes ofspring, and moste 19. greatest. possession had. O! a noble thing and clere is power, that is not 20. thynge. founden mighty to kepe him-selfe! Now, trewly, a greet fole is 21. Nowe. great. he, that for suche thing wolde sette the knotte in thyne herte! Also powr of rëalmes, is not thilke grettest power amonges the 23. greatest. worldly powers reckened? And if suche powers han wrecched∣nesse 24. wretchydnesse (several times); wretched (several times). in hem-selfe, it foloweth other powers of febler condicion to ben wrecched; and than, that wrecchednesse shulde be cause of suche a knotte! But every wight that hath reson wot wel that 27. reason wote. wrecchednesse by no way may ben cause of none suche knotte; wherfore suche power is no cause. That powers have wrecched∣nesse in hem-selfe, may right lightly ben preved. If power lacke on any syde, on that syde is no power; but no power is wrecched∣nesse; for al-be-it so the power of emperours or kinges, or els of their rëalmes (which is the power of the prince) strecchen 33. stretchen.
wyde and brode, yet besydes is ther mokel folk of whiche he 34. folke. hath no commaundement ne lordshippe; and there-as lacketh his power, his nonpower entreth, where-under springeth that maketh hem wrecches. No power is wrecchednesse and nothing els; but in this maner hath kinges more porcion of wrecchednesse than of power. Trewly, suche powers ben unmighty; for ever they ben in drede how thilke power from lesing may be keped 40. howe. of sorow; so drede sorily prikkes ever in their hertes: litel 41. prickes. is that power whiche careth and ferdeth it-serfe to mayntayne. Unmighty is that wrecchednesse whiche is entred by the ferdful weninge of the wrecche him-selfe; and knot y-maked by wrecched∣nesse is betwene wrecches; and wrecches al thing bewaylen; wherfore the knot shulde be bewayled; and there is no suche parfit blisse that we supposed at the ginning! Ergo, power in 47. parfyte. nothing shulde cause suche knottes. Wrecchednesse is a kyndely propertee in suche power, as by way of drede, whiche they mowe 49. propertie. nat eschewe, ne by no way live in sikernesse. For thou wost wel 50. woste. (quod she) he is nought mighty that wolde don that he may not don ne perfourme.'

'Therfore,' quod I, 'these kinges and lordes that han suffi∣saunce at the ful of men and other thinges, mowen wel ben holden mighty; their comaundementes ben don; it is nevermore 51-5. done (thrice). denyed.'
'Foole,' quod she, 'or he wot him-selfe mighty, or wot it not; for he is nought mighty that is blynde of his might and wot it not.'
'That is sothe,' quod I.

'Than if he wot it, he must nedes ben a-drad to lesen it. He 61. a dradde. that wot of his might is in doute that he mote nedes lese; and so 57-62. wotte (four times). ledeth him drede to ben unmighty. And if he recche not to lese, 63. leadeth. retche. litel is that worth that of the lesing reson reccheth nothing; and 64. worthe. reason retcheth. if it were mighty in power or in strength, the lesing shulde ben withset; and whan it cometh to the lesing, he may it not with∣sitte. Ergo, thilke might is leude and naughty. Such mightes arn y-lyke to postes and pillers that upright stonden, and greet 68. arne. great. might han to bere many charges; and if they croke on any syde, 69. beare. litel thing maketh hem overthrowe.' 70. thynge.

'This is a good ensample,' quod I, 'to pillers and postes that
I have seen overthrowed my-selfe; and hadden they ben under∣put 72. sene. with any helpes, they had not so lightly falle.' 73. fal.

'Than holdest thou him mighty that hath many men armed and many servauntes; and ever he is adrad of hem in his herte; 75. adradde. and, for he gasteth hem, somtyme he mot the more fere have. 76. mote. feare. Comenly, he that other agasteth, other in him ayenward werchen 77. ayen∣warde. the same; and thus warnisshed mot he be, and of warnisshe the 78. mote. hour drede. Litel is that might and right leude, who-so taketh hede.'

'Than semeth it,' quod I, 'that suche famulers aboute kinges and grete lordes shulde greet might have. Although a sypher in 82. great (twice). Althoughe. augrim have no might in significacion of it-selve, yet he yeveth power in significacion to other; and these clepe I the helpes to a poste to kepe him from falling.'
'Certes,' quod she, 'thilke skilles ben leude. Why? But-if the shorers be wel grounded, the helpes shulden slyden and suffre the charge to falle; her might litel avayleth.' 88. fal.

'And so me thinketh,' quod I, 'that a poste alone, stonding upright upon a basse, may lenger in greet burthen endure than 90. graet (sic). croken pilers for al their helpes, and her ground be not siker.' 91. grounde.

'That is sothe,' quod she; 'for as, [if] the blynde in bering of 92. Supply if. bearyng. the lame ginne stomble, bothe shulde falle, right so suche pillers, 93. fal. so envyroned with helpes, in falling of the grounde fayleth †al∣togider. 94. al togyther. How ofte than suche famulers, in their moste pryde 95. howe. of prosperitè, ben sodainly overthrowen! Thou hast knowe 96. haste. many in a moment so ferre overthrowe, that cover might they never. Whan the hevinesse of suche fayling cometh by case of fortune, they mowe it not eschue; and might and power, if ther were any, shulde of strength such thinges voyde and weyve; and so it is not. Lo, than! whiche thing is this power, that, tho men han it, they ben agast; and in no tyme of ful having be they siker! And if they wold weyve drede, as they mow not, litel is in worthines. Fye therfore on so naughty thing, any knot to cause! Lo! in adversitè, thilk ben his foes that glosed and semed frendes in welth; thus arn his familiers his foes and his enemyes; and nothing is werse, ne more mighty for to anoy than is a familier enemy; and these thinges may they not weyve; so 108. enemye.
trewly their might is not worth a cresse. And over al thinge, he 109. worthe. that may not withdrawe the brydel of his flesshly lustes and his wrecched complayntes (now think on thy-selfe) trewly he is not 111. wretched. nowe thynke. mighty; I can seen no way that lyth to the knotte. Thilke 112. sene. waye. lythe. people than, that setten their hertes upon suche mightes and powers, often ben begyled. Pardè, he is not mighty that may do any thing, that another may doon him the selve, and that men 115. maye doone. have as greet power over him as he over other. A justice that 116. great. demeth men ayenward hath ben often demed. Buserus slew his 117. ayenwarde. slewe. gestes, and he was slayn of Hercules his geste. Hugest betrays∣shed 118. slayne. many men, and of Collo was he betrayed. He that with swerde smyteth, with swerde shal be smitten.'
Than gan I to studyen a whyle on these thinges, and made a countenaunce with my hande in maner to ben huisht. 122. huyshte.
'Now let seen,' quod she, 'me thinketh somwhat there is 123. Nowe. sene. within thy soule, that troubleth thy understanding; saye on what it is.'
Quod I tho, 'me thinketh that, although a man by power have suche might over me, as I have over another, that disproveth no might in my person; but yet may I have power and might never-the-later.'

'See now,' quod she, 'thyne owne leudenesse. He is mighty 130. Se nowe. that may without wrecchednesse; and he is unmighty that may it 131. maye. wretchydnesse. not withsitte; but than he, that might over thee, and he wol, 132. the. putte on thee wrecchednesse, thou might it not withsitte. Ergo, 133. put. the wretchydnesse. thou seest thy-selfe what foloweth! But now (quod she) woldest 134. nowe. thou not skorne, and thou see a flye han power to don harm to 135. se. done harme. an-other flye, and thilke have no might ne ayenturning him-selfe to defende?'
'Yes, certes,' quod I.

'Who is a frayler thing,' quod she, 'than the fleshly body of a man, over whiche have oftentyme flyes, and yet lasse thing than a flye, mokel might in grevaunce and anoying, withouten any 141. anoyeng. withsittinge, for al thilke mannes mightes? And sithen thou seest thyne flesshly body in kyndely power fayle, how shulde than 143. howe. the accident of a thinge ben in more suretè of beinge than sub∣stancial? Wherfore, thilke thinges that we clepe power is but
accident to the flesshly body; and so they may not have that suretee in might, whiche wanteth in the substancial body. Why 147. suretie. there is no way to the knotte, [for him] that loketh aright after the 148. waye. Supply for him. hye way, as he shulde. 149. waye.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER VIII.
DIV3.P: VERILY it is proved that richesse, dignitè, and power ben not trewe way to the knotte, but as rathe by suche thinges the CH. VIII. 2. waye. knotte to be unbounde; wherfore on these thinges I rede no wight truste to gette any good knotte. But what shul we saye of renomè in the peoples mouthes? Shulde that ben any cause? What supposest thou in thyn herte?'
'Certes,' quod I, 'yes, I trowe; for your slye resons I dare not safely it saye.'
'Than,' quod she, 'wol I preve that shrewes as rathe shul ben in the knotte as the good; and that were ayenst kynde.'

'Fayn,' quod I, 'wolde I that here; me thinketh wonder how 11. Fayne. howe. renomè shuld as wel knitte a shrewe as a good person; renomè in every degree hath avaunced; yet wist I never the contrarye. Shulde than renomè accorde with a shrewe? It may not sinke in 14. maye. my stomake til I here more.'
'Now,' quod she, 'have I not sayd alwayes, that shrewes shul 16. Nowe. not have the knotte?'
'What nedeth,' quod I, 'to reherse that any more? I wot wel 18. wotte. every wight, by kyndely reson, shrewes in knitting wol eschewe.' 19. reason.
'Than,' quod she, 'the good ought thilke knotte to have.'
'How els?' quod I. 21. Howe.
'It were greet harm,' quod she, 'that the good were weyved 22. great harme. and put out of espoire of the knotte, if he it desyred.'
'O,' quod I, 'alas! On suche thing to thinke, I wene that heven wepeth to see suche wronges here ben suffred on erthe; the 25. se. good ought it to have, and no wight els.'
'The goodnesse,' quod she, 'of a person may not ben knowe outforth but by renomè of the knowers; wherfore he must be renomed of goodnesse, to come to the knot.'
'So must it be,' quod I, 'or els al lost that we carpen.'

'Sothly,' quod she, 'that were greet harm, but-if a good man 31. great harme. might have his desyres in service of thilke knot, and a shrewe to be †weyved, and they ben not knowen in general but by lacking 33. veyned; read weyued. and praysing, and in renomè; and so by the consequence it foloweth, a shrewe to ben praysed and knit; and a good to be forsake and unknit.'

'Ah,' quod I tho, 'have ye, lady, ben here abouten; yet wolde I see, by grace of our argumentes better declared, how good and 38. se. howe. bad do acorden by lacking and praysing; me thinketh it ayenst kynde.'

'Nay,' quod she, 'and that shalt thou see as yerne; these 41. se. elementes han contrarious qualitees in kynde, by whiche they 42. qualyties. mowe not acorde no more than good and badde; and in [some] 43. I supply some. qualitees they acorde, so that contraries by qualitè acorden by qualitè. Is not erthe drye; and water, that is next and bitwene th'erthe, is wete? Drye and wete ben contrarie, and mowen not 46. therthe. acorde, and yet this discordaunce is bounde to acorde by cloudes; for bothe elementes ben colde. Right so the eyre, that is next the water, is wete; and eke it is hot. This eyre by his hete con∣trarieth 49. hotte. water that is cold; but thilke contrarioustè is oned †by 50. colde. contrariousty. my; read by. moysture; for bothe be they moyst. Also the fyr, that is next the †eyre and it encloseth al about, is drye, wherthrough it contrarieth †eyre, that is wete; and in hete they acorde; for bothe they ben hote. Thus by these acordaunces discordantes ben joyned, and in a maner of acordaunce they acorden by conneccion, that is, knitting togither; of that accorde cometh 56. connection. a maner of melodye that is right noble. Right so good and bad arn contrarie in doinges, by lacking and praysing; good is bothe 58. arne. lacked and praysed of some; and badde is bothe lacked and praysed of some; wherfore their contrarioustee acorde bothe by 60. contraryoustie. lacking and praysing. Than foloweth it, though good be never so mokel praysed, [it] oweth more to ben knit than the badde; 62. I supply it. or els bad, for the renomè that he hath, must be taken as wel as the good; and that oweth not.'
'No, forsothe,' quod I.

'Wel,' quod she, 'than is renomè no way to the knot. Lo, 66. waye. foole,' quod she, 'how clerkes wryten of suche glorie of renomè:— 67. howe.
"O glorie, glorie, thou art non other thing to thousandes of folke 68. arte none. thynge. but a greet sweller of eeres!" Many oon hath had ful greet renomè 69. great. one. great. by false opinion of variaunt people. And what is fouler than folk wrongfully to ben praysed, or by malice of the people giltlesse 71. folke. lacked? Nedes shame foloweth therof to hem that with wrong prayseth, and also to the desertes praysed; and vilanye and reproof of him that disclaundreth. 74. reprofe.

Good child (quod she) what echeth suche renomè to the 75. chylde. conscience of a wyse man, that loketh and mesureth his good∣nesse, 76. measureth. not by slevelesse wordes of the people, but by sothfastnesse of conscience? By god, nothing. And if it be fayr, a mans name 78. fayre. be eched by moche folkes praysing, and fouler thing that mo folk 79. folke. not praysen? I sayd to thee a litel here-beforn, that no folk in 80. the. beforne. folke. straunge countreyes nought praysen; suche renomè may not comen to their eeres, bycause of unknowing and other obstacles, as I sayde: wherfore more folk not praysen, and that is right foul 83. folke. foule. to him that renomè desyreth, to wete, lesse folk praisen than 84. folke. renomè enhaunce. I trowe, the thank of a people is naught 85. thanke. worth in remembraunce to take; ne it procedeth of no wyse 86. worthe. jugement; never is it stedfast pardurable. It is veyne and fleing; with winde wasteth and encreseth. Trewly, suche glorie ought to 88. encreaseth. be hated. If gentillesse be a cleer thing, renomè and glorie to 89. clere thynge. enhaunce, as in reckening of thy linage, than is gentilesse of thy kinne; for-why it semeth that gentilesse of thy kinne is but praysing and renomè that come of thyne auncestres desertes: and if so be that praysing and renomè of their desertes make their clere gentillesse, than mote they nedes ben gentil for their gentil dedes, and not thou; for of thy-selfe cometh not such maner gentilesse, praysinge of thy desertes. Than gentillesse of thyne auncesters, that forayne is to thee, maketh thee not gentil, but ungentil and reproved, and-if thou continuest not their gentilesse. And therfore a wyse man ones sayde: "Better is it thy kinne to ben by thee gentyled, than thou to glorifye of thy 97-100. the (thrice). kinnes gentilesse, and hast no desert therof thy-selfe." 101. haste. deserte.

How passinge is the beautee of flesshly bodyes, more flittinge 102. Howe. beautie. than movable floures of sommer! And if thyne eyen weren as good as the lynx, that may seen thorow many stone walles, bothe fayre 104. maye sene thorowe.
and foule, in their entrayles, of no maner hewe shulde apere to thy sight; that were a foule sight. Than is fayrnesse by feblesse 106. fayrenesse. of eyen, but of no kynde; wherfore thilke shulde be no way to the knot; whan thilke is went, the knotte wendeth after. Lo, now, at al proves, none of al these thinges mowe parfitly ben in understanding, to ben way to the during blisse of the knotte. 110. waye. But now, to conclusion of these maters, herkeneth these wordes. 109-111. nowe (twice). 111. nowe. Very sommer is knowe from the winter: in shorter cours draweth the dayes of Decembre than in the moneth of June; the springes of Maye faden and †falowen in Octobre. These thinges ben not unbounden from their olde kynde; they have not lost her werke 115. loste. of their propre estat. Men, of voluntarious wil, withsitte that 116. estate. hevens governeth. Other thinges suffren thinges paciently to werche; man, in what estat he be, yet wolde he ben chaunged. Thus by queynt thinges blisse is desyred; and the fruit that 119. fruite. cometh of these springes nis but anguis and bitter; al-though it be a whyle swete, it may not be with-holde; hastely they departe; 121. maye. thus al-day fayleth thinges that fooles wende. Right thus hast 122. al-daye. haste. thou fayled in thy first wening. He that thinketh to sayle, and drawe after the course of the sterre de polo antartico, shal he never come northward to the contrarye sterre of polus articus; of whiche 125. northwarde. thinges if thou take kepe, thy first out-waye-going "prison" and "exile" may be cleped. The ground falsed underneth, and so 127. grounde. hast thou fayled. No wight, I wene, blameth him that stinteth in misgoing, and secheth redy way of his blisse. Now me 129. Nowe. thinketh (quod she) that it suffyseth in my shewing; the wayes by dignetè, richesse, renomè, and power, if thou loke clerely, arn no wayes to the knotte.' 132. ways.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER IX.
DIV3.P:
'EVERY argument, lady,' quod I tho, 'that ye han maked in these fore-nempned maters, me thinketh hem in my ful witte conceyved; shal I no more, if god wil, in the contrarye be begyled. But fayn wolde I, and it were your wil, blisse of the CH. IX. 4. fayne. knotte to me were declared. I might fele the better how my 5. howe.
herte might assente, to pursue the ende in service, as he hath begonne.'

'O,' quod she, 'there is a melodye in heven, whiche clerkes clepen "armony"; but that is not in brekinge of voice, but it is a maner swete thing of kyndely werching, that causeth joye[s] 10. ioye; read joyes. out of nombre to recken, and that is joyned by reson and by wysdome in a quantitè of proporcion of knitting. God made al thing in reson and in witte of proporcion of melody, we mowe not 11-3. reason. suffyse to shewe. It is written by grete clerkes and wyse, that, 14. great. in erthly thinges, lightly by studye and by travayle the knowinge may be getten; but of suche hevenly melody, mokel travayle wol bringe out in knowing right litel. Swetenesse of this paradyse hath you ravisshed; it semeth ye slepten, rested from al other diseses; so kyndely is your herte therein y-grounded. Blisse of 19. diseases. hertes; read herte. two hertes, in ful love knitte, may not aright ben imagined; ever is their contemplacion, in ful of thoughty studye to plesaunce, mater in bringinge comfort everiche to other. And therfore, of 22. comforte. erthly thinges, mokel mater lightly cometh in your lerning. Knowledge of understonding, that is nigh after eye, but not so nigh the covetyse of knittinge in your hertes. More soverain 24-5. nyghe (twice). 25. soueraine desyre. desyr hath every wight in litel heringe of hevenly conninge than of mokel material purposes in erthe. Right so it is in propertee 27. propertie. of my servauntes, that they ben more affiched in steringe of litel thinge in his desyr than of mokel other mater lasse in his 29. desyre. conscience. This blisse is a maner of sowne delicious in a queynte voice touched, and no dinne of notes; there is non 31. none. impression of breking labour. I can it not otherwyse nempne, 32. breakynge laboure. canne. for wantinge of privy wordes, but paradyse terrestre ful of delicious melody, withouten travayle in sown, perpetual service in ful joye coveyted to endure. Only kynde maketh hertes in understonding 35. Onely. so to slepe, that otherwyse may it nat be nempned, ne in other maner names for lyking swetnesse can I nat it declare; al sugre and hony, al minstralsy and melody ben but soot and galle in 38. soote. comparison, by no maner proporcion to reken, in respect of this 39. respecte. blisful joye. This armony, this melody, this perdurable joye may nat be in doinge but betwene hevens and elementes, or twey kyndly hertes ful knit in trouth of naturel understonding, withouten weninge and disceit; as hevens and planettes, whiche thinges
continually, for kyndly accordaunces, foryeteth al contrarious mevinges, that in-to passive diseses may sowne; evermore it 45. diseases. thirsteth after more werking. These thinges in proporcion be so wel joyned, that it undoth al thing whiche in-to badnesse by any way may be accompted.'

'Certes,' quod I, 'this is a thing precious and noble. Alas! that falsnesse ever, or wantrust shulde ever be maynteyned, this joye to voyde. Alas! that ever any wrecche shulde, thorow wrath 51. wretch. thorowe. or envy, janglinge dare make, to shove this melody so farre a-backe, that openly dar it nat ben used; trewly, wrecches ben 53. dare. fulfilled with envy and wrathe, and no wight els. Flebring and tales in suche wrecches dare appere openly in every wightes 53-5. wretches. eere, with ful mouth so charged, [with] mokel malice moved 56. eare. I supply with. many innocentes to shende; god wolde their soule therwith were 57. innoctenes; misprint for innocentes. strangled! Lo! trouth in this blisse is hid, and over-al under covert him hydeth; he dar not come a-place, for waytinge of 59. dare. shrewes. Commenly, badnesse goodnesse amaistreth; with my∣selfe and my soule this joye wolde I bye, if the goodnesse were as moche as the nobley in melody.'
'O,' quod she, 'what goodnesse may be acompted more in this material worlde? Truly, non; that shalt thou understonde. Is nat every thing good that is contrariant and distroying yvel?' 65. distroyeng.
'How els?' quod I. 66. Howe.

'Envy, wrathe, and falsnesse ben general,' quod she; 'and that wot every man being in his right mynde; the knotte, the whiche we have in this blisse, is contrariaunt and distroyeth such maner yvels. Ergo, it is good. What hath caused any wight to don any good dede? Fynd me any good, but-if this knotte 71. Fynde. be the cheef cause. Nedes mot it be good, that causeth so 72. chefe. mote. many good dedes. Every cause is more and worthier than thing 73. thynge. caused; and in that mores possession al thinges lesse ben compted. As the king is more than his people, and hath in possession al his rëalme after, right so the knot is more than al other goodes; thou might recken al thinges lasse; and that to him longeth, oweth in-to his mores cause of worship and of wil †to turne; it is els rebel and out of his mores defending to 79. do; read to, as in l. 81. voyde. Right so of every goodnesse; in-to the knotte and in-to the cause of his worship [it] oweth to tourne. And trewly, 81. Supply it.
every thing that hath being profitably is good, but nothing hath to ben more profitably than this knot; kinges it mayntayneth, and hem, their powers to mayntayne. It maketh misse to ben amended with good governaunce in doing. It closeth hertes so togider, that rancour is out-thresten. Who that it lengest kepeth, lengest is glad[d]ed.'

'I trowe,' quod I, 'heretykes and misse-mening people hence∣forward 88. meanynge. wol maintayne this knotte; for therthorough shul they 89. forwarde. ben maintayned, and utterly wol turne and leve their olde yvel 90. leaue. understanding, and knitte this goodnesse, and profer so ferre in service, that name of servauntes might they have. Their jangles shal cese; me thinketh hem lacketh mater now to alege.' 93. cease. nowe.

'Certes,' quod Love, 'if they, of good wil thus turned, as thou sayst, wolen trewly perfourme, yet shul they be abled party of this blisse to have; and they wol not, yet shul my servauntes the werre wel susteyne in myn helpe of maintenaunce to the ende. And they, for their good travayle, shullen in reward so ben meded, that endelesse joye body and soule †to-gider in this shullen 99. togyther. abyden. There is ever accion of blisse withouten possible corrupcion; there is accion perpetuel in werke without travayle; 100-1. action (twice). there is everlasting passife, withouten any of labour; continuel plyte, without cesinge coveyted to endure. No tonge may telle, 103. ceasynge. tel. ne herte may thinke the leest point of this blisse.' 104. hert.
'God bring me thider!' quod I than.

'Continueth wel,' quod she, 'to the ende, and thou might not fayle than; for though thou spede not here, yet shal the passion of thy martred lyfe ben written, and rad toforn the grete Jupiter, 108. radde toforne. great. that god is of routhe, an high in the holownesse of heven, there he sit in his trone; and ever thou shalt forward ben holden 110. sytte. forwarde. amonge al these hevins for a knight, that mightest with no penaunce ben discomfited. He is a very martyr that, livingly goinge, is gnawen to the bones.'
'Certes,' quod I, 'these ben good wordes of comfort; a litel 114. comforte. myne herte is rejoyced in a mery wyse.'
'Ye,' quod she; 'and he that is in heven felith more joye, than whan he firste herde therof speke.'

'So it is,' quod I; 'but wist I the sothe, that after disese 118. disease comforte. comfort wolde folowe with blisse, so as ye have often declared,
I wolde wel suffre this passion with the better chere. But my thoughtful sorowe is endelesse, to thinke how I am cast out 121. howe. of a welfare; and yet dayneth not this yvel non herte, non hede, 122. none (twice). to meward throwe: which thinges wolde greetly me by wayes 123. mewarde. greatly. of comfort disporte, to weten in my-selfe a litel with other me[n] 124. comforte. me; read men? ben y-moved; and my sorowes peysen not in her balaunce the weyght of a peese. Slinges of her daunger so hevily peysen, they drawe my causes so hye, that in her eyen they semen but light and right litel.'

'O! for,' quod she, 'heven with skyes that foule cloudes maken and darke †weders, with gret tempestes and huge, 130. wethers; read weders. maketh the mery dayes with softe shyning sonnes. Also the yere with-draweth floures and beautee of herbes and of erth; 132. beautie. the same †yere maketh springes and jolitè in Vere so to renovel 133. yeres; read yere. with peinted coloures, that erthe semeth as gay as heven. Sees that blasteth and with wawes throweth shippes, of whiche the living creatures for greet peril for hem dreden; right so, the 136. great. same sees maketh smothe waters and golden sayling, and com∣forteth hem with noble haven that firste were so ferde. Hast thou not (quod she) lerned in thy youth, that Jupiter hath in his warderobe bothe garmentes of joye and of sorowe? What wost thou how soone he wol turne of the garment of care, 141. howe. and clothe thee in blisse? Pardè, it is not ferre fro thee. Lo, 142. the. an olde proverbe aleged by many wyse:—"Whan bale is greetest, 143. greatest. than is bote a nye-bore." Wherof wilt thou dismaye? Hope 144. wylte. wel and serve wel; and that shal thee save, with thy good bileve.' 145. the.
'Ye, ye,' quod I; 'yet see I not by reson how this blisse 146. se. reason howe. is coming; I wot it is contingent; it may falle on other.' 147. wote. fal.

'O,' quod she, 'I have mokel to done to clere thyne under∣standing, and voyde these errours out of thy mynde. I wol prove it by reson, thy wo may not alway enduren. Every thing 150. reason. kyndely (quod she) is governed and ruled by the hevenly bodyes, whiche haven ful werchinge here on erthe; and after course of these bodyes, al course of your doinges here ben governed and ruled by kynde.

Thou wost wel, by cours of planettes al your dayes proceden; and to everich of singuler houres be enterchaunged stondmele
about, by submitted worching naturally to suffre; of whiche changes cometh these transitory tymes that maketh revolving of your yeres thus stondmele; every hath ful might of worchinge, til al seven han had her course about. Of which worchinges and possession of houres the dayes of the weke have take her names, after denominacion in these seven planettes. Lo, your Sonday 162. denomination. ginneth at the first hour after noon on the Saturday, in whiche hour is than the Sonne in ful might of worching; of whom Son∣day taketh his name. Next him foloweth Venus, and after Mercurius, and than the Moone; so than Saturnus, after whom Jovis; and than Mars; and ayen than the Sonne; and so forth †by .xxiiii. houres togider; in whiche hour ginning in the seconde 168. be; for by. day stant the Moone, as maister for that tyme to rule; of whom 169. stante. Monday taketh his name; and this course foloweth of al other dayes generally in doing. This course of nature of these bodyes chaunging stinten at a certain terme, limitted by their first kynde; 172. certayne. and of hem al governementes in this elemented worlde proceden, as in springes, constellacions, engendrures, and al that folowen kynde and reson; wherfore [in] the course that foloweth, sorowe 175. Supply in. and joy kyndely moten entrechangen their tymes; so that alway oon wele, as alway oon wo, may not endure. Thus seest 177. on (for oon; twice). thou appertly, thy sorowe in-to wele mot ben chaunged; wherfore 178. mote. in suche case to better syde evermore enclyne thou shuldest. Trewly, next the ende of sorowe anon entreth joy; by maner of necessitè it wol ne may non other betyde; and so thy conti[n]∣gence 181. conty∣gence. is disproved; if thou holde this opinion any more, thy wit is right leude. Wherfore, in ful conclusion of al this, thilke Margaryte thou desyrest hath ben to thee dere in thy herte, and 184. the. for her hast thou suffred many thoughtful diseses; herafter shal 185. diseases. [she] be cause of mokel mirth and joye; and loke how glad canst 186. Supply she. howe. canste. thou ben, and cese al thy passed hevinesse with manifolde 187. cease. joyes. And than wol I as blythly here thee speken thy mirthes 188. the. in joye, as I now have y-herd thy sorowes and thy complayntes. 189. ioy. nowe. yherde. And if I mowe in aught thy joye encrese, by my trouthe, on 190. encrease. my syde shal nat be leved for no maner traveyle, that I with 191. leaued. al my mightes right blythly wol helpe, and ever ben redy you bothe to plese.' And than thanked I that lady with al goodly
maner that I worthily coude; and trewly I was greetly rejoysed 194. worthely. greatly. in myne herte of her fayre behestes; and profered me to be 195. hert. slawe, in al that she me wolde ordeyne, while my lyf lested. 196. lyfe.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER X.
DIV3.P: 'ME thinketh,' quod I, 'that ye have right wel declared, that way to the knot shuld not ben in none of these disprovinge thinges; and now, order of our purpos this asketh, 3. nowe. purpose. that ye shulde me shewe if any way be †thider, and whiche 4. thyther. thilke way shulde ben; so that openly may be seye the verry 5. maye be sey. hye way in ful confusioun of these other thinges.' 6. waye.

'Thou shalt,' quod she, 'understande that [of] one of three 7. I supply of. lyves (as I first sayd) every creature of mankynde is sprongen, and so forth procedeth. These lyves ben thorow names departed 9. thorowe. in three maner of kyndes, as bestialliche, manliche, and resona∣bliche; 7-10. thre (twice). of whiche two ben used by flesshely body, and the thirde by his soule. "Bestial" among resonables is forboden in every lawe and every secte, bothe in Cristen and other; for every 13. christen. wight dispyseth hem that liveth by lustes and delytes, as him that is thral and bounden servaunt to thinges right foule; suche ben compted werse than men; he shal nat in their degree ben rekened, ne for suche one alowed. Heritykes, sayn they, chosen 17. sayne. lyf bestial, that voluptuously liven; so that (as I first sayde to 18. lyfe. thee) in manly and resonable livinges our mater was to declare; 19. the. lyuenges. but [by] "manly" lyfe, in living after flesshe, or els flesshly wayes to chese, may nat blisse in this knotte be conquered, as by reson 21. reason. it is proved. Wherfore by "resonable" lyfe he must nedes it have, sithe a way is to this knotte, but nat by the firste tway lyves; wherfore nedes mot it ben to the thirde; and for to live in flesshe, 24. mote. but nat after flessh, is more resonablich than manliche rekened by clerkes. Therfore how this way cometh in, I wol it blythely 26. howe. waye. declare.

See now (quod she) that these bodily goodes of manliche 28. Se nowe. livinges yelden †sorowfulle stoundes and smertande houres. Who∣so 29. lyuenges. soroufully; read sorowfulle. so †wol remembre him to their endes, in their worchinges they 30. wele; read wol.
ben thoughtful and sorie. Right as a bee that hath had his hony, 31. hadde. anon at his flight beginneth to stinge; so thilke bodily goodes at 32. anone. the laste mote awaye, and than stinge they at her goinge, wher∣through entreth and clene voydeth al blisse of this knot.'

'Forsothe,' quod I, 'me thinketh I am wel served, in shewing of these wordes. Although I hadde litel in respect among other 36. respecte amonge. grete and worthy, yet had I a fair parcel, as me thought, for the 37. great. faire. tyme, in forthering of my sustenaunce; whiche while it dured, I thought me havinge mokel hony to myne estat. I had richesse 39. estate, suffisauntly to weyve nede; I had dignitè to be reverenced in worship. Power me thought that I had to kepe fro myne enemyes, and me semed to shyne in glorie of renomè as manhood asketh 42. manhode. in mene; for no wight in myne administracion coude non yvels 43. meane. -tion. ne trechery by sothe cause on me putte. Lady, your-selve weten wel, that of tho confederacies maked by my soverains I nas but a servaunt, and yet mokel mene folk wol fully ayenst 46. meane folke. reson thilke maters maynteyne, in whiche mayntenaunce [they] 47. reason. I supply they. glorien them-selfe; and, as often ye haven sayd, therof ought 48. sayde. nothing in yvel to be layd to me-wardes, sithen as repentaunt 49. nothynge. layde. I am tourned, and no more I thinke, neither tho thinges ne none suche other to sustene, but utterly distroye, without med∣linge maner, in al my mightes. How am I now cast out of al 52. Howe. nowe caste. swetnesse of blisse, and mischevously [is] stongen my passed 53. Supply is. joy! Soroufully muste I bewayle, and live as a wrecche. 54. wretche.

Every of tho joyes is tourned in-to his contrary. For richesse, now have I povertè; for dignitè, now am I emprisoned; in 56. nowe (thrice). stede of power, wrecchednesse I suffre; and for glorie of renomè, 57. wretchednesse. I am now dispysed and foulich hated. Thus hath farn Fortune, 58. nowe. that sodaynly am I overthrowen, and out of al welth dispoyled. Trewly, me thinketh this way in entree is right hard; god graunt 60. entre. harde. me better grace er it be al passed; the other way, lady, me 61. ladye. thought right swete.'

'Now, certes,' quod Love, 'me list for to chyde. What ayleth 63. Nowe. thy darke dulnesse? Wol it nat in clerenesse ben sharped? Have I nat by many resons to thee shewed, suche bodily goodes 65. reasons. the. faylen to yeve blisse, their might so ferforth wol nat strecche? 66. ferforthe. stretche.
Shame (quod she) it is to say, thou lyest in thy wordes. Thou ne hast wist but right fewe that these bodily goodes had al atones; commenly they dwellen nat togider. He that plentè hath in riches, of his kinne is ashamed; another of linage right noble and wel knowe, but povert him handleth; he were lever unknowe. Another hath these, but renomè of peoples praysing may he nat have; overal he is hated and defamed of thinges right foule. Another is fair and semely, but dignitè him fayleth; and he that 74. faire. hath dignitè is croked or lame, or els misshapen and foully dis∣pysed. 75. fouly. Thus partable these goodes dwellen commenly; in one houshold ben they but silde. Lo! how wrecched is your truste 77. sylde. howe reetched (!). on thing that wol nat accorde! Me thinketh, thou clepest thilke plyte thou were in "selinesse of fortune"; and thou sayest, for that the selinesse is departed, thou art a wrecch. Than foloweth 80. arte a wretch. this upon thy wordes; every soule resonable of man may nat dye; and if deth endeth selinesse and maketh wrecches, as nedes of 82. dethe. wretches. fortune maketh it an ende. Than soules, after deth of the body, 83. dethe. in wrecchednesse shulde liven. But we knowe many that han geten the blisse of heven after their deth. How than may this 85. dethe. Howe. lyf maken men blisful, that whan it passeth it yeveth no wrecched∣nesse, 84-6. wretchednesse. 86. lyfe. and many tymes blisse, if in this lyfe he con live as he shulde? And wolt thou acompt with Fortune, that now at [t]he 88. wolte. now. he; read the. first she hath don thee tene and sorowe? If thou loke to the 89. done the. maner of al glad thinges and sorouful, thou mayst nat nay it, that yet, and namely now, thou standest in noble plyte in a good 91. nowe. ginning, with good forth-going herafter. And if thou wene to be a wrecch, for such welth is passed, why than art thou nat wel 93. wretch. fortunate, for badde thinges and anguis wrecchednesse ben passed? 94. wretchednesse. Art thou now come first in-to the hostry of this lyfe, or els the both of this worlde? Art thou now a sodayn gest in-to this 95-6. nowe (twice). 96. sodayne. wrecched exile? Wenest there be any thing in this erthe stable? 97. wretched. thynge. Is nat thy first arest passed, that brought thee in mortal sorowe? 98. the (sic). Ben these nat mortal thinges agon with ignorance of beestial wit, and hast receyved reson in knowing of vertue? What comfort is 100. reason. comforte. in thy herte, the knowinge sikerly in my service [to] be grounded? 101. hert. I supply to. And wost thou nat wel, as I said, that deth maketh ende of al 102. woste.
fortune? What than? Standest thou in noble plyte, litel hede or recking to take, if thou let fortune passe dy[i]ng, or els that 104. rcekyng. dyng (sic). she fly whan her list, now by thy lyve? Pardy, a man hath nothing so leef as his lyf; and for to holde that, he doth al his 106. lefe. lyfe. cure and diligent traveyle. Than, say I, thou art blisful and fortunat sely, if thou knowe thy goodes that thou hast yet †beleved, whiche nothing may doute that they ne ben more worthy 109. beloued; read beleued. nothynge. than thy lyf?'
'What is that?' quod I.

'Good contemplacion,' quod she, 'of wel-doing in vertue in tyme 112. contemplation. coming, bothe in plesaunce of me and of thy Margarit-peerle. Hastely thyn hert in ful blisse with her shal be esed. Therfore dis∣may 114. eased. thee nat; Fortune, in hate grevously ayenst thy bodily person, ne yet to gret tempest hath she nat sent to thee, sithen the holding cables and ankers of thy lyfe holden by knitting so faste, that thou discomforte thee nought of tyme that is now, ne dispayre thee not of tyme to come, but yeven thee comfort in hope of 115-9. the (five times). 119. comforte. weldoing, and of getting agayn the double of thy lesing, with 120. agayne. encreasynge. encresing love of thy Margarite-perle therto! For this, hiderto, thou hast had al her ful daunger; and so thou might amende al that is misse and al defautes that somtyme thou diddest; and that now, in al thy tyme, to that ilke Margaryte in ful service of my lore thyne herte hath continued; wherfore she ought moche the rather enclyne fro her daungerous sete. These thinges ben yet knit by the holding anker in thy lyve, and holden mote they; to god I pray, al these thinges at ful ben perfourmed. For whyle this anker holdeth, I hope thou shalt safely escape; and [in a] 129. shalte. Supply in a. whyle thy trewe-mening service aboute bringe, in dispyte of al 130. meanyng. false meners that thee of-newe haten; for [in] this trewe service 131. meaners. the. Supply in. thou art now entred.' 132. arte nowe.

'Certayn,' quod I, 'among thinges I asked a question, whiche 133. Certayn begins with a large capital C, on fol. 306, verso. amonge. was the way to the knot. Trewly, lady, how-so it be I tempt you with questions and answers, in speking of my first service, I am now in ful purpos in the pricke of the herte, that thilke service 136. nowe. purpose. was an enprisonment, and alway bad and naughty, in no maner to be desyred; ne that, in getting of the knot, may it nothing aveyle. A wyse gentil herte loketh after vertue, and none other 136-9. hert.
bodily joyes alone. And bycause toforn this in tho wayes I was 140. toforne. set, I wot wel my-selfe I have erred, and of the blisse fayled; and 141. sette. wote. so out of my way hugely have I ronne.' 142. ron.

'Certes,' quod she, 'that is sothe; and there thou hast mis∣went, eschewe the path from hens-forward, I rede. Wonder 144. pathe. -forwarde. I trewly why the mortal folk of this worlde seche these ways out∣forth; 145. folke. and it is preved in your-selfe. Lo, how ye ben confounded 146. howe. with errour and folly! The knowing of very cause and way is goodnesse and vertue. Is there any thing to thee more precious 148. thynge. the. than thy-selfe? Thou shalt have in thy power that thou woldest never lese, and that in no way may be taken fro thee; and thilke 150. the. thing is that is cause of this knot. And if deth mowe it nat reve 151. dethe. more than an erthly creature, thilke thing than abydeth with thy∣selfe 152. thynge. soule. And so, our conclusion to make, suche a knot, thus getten, abydeth with this thinge and with the soule, as long as they laste. A soule dyeth never; vertu and goodnesse evermore 155. last. with the soule endureth; and this knot is parfit blisse. Than 156. parfite. this soule in this blisse endlesse shal enduren. Thus shul hertes of a trewe knot ben esed: thus shul their soules ben plesed: thus 158. eased. pleased. perpetually in joye shul they singe.'
'In good trouth,' quod I, 'here is a good beginning; yeve us more of this way.'
Quod she, 'I said to thee nat longe sithen, that resonable lyf 162. the. lyfe. was oon of three thinges; and it was proved to the soule. 163. one. thre.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER XI.
DIV3.P:
EVERY soule of reson hath two thinges of stering lyf, oon in CH. XI. 1. euery (with small e). reason. lyfe. one. vertue, and another in the bodily workinge; and whan the soule is the maister over the body, than is a man maister of him∣selfe. And a man, to be a maister over him-selfe, liveth in vertu and in goodnesse, and as reson of vertue techeth. So the soule and the body, worching vertue togider, liven resonable lyf, whiche clerkes 6. lyfe. clepen "felicitè in living"; and therein is the hye way to this knot. 7. lyueng. These olde philosophers, that hadden no knowing of divine grace, of kyndly reson alone, wenden that of pure nature, withouten any 9. reason.
helpe of grace, me might have y-shoned th'other livinges. 10. thother lyuenges. Resonably have I lived; and for I thinke herafter, if god wol, and I have space, thilke grace after my leude knowing declare, I leve it as at this tyme. But, as I said, he that out-forth loketh 13. leaue. after the wayes of this knot, [his] conning with whiche he shulde 14. I supply his. knowe the way in-forth, slepeth for the tyme. Wherfore he that wol this way knowe, must leve the loking after false wayes out∣forth, 16. leaue. and open the eyen of his conscience, and unclose his herte. Seest nat, he that hath trust in the bodily lyfe is so besy bodily woundes to anointe, in keping from smert (for al-out may they nat 19. anoynt. be heled), that of woundes in his true understanding he taketh no 20. healed. hede; the knowing evenforth slepeth so harde: but anon, as in knowing awake, than ginneth the prevy medicynes, for heling of 22. healyng. his trewe intent, inwardes lightly †helen conscience, if it be wel 23. healeth; read helen. handled. Than must nedes these wayes come out of the soule by stering lyfe of the body; and els may no man come to parfit 25. maye. parfite. blisse of this knotte. And thus, by this waye, he shal come to the knotte, and to the parfit selinesse that he wende have had in 27. parfyte. bodily goodes outforth.'
'Ye,' quod I, 'shal he have both knot, riches, power, dignitè, and renomè in this maner way?' 30. waye.

'Ye,' quod she, 'that shal I shewe thee. Is he nat riche that 31. the. hath suffisaunce, and hath the power that no man may amaistrien? Is nat greet dignitè to have worship and reverence? And hath 33. great. he nat glorie of renomè, whos name perpetual is during, and out 34. whose. of nombre in comparacion?' 35. comparation.
'These be thinges that men wenen to getten outforth,' quod I.
'Ye,' quod she; 'they that loken after a thing that nought is 37. thynge. therof, in al ne in partie, longe mowe they gapen after!'
'That is sothe,' quod I.

'Therfore,' quod she, 'they that sechen gold in grene trees, and 40. golde. wene to gader precious stones among vynes, and layn her nettes 41. amonge. layne. in mountains to fisshe, and thinken to hunte in depe sees after 42. hunt. hart and hynd, and sechen in erth thilke thinges that surmounteth 43. hynde. heven, what may I of hem say, but folisshe ignoraunce misledeth wandring wrecches by uncouth wayes that shulden be forleten, 45. wretches. and maketh hem blynde fro the right pathe of trewe way that
shulde ben used? Therfore, in general, errour in mankynde departeth thilke goodes by mis-seching, whiche he shulde have 48. mysse. hole, and he sought by reson. Thus goth he begyled of that he 49. reason. sought; in his hode men have blowe a jape.'
'Now,' quod I, 'if a man be vertuous, and al in vertue liveth, 51. Nowe. how hath he al these thinges?' 52. howe.

'That shal I proven,' quod she. 'What power hath any man to lette another of living in vertue? For prisonment, or any 54. let. lyueng. other disese, [if] he take it paciently, discomfiteth he nat; the 55. I supply if. tyrant over his soule no power may have. Than hath that man, 56. maye. so tourmented, suche power, that he nil be discomfit; ne over∣come may he nat ben, sithen pacience in his soule overcometh, and †is nat overcomen. Suche thing that may nat be a-maistred, 59. as; read is. he hath nede to nothing; for he hath suffisaunce y-now, to helpe him-selfe. And thilke thing that thus hath power and suffisance, and no tyrant may it reve, and hath dignitè to sette at nought al thinges, here it is a greet dignitè, that deth may a-maistry. Wher∣fore 63. great. thilke power [with] suffisaunce, so enclosed with dignitè, by 64. I supply with. al reson renomè must have. This is thilke riches with suffisaunce ye sholde loke after; this is thilke worshipful dignitè ye shulde coveyte; this is thilke power of might, in whiche ye shulde truste; 67. coueyt. this is the ilke renomè of glorie that endlesse endureth; and al nis but substaunce in vertuous lyving.'

'Certes,' quod I, 'al this is sothe; and so I see wel that vertue with ful gripe encloseth al these thinges. Wherfore in sothe I may saye, by my trouth, vertue of my Margarite brought me first in-to your service, to have knitting with that jewel, nat sodain longinges ne folkes smale wordes, but only our conversacion 74. onely. conversation. togider; and than I, seinge th'entent of her trewe mening with 75. thentent. florisshing vertue of pacience, that she used nothing in yvel, to 76. nothynge. quyte the wicked lesinges that false tonges ofte in her have laid, 77. leasynges. layde. I have seye it my-selfe, goodly foryevenesse hath spronge out of 78. sey. her herte. Unitè and accord, above al other thinges, she 79. hert. accorde. desyreth in a good meke maner; and suffereth many wicked tales.
Trewly, lady, to you it were a gret worship, that suche thinges 82. Trewly (with large capital T). by due chastisment were amended.'

'Ye,' quod she, 'I have thee excused; al suche thinges as yet 84. the. mowe nat be redressed; thy Margarites vertue I commende wel the more, that paciently suche anoyes suffreth. David king was meke, and suffred mokel hate and many yvel speches; no despyt 87. dispite. ne shame that his enemys him deden might nat move pacience out of his herte, but ever in one plyte mercy he used. Wherfore 89. Werfore. god him-selfe took reward to the thinges; and theron suche 90. toke rewarde. punisshment let falle. Trewly, by reson, it ought be ensample of 91. fal. reason. drede to al maner peoples mirth. A man vengeable in wrath no governance in punisshment ought to have. Plato had a cause his servant to †scourge, and yet cleped he his neibour to performe the 94. scoure (!); read scourge. doinge; him-selfe wolde nat, lest wrath had him a-maistred; and so might he have layd on to moche: evermore grounded vertue 96. layde. sheweth th' entent fro within. And trewly, I wot wel, for her good∣nesse 97. thentent. wotte. and vertue, thou hast desyred my service to her plesance wel the more; and thy-selfe therto fully hast profered.' 99. haste.
'Good lady,' quod I, 'is vertue the hye way to this knot that 100. waye. long we have y-handled?'
'Ye, forsoth,' quod she, 'and without vertue, goodly this knot may nat be goten.'

'Ah! now I see,' quod I, 'how vertu in me fayleth; and I, as 104. nowe I se. howe. a seer tree, without burjoning or frute, alwaye welke; and 105. tre. so I stonde in dispeyre of this noble knot; for vertue in me hath no maner workinge. A! wyde-where aboute have I traveyled!'

'Pees,' quod she, 'of thy first way; thy traveyle is in ydel; 109. Peace. and, as touchinge the seconde way, I see wel thy meninge. Thou 110. se. meanyng. woldest conclude me, if thou coudest, bycause I brought thee 111. the. to service; and every of my servantes I helpe to come to this 112. one. blisse, as I sayd here-beforn. And thou saydest thy-selfe, thou 113. beforne. mightest nat be holpen as thou wenest, bycause that vertue in 114. wenyst. thee fayleth; and this blisse parfitly without vertue may nat be 115. the. maye. goten; thou wenest of these wordes contradiccion to folowe. 116. contradiction. Pardè, at the hardest, I have no servant but he be vertuous in dede and thought. I brought thee in my service, yet art thou 118. the. arte. nat my servant; but I say, thou might so werche in vertue her∣after, that than shalt thou be my servant, and as for my servant
acompted. For habit maketh no monk; ne weringe of gilte 121. habyte. monke. wearynge. spurres maketh no knight. Never-the-later, in confort of thyne 122. conforte. herte, yet wol I otherwyse answere.'

'Certes, lady,' quod I tho, 'so ye muste nedes; or els I had nigh caught suche a †cardiacle for sorowe, I wot it wel, I shulde 125. nyghe. cordiacle; read cardiacle. wotte. it never have recovered. And therfore now I praye [thee] to 126. nowe. I supply thee. enforme me in this; or els I holde me without recovery. I may 127. re∣couerye. nat long endure til this lesson be lerned, and of this mischeef the 128. mischefe. remedy knowen.'

'Now,' quod she, 'be nat wroth; for there is no man on-lyve 130. Nowe. wrothe. that may come to a precious thing longe coveited, but he somtyme 131. maye. suffre teneful diseses: and wenest thy-selfe to ben unliche to al 132. diseases. wenyst. other? That may nat ben. And with the more sorowe that 133. maye. a thing is getten, the more he hath joye the ilke thing afterwardes 134. thynge. to kepe; as it fareth by children in scole, that for lerninge arn 135. schole. arne. beten, whan their lesson they foryetten. Commenly, after a good 136. beaten. disciplyning with a yerde, they kepe right wel doctrine of their scole.' 138. schole.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER XII.
DIV3.P: RIGHT with these wordes, on this lady I threw up myne eyen, CH. XII. 1. threwe. to see her countenaunce and her chere; and she, aperceyv∣ing 2. se. this fantasye in myne herte, gan her semblaunt goodly on me caste, and sayde in this wyse.

'It is wel knowe, bothe to reson and experience in doinge, 5. Reason. every active worcheth on his passive; and whan they ben togider, "active" and "passive" ben y-cleped by these philosophers. If 7. ycleaped. fyr be in place chafinge thing able to be chafed or hete[d], and 8. fyre. thynge. hete; read heted. thilke thinges ben set in suche a distaunce that the oon may 9. sette. one. werche, the other shal suffre. Thilke Margarite thou desyrest is ful of vertue, and able to be active in goodnesse: but every herbe sheweth his vertue outforth from within. The sonne yeveth light, 12. outforthe. that thinges may be seye. Every fyr heteth thilke thing that it 13. sey. fyre. †neigheth, and it be able to be hete[d]. Vertue of this Margarite 14. neighed; read neigheth. hete; read heted.
outforth †wercheth; and nothing is more able to suffre worching, 15. wrethe (!); read wercheth. nothynge. or worke cacche of the actife, but passife of the same actife; and 16. catche. no passife, to vertues of this Margaryte, but thee, in al my Donet can I fynde! So that her vertue muste nedes on thee werche; 17-8. the (twice). in what place ever thou be, within distaunce of her worthinesse, as her very passife thou art closed. But vertue may thee nothing 20. arte. the. profyte, but thy desyr be perfourmed, and al thy sorowes cesed. 21. desyre. ceased. Ergo, through werchinge of her vertue thou shalt esely ben 22. shalte easely. holpen, and driven out of al care, and welcome to this longe by thee desyred!' 24. the.

'Lady,' quod I, 'this is a good lesson in ginning of my joye; but wete ye wel forsothe, though I suppose she have moche 26. thoughe. vertue, I wolde my spousaile were proved, and than may I live 27. maye. out of doute, and rejoice me greetly, in thinking of tho vertues 28. greatly. so shewed.'

'I herde thee saye,' quod she, 'at my beginning, whan I receyved 30. the say. thee firste for to serve, that thy jewel, thilke Margaryte thou 31. the. desyrest, was closed in a muskle with a blewe shel.'
'Ye, forsothe,' quod I; 'so I sayd; and so it is.'

'Wel,' quod she, 'every-thing kyndly sheweth it-selfe; this jewel, closed in a blewe shel, [by] excellence of coloures sheweth 35. Supply by. vertue from within; and so every wight shulde rather loke to the propre vertue of thinges than to his forayne goodes. If a thing be engendred of good mater, comenly and for the more part, it 38. parte. foloweth, after the congelement, vertue of the first mater (and it be not corrupt with vyces) to procede with encrees of good 40. encrease. vertues; eke right so it fareth of badde. Trewly, greet excellence 41. great. in vertue of linage, for the more part, discendeth by kynde to 42. parte. the succession in vertues to folowe. Wherfore I saye, the †colour 43. colours; read colour. of every Margarit sheweth from within the fynesse in vertue. Kyndely heven, whan mery †weder is a-lofte, apereth in mannes 45. wether; read weder. eye of coloure in blewe, stedfastnesse in pees betokening within 46. peace. and without. Margaryte is engendred by hevenly dewe, and sheweth in it-selfe, by fynenesse of colour, whether the engendrure 48. coloure. were maked on morowe or on eve; thus sayth kynde of this perle. This precious Margaryte that thou servest, sheweth it-selfe discended, by nobley of vertue, from this hevenlich dewe, norisshed
and congeled in mekenesse, that †moder is of al vertues; and, by werkes that men seen withouten, the significacion of the coloures 53. sene. signification. ben shewed, mercy and pitee in the herte, with pees to al other; 54. pytie. and al this is y-closed in a muskle, who-so redily these vertues loken. Al thing that hath soule is reduced in-to good by mene thinges, 56. meane. as thus: In-to god man is reduced by soules resonable; and so forth beestes, or bodyes that mowe not moven, after place ben 58. forthe. reduced in-to manne by beestes †mene that moven from place to 59. meue; misprint for mene. mouyn. place. So that thilke bodyes that han felinge soules, and move not from places, holden the lowest degree of soulinge thinges in felinge; and suche ben reduced in-to man by menes. So it 62. meanes. foloweth, the muskle, as †moder of al vertues, halt the place of 52, 63. mother; read moder. 63. halte. mekenesse, to his lowest degree discendeth downe of heven, and there, by a maner of virgine engendrure, arn these Margarytes 65. arne. engendred, and afterward congeled. Made not mekenesse so 66. afterwarde. lowe the hye heven, to enclose and cacche out therof so noble 67. catche. a dewe, that after congelement, a Margaryte, with endelesse vertue and everlasting joy, was with ful vessel of grace yeven to every creature, that goodly wolde it receyve?'
'Certes,' quod I, 'these thinges ben right noble; I have er this herd these same sawes.' 72. herde.
'Than,' quod she, 'thou wost wel these thinges ben sothe?' 73. woste.
'Ye, forsothe,' quod I, 'at the ful.'

'Now,' quod she, 'that this Margaryte is ful of vertue, it is wel 75. Nowe. proved; wherfore som grace, som mercy, among other vertues, 76. some (twice). amonge. I wot right wel, on thee shal discende?' 77. wotte.
'Ye,' quod I; 'yet wolde I have better declared, vertues in this Margarite kyndely to ben grounded.'
'That shal I shew thee,' quod she, 'and thou woldest it lerne.' 77,80. the (twice).

'Lerne?' quod I, 'what nedeth suche wordes? Wete ye nat wel, lady, your-selfe, that al my cure, al my diligence, and al my might, have turned by your counsayle, in plesaunce of that perle? Al my thought and al my studye, with your helpe, desyreth, in worshippe [of] thilke jewel, to encrese al my travayle and al my 85. I supply of. encrease. besinesse in your service, this Margaryte to gladde in some halve. Me were lever her honour, her plesaunce, and her good chere 87. leauer. pleasaunce.
thorow me for to be mayntayned and kept, and I of suche thinge 88. thorowe. kepte. in her lykinge to be cause, than al the welthe of bodily goodes ye coude recken. And wolde never god but I putte my-selfe in 90. put. greet jeopardy of al that I †welde, (that is now no more but 91. great ieoperdye. wolde; read welde. nowe. lyfe. my lyf alone), rather than I shulde suffre thilke jewel in any pointe ben blemisshed; as ferre as I may suffre, and with my mightes strecche.' 94. stretche.
'Suche thing,' quod she, 'may mokel further thy grace, and 95. maye. thee in my service avaunce. But now (quod Love) wilt thou 96. the. nowe. wylte. graunte me thilke Margaryte to ben good?'

'O! good †god,' quod I, 'why tempte ye me and tene with 98. good good; read good god. suche maner speche? I wolde graunt that, though I shulde anon 99. thoughe. anone. dye; and, by my trouthe, fighte in the quarel, if any wight wolde 100. fyght. countreplede.'
'It is so moche the lighter,' quod Love, 'to prove our entent.'

'Ye,' quod I; 'but yet wolde I here how ye wolde prove that 103. howe. she were good by resonable skil, that it mowe not ben denyed. 104. reasonable. For although I knowe, and so doth many other, manifold good∣nesse 105. dothe. and vertue in this Margaryte ben printed, yet some men there ben that no goodnesse speken; and, wher-ever your wordes ben herd and your resons ben shewed, suche yvel spekers, lady, 108. herde. reasons. by auctoritè of your excellence, shullen be stopped and ashamed! And more, they that han non aquayntaunce in her persone, yet 110. none. mowe they knowe her vertues, and ben the more enfourmed in what wyse they mowe sette their hertes, whan hem liste in-to your service any entree make. For trewly al this to beginne, I wot 113. entre. wote. wel my-selfe that thilke jewel is so precious perle, as a womanly woman in her kynde; in whom of goodnesse, of vertue, and also 115. whome. of answeringe shappe of limmes, and fetures so wel in al pointes acording, nothing fayleth. I leve that kynde her made with greet 117. nothynge. great. studye; for kynde in her person nothing hath foryet[en], and that 118. foryet. is wel sene. In every good wightes herte she hath grace of commending and of vertuous praysing. Alas! that ever kynde made her deedly! Save only in that, I wot wel, that Nature, 121. onely. in fourminge of her, in no-thinge hath erred.'

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER XIII.
DIV3.P: 'CERTES,' quod Love, 'thou hast wel begonne; and I aske CH. XIII. 1. haste. thee this question: Is not, in general, every-thing good?'
'I not,' quod I.
'No?' quod she; '†saw not god everything that he made, and 2,4. thynge. 4. saue; read saw. weren right good?' 5. werne.
'Than is wonder,' quod I, 'how yvel thinges comen a-place, 6. howe. sithen that al thinges weren right good.'

'Thus,' quod she, 'I wol declare. Everiche qualitè and every accion, and every thing that hath any maner of beinge, it is of 9. action. god; and god it made, of whom is al goodnesse and al being. Of him is no badnesse. Badde to be, is naught; good to be, is somwhat; and therfore good and being is oon in under∣standing.' 12. one.
'How may this be?' quod I. 'For often han shrewes me 14. Howe. assailed, and mokel badnesse therin have I founden; and so me semeth bad to be somwhat in kynde.'

'Thou shalt,' quod she, 'understande that suche maner badnesse, whiche is used to purifye wrong-doers, is somwhat; and god it 18. wronge. made, and being [it] hath; and that is good. Other badnesse no 19. I supply it. being hath utterly; it is in the negative of somwhat, and that is naught and nothing being. The parties essential of being arn 21. arne. sayd in double wyse, as that it is; and these parties ben founde in every creature. For al thing, a this halfe the first being, is being through participacion, taking partie of being; so that [in] 24. I supply in. and of; I omit and. every creature is difference bitwene being of him through whom it is, and his own being. Right as every good is a maner of being, so is it good thorow being; for it is naught other to be. 27. thorowe. And every thing, though it be good, is not of him-selfe good; but it is good by that it is ordinable to the greet goodnesse. 29. great. determission (!); read determinison. This dualitè, after clerkes †determinison, is founden in every creature, be it never so single of onhed.'

'Ye,' quod I; 'but there-as it is y-sayd that god †saw every∣thing 32. ysayde. saue; read saw. of his making, and [they] were right good (as your-selfe 33. I supply they. sayd to me not longe tyme sithen), I aske whether every creature
is y-sayd "good" through goodnesse unfourmed eyther els fourmed; 35. ysayde. and afterward, if it be accept utterly good?' 36. afterwarde. accepte.

'I shal say thee,' quod she. 'These grete passed clerkes han 37. the. great. devyded good in-to good being alone, and that is nothing but †god, for nothing is good in that wyse but god: also, in good by 39. good; read god. participacion, and that is y-cleped "good" for far fet and repre∣sentative 40. farre fette. of †godly goodnesse. And after this maner manyfold 41. goodly; read godly. manyfolde. good is sayd, that is to saye, good in kynde, and good in gendre, and good of grace, and good of joy. Of good in kynde Austen sayth, "al that ben, ben good." But peraunter thou woldest 44. saythe. wete, whether of hem-selfe it be good, or els of anothers goodnesse: for naturel goodnesse of every substaunce is nothing els than his substancial being, which is y-cleped "goodnesse" after comparison 47. ycleaped. that he hath to his first goodnesse, so as it is inductatife by menes 48. meanes. in-to the first goodnesse. Boece sheweth this thing at the ful, that this name "good" is, in general, name in kynde, as it is com∣parisoned generally to his principal ende, which is god, knotte of al goodnesse. Every creature cryeth "god us made"; and so they han ful apeted to thilke god by affeccion such as to hem 53. affection. longeth; and in this wyse al thinges ben good of the gret god, which is good alone.'

'This wonder thing,' quod I, 'how ye have by many resons 56. howe. reasons. proved my first way to be errour and misgoing, and cause[d] of 57. waye. cause; read caused. badnesse and feble meninge in the grounde ye aleged to be roted. Whence is it that suche badnesse hath springes, sithen al thinges 59. baddesse (!). thus in general ben good, and badnesse hath no being, as ye have declared? I wene, if al things ben good, I might than with the first way in that good have ended, and so by goodnesse have comen to blisse in your service desyred.'

'Al thing,' quod she, 'is good by being in participacion out of the firste goodnesse, whiche goodnesse is corrupt by badnesse 65. corrupte. and badde-mening maners. God hath [ordeyned] in good thinges, 66. meanynge. I supply ordeyned. that they ben good by being, and not in yvel; for there is absence of rightful love. For badnesse is nothing but only yvel wil of the 68. nothynge. onely. user, and through giltes of the doer; wherfore, at the ginninge of the worlde, every thing by him-selfe was good; and in universal they weren right good. An eye or a hand is fayrer and betterer 71. werne. hande.
in a body set, in his kyndely place, than from the body dissevered. 72. sette. disceuered. Every thing in his kyndly place, being kyndly, good doth werche; 73. dothe. and, out of that place voyded, it dissolveth and is defouled him∣selve. Our noble god, in gliterande wyse, by armony this world 75. worlde ordeyned, as in purtreytures storied with colours medled, in whiche blacke and other derke colours commenden the golden and the asured paynture; every put in kyndely place, oon, besyde 78. putte. one. another, more for other glitereth. Right so litel fayr maketh 79. lytle fayre. right fayr more glorious; and right so, of goodnesse, and of other 80. fayre. thinges in vertue. Wherfore other badde and not so good perles as this Margaryte that we han of this matier, yeven by the ayre litel goodnesse and litel vertue, [maken] right mokel goodnesse 83. Supply maken. and vertue in thy Margaryte to ben proved, in shyning wyse to be founde and shewed. How shulde ever goodnesse of pees have 85. Howe. peace. ben knowe, but-if unpees somtyme reigne, and mokel yvel †wrathe? 86. vnpeace. wrothe; read wrathe. How shulde mercy ben proved, and no trespas were, by due 87. Howe. trespeace (!). justificacion, to be punisshed? Therfore grace and goodnesse of a wight is founde; the sorouful hertes in good meninge to endure, 89. meanynge. ben comforted; unitè and acord bitwene hertes knit in joye to 90. acorde. knytte. abyde. What? wenest thou I rejoyce or els accompte him among 91. amonge. my servauntes that pleseth Pallas in undoinge of Mercurye, al-be-it 92. pleaseth. that to Pallas he be knit by tytle of lawe, not according to 93. knytte. resonable conscience, and Mercurie in doinge have grace to ben 94. reasonable. suffered; or els him that †weyveth the moone for fayrenesse of 95. weneth; read weyveth. the eve-sterre? Lo! otherwhyle by nightes, light of the moone greetly comforteth in derke thoughtes and blynde. Understanding 97. greatly. of love yeveth greet gladnesse. Who-so list not byleve, whan 98. great. lyste. a sothe tale is shewed, a dewe and a deblys his name is entred. 99. adewe. Wyse folk and worthy in gentillesse, bothe of vertue and of 100. folke. livinge, yeven ful credence in sothnesse of love with a good herte, 101. hert. there-as good evidence or experience in doinge sheweth not the contrarie. Thus mightest thou have ful preef in thy Margarytes 103. prefe. goodnesse, by commendement of other jewels badnesse and yvelnesse in doing. Stoundemele diseses yeveth several houres 105. diseases. in joye.'

'Now, by my trouthe,' quod I, 'this is wel declared, that my 107. Nowe.
Margaryte is good; for sithen other ben good, and she passeth manye other in goodnesse and vertue; wherthrough, by maner 109. wherthroughe. necessarie, she muste be good. And goodnesse of this Margaryte is nothing els but vertue; wherfore she is vertuous; and if there 111. no thynge. fayled any vertue in any syde, there were lacke of vertue. Badde nothing els is, ne may be, but lacke and want of good and good∣nesse; 113. wante. and so shulde she have that same lacke, that is to saye, badde; and that may not be. For she is good; and that is good, 115. maye. me thinketh, al good; and so, by consequence, me semeth, vertuous, and no lacke of vertue to have. But the sonne is not knowe but he shyne; ne vertuous herbes, but they have her kynde werchinge; ne vertue, but it strecche in goodnesse or profyt to another, is no 119. stretche. profyte. vertue. Than, by al wayes of reson, sithen mercy and pitee ben 120. reason. pytie. moste commended among other vertues, and they might never ben 121. amonge. shewed, [unto] refresshement of helpe and of comfort, but now 122.
