Supply unto. comforte. nowe. at my moste nede; and that is the kynde werkinge of these vertues; trewly, I wene, I shal not varye from these helpes. Fyr, 124. Fyre. and-if he yeve non hete, for fyre is not demed. The sonne, but 125. none heate. he shyne, for sonne is not accompted. Water, but it wete, the name shal ben chaunged. Vertue, but it werche, of goodnesse doth it fayle; and in-to his contrarie the name shal ben reversed. 128. dothe. And these ben impossible; wherfore the contradictorie, that is necessarye, nedes muste I leve.'

'Certes,' quod she, 'in thy person and out of thy mouthe these wordes lyen wel to ben said, and in thyne understanding to be leved, as in entent of this Margaryte alone. And here now my 133. nowe. speche in conclusion of these wordes.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER XIV.
DIV3.P:
IN these thinges,' quod she, 'that me list now to shewe CH. XIV. 1. nowe. openly, shal be founde the mater of thy sicknesse, and what shal ben the medicyn that may be thy sorowes lisse and comfort, as wel thee as al other that amisse have erred and out of 4. the. the way walked, so that any drope of good wil in amendement [may] ben dwelled in their hertes. Proverbes of Salomon openly 6. Supply may. techeth, how somtyme an innocent walkid by the way in blynd∣nesse 7. teacheth. howe.
of a derke night; whom mette a woman (if it be leefly to 8. lefely. saye) as a strumpet arayed, redily purveyed in turninge of thoughtes with veyne janglinges, and of rest inpacient, by dis∣simulacion of my termes, saying in this wyse: "Com, and be we 11. sayeng. Come. dronken of our swete pappes; use we coveitous collinges." And thus drawen was this innocent, as an oxe to the larder.'
'Lady,' quod I, 'to me this is a queynte thing to understande; 14. thynge. I praye you, of this parable declare me the entent.'

'This innocent,' quod she, 'is a scoler lerninge of my lore, in 16. scholer. seching of my blisse, in whiche thinge the day of his thought 17. daye. turning enclyneth in-to eve; and the sonne, of very light faylinge, maketh derke night in his conninge. Thus in derknesse of many doutes he walketh, and for blyndenesse of understandinge, he ne wot in what waye he is in; forsothe, suche oon may lightly ben 21. wote. one. begyled. To whom cam love fayned, not clothed of my livery, 22. whome came. but [of] unlefful lusty habit, with softe speche and mery; and 23. Supply of. unleful lustye habyte. with fayre honyed wordes heretykes and mis-meninge people 24. misse-. skleren and wimplen their errours. Austen witnesseth of an heretyk, that in his first beginninge he was a man right expert 26. heretyke. experte. in resons and swete in his wordes; and the werkes miscorden. 27. resones. Thus fareth fayned love in her firste werchinges. Thou knowest these thinges for trewe; thou hast hem proved by experience 29. haste. somtyme, in doing to thyne owne person; in whiche thing thou hast founde mater of mokel disese. Was not fayned love redily purveyed, thy wittes to cacche and tourne thy good thoughtes? 32. catche. Trewly, she hath wounded the conscience of many with florissh∣inge of mokel jangling wordes; and good worthe thanked I it for no glose. I am glad of my prudence thou hast so manly her 35. gladde. †weyved. To me art thou moche holden, that in thy kynde 36. veyned; read weyved. arte. course of good mening I returne thy mynde. I trowe, ne had 37. meanyng. I shewed thee thy Margaryte, thou haddest never returned. Of 38. the. first in good parfit joye was ever fayned love impacient, as the 39. parfyte. water of Siloë, whiche evermore floweth with stilnesse and privy noyse til it come nighe the brinke, and than ginneth it so out of mesure to bolne, with novelleries of chaunging stormes, that in 42. measure. course of every renning it is in pointe to spille al his circuit of 43. spyl. †bankes. Thus fayned love prively, at the fullest of his flowinge, 44. cankes (!); read bankes.
[ginneth] newe stormes [of] debat to arayse. And al-be-it that 45. I supply ginneth and of. debate. Mercurius [servants] often with hole understandinge knowen 46. I supply servants. suche perillous maters, yet Veneriens so lusty ben and so leude in their wittes, that in suche thinges right litel or naught don they fele; and wryten and cryen to their felawes: "here is blisse, here is joye"; and thus in-to one same errour mokel folk they drawen. "Come," they sayen, "and be we dronken of our 51. sayne. pappes"; that ben fallas and lying glose, of whiche mowe they not souke milke of helthe, but deedly venim and poyson, corrupcion of sorowe. Milke of fallas is venim of disceyt; milke of lying glose 52-4. lyeng. 54. disceyte. is venim of corrupcion. Lo! what thing cometh out of these 55. thynge. pappes! "Use we coveited collinges"; desyre we and meddle we false wordes with sote, and sote with false! Trewly, this is the sori∣nesse of fayned love; nedes, of these surfettes sicknesse muste 58. must. folowe. Thus, as an oxe, to thy langoring deth were thou drawen; the sote of the smoke hath thee al defased. Ever the deper thou 60. the. somtyme wadest, the soner thou it founde; if it had thee killed, 61. the. it had be litel wonder. But on that other syde, my trewe servaunt[s] not faynen ne disceyve conne; sothly, their doinge 63. seruaunt. is open; my foundement endureth, be the burthen never so greet; ever in one it lasteth. It yeveth lyf and blisful goodnesse 65. great. lyfe. in the laste endes, though the ginninges ben sharpe. Thus of two contraries, contrarye ben the effectes. And so thilke Margaryte thou servest shal seen thee, by her service out of 68. sene the. perillous tribulacion delivered, bycause of her service in-to newe disese fallen, by hope of amendement in the laste ende, with joye to be gladded. Wherfore, of kynde pure, her mercy with grace of good helpe shal she graunte; and els I shal her so strayne, 72. graunt. that with pitè shal she ben amaystred. Remembre in thyne herte how horribly somtyme to thyne Margaryte thou trespasest, 74. howe. and in a grete wyse ayenst her thou forfeytest! Clepe ayen thy 75. great. mynde, and know thyne owne giltes. What goodnesse, what 76. knowe. bountee, with mokel folowing pitè founde thou in that tyme? 77. bountie. Were thou not goodly accepted in-to grace? By my pluckinge was she to foryevenesse enclyned. And after, I her styred to drawe thee to house; and yet wendest thou utterly for ever 80. the. have ben refused. But wel thou wost, sithen that I in suche
sharpe disese might so greetly avayle, what thinkest in thy wit? 70,82. disease. 82. greatly. How fer may my wit strecche? And thou lache not on thy syde, 83. howe ferre maye my wytte stretche. I wol make the knotte. Certes, in thy good bering I wol acorde with the psauter: "I have founde David in my service true, and with holy oyle of pees and of rest, longe by him desyred, utterly 86. peace. he shal be anoynted." Truste wel to me, and I wol thee not 87. the. fayle. The †leving of the first way with good herte of continuance 88. leanyng (!) that I see in thee grounded, this purpose to parfourme, draweth 89. se. the. me by maner of constrayning, that nedes muste I ben thyne helper. Although mirthe a whyle be taried, it shal come at suche seson, that thy thought shal ben joyed. And wolde never god, sithen thyne herte to my resons arn assented, and openly hast confessed 93. reasones arne. haste. thyne amisse-going, and now cryest after mercy, but-if mercy 94. nowe. folowed; thy blisse shal ben redy, y-wis; thou ne wost how sone. Now be a good child, I rede. The kynde of vertues, in thy 96. chylde. Margaryte rehersed, by strength of me in thy person shul werche. Comfort thee in this; for thou mayst not miscary.' And these 98. Comforte the. wordes sayd, she streyght her on length, and rested a whyle. 99. sayde. COLOPHON. booke. boke.

DIV2.TRAILER: ¶ Thus endeth the seconde book, and here after foloweth the thirde book.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER I.
DIV3.P:
OF nombre, sayn these clerkes, that it is naturel somme of BOOK. III: CH. I. 1. sayne. discrete thinges, as in tellinge oon, two, three, and so forth; 2. one. thre. but among al nombres, three is determined for moste certayn. 3. amonge. thre. Wherfore in nombre certayn this werk of my besy leudenesse 3,4. certayne. 4. werke. I thinke to ende and parfourme. Ensample by this worlde, in three tymes is devyded; of whiche the first is cleped †Deviacion, 6. thre. Demacion; read Deuiacion. that is to say, going out of trewe way; and al that tho dyeden, in helle were they punisshed for a man[ne]s sinne, til grace and mercy 8. hel. fette hem thence, and there ended the firste tyme. The seconde tyme lasteth from the comming of merciable grace until the ende of transitorie tyme, in whiche is shewed the true way in fordoinge of the badde; and that is y-cleped tyme of Grace. And that
thing is not yeven by desert of yeldinge oon benefyt for another, 13. thynge. deserte. one benefyte. but only through goodnesse of the yever of grace in thilke tyme. 14. onely. Who-so can wel understande is shapen to be saved in souled blisse. The thirde tyme shal ginne whan transitorie thinges of 16. gyn. worldes han mad their ende; and that shal ben in Joye, glorie, and 17. made. rest, both body and soule, that wel han deserved in the tyme of Grace. And thus in that heven †togider shul they dwelle per∣petuelly, 19. togyther. dwel. without any imaginatyfe yvel in any halve. These tymes are figured by tho three dayes that our god was closed 21. thre. in erthe; and in the thirde aroos, shewing our resurreccion to 22. arose. resurrection. joye and blisse of tho that it deserven, by his merciable grace. So this leude book, in three maters, accordaunt to tho tymes, 24. boke. thre. lightly by a good inseër may ben understonde; as in the firste, 25. maye. Errour of misse-goinge is shewed, with sorowful pyne punisshed, 26. erroure. †that cryed after mercy. In the seconde, is Grace in good waye 27. is (!); read that. proved, whiche is faylinge without desert, thilke first misse 28. deserte. amendinge, in correccion of tho erroures, and even way to bringe, 29. correction. waye. with comfort of welfare in-to amendement wexinge. And in the 30. comforte. thirde, Joye and blisse graunted to him that wel can deserve it, 31. canne. and hath savour of understandinge in the tyme of grace. Thus in Joye, of my thirde boke, shal the mater be til it ende.

But special cause I have in my herte to make this proces 34. hert. processe. of a Margarit-perle, that is so precious a gemme †whyt, clere and 35. peerle. with; read whyt (see l. 44). litel, of whiche stones or jewel[les] the tonges of us Englissh 36. iewel; read iewelles. people tourneth the right names, and clepeth hem 'Margery-perles'; thus varieth our speche from many other langages. For trewly Latin, Frenche, and many mo other langages clepeth hem, 39. cleapeth. Margery-perles, [by] the name 'Margarites,' or 'Margarite-perles'; 40. Supply by. wherfore in that denominacion I wol me acorde to other mens tonges, in that name-cleping. These clerkes that treten of kyndes, 42. treaten. and studien out the propertee there of thinges, sayn: the Mar∣garite 43. propertie. sayne. is a litel whyt perle, throughout holowe and rounde and 44. whyte. vertuous; and on the see-sydes, in the more Britayne, in muskle∣shelles, of the hevenly dewe, the best ben engendred; in whiche by experience ben founde three fayre vertues. Oon is, it yeveth 47. One. comfort to the feling spirites in bodily persones of reson. Another 48. comforte. reason.
is good; it is profitable helthe ayenst passions of sorie mens hertes. And the thirde, it is nedeful and noble in staunching of bloode, there els to moche wolde out renne. To whiche perle and vertues 51. ren. me list to lyken at this tyme Philosophie, with her three speces, 52. thre. that is, natural, and moral, and resonable; of whiche thinges hereth what sayn these grete clerkes. Philosophie is knowing of 54. sayn. great. devynly and manly thinges joyned with studie of good living; and this stant in two thinges, that is, conninge and opinion. Con∣ninge 56. stante. is whan a thing by certayn reson is conceyved. But 57. certayne. wrecches and fooles and leude men, many wil conceyve a thing 58. wretches. and mayntayne it as for sothe, though reson be in the contrarye; wherfore conninge is a straunger. Opinion is whyl a thing is in 60. whyle. non-certayn, and hid from mens very knowleging, and by no parfit 61. -certayne. hydde. reson fully declared, as thus: if the sonne be so mokel as men 62. parfyte reason. wenen, or els if it be more than the erthe. For in sothnesse the certayn quantitè of that planet is unknowen to erthly dwellers; and 64. certayne. yet by opinion of some men it is holden for more than midle-erth.

The first spece of philosophie is naturel; whiche in kyndely thinges †treteth, and sheweth causes of heven, and strength of 67. treten; read treteth. kyndely course; as by arsmetrike, geometry, musike, and by astronomye techeth wayes and cours of hevens, of planetes, and 69. course. of sterres aboute heven and erthe, and other elementes.

The seconde spece is moral, whiche, in order, of living maners techeth; and by reson proveth vertues of soule moste worthy in our living; whiche ben prudence, justice, temperaunce, and 73. lyueng. strength. Prudence is goodly wisdom in knowing of thinges. 74. wysdome. Strength voideth al adversitees aliche even. Temperaunce dis∣troyeth beestial living with esy bering. And Justice rightfully 76. lyueng. easy bearyng. jugeth; and juging departeth to every wight that is his owne.

The thirde spece turneth in-to reson of understanding; al 78. reason. thinges to be sayd soth and discussed; and that in two thinges is devyded. Oon is art, another is rethorike; in whiche two al 80. one. arte. lawes of mans reson ben grounded or els maintayned. 81. reason.

And for this book is of LOVE, and therafter bereth his name, 82. booke. beareth. and philosophie and lawe muste here-to acorden by their clergial discripcions, as: philosophie for love of wisdom is declared, lawe 84. wisdome. for mainteynaunce of pees is holden: and these with love must 85. peace. nedes acorden; therfore of hem in this place have I touched.
Ordre of homly thinges and honest maner of livinge in vertue, with rightful jugement in causes and profitable administracion in 88. administration. comminaltees of realmes and citees, by evenhed profitably to 89. commynalties. cytes. raigne, nat by singuler avauntage ne by privè envy, ne by soleyn purpos in covetise of worship or of goodes, ben disposed in open 91. purpose. rule shewed, by love, philosophy, and lawe, and yet love, toforn al other. Wherfore as sustern in unitè they accorden, and oon 93. susterne. one. ende, that is, pees and rest, they causen norisshinge; and in the 94. peace. joye maynteynen to endure.

Now than, as I have declared: my book acordeth with dis∣cripcion 96. Nowe. boke. discription. 97-8. thre. of three thinges; and the Margarit in vertue is lykened to Philosophy, with her three speces. In whiche maters ever 97-8. thre. twey ben acordaunt with bodily reson, and the thirde with the 99. reason. soule. But in conclusion of my boke and of this Margarite-perle 100. peerle. in knittinge togider, Lawe by three sondrye maners shal be lykened; 101. thre. that is to saye, lawe, right, and custome, whiche I wol declare. Al that is lawe cometh of goddes ordinaunce, by kyndly worching; and thilke thinges ordayned by mannes wittes arn y-cleped right, which is ordayned by many maners and in constitucion written. 105. constitution. But custome is a thing that is accepted for right or for lawe, there-as lawe and right faylen; and there is no difference, whether it come of scripture or of reson. Wherfore it sheweth, that lawe is kyndly governaunce; right cometh out of mannes probable reson; and custome is of commen usage by length of tyme 110. reason. used; and custome nat writte is usage; and if it be writte, constitucion it is y-written and y-cleped. But lawe of kynde is 112. constitutyon. commen to every nation, as conjunccion of man and woman in 113. coniunction. love, succession of children in heritance, restitucion of thing 114. restitution. by strength taken or lent; and this lawe among al other halt 115. halte. the soveraynest gree in worship; whiche lawe began at the beginning of resonable creature; it varied yet never for no 117. reasonable. chaunging of tyme. Cause, forsothe, in ordayning of lawe was to constrayne mens hardinesse in-to pees, and withdrawing his yvel 119. peace. wil, and turning malice in-to goodnesse; and that innocence sikerly, withouten teneful anoye, among shrewes safely might 121. amonge inhabite by proteccion of safe-conducte, so that the shrewes, harm 122. harme for harme.
for harme, by brydle of ferdnesse shulden restrayne. But for∣sothe, 123. ferdenesse. in kyndely lawe, nothing is commended but such as goddes 124. nothynge. wil hath confirmed, ne nothing denyed but contrarioustee of 125. contraryoustie. goddes wil in heven. Eke than al lawes, or custome, or els constitucion by usage or wryting, that contraryen lawe of kynde, utterly ben repugnaunt and adversarie to our goddes wil of heven. Trewly, lawe of kynde for goddes own lusty wil is verily to mayntayne; under whiche lawe (and unworthy) bothe professe 130. law. and reguler arn obediencer and bounden to this Margarite-perle 131. arne. as by knotte of loves statutes and stablisshment in kynde, whiche that goodly may not be withsetten. Lo! under this bonde am 133. maye. I constrayned to abyde; and man, under living lawe ruled, by that lawe oweth, after desertes, to ben rewarded by payne or by mede, 135. payn. but-if mercy weyve the payne. So than †by part resonfully may 136. be; read by. parte reasonfully. be seye, that mercy bothe right and lawe passeth. Th' entent 137. sey. thentent. of al these maters is the lest clere understanding, to weten, at th'ende of this thirde boke; ful knowing, thorow goddes grace, 139. thende. thorowe. I thinke to make neverthelater. Yet if these thinges han a good and a †sleigh inseër, whiche that can souke hony of the harde 141. sleight; read sleigh. stone, oyle of the drye rocke, [he] may lightly fele nobley of mater 142. I insert he. in my leude imaginacion closed. But for my book shal be of 143. ymagination. boke. joye (as I sayd), and I [am] so fer set fro thilke place fro whens 144. Supply am. ferre. gladnesse shulde come; my corde is to short to lete my boket 145. let. ought cacche of that water; and fewe men be abouten my corde to eche, and many in ful purpos ben redy it shorter to make, and 147. purpose. to enclose th' entrè, that my boket of joye nothing shulde cacche, 146-8. catch. 148. thentre. but empty returne, my careful sorowes to encrese: (and if I dye for payne, that were gladnesse at their hertes): good lord, send 150. lorde sende. me water in-to the cop of these mountayns, and I shal drinke therof, my thurstes to stanche, and sey, these be comfortable 152. stanch. welles; in-to helth of goodnesse of my saviour am I holpen. And yet I saye more, the house of joye to me is nat opened. How dare my sorouful goost than in any mater of gladnesse thinken to trete? For ever sobbinges and complayntes be redy refrete in his meditacions, as werbles in manifolde stoundes comming about 157. meditations. I not than. And therfore, what maner of joye coude [I] endyte? 158. I supply I. But yet at dore shal I knocke, if the key of David wolde the locke
unshitte, and he bringe me in, whiche that childrens tonges both 160. vnshyt. bring. openeth and closeth; whos spirit where he †wol wercheth, 161. whose spirite. wel; read wol. departing goodly as him lyketh.

Now to goddes laude and reverence, profit of the reders, 163. Nowe. profite. amendement of maners of the herers, encresing of worship among Loves servauntes, releving of my herte in-to grace of my jewel, 165. hert. and fren[d]ship [in] plesance of this perle, I am stered in this 166. frenship. I supply in. peerle. making, and for nothing els; and if any good thing to mennes lyking in this scripture be founde, thanketh the maister of grace, whiche that of that good and al other is authour and principal doer. And if any thing be insufficient or els mislyking, †wyte 170. with; read wyte. that the leudnesse of myne unable conning: for body in disese anoyeth the understanding in soule. A disesely habitacion 172. habitation. letteth the wittes [in] many thinges, and namely in sorowe. The 173. I supply in. peerle. custome never-the-later of Love, †by long tyme of service, in 174. be; read by. termes I thinke to pursue, whiche ben lyvely to yeve under∣standing in other thinges. But now, to enforme thee of this 176. nowe. enform the. Margarites goodnesse, I may her not halfe preyse. Wherfore, nat she for my boke, but this book for her, is worthy to be commended, tho my book be leude; right as thinges nat for places, but places 178-9. boke (thrice). for thinges, ought to be desyred and praysed.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER II.
DIV3.P: 'NOW,' quod Love, 'trewly thy wordes I have wel under∣stonde. CH. II. 1. Nowe. Certes, me thinketh hem right good; and me wondreth why thou so lightly passest in the lawe.'
'Sothly,' quod I, 'my wit is leude, and I am right blynd, and 4. blynde. that mater depe. How shulde I than have waded? Lightly 5. howe. might I have drenched, and spilte ther my-selfe.'

'Ye,' quod she, 'I shal helpe thee to swimme. For right as 7. Yea. the. swym. lawe punissheth brekers of preceptes and the contrary-doers of the written constitucions, right so ayenward lawe rewardeth and 9. constitutions. ayenwarde. yeveth mede to hem that lawe strengthen. By one lawe this rebel is punisshed and this innocent is meded; the shrewe is enprisoned and this rightful is corowned. The same lawe that joyneth by wedlocke without forsaking, the same lawe yeveth
lybel of departicion bycause of devorse both demed and declared.'
'Ye, ye,' quod I, 'I fynde in no lawe to mede and rewarde in goodnes the gilty of desertes.' 17. gyltie.

'Fole,' quod she, 'gilty, converted in your lawe, mikel merit 18. gyltie. merite. deserveth. Also Pauly[n] of Rome was crowned, that by him the 19. Pauly (for Paulyn; first time). maynteyners of Pompeus weren knowen and distroyed; and yet toforn was this Paulyn cheef of Pompeus counsaile. This lawe 21. toforne. chefe. in Rome hath yet his name of mesuring, in mede, the bewraying of the conspiracy, ordayned by tho senatours the deth. Julius Cesar is acompted in-to Catons rightwisnesse; for ever in trouth florissheth his name among the knowers of reson. Perdicas was 25. amonge. crowned in the heritage of Alexander the grete, for tellinge of 26. great. a prevy hate that king Porrus to Alexander hadde. Wherfore every wight, by reson of lawe, after his rightwysenesse apertely 25-8. reason. his mede may chalenge; and so thou, that maynteynest lawe of kynde, and therfore disese hast suffred in the lawe, reward is 30. disease. rewarde. worthy to be rewarded and ordayned, and †apertly thy mede 31. apartly (for apertly). might thou chalenge.'

'Certes,' quod I, 'this have I wel lerned; and ever hens∣forward I shal drawe me therafter, in oonhed of wil to abyde, this 34. onehed. lawe bothe maynteyne and kepe; and so hope I best entre in-to your grace, wel deservinge in-to worship of a wight, without nedeful compulsion, [that] ought medefully to be rewarded.' 37. I supply that.

'Truly,' quod Love, 'that is sothe; and tho[ugh], by consti∣tucion, 38. constitution. good service in-to profit and avantage strecche, utterly 39. profite. stretch. many men it demen to have more desert of mede than good wil nat compelled.'
'See now,' quod I, 'how †many men holden of this the con∣trary. 42. Se. howe may. And what is good service? Of you wolde I here this question declared.'
'I shal say thee,' quod she, 'in a fewe wordes:—resonable 45. the. workinges in plesaunce and profit of thy soverayne.' 46. profite.
'How shulde I this performe!' quod I. 47. Howe.

'Right wel,' quod she; 'and here me now a litel. It is hardely 48. nowe. (quod she) to understande, that right as mater by due over∣chaunginges foloweth his perfeccion and his forme, right so every 50. perfection.
man, by rightful werkinges, ought to folowe the lefful desyres in 51. leful. his herte, and see toforn to what ende he deserveth. For many 52. hert. se. tymes he that loketh nat after th'endes, but utterly therof is unknowen, befalleth often many yvels to done, wherthrough, er he be war, shamefully he is confounded; th'ende[s] therof neden to 55. ware. be before loked. To every desirer of suche foresight in good service, three thinges specially nedeth to be rulers in his workes. 57. thre. First, that he do good; next, that he do [it] by eleccion in his 58. I supply it. electyon. owne herte; and the thirde, that he do godly, withouten any 59. hert. surquedry in thoughtes. That your werkes shulden be good, in service or in any other actes, authoritès many may be aleged; neverthelater, by reson thus may it be shewed. Al your werkes 62. reason. maye. be cleped seconde, and moven in vertue of the firste wercher, whiche in good workes wrought you to procede; and right so your werkes moven in-to vertue of the laste ende: and right in the first workinge were nat, no man shulde in the seconde werche. Right so, but ye feled to what ende, and seen their goodnes closed, ye shulde no more †recche what ye wrought; but the 68. recth (for retch); read recche. ginning gan with good, and there shal it cese in the laste ende, if 69. cease. it be wel considred. Wherfore the middle, if other-wayes it drawe than accordant to the endes, there stinteth the course of good, and another maner course entreth; and so it is a partie by him∣selve; and every part [that] be nat accordant to his al, is foul and 73. parte. I supply that. ought to be eschewed. Wherfore every thing that is wrought and be nat good, is nat accordant to th'endes of his al hole; it is 73-5. foule. foul, and ought to be withdrawe. Thus the persons that neither don good ne harm shamen foule their making. Wherfore, without 77. harme. working of good actes in good service, may no man ben accepted. Truely, the ilke that han might to do good and doon it nat, the 79. done. crowne of worship shal be take from hem, and with shame shul they be anulled; and so, to make oon werke acordant with his 81. one. endes, every good servaunt, by reson of consequence, muste do 82. reason. good nedes. Certes, it suffiseth nat alone to do good, but goodly withal folowe; the thanke of goodnesse els in nought he deserveth. For right as al your being come from the greetest 85. greatest. good, in whom al goodnesse is closed, right so your endes ben directe to the same good. Aristotel determineth that ende and good ben one, and convertible in understanding; and he that in
wil doth awey good, and he that loketh nat to th'ende, loketh nat to good; but he that doth good and doth nat goodly, [and] 90. I supply and. draweth away the direction of th'ende nat goodly, must nedes be badde. Lo! badde is nothing els but absence or negative 92. bad. negatyfe (first time). of good, as derkenesse is absence or negative of light. Than he that dooth [not] goodly, directeth thilke good in-to th'ende of 94. I supply not. badde; so muste thing nat good folowe: eke badnesse to suche folke ofte foloweth. Thus contrariaunt workers of th'ende that is good ben worthy the contrary of th'ende that is good to have.'
'How,' quod I, 'may any good dede be doon, but-if goodly it 99. done. helpe?'

'Yes,' quod Love, 'the devil doth many good dedes, but 101. dothe. goodly he leveth be-hynde; for †ever badly and in disceyvable 102. even; read ever. wyse he worketh; wherfore the contrary of th'ende him foloweth. And do he never so many good dedes, bicause goodly is away, his goodnes is nat rekened. Lo! than, tho[ugh] a man do good, 105. tho. but he do goodly, th'ende in goodnesse wol nat folowe; and thus in good service both good dede and goodly doon musten joyne togider, and that it be doon with free choise in herte; and els 107-8. done (twice). 108. hert. deserveth he nat the merit in goodnes: that wol I prove. For 109. merite. if thou do any-thing good by chaunce or by happe, in what thing art thou therof worthy to be commended? For nothing, by reson 111. reason. of that, turneth in-to thy praysing ne lacking. Lo! thilke thing doon by hap, by thy wil is nat caused; and therby shulde I 113. done. shulde I; put for shuldest thou. thanke or lacke deserve? And sithen that fayleth, th'ende which that wel shulde rewarde, must ned[e]s faile. Clerkes sayn, no man 115. neds (sic). but willinge is blessed; a good dede that he hath doon is nat doon of free choice willing; without whiche blissednesse may nat 116-7. done (twice). folowe. Ergo, neither thanke of goodnesse ne service [is] in that 118. I supply is and that. [that] is contrary of the good ende. So than, to good service longeth good dede goodly don, thorow free choice in herte.' 120. thorowe fre. hert.
'Truely,' quod I, 'this have I wel understande.'

'Wel,' quod she, 'every thing thus doon sufficiently by lawe, 122. done. that is cleped justice, [may] after-reward clayme. For lawe and 123. I supply may. rewarde claym. justice was ordayned in this wyse, suche desertes in goodnesse,
after quantitè in doinge, by mede to rewarde; and of necessitè of suche justice, that is to say, rightwysenesse, was free choice in deserving of wel or of yvel graunted to resonable creatures. Every man hath free arbitrement to chose, good or yvel to performe.'

'Now,' quod I tho, 'if I by my good wil deserve this Margarit∣perle, 130. Nowe. and am nat therto compelled, and have free choice to do what me lyketh; she is than holden, as me thinketh, to rewarde th'entent of my good wil.'
'Goddes forbode els,' quod Love; 'no wight meneth other∣wyse, 134. meaneth. I trowe; free wil of good herte after-mede deserveth.' 135. hert.

'Hath every man,' quod I, 'free choice by necessary maner of 136. fre. wil in every of his doinges that him lyketh, by goddes proper purvyaunce? I wolde see that wel declared to my leude under∣standing; 138. se. standing; for "necessary" and "necessitè" ben wordes of mokel entencion, closing (as to saye) so mote it be nedes, and otherwyse 140. entention. may it nat betyde.'

'This shalt thou lerne,' quod she, 'so thou take hede in my 142. lern. speche. If it were nat in mannes owne libertè of free wil to do good or bad, but to the one teyed by bonde of goddes preordi∣naunce, than, do he never so wel, it were by nedeful compulcion of thilk bonde, and nat by free choice, wherby nothing he 143-6. fre (twice). desyreth: and do he never so yvel, it were nat man for to wyte, but onlich to him that suche thing ordayned him to done. 148. onelych. Wherfore he ne ought for bad[de] be punisshed, ne for no good 149. bad. dede be rewarded; but of necessitè of rightwisnesse was therfore free choice of arbitrement put in mans proper disposicion. Truely, 151. disposition. if it were otherwyse, it contraried goddes charitè, that badnesse and goodnesse rewardeth after desert of payne or of mede.' 153. payn.

'Me thinketh this wonder,' quod I; 'for god by necessitè forwot al thinges coming, and so mote it nedes be; and thilke 155. forwote. thinges that ben don †by our free choice comen nothing of neces∣sitè 156. be; for by. fre. but only †by wil. How may this stonde †togider? And so 157. onely be; for by. Howe. me thinketh truely, that free choice fully repugneth goddes 158. fre. forweting. Trewly, lady, me semeth, they mowe nat stande †togider.' 157-60. togyther; read togider.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER III.
DIV3.P: THAN gan Love nighe me nere, and with a noble counte∣nance CH. III. 1. nygh. of visage and limmes, dressed her nigh my sitting-place.

'Take forth,' quod she, 'thy pen, and redily wryte these wordes. For if god wol, I shal hem so enforme to thee, that thy 5. the. leudnesse which I have understande in that mater shal openly be 6. vnderstand. clered, and thy sight in ful loking therin amended. First, if thou thinke that goddes prescience repugne libertè of arbitrement, it is 8. lyberte of arbetry of arbitrement; omit arbetry of. impossible that they shulde accorde in onheed of sothe to under∣stonding.'
'Ye,' quod I, 'forsothe; so I it conceyve.'
'Wel,' quod she, 'if thilke impossible were away, the repug∣naunce that semeth to be therin were utterly removed.'
'Shewe me the absence of that impossibilitè,' quod I.

'So,' quod she, 'I shal. Now I suppose that they mowe 15. Nowe. stande togider: prescience of god, whom foloweth necessitè of thinges comming, and libertè of arbitrement, thorow whiche thou 17. thorowe. belevest many thinges to be without necessitè.'
'Bothe these proporcions be sothe,' quod I, 'and wel mowe stande togider; wherfore this case as possible I admit.'
'Truely,' quod she, 'and this case is impossible.'
'How so?' quod I. 22. Howe.
'For herof,' quod she, 'foloweth and wexeth another im∣possible.'
'Prove me that,' quod I.

'That I shal,' quod she; 'for somthing is comming without necessitè, and god wot that toforn; for al thing comming he before wot, and that he beforn wot of necessitè is comming, as he beforn wot be the case by necessary maner; or els, thorow 29. beforne. maner than (omit than). thorowe. necessitè, is somthing to be without necessitè; and wheder, to 30. whederto. every wight that hath good understanding, is seen these thinges to be repugnaunt: prescience of god, whiche that foloweth neces∣sitè, and libertè of arbitrement, for whiche is removed necessitè? For truely, it is necessary that god have forweting of thing withouten any necessitè cominge.'

'Ye,' quod I; 'but yet remeve ye nat away fro myne under∣standing the necessitè folowing goddes be foreweting, as thus. God beforn wot me in service of love to be bounden to this Margarite∣perle, 38. beforne wote. and therfore by necessitè thus to love am I bounde; and if I had nat loved, thorow necessitè had I ben kept from al love∣dedes.' 40. thorowe. kepte.

'Certes,' quod Love, 'bicause this mater is good and necessary to declare, I thinke here-in wel to abyde, and not lightly to passe. Thou shalt not (quod she) say al-only, "god beforn wot me to be 44. shalte. onely. a lover or no lover," but thus: "god beforn wot me to be a lover 44-5. beforne wote (twice). without necessitè." And so foloweth, whether thou love or not love, every of hem is and shal be. But now thou seest the impos∣sibilitè 47. nowe. of the case, and the possibilitè of thilke that thou wendest had been impossible; wherfore the repugnaunce is adnulled.'

'Ye,' quod I; 'and yet do ye not awaye the strength of ne∣cessitè, whan it is said, th[r]ough necessitè it is me in love to 51. though; read through. abyde, or not to love without necessitè for god beforn wot it. 52. beforne wote. This maner of necessitè forsothe semeth to some men in-to co∣accion, 53. coaction. that is to sayne, constrayning, or else prohibicion, that is, defendinge; wherfore necessitè is me to love of wil. I under∣stande me to be constrayned by some privy strength to the wil of lovinge; and if [I] no[t] love, to be defended from the wil of 57. Supply I; for no read not; see l. 59. lovinge: and so thorow necessitè me semeth to love, for I love; 58. thorowe. or els not to love, if I not love; wherthrough neither thank ne 59. thanke. maugrè in tho thinges may I deserve.' 60. maye.

'Now,' quod she, 'thou shalt wel understande, that often we 61. Nowe. shalte. sayn thing thorow necessitè to be, that by no strength to be 62. sayne. thorowe. neither is coarted ne constrayned; and through necessitè not 63. throughe. to be, that with no defendinge is removed. For we sayn it is 64. sayne. thorow necessitè god to be immortal, nought deedliche; and it 65. thorowe. is is necessitè, god to be rightful; but not that any strength of violent maner constrayneth him to be immortal, or defendeth him 67. violente. to be unrightful; for nothing may make him dedly or unrightful. Right so, if I say, thorow necessitè is thee to be a lover or els 69. thorowe. the. noon; only thorow wil, as god beforn wete. It is nat to under∣stonde 70. none. onely thorowe. beforne. that any thing defendeth or forbit thee thy wil, whiche shal 71. the.
nat be; or els constrayneth it to be, whiche shal be. That same thing, forsoth, god before wot, whiche he beforn seeth. Any thing commende of only wil, that wil neyther is constrayned 73-4. thynge. 74. commende; for comminge. onely. ne defended thorow any other thing. And so thorow libertè of 75. thorowe (twice). arbitrement it is do, that is don of wil. And trewly, my good 76. done. child, if these thinges be wel understonde, I wene that non in∣convenient 77. childe. vnderstond. shalt thou fynde betwene goddes forweting and libertè of arbitrement; wherfore I wot wel they may stande togider. Also farthermore, who that understanding of prescience properlich considreth, thorow the same wyse that any-thing be 81. thorowe. afore wist is said, for to be comming it is pronounced; there is nothing toforn wist but thing comming; foreweting is but of trouth[e]; dout[e] may nat be wist; wherfore, whan I sey that god 84. trouth. dout. toforn wot any-thing, thorow necessitè is thilke thing to be com∣ming; 85. wote. thorowe. al is oon if I sey, it shal be. But this necessitè neither 86. if it shal be; omit if. constrayneth ne defendeth any-thing to be or nat to be. Therfore sothly, if love is put to be, it is said of necessitè to be; or els, for it is put nat to be, it is affirmed nat to be of necessitè; nat for that necessitè constrayneth or defendeth love to be or nat to be. For whan I say, if love shal be, of necessitè it shal be, here foloweth necessitè the thing toforn put; it is as moch to say as if it were thus 92. toforne. pronounced—"that thing shal be." Noon other thing signifyeth 93. None. this necessitè but only thus: that shal be, may nat togider be 94. onely. and nat be. Evenlich also it is soth, love was, and is, and shal be, nat of necessitè; and nede is to have be al that was; and nedeful is to be al that is; and comming, to al that shal be. And it is nat the same to saye, love to be passed, and love passed to be passed; or love present to be present, and love to be present; or els love to be comminge, and love comminge to be comming. Dyversitè in setting of wordes maketh dyversitè in understandinge; altho[ugh] in the same sentence they accorden 102. altho. of significacion; right as it is nat al oon, love swete to be swete, 103. signification. one. and love to be swete. For moch love is bitter and sorouful er hertes ben esed; and yet it glad[d]eth thilke sorouful herte on 105. eased. hert. suche love to thinke.'

'Forsothe,' quod I, 'outherwhile I have had mokel blisse in herte of love that stoundmele hath me sorily anoyed. And 108. hert.
certes, lady, for I see my-self thus knit with this Margarite-perle 109. se. peerle. as by bonde of your service and of no libertè of wil, my herte wil 110. hert. now nat acorde this service to love. I can demin in my-selfe 111. nowe. non otherwise but thorow necessitè am I constrayned in this 112. thorowe. service to abyde. But alas! than, if I thorow nedeful compulsioun 113. thorowe. maugre me be with-holde, litel thank for al my greet traveil have 114. thanke. great. I than deserved.'

'Now,' quod this lady, 'I saye as I sayde: me lyketh this 116. Nowe. mater to declare at the ful, and why: for many men have had dyvers fantasyes and resons, both on one syde therof and in the 118. reasons. other. Of whiche right sone, I trowe, if thou wolt understonde, thou shalt conne yeve the sentence to the partie more probable 120. shalte con. by reson, and in soth knowing, by that I have of this mater 121. reason. maked an ende.'

'Certes,' quod I, 'of these thinges longe have I had greet lust 123. great luste. to be lerned; for yet, I wene, goddes wil and his prescience acordeth with my service in lovinge of this precious Margarite∣perle. After whom ever, in my herte, with thursting desyre wete, 126. hert. weete. I do brenne; unwasting, I langour and fade; and the day of my desteny in dethe or in joye I †onbyde; but yet in th'ende I am 128. vnbyde (!). comforted †by my supposaile, in blisse and in joye to determine 129. be; for by. after my desyres.'

'That thing,' quoth Love, 'hastely to thee neigh, god graunt of his grace and mercy! And this shal be my prayer, til thou be lykende in herte at thyne owne wil. But now to enforme thee in 133. nowe. the. this mater (quod this lady) thou wost where I lefte; that was: love to be swete, and love swete to be swete, is not al oon for to 135. one. say. For a tree is nat alway by necessitè white. Somtyme, er it were white, it might have be nat white; and after tyme it is white, it may be nat white. But a white tree evermore nedeful 138. maye. is to be white; for neither toforn ne after it was white, might it be togider white and nat white. Also love, by necessitè, is nat present as now in thee; for er it were present, it might have be 141. nowe. the. that it shulde now nat have be; and yet it may be that it shal nat 142. nowe. maye. be present; but thy love present whiche to her, Margarite, thee 143. the. hath bounde, nedeful is to be present. Trewly, som doing of 144. some.
accion, nat by necessitè, is comminge fer toforn it be; it may be 145. action. ferre. that it shal nat be comminge. Thing forsoth comming nedeful is to be comming; for it may nat be that comming shal nat be comming. And right as I have sayd of present and of future tymes, the same sentence in sothnesse is of the preterit, that is to say, tyme passed. For thing passed must nedes be passed; and er it were, it might have nat be; wherfore it shulde nat have passed. Right so, whan love comming is said of love that is to come, nedeful is to be that is said; for thing comming never is nat comminge. And so, ofte, the same thing we sayn of the same; as 154. thynge. whan we sayn "every man is a man," or "every lover is a lover," 155. sayne. so muste it be nedes. In no waye may he be man and no man to∣gider. And if it be nat by necessitè, that is to say nedeful, al thing comming to be comming, than somthing comming is nat com∣minge, and that is impossible. Right as these termes "nedeful," "necessitè," and "necessary" betoken and signify thing nedes to be, and it may nat otherwyse be, right [so] †this terme "im∣possible" 161. I supply so. these termes; read this terme. signifyeth, that [a] thing is nat and by no way may it be. 162. I supply a. Than, thorow pert necessitè, al thing comming is comming; but that is by necessitè foloweth, with nothing to be constrayned. Lo! whan that "comming" is said of thinge, nat alway thing thorow necessitè is, altho[ugh] it be comming. For if I say, "to∣morowe 163-6. thorowe. (twice). 166. altho. love is comming in this Margarites herte," nat therfore 167. hert. thorow necessitè shal the ilke love be; yet it may be that it shal nat be, altho[ugh] it were comming. Neverthelater, somtyme it 169. altho. is soth that somthing be of necessitè, that is sayd "to come"; as if I say, to-morowe †be comminge the rysinge of the sonne. If 171. by; read be. therfore with necessitè I pronounce comming of thing to come, in this maner love to-morne comminge in thyne Margarite to thee∣ward, 173. the warde. by necessitè is comminge; or els the rysing of the sonne to-morne comminge, through necessitè is comminge. Love sothely, whiche may nat be of necessitè alone folowinge, thorow necessitè 176. thorowe. comming it is mad certayn. For "futur" of future is said; that is to 177. made certayne. sayn, "comming" of comminge is said; as, if to-morowe comming is thorow necessitè, comminge it is. Arysing of the sonne, thorow 179. thorowe. two necessitès in comming, it is to understande; that oon is to-for[e]going 180. one. to forgoing. necessitè, whiche maketh thing to be; therfore it shal be, for nedeful is that it be. Another is folowing necessitè, whiche
nothing constrayneth to be, and so by necessitè it is to come; why? for it is to come. Now than, whan we sayn that god beforn wot 184. Nowe. thing comming, nedeful [it] is to be comming; yet therfore make 185. I supply it. we nat in certayn evermore, thing to be thorow necessitè com∣minge. 186. certayne. thynge. thorowe. Sothly, thing comming may nat be nat comming by no 187. maye. way; for it is the same sentence of understanding as if we say thus: if god beforn wot any-thing, nedeful is that to be comming. But yet therfore foloweth nat the prescience of God, thing thorow 190. thorowe. necessitè to be comming: for al-tho[ugh] god toforn wot al 191. wote. thinges comming, yet nat therfore he beforn wot every thing comming thorow necessitè. Some thinges he beforn wot com∣ming 193. thorowe. of free wil out of resonable creature.'
'Certes,' quod I, 'these termes "nede" and "necessitè" have a queint maner of understanding; they wolden dullen many mennes wittes.'
'Therfore,' quod she, 'I wol hem openly declare, and more clerely than I have toforn, er I departe hen[ne]s. 200. hense; read hennes.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER IV.
DIV3.P: HERE of this mater,' quod she, 'thou shalt understande CH. IV. 1. shalte. that, right as it is nat nedeful, god to wilne that he wil, no more in many thinges is nat nedeful, a man to wilne that he wol. And ever, right as nedeful is to be, what that god wol, right so to be it is nedeful that man wol in tho thinges, whiche that god hath put in-to mannes subjeccion of willinge; as, if 6. subiection. a man wol love, that he love; and if he ne wol love, that he love nat; and of suche other thinges in mannes disposicion. For-why, 8. disposition. now than that god wol may nat be, whan he wol the wil of man 9. nowe. thorow no necessitè to be constrayned or els defended for to 10. thorowe. wilne, and he wol th'effect to folowe the wil; than is it nedeful, 11. theffecte. folow. wil of man to be free, and also to be that he wol. In this maner 12. fre. it is soth, that thorow necessitè is mannes werke in loving, that 13. thorowe. he wol do altho[ugh] he wol it nat with necessitè.' 14. altho.

Quod I than, 'how stant it in love of thilke wil, sithen men 15. howe stante.
loven willing of free choice in herte? Wherfore, if it be thorow 16. thorowe. necessitè, I praye you, lady, of an answere this question to assoyle.'

'I wol,' quod she, 'answere thee blyvely. Right as men wil 19. the. not thorow necessitè, right so is not love of wil thorow necessitè; ne thorow necessitè wrought thilke same wil. For if he wolde 20-1. thorowe (thrice). it not with good wil, it shulde nat have been wrought; although that he doth, it is nedeful to be doon. But if a man do sinne, it 23. dothe. doone. is nothing els but to †wilne that he shulde nat; right so sinne 24. wyl; read wilne; see l. 30. of wil is not to be [in] maner necessary don, no more than wil is 25. I supply in. done. necessarye. Never-the-later, this is sothe; if a man wol sinne, it is necessarye him to sinne, but th[r]ough thilke necessitè nothing is constrayned ne defended in the wil; right so thilke thing that 28. thynge. free-wil wol and may, and not may not wilne; and nedeful is 29. frewyl. maye. that to wilne he may not wilne. But thilke to wilne nedeful is; for 30. maye. impossible to him it is oon thing and the same to wilne and not to 30-1. Some words repeated here. 31. one. wilne. The werke, forsothe, of wil, to whom it is yeve that it be that 32. whome. he hath in wil, and that he wol not, voluntarie †or spontanye it is; 33. of; read or. for by spontanye wil it is do, that is to saye, with good wil not constrayned: than by wil not constrayned it is constrayned to be; and that is it may not †togider be. If this necessitè maketh 36. togyther; read togider. libertè of wil, whiche that, aforn they weren, they might have ben 37. libertie. aforne. eschewed and shonned: god than, whiche that knoweth al tr[o]uthe, and nothing but tr[o]uthe, al these thinges, as they 39. truthe (twice). arn spontanye or necessarie, †seeth; and as he seeth, so they 40. arne. syght; read seeth. ben. And so with these thinges wel considred, it is open at the ful, that without al maner repugnaunce god beforn wot al maner 42. beforne. thinges [that] ben don by free wil, whiche, aforn they weren, 43 I supply that. fre. aforne. [it] might have ben [that] never they shulde be. And yet ben 44. I supply it and that. they thorow a maner necessitè from free wil †discended. 45. frewyl discendeth (!).

Hereby may (quod she) lightly ben knowe that not al thinges to 46. maye. be, is of necessitè, though god have hem in his prescience. For som thinges to be, is of libertè of wil. And to make thee to have 48. libertie. the. ful knowinge of goddes beforn-weting, here me (quod she) what 49. beforne. I shal say.'
'Blythly, lady,' quod I, 'me list this mater entyrely to under∣stande.'

'Thou shalt,' quod she, 'understande that in heven is goddes 53. shalte. beinge; although he be over al by power, yet there is abydinge of devyne persone; in whiche heven is everlastinge presence, with∣outen any movable tyme. There A break here in Th. is nothing preterit ne passed, there is nothing future ne comming; but al thinges togider in that place ben present everlasting, without any meving. Wherfore, to god, al thing is as now; and though a thing be nat, in kyndly 59. nowe. thynge. nature of thinges, as yet, and if it shulde be herafter, yet evermore we shul saye, god it maketh be tyme present, and now; for no 61. nowe. future ne preterit in him may be founde. Wherfore his weting and his before-weting is al oon in understanding. Than, if weting 63. one. and before-weting of god putteth in necessitè to al thinges whiche he wot or before-wot; ne thing, after eternitè or els after any tyme, he wol or doth of libertè, but al of necessitè: whiche thing 66. dothe. if thou wene it be ayenst reson, [than is] nat thorow necessitè to 67. reason. I supply than is. thorowe. be or nat to be, al thing that god wot or before-wot to be or nat to be; and yet nothing defendeth any-thing to be wist or to be 69. thynge. before-wist of him in our willes or our doinges to be don, or els 70. done. comminge to be for free arbitrement. Whan thou hast these 71. haste. declaracions wel understande, than shalt thou fynde it resonable 72. declarations. at prove, and that many thinges be nat thorow necessitè but thorow libertè of wil, save necessitè of free wil, as I tofore said, 73-4. thorowe (twice). and, as me thinketh, al utterly declared.'

'Me thinketh, lady,' quod I, 'so I shulde you nat displese, and 76. displease. evermore your reverence to kepe, that these thinges contraryen in any understanding; for ye sayn, somtyme is thorow libertè of 78. sayne. wil, and also thorow necessitè. Of this have I yet no savour, 78-9. thorowe. without better declaracion.' 80. declaration.

'What wonder,' quod she, 'is there in these thinges, sithen al day thou shalt see at thyne eye, in many thinges receyven in hem∣selfe 82. shalte se. revers, thorow dyvers resons, as thus:—I pray thee (quod 83. reasons. the. she) which thinges ben more revers than "comen" and "gon"? 84. gone. For if I bidde thee "come to me," and thou come, after, whan I bidde thee "go," and thou go, thou reversest fro thy first 85-6. thee (twice). comming.'
'That is soth,' quod I.
'And yet,' quod she, 'in thy first alone, by dyvers reson, was 89. reasone. ful reversinge to understande.'
'As how?' quod I. 91. howe.
'That shal I shewe thee,' quod she, 'by ensample of thinges 92. the. that have kyndly moving. Is there any-thing that meveth more kyndly than doth the hevens eye, whiche I clepe the sonne?'
'Sothly,' quod I, 'me semeth it is most kyndly to move.'

'Thou sayest soth,' quod she. 'Than, if thou loke to the sonne, in what parte he be under heven, evermore he †hyeth him 97. heigheth; read hyeth. in moving fro thilke place, and †hyeth meving toward the ilke 98. higheth; read hyeth. towarde. same place; to thilke place from whiche he goth he †hyeth 99. gothe. heigheth; read hyeth. comminge; and without any ceesinge to that place he neigheth 100. ceasynge. from whiche he is chaunged and withdrawe. But now in these 101. nowe. thinges, after dyversitè of reson, revers in one thinge may be seye 102. reason. sey. without repugnaunce. Wherfore in the same wyse, without any repugnaunce, by my resons tofore maked, al is oon to beleve, 104. reasons. one. somthing to be thorow necessité comminge for it is comming, and 105. thorowe. yet with no necessitè constrayned to be comming, but with necessitè that cometh out of free wil, as I have sayd.'
Tho liste me a litel to speke, and gan stinte my penne of my 108. list. stynt. wryting, and sayde in this wyse. 109. sayd.

'Trewly, lady, as me thinketh, I can allege authoritees grete, 110. gret. that contrarien your sayinges. Job saith of mannes person, 111. sayenges. "thou hast put his terme, whiche thou might not passe." Than 112. putte. saye I that no man may shorte ne lengthe the day ordayned of 113. length. his †dying, altho[ugh] somtyme to us it semeth som man to do 114. doyng; read dying. some. a thing of free wil, wherthorow his deeth he henteth.' 115. thynge.-thorowe. dethe.

'Nay, forsothe,' quod she, 'it is nothing ayenst my saying; for 116. Naye. sayeng. god is not begyled, ne he seeth nothing wheder it shal come of libertè or els of necessitè; yet it is said to be ordayned at god immovable, whiche at man, or it be don, may be chaunged. 119. done. Suche thing is also that Poule the apostel saith of hem that tofore 120. saithe. toforne werne. wern purposed to be sayntes, as thus: "whiche that god before wiste and hath predestined conformes of images of his †sone, that 122. wyst. sonne; read sone. he shulde ben the firste begeten, that is to saye, here amonges
many brethren; and whom he hath predestined, hem he hath 124. brethern. cleped; and whom he hath cleped, hem he hath justifyed; and whom he hath justifyed, hem he hath magnifyed." This purpos, 126. purpose. after whiche they ben cleped sayntes or holy in the everlasting present, wher is neither tyme passed ne tyme comminge, but ever it is only present, and now as mokel a moment as sevin thousand 129. onely. nowe. thousande. winter; and so ayenward withouten any meving is nothing lich 130. ayenwarde. temporel presence for thinge that there is ever present. Yet amonges you men, er it be in your presence, it is movable thorow 132. thorowe. libertè of arbitrement. And right as in the everlasting present no maner thing was ne shal be, but only is; and now here, in 134. onely. nowe. your temporel tyme, somthing was, and is, and shal be, but movinge stoundes; and in this is no maner repugnaunce: right so, in the everlasting presence, nothing may be chaunged; and, in your temporel tyme, otherwhyle it is proved movable by libertè of wil or it be do, withouten any inconvenience therof to folowe. In your temporel tyme is no suche presence as in the tother; for your present is don whan passed and to come ginnen entre; 141. done. whiche tymes here amonges you everich esily foloweth other. 142. easely. But the presence everlasting dureth in oonhed, withouten any 143. onehed. imaginable chaunging, and ever is present and now. Trewly, the 144. nowe course of the planettes and overwhelminges of the sonne in dayes and nightes, with a newe ginning of his circute after it is ended, that is to sayn, oon yeer to folowe another: these maken your 147. one yere. transitory tymes with chaunginge of lyves and mutacion of people, 148. mutation. but right as your temporel presence coveiteth every place, and al thinges in every of your tymes be contayned, and as now both 150. nowe. seye and wist to goddes very knowinge.' 151. sey.

'Than,' quod I, 'me wondreth why Poule spak these wordes 152. spake. by voice of significacion in tyme passed, that god his sayntes 153. signification. before-wist hath predestined, hath cleped, hath justifyed, and hath magnifyed. Me thinketh, he shulde have sayd tho wordes 155. sayde. in tyme present; and that had ben more accordaunt to the everlasting present than to have spoke in preterit voice of passed understanding.'

'O,' quod Love, 'by these wordes I see wel thou hast litel 159. se. understanding of the everlasting presence, or els of my before
spoken wordes; for never a thing of tho thou hast nempned was tofore other or after other; but al at ones evenlich at the god ben, and al togider in the everlasting present be now to under∣standing. This eternal presence, as I sayd, hath inclose togider in one al tymes, in which close and one al thinges that ben in dyvers tymes and in dyvers places temporel, [and] without poste∣rioritè 166. I supply and. or prioritè ben closed ther in perpetual now, and maked 163, 167. nowe. 167. therin; read ther in. to dwelle in present sight. But there thou sayest that Poule shulde 168. dwel. have spoke thilke forsaid sentence †by tyme present, and that 169. be; read by. most shulde have ben acordaunt to the everlasting presence, why gabbest thou †in thy wordes? Sothly, I say, Poule moved 171. to; read in. the wordes by significacion of tyme passed, to shewe fully that thilk wordes were nat put for temporel significacion; for al [at] thilk 172-3. signification (twice). 173. I supply at. tyme [of] thilke sentence were nat temporallich born, whiche that 174. were nat thilke sentence; transpose, and insert of. borne. Poule pronounced god have tofore knowe, and have cleped, than magnifyed. Wherthorow it may wel be knowe that Poule used tho 176. Wherthorowe. know. wordes of passed significacion, for nede and lacke of a worde 177. signification. in mannes bodily speche betokeninge the everlasting presence. 178. spech. And therfore, [in] worde moste semeliche in lykenesse to ever∣lasting 179. I supply in; and omit is after worde. presence, he took his sentence; for thinges that here-beforn 180. toke. ben passed utterly be immovable, y-lyke to the everlasting 181. beforne. presence. As thilke that ben there never mowe not ben present, so thinges of tyme passed ne mowe in no wyse not ben passed; but al thinges in your temporal presence, that passen in a litel while, shullen ben not present. So than in that, it is more similitude to the everlasting presence, significacion of tyme passed 186. signification. than of tyme temporal present, and so more in accordaunce. In this maner what thing, of these that ben don thorow free arbitre∣ment, 188. thynge. done thorowe fre. or els as necessary, holy writ pronounceth, after eternitè he 189. writte. speketh; in whiche presence is everlasting sothe and nothing but sothe immovable; nat after tyme, in whiche naught alway ben your willes and your actes. And right as, while they be nat, it is nat nedeful hem to be, so ofte it is nat nedeful that somtyme they shulde be.'
'As how?' quod I; 'for yet I must be lerned by some ensample.'

'Of love,' quod she, 'wol I now ensample make, sithen I knowe 197. nowe.
the heed-knotte in that yelke. Lo! somtyme thou wrytest no art, ne art than in no wil to wryte. And right as while thou 199. arte (twice). wrytest nat or els wolt nat wryte, it is nat nedeful thee to wryte 200. the. or els wilne to wryte. And for to make thee knowe utterly that 201. the. thinges ben otherwise in the everlastinge presence than in temporal tyme, see now, my good child: for somthing is in the 203. se nowe. childe. somthynge. everlastinge presence, than in temporal tyme it was nat; in †eterne tyme, in eterne presence shal it nat be. Than no reson 205. eternite; read eterne. reason. defendeth, that somthing ne may be in tyme temporal moving, that in eterne is immovable. Forsothe, it is no more contrary ne revers for to be movable in tyme temporel, and [im]movable 208. movable (!). in eternitè, than nat to be in any tyme and to be alway in eternitè; and to have be or els to come in tyme temporel, and 210. and have to be. nat have be ne nought comming to be in eternitè. Yet never-the-later, I say nat somthing to be never in tyme temporel, that ever is [in] eternitè; but al-only in som tyme nat to be. For 213. I supply in. al onely. somtyme. I saye nat thy love to-morne in no tyme to be, but to-day alone I deny it to be; and yet, never-the-later, it is alway in eternitè.' 215. deny ne it; omit ne. alwaye.

'A! so,' quod I, 'it semeth to me, that comming thing or els passed here in your temporal tyme to be, in eternitè ever now 217. nowe. and present oweth nat to be demed; and yet foloweth nat thilke thing, that was or els shal be, in no maner ther to ben passed 219. thynge. thereto; read ther to. or els comming; than utterly shul we deny for there without ceesing it is, in his present maner.' 221. ceasyng.

'O,' quod she, 'myne owne disciple, now ginnest thou [be] 222. nowe. I supply be. able to have the name of my servaunt! Thy wit is clered; away 223. witte. is now errour of cloude in unconning; away is blyndnesse of 224. nowe. awaye. love; away is thoughtful study of medling maners. Hastely shalt thou entre in-to the joye of me, that am thyn owne 226. shalte. maistres! Thou hast (quod she), in a fewe wordes, wel and 227. haste. clerely concluded mokel of my mater. And right as there is no revers ne contrarioustee in tho thinges, right so, withouten 229. contrarioustie. any repugnaunce, it is sayd somthing to be movable in tyme temporel, †afore it be, that in eternité dwelleth immovable, nat 231. and for; read afore. afore it be or after that it is, but without cessing; for right naught is there after tyme; that same is there everlastinge that
temporalliche somtyme nis; and toforn it be, it may not be, as 234. toforne. maye. I have sayd.'

'Now sothly,' quod I, 'this have I wel understande; so that 236. Nowe. now me thinketh, that prescience of god and free arbitrement 237. nowe. fre. withouten any repugnaunce acorden; and that maketh the strength of eternitè, whiche encloseth by presence during al tymes, and al thinges that ben, han ben, and shul ben in any tyme. I wolde now (quod I) a litel understande, sithen that 241. nowe. [god] al thing thus beforn wot, whether thilke wetinge be of tho 242. I supply god. beforne. thinges, or els thilke thinges ben to ben of goddes weting, and so of god nothing is; and if every thing be thorow goddes weting, and 244. nothynge. thorowe. therof take his being, than shulde god be maker and auctour of badde werkes, and so he shulde not rightfully punisshe yvel doinges of mankynde.'

Quod Love, 'I shal telle thee, this lesson to lerne. Myne 248. tel the. owne trewe servaunt, the noble philosophical poete in Englissh, whiche evermore him besieth and travayleth right sore my name to encrese (wherfore al that willen me good owe to do him 251. encrease. worship and reverence bothe; trewly, his better ne his pere in scole of my rules coude I never fynde)—he (quod she), in a tretis 253. schole. treatise. that he made of my servant Troilus, hath this mater touched, and at the ful this question assoyled. Certaynly, his noble sayinges 255. sayenges. can I not amende; in goodnes of gentil manliche speche, without 256. gentyl manlyche. any maner of nycetè of †storiers imaginacion, in witte and in 257. nycite. starieres (!). good reson of sentence he passeth al other makers. In the boke 258. reason. of Troilus, the answere to thy question mayst thou lerne. Never-the-later, 259. mayste. yet may lightly thyne understandinge somdel ben lerned, 260. somdele. if thou have knowing of these to-fornsaid thinges; with that thou have understanding of two the laste chapiters of this seconde boke, that is to say, good to be somthing, and bad to wante al 263. want. maner being. For badde is nothing els but absence of good; and [as] that god in good maketh that good dedes ben good, 265. I supply as. in yvel he maketh that they ben but naught, that they ben bad; for to nothing is badnesse to be [lykned].' 267. I supply lykned.
'I have,' quod I tho, 'ynough knowing therin; me nedeth of other thinges to here, that is to saye, how I shal come to my 269. howe. blisse so long desyred.'

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER V.
DIV3.P: 'IN this mater toforn declared,' quod Love, 'I have wel shewed, that every man hath free arbitrement of thinges in CH. V. 2. fre. his power, to do or undo what him lyketh. Out of this grounde muste come the spire, that by processe of tyme shal in greetnesse 4. greatnesse. sprede, to have braunches and blosmes of waxing frute in grace, of whiche the taste and the savour is endelesse blisse, in joye 6. ioy. ever to onbyde.' A break here in Th.
'Now, trewly, lady, I have my grounde wel understonde; 8. Nowe. but what thing is thilke spire that in-to a tree shulde wexe? Expowne me that thing, what ye therof mene.' 10. meane.

'That shal I,' quod she, 'blithly, and take good hede to the wordes, I thee rede. Continuaunce in thy good service, by longe 12. the. processe of tyme in ful hope abyding, without any chaunge to wilne in thyne herte, this is the spire. Whiche, if it be wel kept and governed, shal so hugely springe, til the fruit of grace is 15. fruite. plentuously out-sprongen. For although thy wil be good, yet 16. al thoughe. may not therfore thilk blisse desyred hastely on thee discenden; 17. the. it must abyde his sesonable tyme. And so, by processe of growing, with thy good traveyle, it shal in-to more and more wexe, til it be found so mighty, that windes of yvel speche, ne scornes of envy, make nat the traveyle overthrowe; ne frostes of mistrust, ne hayles of jelousy right litel might have, in harming of suche springes. Every yonge setling lightly with smale stormes is apeyred; but whan it is woxen somdel in gretnesse, than han 24. somdele. grete blastes and †weders but litel might, any disadvantage to 25. great. wethers; read weders. them for to werche.'

'Myne owne soverayne lady,' quod I, 'and welth of myne herte, and it were lyking un-to your noble grace therthrough nat 28. hert. to be displesed, I suppose ye erren, now ye maken jelousy, envy, 29. displeased. nowe. and distourbour to hem that ben your servauntes. I have lerned ofte, to-forn this tyme, that in every lovers herte greet plentee of 31. to-forne. hert great plentie. jelousyes greves ben sowe, wherfore (me thinketh) ye ne ought in no maner accompte thilke thing among these other welked 33. thynge. wivers and venomous serpentes, as envy, mistrust, and yvel speche.'

'O fole,' quod she, 'mistrust with foly, with yvel wil medled, engendreth that welked padde! Truely, if they were distroyed, jelousy undon were for ever; and yet some maner of jelousy, 38. vndone. I wot wel, is ever redy in al the hertes of my trewe servauntes, as thus: to be jelous over him-selfe, lest he be cause of his own disese. This jelousy in ful thought ever shulde be kept, for 41. disease. ferdnesse to lese his love by miskeping, thorow his owne doing in 42. thorowe. leudnesse, or els thus: lest she, that thou servest so fervently, is beset there her better lyketh, that of al thy good service she compteth nat a cresse. These jelousies in herte for acceptable qualitees ben demed; these oughten every trewe lover, by kyndly [maner], evermore haven in his mynde, til fully the grace and 47. I supply maner. blisse of my service be on him discended at wil. And he that than jelousy caccheth, or els by wening of his owne folisshe 49. catcheth. wilfulnesse mistrusteth, truely with fantasy of venim he is foule 50. venyme. begyled. Yvel wil hath grounded thilke mater of sorowe in his leude soule, and yet nat-for-than to every wight shulde me nat truste, ne every wight fully misbeleve; the mene of these thinges 53. trust. meane. †oweth to be used. Sothly, withouten causeful evidence mistrust 54. owen; read oweth. in jelousy shulde nat be wened in no wyse person commenly; suche leude wickednesse shulde me nat fynde. He that is wyse and with yvel wil nat be acomered, can abyde wel his tyme, til grace and blisse of his service folowing have him so mokel esed, 58. eased. as his abydinge toforehande hath him disesed.' 59. diseased.

'Certes, lady,' quod I tho, 'of nothing me wondreth, sithen thilke blisse so precious is and kyndly good, and wel is and worthy in kynde whan it is medled with love and reson, as ye toforn 62. reason. have declared. Why, anon as hye oon is spronge, why springeth 63. one. sprong. nat the tother? And anon as the oon cometh, why receyveth nat 64. anone. one. the other? For every thing that is out of his kyndly place, by ful appetyt ever cometh thiderward kyndely to drawe; and his kyndly 66. appetite. thiderwarde. being ther-to him constrayneth. And the kyndly stede of this blisse is in suche wil medled to †onbyde, and nedes in that it 68. vnbyde; read onbyde. shulde have his kyndly being. Wherfore me thinketh, anon as that wil to be shewed and kid him profreth, thilke blisse shulde him 70. kydde. hye, thilk wil to receyve; or els kynde[s] of goodnesse worchen 71. kynde; read kyndes. nat in hem as they shulde. Lo, be the sonne never so fer, ever 72. ferre.
it hath his kynde werching in erthe. Greet weight on hye on-lofte 73. great. caried stinteth never til it come to †his resting-place. Waters 74. this; read his. to the see-ward ever ben they drawing. Thing that is light 75. see warde. blythly wil nat sinke, but ever ascendeth and upward draweth. Thus kynde in every thing his kyndly cours and his beinge-place 77. course. sheweth. Wherfore †by kynde, on this good wil, anon as it were 78. be; read by. spronge, this blisse shulde thereon discende; her kynde[s] wolde, 79. kynde; read kyndes. they dwelleden togider; and so have ye sayd your-selfe.' 80. sayde.

'Certes,' quod she, 'thyne herte sitteth wonder sore, this blisse for to have; thyne herte is sore agreved that it tarieth so longe; 81-2. hert. and if thou durstest, as me thinketh by thyne wordes, this blisse woldest thou blame. But yet I saye, thilke blisse is kyndly good, and his kyndely place [is] in that wil to †onbyde. Never-the-later, 85. I supply is. vnbyde; read onbyde. their comming togider, after kyndes ordinaunce, nat sodaynly may betyde; it muste abyde tyme, as kynde yeveth him leve. 87. maye. leaue. For if a man, as this wil medled gonne him shewe, and thilke blisse in haste folowed, so lightly comminge shulde lightly cause going. Longe tyme of thursting causeth drink to be the more 90. drinke. delicious whan it is atasted.'

'How is it,' quod I than, 'that so many blisses see I al day at 92. Howe. se. daye. myne eye, in the firste moment of a sight, with suche wil accorde? Ye, and yet other-whyle with wil assenteth, singulerly by him-selfe; there reson fayleth, traveyle was non; service had no tyme. This 95. reason. none. is a queynt maner thing, how suche doing cometh aboute.' 96. thynge howe.

'O,' quod she, 'that is thus. The erthe kyndely, after sesons 97. seasons. and tymes of the yere, bringeth forth innumerable herbes and 98. forthe. trees, bothe profitable and other; but suche as men might leve 99. leaue. (though they nought in norisshinge to mannes kynde serven, or 100. they were nought; omit were. els suche as tournen sone unto mennes confusion, in case that 101. soone. therof they ataste), comen forth out of the erthe by their owne 102. forthe. kynde, withouten any mannes cure or any businesse in traveyle. And the ilke herbes that to mennes lyvelode necessarily serven, without whiche goodly in this lyfe creatures mowen nat enduren, and most ben †norisshinge to mankynde, without greet traveyle, 106. norisshen; read norisshinge. greet tilthe, and longe abydinge-tyme, comen nat out of the erthe, 106-7. great (twice). and [y]it with sede toforn ordayned, suche herbes to make springe 108. it; read yit; see l. 111. seede toforne. spring.
and forth growe. Right so the parfit blisse, that we have in meninge 109. forthe. parfyte. meanynge. of during-tyme to abyde, may nat come so lightly, but with greet 110. great. traveyle and right besy tilth; and yet good seed to be sowe; for 111. seede. ofte the croppe fayleth of badde seede, be it never so wel traveyled. And thilke blisse thou spoke of so lightly in comming, trewly, is nat necessary ne abydinge; and but it the better be stamped, and the venomous jeuse out-wrongen, it is lykely to enpoysonen al tho that therof tasten. Certes, right bitter ben the herbes that shewen first [in] the yere of her own kynde. Wel the more is the 117. I supply in. harvest that yeldeth many graynes, tho longe and sore it hath ben traveyled. What woldest thou demen if a man wold yeve three quarters of nobles of golde? That were a precious gift?'

LG.L: 'Ye, certes,' quod I.
'And what,' quod she, 'three quarters ful of perles?' 119-122. thre (twice). 122. peerles.
'Certes,' quod I, 'that were a riche gift.'
'And what,' quod she, 'of as mokel azure?'
Quod I, 'a precious gift at ful.'
'Were not,' quod she, 'a noble gift of al these atones?' 123-6. gifte (thrice).

DIV3.P: 'In good faith,' quod I, 'for wanting of Englissh naming of so noble a worde, I can not, for preciousnesse, yeve it a name.'

'Rightfully,' quod she, 'hast thou demed; and yet love, knit 129. haste. knytte. in vertue, passeth al the gold in this erthe. Good wil, accordant 130. golde. to reson, with no maner propertè may be countrevayled. Al the 131. reason. azure in the worlde is nat to accompte in respect of reson. Love 132. respecte. that with good wil and reson accordeth, with non erthly riches 132-3. reason (twice). may nat ben amended. This yeft hast thou yeven, I know it my-selfe, and thy Margarite thilke gift hath receyved; in whiche thinge to rewarde she hath her-selfe bounde. But thy gift, as 136. gifte. I said, by no maner riches may be amended; wherfore, with thinge that may nat be amended, thou shalt of thy Margarites rightwisenesse be rewarded. Right suffred yet never but every good dede somtyme to be yolde. Al wolde thy Margarite with no rewarde thee quyte, right, that never-more dyeth, thy mede in 141. the. merit wol purvey. Certes, such sodayn blisse as thou first 142. sodayne. nempnest, right wil hem rewarde as thee wel is worthy; and 143. the. though at thyn eye it semeth, the reward the desert to passe, 144. rewarde. right can after sende suche bitternesse, evenly it to rewarde. So
that sodayn blisse, by al wayes of reson, in gret goodnesse may 146. sodayne. reason. not ben acompted; but blisse long, both long it abydeth, and endlesse it wol laste. See why thy wil is endelesse. For if thou 148. last. Se. lovedest ever, thy wil is ever ther t'abyde and neveremore to 149. tabyde. chaunge; evenhed of rewarde must ben don by right; than muste nedes thy grace and this blisse [ben] endelesse in joye to †onbyde. 151. I supply ben. ioy. vnbyde (!). Evenliche disese asketh evenliche joye, whiche hastely thou shalt 152. ioy. have.'

'A!' quod I, 'it suffyseth not than alone good wil, be it never so wel with reson medled, but-if it be in good service longe travayled. And so through service shul men come to the joye; and this, me thinketh, shulde be the wexing tree, of which ye first 157. tre. meved. A break here in Th.

DIV3.HEAD: CHAPTER VI.
DIV3.P: NOW, lady,' quod I, 'that tree to sette, fayn wolde I lerne.' CH. VI. 1. Nowe. set fayne. 'So thou shalt,' quod she, 'er thou depart hence. The first thing, thou muste sette thy werke on grounde siker and good, 3. set. accordaunt to thy springes. For if thou desyre grapes, thou goest not to the hasel; ne, for to fecchen roses, thou sekest not 5. fetchen. on okes; and if thou shalt have hony-soukels, thou levest the 6. leauest. frute of the soure docke. Wherfore, if thou desyre this blisse in parfit joye, thou must sette thy purpos there vertue foloweth, and 8. parfite ioy. set. purpose. not to loke after the bodily goodes; as I sayd whan thou were wryting in thy seconde boke. And for thou hast set thy-selfe in 10. booke. haste. so noble a place, and utterly lowed in thyn herte the misgoing of thy first purpos, this †setling is the esier to springe, and the more 12. purpose. setteles; read setling. lighter thy soule in grace to be lissed. And trewly thy desyr, 13. desyre. that is to say, thy wil algates mot ben stedfast in this mater with∣out 14. mote. any chaunginge; for if it be stedfast, no man may it voyde.'

'Yes, pardè,' quod I, 'my wil may ben turned by frendes, and 15-16. maye (twice). disese of manace and thretning in lesinge of my lyfe and of my 17. disease. limmes, and in many other wyse that now cometh not to mynde. 18. nowe. And also it mot ofte ben out of thought; for no remembraunce 19. mote. may holde oon thing continuelly in herte, be it never so lusty 20. one. desyred.'

'Now see,' quod she, 'thou thy wil shal folowe, thy free wil to 22. Nowe se. be grounded continuelly to abyde. It is thy free wil, that thou 22, 23. frewyl (twice). lovest and hast loved, and yet shal loven this Margaryte-perle; 24. haste. and in thy wil thou thinkest to holde it. Than is thy wil knit in love, not to chaunge for no newe lust besyde; this wil techeth 26. teacheth. thyn herte from al maner varying. But than, although thou be 27. varyeng. thretened in dethe or els in otherwyse, yet is it in thyn arbitre∣ment to chose, thy love to voyde or els to holde; and thilke arbitrement is in a maner a jugement bytwene desyr and thy 30. desyre. herte. And if thou deme to love thy good wil fayleth, than art 31. arte. thou worthy no blisse that good wil shulde deserve; and if thou chose continuaunce in thy good service, than thy good wil abydeth; nedes, blisse folowing of thy good wil must come by strength of thilke jugement; for thy first wil, that taught thyn herte to abyde, and halt it from th'eschaunge, with thy reson 36. halte. is accorded. Trewly, this maner of wil thus shal abyde; im∣possible it were to turne, if thy herte be trewe; and if every 38. hert. man diligently the meninges of his wil consider, he shal wel understande that good wil, knit with reson, but in a false herte 40. reason. never is voyded; for power and might of keping this good wil is thorow libertè of arbitrement in herte, but good wil to kepe 42. thorowe. hert. may not fayle. Eke than if it fayle, it sheweth it-selfe that good wil in keping is not there. And thus false wil, that putteth out the good, anon constrayneth the herte to accorde in lovinge of 45. anone. thy good wil; and this accordaunce bitwene false wil and thyn herte, in falsitè ben lykened †togider. Yet a litel wol I say 47. togyther. thee in good wil, thy good willes to rayse and strenghte. Tak 48. the. strength. Take. hede to me (quod she) how thy willes thou shalt understande. 49. howe. Right as ye han in your body dyvers membres, and fyve sondrye wittes, everiche apart to his owne doing, whiche thinges as instrumentes ye usen; as, your handes apart to handle; feet, 51-2. aparte (twice). 52. fete. to go; tonge, to speke; eye, to see: right so the soule hath 53. se. in him certayne steringes and strengthes, whiche he useth as instrumentes to his certayne doinges. Reson is in the soule, 55. Reason. which he useth, thinges to knowe and to prove; and wil, whiche he useth to wilne; and yet is neyther wil ne reson al the soule; 57. reason. but everich of hem is a thing by him-selfe in the soule. And
right as everich hath thus singuler instrumentes by hemselfe, they han as wel dyvers aptes and dyvers maner usinges; and thilke aptes mowen in wil ben cleped affeccions. Affeccion is 61. affections. Affection. an instrument of willinge in his apetytes. Wherfore mokel folk 62. folke. sayn, if a resonable creatures soule any thing fervently wilneth, affectuously he wilneth; and thus may wil, by terme of equivocas, in three wayes ben understande. Oon is instrument of willing; 65. thre. One. another is affection of this instrument; and the third is use, that setteth it a-werke.
