Enclyned is, but they ben charitable,
Pitous, devout, fulle of humilitee, 346. F. Pitouse devoute ful.
Shamfaste, debonaire, and amiable,
Dredful, and of hir wordes mesurable: 348. F. om. and.
What womman thise hath not, peraventure,
Ne solweth nat the wey of her nature. 350. F. hir.
Men seyn: 'our firste moder, natheles, 351. F. oure; Th. our. A. firste; F. Th. first.
Made al man-kynde lese his libertee,
And naked it of joye, douteles; 353. F. Ioy; Th. ioye.
For goddes hestes disobeyed she,
Whan she presumed tasten of a tree,
Which god forbad that she nat ete of sholde; 356. A. nat; F. ne.
And, nad the devel been, namore she wolde.' 357. F. nade; Th. ne had; A. nad. F. she ne wolde.
Th' envýous swelling that the feend, our fo, 358. F. The enviouse; Tr. Thenvyous. F. suellyng. F. fend.
Had unto man in herte, for his welthe, 359. Th. herte; F. D. hert. 359. F. Sent; hir.
Sente a serpent, and made her for to go
To disceyve Eve; and thus was mannes helthe 361. F. deceyve; Th. disceyue.
Beraft him by the fende, right in a stelthe,
The womman noght knowing of the deceyt; 363. F. woman.
God wot, ful fer was it from her conceyt. 364. F. Gode wote; hir.
Wherfore I sey, this godë womman Eve 365. F. good; Tr. goode. F. woman.
Our fader Adam ne deceyved noght.
Ther may no man for a deceyt it preve
Proprely, but-if that she, in her thoght,
Had it compassed first, er it was wroght; 369. F. er; A. Th. or.
And, for swich was nat her impressioun, 370. F. hir.
Men calle it may no déceyt, by resoun.
No wight deceyveth but he it purpóse;
The feend this déceyt caste, and nothing she. 373. F. cast.
Than is it wrong to demen or suppose 374. F. wronge.
That she sholde of this harm the cause be. 375. F. harme. A. of that gilt.
Wyteth the feend, and his be the maugree; 376. F. fende; mawgre.
And for excused have her innocence, 377. F. hir.
Sauf only that she brak obedience. 378. F. oonly. F. breeke; D. Th. brake.
And touching this, ful fewe men ther been, 379. F. that; Th. this. F. ben.
Unnethes any, dar I saufly seye—
Fro day to day, as that men mow wel seen, 381. A. D. mowe; T. mow; Th. may; F. now.
But that the hest of god they disobeye.
Have this in mynde, sires, I yow preye;
If that ye be discreet and resonable,
Ye wol her holde the more excusable. 385. A. Th. holde; F. hold.
And wher men seyn, 'in man is stedfastnesse, 386. F. Th. where; B. whan.
And woman is of her corage unstable,'
Who may of Adam bere swich witnesse? 388. F. swiche.
Telleth me this:—was he nat chaungeable?
They bothe weren in a caas semblable,
Sauf willingly the feend deceyved Eve, 391. A. F. feende; Tr. worme.
And so did she nat Adam, by your leve. 392. F. dide; Th. dyd.
Yet was this sinne happy to mankynde,
The feend deceyved was, for al his sleight; 394. F. feende.
For aught he coude him in his sleightes wynde, 395. F. sleythes; Th. sleyghtes; A. sleightes.
God, to discharge mankynde of the weight
Of his trespas, cam doun from hevenes height, 397. F. trespase; Th. trespace. F. the hevenes; A. Tr. S. Th. om. the.
And flesh and blood he took of a virgyne, 398. F. tooke.
And suffred deeth, him to deliver of pyne.
And god, to whom ther may nothing hid be,
If he in woman knowe had such malyce 401. F. suche.
As men of hem recorde in generaltee,
Of our lady, of lyf reparatryce, 403. F. Yf (for Of). F. lyfe.
Nolde han be born; but, for that she of vyce
Was voyde, and of al vertu (wel he wiste) 405. F. woyde; Th. voyde.
Endowed, of her to be bore him liste. 406. F. hir.
Her heped vertu hath swich excellence
That al to lene is mannes facultee 408. F. leene; Th. leane; S. low; A. weyke.
To déclare it, and therfor in suspence
Her duë preysing put mot nedes be. 410. Th. dewe. F. moot.
But this we witen verrayly, that she, 411. A. we witen; rest I sey. F. verraly.
Next god, the best frend is that to man longeth; 412. F. men (for man).
The key of mercy by her girdil hongeth. 413. F. mercye; hir girdille.
And of mercy hath every man swich nede 414. F. mercye.
That, cessing that, farwel the joye of man! 415. F. farewel; Ioy.
Of her power now taketh right good hede;
She mercy may, wol, and purchace can. 417. F. mercye.
Displese her nat, honoureth that womman, 418. F. honureth; Th. honoureth.
And other wommen alle, for her sake! 419. A. Tr. alle; F. al.
And, but ye do, your sorowe shal awake.
Thou precious gemme, O martir Margarete,
Of thy blood draddest noon effusioun!
Thy martirdom ne may I nat foryete; 423. F. martirdome. Th. Thou louer trewe, thou mayden mansuete.
Thou, constant womman in thy passioun,
Overcoom the feendes temptacioun; 425. F. feendis.
And many a wight converted thy doctryne
Unto the feith of god, holy virgyne! 427. From A; F. B. omit (!).
But understondeth, I commende hir noght
By enchesoun of hir virginitee;
Trusteth right wel, it cam not in my thoght; 430. A. nat; Tr. not; rest neuer.
For ever I werrey ayein chastitee, 431. F. om. I.
And ever shal; but this, lo! meveth me,
Her loving herte and constant to her lay 433. F. hert; hir.
Dryve out of rémembrauncë I ne may. 434. F. of my; Th. om. my.
In any boke also wher can ye fynde, 435. F. where.
That of the werkes or the dethe or lyf 436. F. werkis; lyfe.
Of Jesu speketh, or maketh any mynde,
That womman him forsook, for wo or stryf? 438. F. wommen (read womman, as in l. 442). F. stryfe.
Wher was ther any wight so ententyf 439. F. ententyfe.
Abouten him as wommen? Pardee, noon!
Th'apostels him forsoken, everichoon. 441. So Th.; F. B. forsoken hym.
Womman forsook him noght; for al the feyth 442. F. forsooke.
Of holy chirche in womman lefte only. 443. F. left oonly.
This is no lees, for holy writ thus seyth; 444. Tr. holy wryt thus; F. thus holy wryt.
Loke, and ye shal so fynde it, hardely. 445. F. Lok.
And therfore it may preved be therby, 446. So A.; F. B. I may wel preve herby.
That in womman regneth stable constaunce
And in men is the chaunge and variaunce! 435-448. Precedes 421-434 in Th. 447-448. F. constance, variance.
Now holdeth this for ferme and for no lye,
That this trewe and just commendacioun 450. F. trew; Th. trewe.
Of wommen is nat told for flaterye, 451. A. is nat told for; F. tolde I nat for; Th. tel I for no.
Ne to cause hem pryde or elacioun,
But only, lo! for this entencioun, 453. F. oonly loo.
To yeve hem corage of perseveraunce
In vertu, and hir honour to enhaunce. 455. F. honure; Th. honour. Th. auaunce.
The more vertu, the lasse is the pryde;
Vertu so digne is, and so noble in kynde
That vyce and she wol not in-fere abyde. 458. A. S. she; rest he.
She putteth vyce clene out of her mynde,
She fleeth from him, she leveth him behynde. 459, 460. A. S. She; rest He. S. hir; F. hi (!); rest his.
O womman, that of vertu art hostesse, 461. F. wertu.
Greet is thyn honour and thy worthinesse! 462. F. Gret; honor.
Than wol we thus concluden and diffyne:
We yow comaunde, our ministres, echoon 464. F. oure; echon.
That redy been to our hestes enclyne, 465. F. oure.
That of thise false men, our rebel foon, 466. F. D. om. false. F. reble; Th. rebel.
Ye do punisshëment, and that anoon!
Voide hem our court and banish hem for ever
So that ther-inne they ne come never. 469. A. ynne; F. in. F. more neuer; A. om. more.
Fulfilled be it, cessing al delay;
Look that ther be non excusacioun. 471. S. Tr. that; rest om.
Writen in th'ayr, the lusty month of May, 472. F. the ayer; A. their; Tr. theyre. F. moneth.
In our paleys (wher many a millioun 473. F. oure; where; milion.
Of loveres trewe han habitacioun) 474. F. louers trwe.
The yere of grace joyful and jocounde 475. F. Iocunde.
A thousand and foure hundred and secounde.

DIV1.TRAILER: Explicit litera Cupidinis, dei amoris, directa suis sub∣ditis amatoribus. COLOPHON. D.T. amatoribus; F. om. B. has—The lettre of Cupide, god of love, directed to his suggestys louers.

DIV1.HEAD: VII. A MORAL BALADE. From Th. (Thynne, ed. 1542); collated with A. (Ashmole 59), and Cx. (Caxton); readings also given from H. (Harl. 2251).

Here foloweth next a Moral Balade, to my lord the Prince, to my lord of Clarence, to my lord of Bedford, and to my lord of Gloucestre, by Henry Scogan; at a souper of feorthe merchande in the Vyntre in London, at the hous of Lowys Johan. TITLE; from A. (which has folowethe nexst); Cx. has Here next foloweth a tretyse, whiche John Skogan sente vnto the lordes and gentilmen of the kynges hows, exortyng them to lose no tyme in theyr yougthe, but to vse vertues; Th. has Scogan vnto the lordes and gentylmen of the kynges house.

LG.L: MY noble sones, and eek my lordes dere, 1. Th. A. sonnes.
I, your fader called, unworthily, 2. Th. A. vnworthely.
Sende un-to you this litel tretys here 3. Th. lytel treatyse; A. balade folowing.
Writen with myn owne hand full rudëly; 4. Th. with; A. H. of.
Although it be that I not reverently 5. Th. H. Although; Cx. And though; A. Yitte howe.
Have writen to your estats, yet I you praye, 6. Th. A. estates. A. yet; H. Th. Cx. om.
Myn unconning taketh benignëly
For goddes sake, and herken what I seye. 8. Cx. herkne (better).
I complayn sore, whan I remembre me 9. Th. me sore; A. H. om. me.
The sodeyn age that is upon me falle; 10. A. H. falle; Th. fal.
More I complayn my mispent juventè 11. Th. But more; A. H. Cx. om. But. Th. iuuentute.
The whiche is impossible ayein to calle. 12. Th. ayen for; A. ageine. A. H. calle; Th. cal.
But certainly, the most complaynte of alle 13. Th. H. certainly; A. comvnely. Th. A. moste. A. H. alle; Th. al.
Is for to thinke, that I have been so nyce 14. A. H. for; Th. om. A. beon; Th. be.
That I ne wolde no virtue to me calle 15. A. H. no; Th. om. A. vertue; Th. vertues. A. calle; Th. cal.
In al my youthe, but vyces ay cheryce. 16. A. ay; Th. aye.
Of whiche I aske mercy of thee, lord, 17. A. thee; Th. the. Th. lorde.
That art almighty god in majestè, 18. Th. H. god; A. lorde.
Beseking thee, to make so even accord
Betwix thee and my soule, that vanitè 20. Th. Betwyxe; A. Bytwene.
Of worldly lust, ne blynd prosperitè 21. A. H. Of; Th. Cx. om. Th. blynde.
Have no lordship over my flesshe so frele. 22. A. so freel; Th. H. to frele.
Thou lord of reste and parfit unitè, 23. Th. lorde; perfyte.
Put fro me vyce, and keep my soules hele. 24. A. H. Cx. soules; Th. soule.
And yeve me might, whyl I have lyf and space, 25. Th. whyle; lyfe.
Me to conforme fully to thy plesaunce; 26. A. H. confourme; Th. confyrme (!).
Shewe upon me th'abundaunce of thy grace, 27. A. H. vpon; Th. to.
In gode werkes graunt me perséveraunce. 28. Th. And in; A. H. om. And.
Of al my youthe forget the ignoraunce;
Yeve me good wil, to serve thee ay to queme; 30. A. thee; Th. the.
Set al my lyf after thyn ordinaunce, 31. Th. lyfe. A. H. thy governaunce.
And able me to mercy, or thou deme!
My lordes dere, why I this complaint wryte
To you, alle whom I love entierly, 34. A. alle whome; Cx. whom that; Th. whom. Th. moste entyrely; Cx. A. entierly.
Is for to warne you, as I can endyte,
That tyme y-lost in youthe folily 36. A. eloste; Th. loste; H. Cx. lost.
Greveth a wight goostly and bodily, 37. A. H. goostely and bodely; Th. Cx. bodily and gostly.
I mene hem that to lust and vyce entende. 38. Th. meane.
Wherfore, I pray you, lordes, specially, 39. A. I prey you lordes; Th. lordes I pray you. A. tendrely.
Your youthe in vertue shapeth to dispende.
Planteth the rote of youthe in suche a wyse 41. Cx. transposes 41-80 and 81-125. A. Plantethe; Th. Cx. Plante.
That in vertue your growing be alway;
Loke ay, goodnesse be in your exercyse, 43. A. ay; Th. alway.
That shal you mighty make, at eche assay,
The feend for to withstonde at eche affray. 45. Cx. The frende (!) for to withstonde; A. For to withstonde the feonde; Th. The fende to withstande.
Passeth wysly this perilous pilgrimage, 46. Th. peryllous; H. perilous.
Thinke on this word, and werke it every day; 47. H. Th. Cx. werke; A. vse.
That shal you yeve a parfit floured age. 48. Th. parfyte.
Taketh also hede, how that these noble clerkes
Write in hir bokes of gret sapience, 50. Th. Writen; A. Wrote. Th. her. Th. great; H. grete; A. noble.
Saying, that fayth is deed withouten werkes;
So is estat withoute intelligence 52. So A.; Th. And right so is estate with negligence.
Of vertue; and therfore, with diligence,
Shapeth of vertue so to plante the rote,
That ye therof have ful experience,
To worship of your lyfe and soules bote.
Taketh also hede, that lordship ne estat, 57. A. Then kepe also that.
Withoute vertue, may not longe endure; 58. Cx. A. Withoute; Th. Without.
Thinketh eek how vyce and vertue at debat 59. Cx. vice; A. H. Th. vices.
Have been, and shal, whyles the world may dure; 60. A. whiles; Th. while. Th. worlde.
And ay the vicious, by aventure, 61. A. H. ay; Th. Cx. euer.
Is overthrowe; and thinketh evermore
That god is lord of vertue and figure 63. Th. lorde of al; H. A. lord of.
Of al goodnesse; and therfore folowe his lore.
My mayster Chaucer, god his soulë have!
That in his langage was so curious,
He sayde, the fader whiche is deed and grave, 67. Th. sayd that the; A. saide that the; H. Cx. om. that. Th. father; A. H. fader.
Biquath nothing his vertue with his hous 68. H. A. Beqwath; Th. Byqueth. Th. house.
Unto his sone; therfore laborious 69. So A. Cx.; Th. children and therefore laborouse.
Ought ye to be, beseching god, of grace, 70. H. Th. Ought; A. Aught; Cx. Owe. Th. om. to. Th. besekyng; A. beseching.
To yeve you might for to be vertuous,
Through which ye might have part of his fayr place. 72. Th. haue; A. H. gete. Th. parte. A. feyre; Th. H. om.
Here may ye see that vertuous noblesse
Cometh not to you by way of auncestrye, 74. A. Comþe.
But it cometh thorugh leefful besinesse 75. A. thorugh; Cx. thurgh; Th. by. A. leofful; Th. leful; H. leeful.
Of honest lyfe, and not by slogardrye.
Wherfore in youthe I rede you edefye 77. Th. you ye; A. H. om. ye.
The hous of vertue in so wys manere 78. Th. house. A. soo wyse; Th. H. suche a.
That in your age it may you kepe and gye 79. Th. om. it.
Fro the tempest of worldly wawes here. 80. H. A. worldly; Th. worldes.
Thinketh how, betwixë vertue and estat 81. Th. howe betwyxe; A. howe bytwene.
There is a parfit blessed mariage; 82. Th. parfyte.
Vertue is cause of pees, vyce of debat
In mannes soule; for which, with ful corage, 84. H. A. for whiche with full; Th. the whiche be ful of.
Cherissheth vertue, vyces to outrage: 85. Th. than vertue; A. om. than.
Dryveth hem away; let hem have no wonning 86. A. Cx. om. 1st hem.
In your soules; leseth not the heritage 87. A. leese; H. lesith.
Which god hath yeve to vertuous living.
Taketh hede also, how men of povre degree 89. Th. howe. A. poure; Th. poore.
Through vertue have be set in greet honour,
And ever have lived in greet prosperitee 90, 91. Th. great.
Through cherisshing of vertuous labour. 92. Th. H. Through; A. By.
Thinketh also, how many a governour
Called to estat, hath oft be set ful lowe 94. Th. H. Called; A. Calde. A. offt; H. Th. Cx. om.
Through misusing of right, and for errour, 95. A. for; Th. H. Cx. of.
Therfore I counsaile you, vertue to knowe. 96. Th. And therfore; rest om. And.
Thus 'by your eldres may ye nothing clayme,' 97. A. By auncetrye thus; Th. H. Thus by your auncestres; Cx. Thus by your eldres.
As that my mayster Chaucer sayth expresse,
'But temporel thing, that man may hurte and mayme'; 99. Th. men (for man).
Than is god stocke of vertuous noblesse; 100. Cx. Than god is.
And sith that he is lord of blessednesse, 101. Th. sythe; lorde. Th. blyssednesse; A. blessednesse.
And made us alle, and for us alle deyde, 102. A. That (for And). A. H. alle; Th. al (1). Cx. alle; Th. al (2). For us alle A. has mankynde that.
Folowe his vertue with ful besinesse, 103. So A.; Th. H. Foloweth hym in vertue.
And of this thing herke how my mayster seyde:—
The firste stok, fader of gentilesse,
What man that claymeth gentil for to be
Must folowe his trace, and alle his wittes dresse
Vertu to sewe, and vyces for to flee.
For unto vertu longeth dignitee,
And noght the revers, saufly dar I deme,
Al were he mytre, croune, or diademe.
This firste stok was ful of rightwisnesse,
Trewe of his word, sobre, pitous, and free,
Clene of his goste, and loved besinesse
Ageinst the vyce of slouthe, in honestee;
And, but his heir love vertu, as dide he,
He is noght gentil, though he riche seme,
Al were he mytre, croune, or diademe.
Vyce may wel be heir to old richesse;
But ther may no man, as men may wel see,
Bequethe his heir his vertuous noblesse;
That is appropred unto no degree,
But to the firste fader in magestee
That maketh him his heir, that can him queme,
Al were he mytre, croune, or diademe. 105-125. Chaucer's poem of Gentilesse is here quoted; see vol. i. p. 392.
Lo here, this noble poete of Bretayne
How hyely he, in vertuous sentence, 127. A. Howe hyely he; Th. Howe lightly.
The losse in youthe of vertue can complayne; 128. A. lesse (!); Th. losse. A. H. in; Th. on.
Wherfore I pray you, dooth your diligence, 129. A. Wherfore; Th. And therefore. A. doothe; Th. with (!).
For your estats and goddes reverence, 130. A. estates; Th. profyte.
T'enprintë vertue fully in your mynde, 131. A. Tenprynte; Th. Tempereth (!). A. H. vertue fully; Th. fully vertue.
That, whan ye come in your juges presence, 132. Cx. in; A. H. in-to; Th. to.
Ye be not set as vertules behynde. 133. A. H. sette as vertu∣lesse; Th. vertulesse than.
Ye lordes have a maner now-a-dayes, 134. H. Cx. Ye; A. For yee; Th. Many. Th. A. nowe.
Though oon shewe you a vertuous matere, 135. Cx. H. you; Th. hem. A. Thaughe one of you here of a gode matere.
Your fervent youthe is of so false alayes 136. Cx. H. Your feruent; Th. Her feruent; A. Your vnsure.
That of that art ye have no joy to here. 137. Th. arte. Cx. H. ye; Th. they. A. That of suche artes you liste not to.
But, as a ship that is withouten stere 138. Cx. A. withouten; Th. without a.
Dryveth up and doun, withouten governaunce, 139. A. withouten; Th. without.
Wening that calm wol lastë, yeer by yere, 140. Th. calme. A. wol laste you; Th. wolde last. Th. yere by yere.
Right so fare ye, for very ignoraunce. 141. Cx. A. H. ye; Th. they.
For very shamë, knowe ye nat, by réson 142. Cx. A. H. ye; Th. they.
That, after an ebbe, ther cometh a flood ful rage? 143. A. Cx. om. ful.
In the same wyse, whan youth passeth his séson, 144. A. Right euen so whane.
Cometh croked and unweldy palled age; 145. A. Comthe.
Sone after comen kalends of dotage; 146. A. Soone; Th. And sone. Th. comen the; Cx. come; A. comthe.
And if your youth no vertue have provyded, 147. Th. if that; Cx. A. H. om. that. Cx. A. your; Th. her. A. H. no vertue haue; Cx. no vertue hath; Th. haue no vertue.
Al men wol saye, fy on your vassalage! 148. Th. fye. Cx. A. your; Th. her.
Thus hath your slouth fro worship you devyded. 149. A. H. your; Th. her. Cx. H. you; Th. hem. A. has Thus hathe youre youthe and slouthe you al misgyded.
Boëce the clerk, as men may rede and see,
Saith, in his Boke of Consolacioun,
What man desyreth †have of vyne or tree 152. Cx. A. H. to haue; Th. om. (read haue).
Plentee of fruit, in the ryping sesoun, 153. A. Plenty of; Cx. Plentyuous; Th. Plentous. Th. fruite. A. H. Cx. the; Th. om. A. H. Cx. riping; Th. reapyng.
Must ay eschewe to doon oppressioun 154. A. H. Cx. ay; Th. euer. A. doon; Th. do.
Unto the rote, whyle it is yong and grene;
Ye may wel see, by this conclusioun, 156. A. H. Cx. Yee may; Th. Thus may ye. A. H. wele see; Cx. see; Th. se wel. A. H. this; Th. that. A. Cx. conclusioun; Th. inclusyon (!).
That youthë vertulees doth mochel tene. 157. A. youthe; Th. youth. A. Th. vertu∣lesse. Th. moche; Cx. ofte muche; A. ay michil (read mochel).
Seeth, there-ayenst, how vertuous noblesse 158. Th. Nowe seeth; A. H. Cx. om. Nowe. Th. howe; A. that.
Roted in youthe, with good perséveraunce, 159. A. youthe; Th. youth.
Dryveth away al vyce and wrecchednesse, 160. A. Cx. vyce; H. vice; Th. vyces.
As slogardrye, ryote and distaunce! 161. A. Al (for As). A. al ryote; H. Cx. Th. om. al.
Seeth eek how vertue causeth suffisaunce, 162. Th. eke howe.
And suffisaunce exyleth coveityse! 163. So A. Cx.; H. om; Th. has Seeth eke howe vertue voydeth al vyce (!).
And who hath vertue hath al abundaunce 164. Th. H. Cx. whoso; A. om. so.
Of wele, as fer as reson can devyse. 165. Th. ferre; A. far. Th. reason.
Taketh hede of Tullius Hostilius,
That cam fro povertee to hy degree; 167. A. came frome pouertee; Th. fro pouert came. Th. hygh; A. hye.
Through vertue redeth eek of Julius 168. Th. eke.
The conquerour, how povre a man was he; 169. Th. howe poore.
Yet, through his vertue and humanitee, 170. A. H. Cx. humanite; Th. his humylite.
Of many a countree had he governaunce. 171. Th. om. a.
Thus vertue bringeth unto greet degree 172. A. unto gret; Cx. to hye; Th. a man to great.
Eche wight that list to do him entendaunce. 173. A. Cx. list; Th. H. lust. Th. enten∣daunce; rest attendaunce.
Rede, here-ayenst, of Nero vertulees; 174. Th. nowe of; A. H. Cx. om. nowe.
Taketh hede also of proude Balthasar;
They hated vertue, equitee, and pees.
Loke how Antiochus fil fro his char, 177. Th. And loke; rest om. And. Th. howe; chare.
That he his skin and bones al to-tar! 178. Th. tare.
Loke what meschauncë they had for hir vyces! 179. A. meschaunces.
Who-so that wol not by these signes be war, 180. Th. H. Cx. om. that. Th. ware.
I dar wel say, infortunat or nyce is. 181. A. Th. infortunate. A. H. Cx. or; Th. and.
I can no more; but here-by may ye see 182. Th. no more nowe say; Cx. no more say; H. no more; A. more (!). Th. herby; se.
How vertue causeth parfit sikernesse, 183. A. Th. Howe. A. Th. perfyte.
And vyces doon exyle prosperitee; 184. A. done exyle; Th. H. exylen al; Cx. exyles al.
The best is, ech to chesen, as I gesse. 185. Th. eche man to; Cx. man to; A. dethe to ( dethe is put for eche). A. cheesen; Th. chose.
Doth as you list, I me excuse expresse; 186. Th. A. Dothe.
I wolde be sory, if that ye mischese. 187. A. Cx. wil (for wolde). Th. right sorie; A. H. Cx. om. right.
God you conferme in vertuous noblesse, 188. A. you conferme; Th. confyrme you.
So that through negligence ye nothing lese! 189. A. no thing; Cx. H. nothing; Th. not it.

DIV1.TRAILER: Explicit. COLOPHON. Cx. Thus endeth the traytye wiche John Skogan sent to the lordes and estates of the kynges hous.

DIV1.HEAD: VIII. JOHN LYDGATE. From Th. (Thynne, ed. 1532); collated with F. (Fairfax 16); B. (Bodley 638, imperfect); T. (Tanner 346); D. (Digby 181); S. (Arch. Selden B. 24); I have also consulted Ad. (Addit. 16165); and P. (Pepys 2006).
THE COMPLAINT OF THE BLACK KNIGHT; OR, THE COMPLAINT OF A LOVERES LYFE.

LG.L: IN May, whan Flora, the fresshe lusty quene,
The soile hath clad in grene, rede, and whyte, 2. Th. reed; F. D. rede.
And Phebus gan to shede his stremes shene
Amid the Bole, with al the bemes brighte, 4. S. his (for 2nd the).
And Lucifer, to chace awey the night, 5. Th. away; F. awey.
Ayen the morowe our orizont hath take 6. Th. D. orizont; F. T. S. orisont.
To bidde lovers out of hir sleepe awake, 7. Th. bidde al; MSS. om. al. F. T. om. lovers.
And hertes hevy for to recomforte
From dreriheed of hevy nightes sorowe,
Nature bad hem ryse, and hem disporte, 10. Th. bade. F. T. D. S. om. 2nd hem.
Ayen the goodly, gladde, greye morowe; 11. D. gladde; rest glad. All grey (or gray).
And Hope also, with seint Johan to borowe,
Bad, in dispyt of daunger and dispeyre, 13. Th. Bade; MSS. Bad. All dispyte (dispite).
For to take the hoolsom lusty eyre: 14. S. go take (rest om. go).
And with a sigh I gan for to abreyde 15. Th. syghe.
Out of my slombre, and sodainly up sterte 16. F. out stert.
As he, alas! that nigh for sorowe deyde,
My sekenes sat ay so nigh my herte. 18. Th. sicknesse; MSS. sekenes. F. S. sat; rest sate. Th. aye. Th. nye.
But, for to finde socour of my smerte,
Or at the leste som réles of my peyne, 20. F. atte; T. at; rest at the. S. sum; rest some, summe. P. reles; D. relece; T. relese; F. relesse; Th. release.
That me so sore halt in every veyne, 21. F. halt; Th. halte.
I roos anon, and thoghte I wolde goon 22. T. S. roos; rest rose. Th. thought.
Into the wode, to here the briddes singe, 23. Th. wodde; S. wod; rest wode. Th. byrdes.
Whan that the misty vapour was agoon 24. Th. T. D. vapoure; F. S. vapour. F. D. agoon; T. Th. agone.
And clere and faire was the morowning; 25. F morownyng; T. morownynge; Th. moronyng.
The dewe also, lyk silver in shyning 26. Th. lyke; F. lykyng (!); rest like; read lyk.
Upon the leves, as any baume swete, 27. Th. leaues.
Til fyry Tytan, with his persaunt hete,
Had dryed up the lusty licour newe
Upon the herbes in the grene mede,
And that the floures, of many dyvers hewe,
Upon hir stalkes gonne for to sprede 32. F. the (for hir).
And for to splaye[n] out hir leves on-brede 33. Th. D. splaye; F. T. S. splay; read splayen. F. S. on; rest in.
Agayn the sonne, gold-burned in his spere, 34. Th. T. Agayne; F. Ageyn; D. Ayen. S. gold; rest golde.
That doun to hem caste his bemes clere. 35. Th. T. downe; F. dovn; D. down; S. doun.
And by a river forth I gan costey 36. Th. forthe.
Of water clere as berel or cristal 37. F. berel; S. beriall; Th. byrel; T. byrell; D. birele.
Til at the laste I found a litel wey
Toward a park, enclosed with a wal 39. D. S. Toward; F. Tovard; Th. T. Towarde.
In compas rounde, and by a gate smal 40. Th. compace; MSS. compas.
Who-so that wolde frely mighte goon 41. T. myghte; S. michty (!); rest might. Th. gone; F. goon.
Into this park, walled with grene stoon. 42. S. park; rest parke.
And in I wente, to here the briddes song, 43. T. wente; rest went. Th. byrdes; rest briddes. S. song; rest songe.
Whiche on the braunches, bothe in playn and vale, 44. Th. branches; F. T. D. braunches. Th. and (correctly); rest omit.
So loude songe, that al the wode rong 45. Th. sange; S. sang; P. song; F. T. D. songe. Th. woode. S. P. rong; rest ronge.
Lyke as it shulde shiver in peces smale;
And, as me thoughte, that the nightingale 47. T. thoughte; Th. F. D. thought.
With so gret mighte her voys gan out-wreste 48. T. myghte; rest might. T. D. wraste; S. brest; Th. F. wrest.
Right as her herte for love wolde breste. 49. T. breste; D. braste; Th. F. brest; S. to-brest.
The soil was playn, smothe, and wonder softe
Al oversprad with tapites that Nature 51. F. T. P. tapites; Th. D. tapettes.
Had mad her-selve, celured eek alofte 52. Th. F. T. -selfe (better selve). F. celured; D. coloured; S. siluered; Th. T. couered.
With bowes grene, the floures for to cure,
That in hir beautè they may longe endure 54. Th. beautie. F. T. may not (for may).
From al assaut of Phebus fervent fere, 55. S. assaut; rest assaute.
Whiche in his spere so hote shoon and clere. 56. Th. sphere; hotte. Th. F. T. D. shone (read shoon).
The eyre attempre, and the smothe wind
Of Zepherus, among the blossomes whyte, 58. S. P. among; rest amonge. T. blossomes; D. blossoms; Th. blosomes; F. blosmes.
So hoolsom was and norisshing by kind, 57, 59. S. wynd, kynd; rest wynde, kynde. 59. All holsom (holsum). Th. F. T. D. and so; S. om. so.
That smale buddes, and rounde blomes lyte 60. F. T. blomes; S. blomys; Th. blosmes; D. blossoms.
In maner gonnen of her brethe delyte 61. All gan, can; see l. 579.
To yeve us hope that hir fruit shal take, 62. S. that; rest om. F. their; T. theire; Th. D. there; S. thai; read hir.
Ayens autumpne, redy for to shake. 63. F. D. Ayens; Th. Ayenst; T. Agayne.
I saw ther Daphne, closed under rinde, 64. T. S. saw; Th. F. D. sawe (!). F. ther; rest the; cf. l. 71. S. Daphin; rest Daphene; read Daphne.
Grene laurer, and the hoolsom pyne; 65. Th. holsome; rest holsom (-sum).
The myrre also, that wepeth ever of kinde;
The cedres hye, upright as a lyne;
The philbert eek, that lowe doth enclyne 68. F. phibert; Th. T. filberte; D. filberde; S. filbard. Th. F. dothe.
Her bowes grene to the erthe adoun 69. Th. S. adoun; rest doun.
Unto her knight, y-called Demophoun. 70. F. I-called; rest called.
Ther saw I eek the fresshe hawëthorn 71. Th. T. D. sawe. P. hawethorn; rest hawthorn, hawthorne, hauthorne.
In whyte motlè, that so swote doth smelle, 72. S. motle; F. motele; rest motley. (Read swoot?). Th. dothe smel.
Ash, firre, and ook, with many a yong acorn, 73. All Asshe; read Ash. All oke; read ook. S. ȝong; T. fressh (!); rest yonge. S. accorne; rest acorne.
And many a tree—mo than I can telle; 74. Th. tel.
And, me beforn, I saw a litel welle, 75. S. beforn; D. before; rest beforne. Th. sawe; wel.
That had his cours, as I gan beholde, 76. T. cours; S. courss; rest course.
Under an hille, with quikke stremes colde. 77. Th. hyl; quicke streames.
The gravel gold, the water pure as glas, 78. S. P. gold; D. colde; rest golde
The bankes rounde, the welle envyroning; 79. wel.
And softe as veluët the yonge gras 78, 80. F. glas, gras; Th. glasse, grasse. 80. Ad. velowet.
That therupon lustily cam springing; 81. Th. T. D. lustely (T. lustily) came (cam) springyng; F. lustely gan syng (!); S. lustily gan spryng.
The sute of trees aboute compassing
Hir shadowe caste, closing the welle rounde, 83. Th. F. wel; T. D. welle.
And al the herbes growing on the grounde.
The water was so hoolsom and vertuous 85. From this point I silently correct obvious errors in spelling of Th. by collation with the MSS. Th. holsome. S. and; rest and so.
Through might of herbes growing there besyde, 86. Th. Thorowe. S. there; rest omit.
Not lyk the welle, wher-as Narcisus 87. F. T. D. Narcius (!).
Y-slayn was, through vengeaunce of Cupyde,
Where so covertly he didë hyde 89. T. dyde; rest dyd, did.
The grayn of cruel dethe upon ech brinke, 90. S. cruell; rest omit.
That deeth mot folowe, who that ever drinke;
Ne lyk the pittë of the Pegacè
Under Pernaso, where poetës slepte;
Nor lyk the welle of pure chastitè 87, 92, 94. I read lyk for lyke.
Which that Dyane with her nymphes kepte, 95. Th. that; rest as. F. T. P. his; rest her.
Whan she naked into the water lepte,
That slow Acteon with his houndes felle
Only for he cam so nigh the welle!
Bút this welle, that I here reherce,
So hoolsom was, that it wolde aswage
Bollen hertes, and the venim perce 101. S. perce; D. perce; Th. peerce; F. T. perysh (!)
Of pensifheed, with al the cruel rage,
And evermore refresshe the visage 103. Th. ouermore (!).
Of hem that were in any werinesse
Of greet labour, or fallen in distresse.
And I, that had, through daunger and disdayne,
So drye a thrust, thoughte I wolde assaye 107. Th. F. thrust; T. thurste; P. D. thurst.
To taste a draughte of this welle, or twayne,
My bitter langour if it mighte alaye;
And on the banke anon adoun I lay, 110. S. adoun; Th. F. P. downe; rest down, doun.
And with myn heed unto the welle I raughte,
And of the water drank I a good draughte;
Wherof, me thought, I was refresshed wele
Of the brenning that sat so nigh my herte,
That verily anon I gan to fele
An huge part relesed of my smerte;
And therwithallë anon up I sterte,
And thoughte I wolde walke, and see more
Forth in the parke, and in the holtes hore.
And through a laundë as I yede a-pace
And gan aboute faste to beholde,
I found anon a délitable place 122. Th. delect∣able.
That was beset with treës yonge and olde,
Whose names here for me shal not be tolde;
Amidde of whiche stood an herber grene,
That benched was, with colours newe and clene. 113-126. S. omits.
This herber was ful of floures inde, 127. D. ynde; T. Iende; F. cende (?); Th. gende; S. of Inde.
In-to the whiche as I beholde gan,
Betwix an hulfere and a wodëbinde,
As I was war, I saw wher lay a man
In blakke and whyte colour, pale and wan,
And wonder deedly also of his hewe,
Of hurtes grene and fresshe woundes newe.
And overmore distrayned with sekenesse,
Besyde al this, he was, ful grevously;
For upon him he had an hoot accesse,
That day by day him shook ful pitously;
So that, for constreynt of his malady 138. S. constreynt; rest constraynyng.
And hertly wo, thus lying al alone,
It was a deeth for to here him grone.
Wherof astonied, my foot I gan withdrawe,
Greetly wondring what it mighte be
That he so lay, and hadde no felawe,
Ne that I coude no wight with him see;
Wherof I hadde routhe, and eek pitè,
And gan anon, so softely as I coude,
Among the busshes me prively to shroude; 147. Th. priuely me; rest me priuely. (Read busshes prively me shroude?).
If that I mighte in any wyse espye
What was the cause of his deedly wo,
Or why that he so pitously gan crye
On his fortune, and on his ure also; 151. Th. om. 2nd his.
With al my might I layde an ere to,
Every word to marke, what he seyde,
Out of his swough among as he abrayde. 154. For among perhaps read anon.
But first, if I shulde make mencioun
Of his persone, and plainly him discryve,
He was in sothe, without excepcioun,
To speke of manhode, oon the best on-lyve;
Ther may no man ayen the trouthe stryve. 159. S. the; rest omit.
For of his tyme, and of his age also
He proved was, ther men shulde have ado,
For oon the beste there, of brede and lengthe 162. Th. therto; rest there.
So wel y-mad by good proporcioun,
If he had be in his deliver strengthe;
But thought and seknesse were occasioun
That he thus lay, in lamentacioun,
Gruffe on the grounde, in place desolat,
Sole by him-self, awhaped and amat. 168. F. P. awaped.
And, for me semeth that it is sitting
His wordes al to putte in remembraunce,
To me, that herdë al his complayning
And al the groundë of his woful chaunce,
If ther-withal I may you do plesaunce,
I wol to you, so as I can. anon, 175. D. hem; S. thame; rest om.
Lyk as he sayde, reherce hem everichon.
But who shal helpe me now to complayne?
Or who shal now my style gye or lede?
O Niobè, let now thy teres rayne
In-to my penne; and helpe eek in this nede, 179. Th. om. this.
Thou woful Mirre, that felest my herte blede
Of pitous wo, and myn hand eek quake 181. So all.
Whan that I wryte, for this mannes sake!
For unto wo accordeth complayning
And doleful cherë unto hevinesse; 184. F. delful; T. delefull; S. dulefull; D. doilfull.
To sorowe also, syghing and weping,
And pitous mourning, unto drerinesse;
And whoso that shal wryten of distresse 187. S. quhoso; rest who. S. writen; rest write (wryte).
In party nedeth to knowe felingly
Cause and rote of al such malady.
But I, alas! that am of witte but dulle,
And have no knowing of such matere, 191. D. no knowyng haue; rest haue no knowyng.
For to discryve and wryten at the fulle
The woful complaynt, which that ye shal here,
But even-lyk as doth a skrivenere
That can no more what that he shal wryte,
But as his maister besyde doth endyte;
Right so fare I, that of no sentement
Saye right naught, as in conclusioun, 198. F. S. as; rest om.
But as I herde, whan I was present,
This man complayne with a pitous soun;
For even-lyk, without addicioun
Or disencrees, either more or lesse, 202. Th. disencrease; F. disencrese; T. disencrece; D. disencrees.
For to reherce anon I wol me dresse.
And if that any now be in this place
That fele in love brenning or fervence, 205. S. louyng.
Or hindred werë to his lady grace 206. F. hindered; S. hinderit; rest hindred.
With false tonges, that with pestilence
Slee trewe men that never did offence
In word nor dede, ne in hir entent—
If any suche be here now present,
Let him of routhe lay to audience,
With doleful chere and sobre countenaunce, 212. F. T. deleful; S. dulfull; D. wofull.
To here this man, by ful high sentence,
His mortal wo and his gret perturbaunce 214. S. grete; rest om.
Cómplayning, now lying in a traunce,
With lokes upcaste, and with ruful chere, 216. S. with full; rest omit (I omit full). COMPLEYNT; in F. only.
Th' effect of whiche was as ye shal here.—
THE thought oppressed with inward sighes sore,
The painful lyf, the body languisshing,
The woful gost, the herte rent and tore,
The pitous chere, pale in compleyning,
The deedly face, lyk ashes in shyning,
The salte teres that fro myn eyën falle,
Parcel declare grounde of my peynes alle:
Whos herte is grounde to blede in hevinesse; 225. D. grownded.
The thought, resceyt of wo and of complaynt;
The brest is cheste of dole and drerinesse; 227. F. S. dule; D. dooll.
The body eek so feble and so faynt;
With hote and colde myn acces is so meynt,
That now I chiver for defaute of hete, 230. Th. T. chyuer; F. shyuer; D. chevir; S. chill.
And, hoot as gleed, now sodainly I swete.
Now hoot as fyr, now cold as asshes dede,
Now hoot fro cold, now cold fro hete agayn; 233. T. D. fro; S. from; Th. F. for (twice).
Now cold as ys, now as coles rede 234. Th. T. D. yse; F. Ise; S. Iss.
For hete I brenne; and thus, betwixe twayne,
I possed am, and al forcast in payne;
So that my hete plainly, as I fele,
Of grevous cold is causë, every-deel.
This is the cold of inward high disdayne, 239. S. distress.
Cold of dispyt, and cold of cruel hate;
This is the cold that doth his besy payne 241. So D. P.; S. doth his besyness; Th. euer doth his besy payne; F. euere doth besy peyn; T. euur doth his bysy hate (sic).
Ayeines trouthe to fighte and to debate. 242. T. Agaynes; F. D. Ayens; Th. Ayenst; S. Aȝeynis. S. and to; rest om. to.
This is the cold that wolde the fyr abate 243. Th. om. wolde.
Of trewe mening; alas! the harde whyle!
This is the cold that wolde me begyle. 245. T. wolde; S. wold; Th. D. wol; F. will.
For ever the better that in trouthe I mente
With al my mighte faythfully to serve, 247. T. myghte; Th. F. might.
With herte and al for to be diligent, 248. S. for; rest om.
The lesse thank, alas! I can deserve!
Thus for my trouthe Daunger doth me sterve.
For oon that shulde my deeth, of mercy, lette
Hath mad despyt newe his swerd to whette 251, 252. T. D. lette, whette; Th. F. let, whet. All despite.
Ayeines me, and his arowes to fyle 253. S. Aȝeynes; T. Agaynes; F. D. Ayens; Th. Agaynst.
To take vengeaunce of wilful crueltè;
And tonges false, through hir sleightly wyle,
Han gonne a werre that wil not stinted be;
And fals Envye, Wrathe, and Enmitè, 257. P. of wrath.
Have conspired, ayeines al right and lawe, 258. S. aȝeynes; T. agaynes; F. D. ayens; Th. agaynst.
Of hir malyce, that Trouthe shal be slawe.
And Male-Bouche gan first the tale telle,
To slaundre Trouthe, of indignacioun;
And Fals-Report so loude rong the belle, 260, 262. Th. tel, bel; rest telle, belle. S. rong; F. T. D. ronge; Th. range.
That Misbeleve and Fals-Suspeccioun,
Have Trouthe brought to his dampnacioun,
So that, alas! wrongfully he dyeth,
And Falsnes now his placë occupyeth,
And entred is in-to Trouthes lond,
And hath therof the ful possessioun.
O rightful god, that first the trouthe fond, 267, 269. S. lond, fond; rest londe, fonde.
How may thou suffre such oppressioun,
That Falshood shulde have jurisdiccioun 271. Th. D. falshode; F. S. falshed; T. falsehede.
In Trouthes right, to slee him giltëlees?
In his fraunchyse he may not live in pees.
Falsly accused, and of his foon forjuged,
Without answere, whyl he was absent,
He dampned was, and may not ben excused, 276. Th. D. be; rest ben.
For Crueltè sat in jugëment 277. S. sat; rest sate, satte.
Of hastinesse, withoute avysëment,
And bad Disdayn do execute anon
His jugëment, in presence of his foon.
Attourney noon ne may admitted been 281. F. non ne may; rest may non.
T'ëxcuse Trouthë, ne a word to speke;
To fayth or ooth the juge list not seen, 283. D. oth; S. soth; rest othe.
There is no gayn, but he wil be wreke.
O lord of trouthe, to thee I calle and clepe; 285. Th. F. T. P. clepe; D. speke; S. cleke (!).
How may thou see, thus in thy presence,
Withoute mercy, murdred innocence?
Now god, that art of trouthe soverain
And seëst how I lye for trouthe bounde,
So sore knit in loves fyry chain
Even at the deth, through-girt with many a wounde
That lykly are never for to sounde,
And for my trouthe am dampned to the deeth,
And not abyde, but drawe along the breeth:
Consider and see, in thyn eternal right,
How that myn herte professed whylom was
For to be trewe with al my fulle might 297. T. D. fulle; Th. F. ful.
Only to oon, the whiche now, alas! 298. Th. S. one; rest oon.
Of voluntè, withoute any trespas, 299 F. more (for any).
Myn accusours hath taken unto grace,
And cherissheth hem, my deth for to purchace.
What meneth this? what is this wonder ure
Of purveyauncë, if I shal it calle, 303. Th. cal.
Of god of love, that false hem so assure,
And trewe, alas! doun of the whele ben falle? 305. Th. fal.
And yet in sothe, this is the worst of alle, 306. Th. al.
That Falshed wrongfully of Trouthe hath name, 307. All the name; I omit the.
And Trouthe ayenward of Falshed bereth the blame. 308. All the blame; read ber'the.
This blinde chaunce, this stormy aventure,
In lovë hath most his experience;
For who that doth with trouthe most his cure
Shal for his mede finde most offence,
That serveth love with al his diligence;
For who can faynë, under lowliheed,
Ne fayleth not to finde grace and speed. 314, 315. D. lowlyheed, speed; rest -hede, spede.
For I loved oon, ful longë sith agoon,
With al my herte, body, and ful might,
And, to be deed, my herte can not goon
From his hest, but holde that he hath hight;
Though I be banisshed out of her sight,
And by her mouth dampned that I shal deye,
†To my behest yet I wil ever obeye. 322. All Vn-to; read To.
For ever, sithë that the world began, 323. F. sithe; S. sithen; rest sith.
Who-so list lokë, and in storie rede,
He shal ay finde that the trewe man
Was put abakke, wher-as the falshede
Y-furthered was; for Love taketh non hede
To slee the trewe, and hath of hem no charge,
Wher-as the false goth freely at hir large.
I take recorde of Palamides,
The trewe man, the noble worthy knight,
That ever loved, and of his payn no relees; 332. Perhaps omit his. D. payn; T. peyn; rest payne (peyne).
Notwithstonding his manhood and his might
Love unto him did ful greet unright;
For ay the bet he did in chevalrye,
The more he was hindred by envye.
And ay the bet he did in every place 337. S. bet; F. bette; rest better.
Through his knighthood and his besy payne, 338. Th. F. om. 2nd his.
The ferther was he from his lady grace, 339. T. lady; F. ladye; rest ladyes.
For to her mercy mighte he never attayne;
And to his deth he coude it not refrayne
For no daungere, but ay obey and serve
As he best coude, plainly, til he sterve.
What was the fyne also of Hercules,
For al his conquest and his worthinesse,
That was of strengthe alone pereles? 346. D. perelees; F. T. S. P. pereles; Th. peerles.
For, lyk as bokes of him list expresse, 347. T. liste of hym; S. can of him.
He sette pillers, through his hy prowesse,
Away at Gades, for to signifye 349. F. Gades; S. Gadis; rest Gaddes.
That no man mighte him passe in chevalrye.
The whiche pillers ben ferre beyonde Inde 351. Th. P. om. ben.
Beset of golde, for a remembraunce; 352. S. Y-sett; D. Sette.
And, for al that, was he set behinde
With hem that Love liste febly avaunce;
For [he] him sette last upon a daunce, 355. I supply he.
Ageynes whom helpe may no stryf;
For al his trouthe, yit he loste his lyf. 357. S. ȝit; rest omit.
Phebus also, for al his persaunt light,
Whan that he wente here in erthe lowe,
Unto the herte with fresh Venus sight 360. S. fresch; rest omit.
Y-wounded was, through Cupydes bowe,
And yet his lady liste him not to knowe.
Though for her love his herte didë blede, 363. T. dide; rest did.
She leet him go, and took of him no hede.
What shal I saye of yonge Piramus?
Of trew Tristram, for al his hye renoun?
Of Achilles, or of Antonius?
Of Arcite eke, or of him Palemoun? 368. S. eke; rest omit.
What was the endë of hir passioun
But, after sorowe, deeth, and than hir grave?
Lo, here the guerdon tha these lovers have!
But false Jason, with his doublenesse,
That was untrewe at Colkos to Medee,
And Theseus, rote of unkindënesse, 374. F. Tereus (for Theseus),
And with these two eek the false Enee;
Lo! thus the falsë, ay in oon degrè,
Had in love hir lust and al hir wille;
And, save falshood, ther was non other skille. 378. F. falshed; S. falshede.
Of Thebes eek the false [knight] Arcyte, 379. I supply knight.
And Demophon †also, for [al] his slouthe, 380. All eke; read also. I supply al.
They had hir lust and al that might delyte
For al hir falshode and hir greet untrouthe. 382. S. and thair (for and hir); rest omit thair (= hir).
Thus ever Love (alas! and that is routhe!)
His false leges forthereth what he may, 384. Th. lieges.
And sleeth the trewe ungoodly, day by day.
For trewe Adon was slayn with the bore 386. So all.
Amid the forest, in the grene shade;
For Venus love he feltë al the sore.
But Vulcanus with her no mercy made;
The foule chorl had many nightes glade,
Wher Mars, her worthy knight, her trewe man, 391. S. worthi knycht & hir trew; rest omit worthi and trew. I follow S.; but omit and.
To finde mercy, comfort noon he can.
Also the yonge fresshe Ipomenes 393. F. T. Ipomones; Th. Ypomedes; S. P. Ypomenes; D. Ipomeus.
So lusty free [was], as of his corage, 394. I supply was.
That for to serve with al his herte he chees
Athalans, so fair of hir visage;
But Love, alas! quitte him so his wage
With cruel daunger plainly, at the laste,
That, with the dethe, guerdonles he paste.
Lo! here the fyne of loveres servyse! 400. F.lovers; T.louys; rest loues.
Lo! how that Love can his servaunts quyte!
Lo! how he can his faythful men despyse,
To slee the trewe, and false to respyte! 403. S. trewe; rest trewe men.
Lo! how he doth the swerd of sorowe byte
In hertes, suche as most his lust obeye, 405. Th. moost.
To save the false, and do the trewe deye!
For fayth nor ooth, word, ne assuraunce, 407. D. S. oth; rest othe.
Trewe mening, awayte, or besinesse,
Stille port, ne faythful attendaunce, 409. F. P. S. port; rest porte.
Manhood, ne might, in armes worthinesse,
Pursute of worship, nor no hy prowesse, 411. S. no; rest omit.
In straunge lande ryding, ne travayle,
Ful lyte or nought in lovë doth avayle. 413. Th. lytel; P. litill; D. litle; rest lyte.
Peril of dethe, nother in see ne lande, 414. F. nother; rest nor.
Hunger ne thurst, sorowe ne sekenesse, 415. Th. syknesse; F. sekenesse.
Ne grete empryses for to take on hande,
Sheding of blode, ne manful hardinesse,
Ne ofte woundinge at sautes by distresse,
Nor †juparting of lyf, nor deeth also— 419. D. Iupardy; rest in partynge (for iupartynge); read juparting; cf. 1. 475.
Al is for nought, Love taketh no hede therto!
But lesings, with hir false flaterye, 421. F. fals (error for false); rest omit.
Through hir falshede, and with hir doublenesse,
With tales newe and many fayned lye,
By fals semblaunt and counterfet humblesse,
Under colour depeynt with stedfastnesse,
With fraude covered under a pitous face 426. S. double (for pitous).
Accepte been now rathest unto grace,
And can hem-selve now best magnifye
With fayned port and fals presumpcioun; 429. S. falss; rest om.
They haunce hir cause with fals surquedrye
Under meninge of double entencioun,
To thenken oon in hir opinioun
And saye another' to sette hemselve alofte
And hinder trouthe, as it is seyn ful ofte.
The whiche thing I bye now al to dere, 435. Th. F. P. bye; D. bie; T. bey; S. by.
Thanked be Venus and the god Cupyde!
As it is sene by myn oppressed chere, 437. Th. T. S. sene; F. seen; P. D. seyn.
And by his arowes that stiken in my syde, 438. Th. sticken; P. D. stekyn.
That, sauf the deth, I nothing abyde 439. S. P. the; rest om.
Fro day to day; alas, the harde whyle!
Whan ever his dart that him list to fyle,
My woful herte for to ryve a-two
For faute of mercy, and lak of pitè
Of her that causeth al my payne and wo
And list not ones, of grace, for to see
Unto my trouthe through her crueltee;
And, most of alle, yit I me complayne, 447. S. ȝit; rest om.
That she hath joy to laughen at my peyne!
And wilfully hath [she] my deeth y-sworn 449. I supply she. S. ysuorn; rest om. y-.
Al giltëlees, and wot no cause why
Save for the trouthe that I have had aforn 451. Th. om. have.
To her alone to serve faithfully!
O god of lovë! unto thee I cry, 453. T. D. S. aboue (for of love); see l. 454.
And to thy blinde double deitee
Of this gret wrongë I compleyne me,
And to thy stormy wilful variaunce
Y-meynt with chaunge and greet unstablenesse;
Now up, now doun, so renning is thy chaunce,
That thee to truste may be no sikernesse.
I wyte it nothing but thy doublenesse;
And who that is an archer and is †blent 461. S. blend (read blent); rest blynde (blinde).
Marketh nothing, but sheteth as he †went. 462. S. as he wend (read went); Th. by wende (!); rest by wenynge (!).
And for that he hath no discrecioun,
Withoute avys he let his arowe go; 464. F. T. avise; D. avice; S. aviss; Th. aduyse.
For lakke of sight, and also of resoun,
In his shetinge, it happeth ofte so,
To hurte his frend rather than his fo; 467. S. P. frend; rest frende.
So doth this god, [and] with his sharpe floon 468. B. begins here. I supply and.
The trewe sleeth, and let the false goon. 469. T. lette; F. leteth; Th. letteth; B. D. letith; S. lattith.
And of his wounding this is the worst of alle,
Whan he hurteth, he doth so cruel wreche 471. B. F. S. he doth; Th. T. doth to.
And maketh the seke for to crye and calle
Unto his fo, for to been his leche;
And hard it is, for a man to seche,
Upon the point of dethe in jupardye, 475. Th. ieopardye; S. Iupartye; F. partie (!); B. D. T. Iupardye; P. Iupard.
Unto his fo, to finde remedye!
Thus fareth it now even by me,
That to my fo, that yaf myn herte a wounde,
Mote aske grace, mercy, and pitè,
And namëly, ther wher non may be founde!
For now my sore my leche wil confounde,
And god of kinde so hath set myn ure,
My lyves fo to have my wounde in cure!
Alas! the whyle now that I was born!
Or that I ever saw the brighte sonne!
For now I see, that ful longe aforn,
Or I was born, my desteny was sponne
By Parcas sustren, to slee me, if they conne; 488. Th. systerne.
For they my deth shopen or my sherte 489. S. haueschapen (for shopen).
Only for trouthe! I may it not asterte.
The mighty goddesse also of Nature
That under god hath the governaunce
Of worldly thinges committed to her cure,
Disposed hath, through her wys purveyaunce, 494. F. hath; Th. haue.
To yeve my lady so moche suffisaunce
Of al vertues, and therwithal purvyde
To murdre trouthe, hath take Daunger to gyde.
For bountè, shappe, and semeliheed,
Prudence, wit, passingly fairnesse,
Benigne port, glad chere with lowliheed,
Of womanheed right plenteous largesse, 501. F. B. plentevous. Th. largnesse.
Nature did in her fully empresse,
Whan she her wroughte; and alther-last Disdayne,
To hinder trouthe, she made her chamberlayne;
Whan Mistrust also, and Fals-Suspeccioun,
With Misbeleve, she made for to be
Cheef of counsayl to this conclusioun,
For to exyle Routhe, and eek Pitè, 508. Th. trouthe; S. treuth; rest routhe; see l. 679.
Out of her court to make Mercy flee,
So that Dispyt now holdeth forth her reyne,
Through hasty bileve of tales that men feyne.
And thus I am, for my trouthe, alas!
Murdred and slayn with wordes sharpe and kene,
Giltlees, god wot, of al maner trespas, 514. Th. Gyltlesse; F. Giltles; P. Gylteles.
And lye and blede upon this colde grene.
Now mercy, swete! mercy, my lyves quene!
And to your grace of mercy yet I preye,
In your servyse that your man may deye!
But if so be that I shal deye algate,
And that I shal non other mercy have,
Yet of my dethe let this be the date
That by your wille I was brought to my grave;
Or hastily, if that you list me save, 523. F. B. P. ye (for you).
My sharpe woundes, that ake so and blede,
Of mercy, charme, and also of womanhede.
For other charme, playnly, is ther non
But only mercy, to helpe in this case;
For though my woundes blede ever in oon,
My lyf, my deeth, standeth in youre grace;
And though my gilt be nothing, alas! 530. F. B. S. gilt; rest gylte (gilte).
I aske mercy in al my beste entente,
Redy to dye, if that ye assente.
For ther-ayeines shal I never stryve 533. S. aȝeynes; T. agaynes; F. B. D. ayens; Th. agaynst.
In worde ne werke; playnly, I ne may;
For lever I have than to be alyve
To dye soothly, and it be her to pay; 536. S. ȝow to pay; rest her to pay.
Ye, though it be this eche same day 537. Th. om. eche.
Or whan that ever her liste to devyse; 538. T. D liste; rest list.
Suffyceth me to dye in your servyse.
And god, that knowest the thought of every wight
Right as it is, in †al thing thou mayst see, 541. All euery; read al.
Yet, ere I dye, with all my fulle might
Lowly I pray, to graunte[n] unto me 543. All graunte (graunt); read graunten.
That ye, goodly, fayre, fresshe, and free,
Which slee me only for defaute of routhe, 545. Th. onely sle me; MSS. slee me only.
Or that I dye, ye may knowe my trouthe.
For that, in sothe, suffyseth unto me, 547. S. vnto; rest om.
And she it knowe in every circumstaunce; 548. S. If (for And).
And after, I am wel apayd that she 549. S. apaid; rest payd (paid).
If that hir list, of dethe to do vengeaunce 550. For to read shal?
Untó me, that am under her legeaunce; 551. F. P. legeaunce; Th. D. ligeaunce; T. lygeaunce.
It sit me not her doom to disobeye,
But, at her luste, wilfully to deye. 553. T. D. luste; Th. F. B. lust. S. Quherso hir list to do me lyue or deye.
Withoute grucching or rebellioun
In wille or worde, hoolly I assent, 555. S. hoolly; Th. holy.
Or any maner contradiccioun,
Fully to be at her commaundëment;
And, if I dyë, in my testament
My herte I sende, and my spirit also,
What-so-ever she list, with hem to do. 560. Th. T. D. lyste; F. S. P. list.
And alder-last unto her womanhede 561. S. vnto; rest to.
And to her mercy me I recommaunde,
That lye now here, betwixe hope and drede,
Abyding playnly what she list commaunde.
For utterly, (this nis no demaunde),
Welcome to me, whyl me lasteth breeth, 566. S. quhill þat me.
Right at her choise, wher it be lyf or deeth!
In this matere more what mighte I seyn, 568. Th. mater.
Sith in her hande and in her wille is al,
Both lyf and deeth, my joy and al my payn?
And fynally, my heste holde I shal, 571. F. B. P. hest.
Til my spirit, by desteny fatal,
Whan that her liste, fro my body wende; 573. T. liste; rest list (lust).
Have here my trouthe, and thus I make an ende!'
And with that worde he gan syke as sore 575. T. sike; S. to sike; Th. D. sygh; F. B. sile (!).
Lyk as his herte ryve wolde atwayne,
And held his pees, and spak a word no more. 577. Th. no worde.
But, for to see his wo and mortal payne,
The teres gonne fro myn eyen rayne
Ful pitously, for very inward routhe
That I him saw so languisshing for trouthe. 581. Th. long wisshing (!). Th. S. for; F. B. D. P. for his; T. for her.
And al this whyle my-self I kepte cloos
Among the bowes, and my-self gan hyde, 583. S. P. gan; rest gonne (gunne).
Til, at the laste, the woful man aroos,
And to a logge wente ther besyde,
Where, al the May, his custome was t'abyde,
Sole, to complaynen of his paynes kene, 587. S. compleynen; rest complayne.
Fro yeer to yere, under the bowes grene.
And for bicause that it drow to the night
And that the sonne his ark diurnál
Y-passed was, so that his persaunt light,
His brighte bemes and his stremes al
Were in the wawes of the water fal,
Under the bordure of our ocëan,
His char of golde his cours so swiftly ran:
And whyl the twylight and the rowes rede
Of Phebus light were dëaurat a lyte,
A penne I took, and gan me faste spede 598. T. faste; rest fast.
The woful playntë of this man to wryte
Word by wordë, as he did endyte;
Lyk as I herde, and coude him tho reporte,
I have here set, your hertes to disporte.
If ought be mis, layeth the wyte on me,
For I am worthy for to bere the blame
If any thing [here] misreported be, 605. I supply here.
To make this dytè for to seme lame 606. Th. dytte.
Through myn unconning; but, to sayn the same,
Lyk as this man his complaynt did expresse,
I aske mercy and forgivënesse.
And, as I wroot, me thoughte I saw a-ferre,
Fer in the weste, lustely appere 611. T. D. weste; rest west.
Esperus, the goodly brighte sterre,
So glad, so fair, so persaunt eek of chere,
I mene Venus, with her bemes clere,
That, hevy hertes only to releve,
Is wont, of custom, for to shewe at eve.
And I, as faste, fel doun on my knee 617. T. D. faste; rest fast. S. D. F. doun; Th. adowne; D. T. Adoun.
And even thus to her gan I to preye:—
'O lady Venus! so faire upon to see,
Let not this man for his trouthe deye,
For that joy thou haddest whan thou leye
With Mars thy knight, whan Vulcanus you fond, 622. T. you; rest om.
And with a chayne invisible you bond
Togider, bothe twayne, in the same whyle
That al the court above celestial
At youre shame gan for to laughe and smyle! 626. S. for to; rest om.
A! fairë lady! welwilly founde at al, 627. MSS. welwilly; Th. wyl I (!).
Comfort to careful, O goddesse immortal!
Be helping now, and do thy diligence
To let the stremes of thyn influence
Descende doun, in forthering of the trouthe,
Namely, of hem that lye in sorowe bounde;
Shew now thy might, and on hir wo have routhe
Er fals Daunger slee hem and confounde.
And specially, let thy might be founde
For to socourë, what-so that thou may, 636. Th. socouer (misprint).
The trewe man that in the herber lay,
And alle trewe forther, for his sake,
O gladde sterre, O lady Venus myne!
And cause his lady him to grace take.
Her herte of stele to mercy so enclyne,
Er that thy bemes go up, to declyne,
And er that thou now go fro us adoun,
Fór that love thou haddest to Adoun!'
And whan that she was gon unto her reste, 645. S. vnto; rest to.
I roos anon, and hoom to bedde wente,
For verily, me thoughte it for the beste; 647. S. verily; Th. T. D. wery (!); B. very wery (!); F. werry wery (!); P. very.
Prayinge thus, in al my best entente,
That alle trewe, that be with Daunger shente,
With mercy may, in reles of hir payn, 650. F. B. reles; T. D. relese; Th. release; S. relesche.
Recured be, er May come eft agayn.
And for that I ne may no lenger wake,
Farewel, ye lovers alle, that be trewe!
Praying to god; and thus my leve I take,
That, er the sonne to-morowe be risen newe,
And er he have ayein his rosen hewe, 656. Th. T. S. P. om. his.
That eche of you may have suche a grace,
His owne lady in armes to embrace.
I mene thus, that, in al honestee, 659. Th. om. that.
Withoute more, ye may togider speke
What so ye listë, at good libertee,
That eche may to other hir herte breke,
On Jelousyë only to be wreke, 663. Th. ialousyes; D. Ielosies; rest Ielosye.
That hath so longe, of malice and envye, 664. T. B. P. of; rest of his.
Werreyed Trouthe with his tirannye. 665. S. Werreyed; D. Werried; rest Werred.
Princesse, plese it your benignitee 666. MSS. Princes; Th. Pryncesse. Th. pleaseth; F. pleseth; P. plesith (read plese). Th. it to your; rest om. to.
This litel dytè for to have in mynde! 667. S. P. for; rest om.
Of womanhedë also for to see
Your trewe man may youre mercy finde; 669. Th. D. om. trewe.
And Pitè eek, that long hath be behinde,
Let him ayein be próvoked to grace;
For, by my trouthe, it is ayeines kinde,
Fals Daunger for to occupye his place! 673. S. for; rest om.
Go, litel quayre, unto my lyves queen,
And my very hertes soverayne;
And be right glad; for she shal thee seen;
Suche is thy grace! But I, alas! in payne
Am left behinde, and not to whom to playne.
For Mercy, Routhe, Grace, and eek Pitè
Exyled be, that I may not attayne
Recure to finde of myn adversitè.

DIV1.HEAD: IX. THE FLOUR OF CURTESYE. From Th. (Thynne, ed. 1532). TITLE: Th. The Floure of Curtesy; (ed. 1561 adds—made by Ihon Lidgate). I note here the rejected spellings.

LG.L: IN Fevrier, whan the frosty mone 1. Feverier.
Was horned, ful of Phebus fyry light, 2. firy.
And that she gan to reyse her stremes sone, 3. streames.
Saint Valentyne! upon thy blisful night
Of duëtee, whan glad is every wight, 5. dutie.
And foules chese (to voyde hir olde sorowe) 6. her.
Everich his make, upon the nexte morowe; 7. Eueryche; next.
The same tyme, I herde a larke singe
Ful lustely, agayn the morowe gray— 9. agayne.
'Awake, ye lovers, out of your slombringe,
This gladde morowe, in al the haste ye may; 11. glad.
Some óbservaunce doth unto this day, 12. dothe.
Your choise ayen of herte to renewe
In cónfirming, for ever to be trewe!
And ye that be, of chesing, at your large, 15. chosyng.
This lusty day, by custome of nature,
Take upon you the blisful holy charge
To serve lovë, whyl your lyf may dure, 18. whyle; lyfe.
With herte, body, and al your besy cure,
For evermore, as Venus and Cipryde 20. Cipride.
For you disposeth, and the god Cupyde.
For joye owe we playnly to obeye 22. obey.
Unto this lordes mighty ordinaunce, 22. obey.
And, mercilesse, rather for to deye
Than ever in you be founden variaunce;
And, though your lyf be medled with grevaunce, 26. lyfe. 26. closet.
And, at your herte, closed be your wounde, 27. there.
Beth alway one, ther-as ye are bounde!'
Thát whan I had herd, and listed longe, 29. herde.
With devout herte, the lusty melodye
Of this hevenly comfortable songe
So ágreable, as by harmonye, 32. ermonye.
I roos anon, and faste gan me hye 33. rose.
Toward a grove, and the way [gan] take 34. Towarde; supply gan.
Foules to sene, everich chese his make. 35. eueryche chose.
And yet I was ful thursty in languisshing;
Myn ague was so fervent in his hete,
Whan Aurora, for drery complayning,
Can distille her cristal teres wete 39. distyl; (read distille); chrystal teeres.
Upon the soile, with silver dewe so swete;
For she [ne] durste, for shame, not apere 41. Supply ne.
Under the light of Phebus bemes clere. 42. beames.
And so, for anguisshe of my paynes kene,
And for constraynte of my sighes sore,
I sette me doun under a laurer grene 45. set; downe.
Ful pitously; and alway more and more,
As I beheld into the holtes hore, 47. behelde.
I gan complayne myn inward deedly smerte, 48. inwarde.
That ay so sore †crampisshed myn herte. 49. aye; crampessh at (read crampisshed).
And whyl that I, in my drery payne, 50. whyle.
Sat, and beheld aboute on every tree 51. Sate; behelde; tre.
The foules sitten, alway twayne and twayne, 52. sytte (read sitten).
Than thoughte I thus; 'alas! what may this be, 53. thought.
That every foul hath his libertee 54. foule.
Frely to chesen after his desyre 55. chose (read chesen).
Everich his make thus, fro yeer to yere? 56. Eueryche; yere to yere.
The sely wrenne, the titmose also, 57. tytemose.
The litel redbrest, have free eleccioun 58. election.
To flyen y-ferë and †togider go 59. togyther (read togider).
Wher-as hem liste, abouten enviroun, 60. Where as; lyst aboute envyron.
As they of kynde have inclinacoun, 61. inclynacion.
And as Nature, emperesse and gyde, 62. empresse (read emperesse).
Of every thing, liste to provyde; 63. lyst.
But man aloon, alas! the harde stounde! 64. alone.
Ful cruelly, by kyndes ordinaunce,
Constrayned is, and by statut bounde, 66. statute.
And debarred from alle such plesaunce. 67. al suche.
What meneth this? What is this purveyaunce
Of god above, agayn al right of kynde, 69. agayne.
Withoute cause, so narowe man to bynde?' 70. Without.
Thus may I [soothly] seen, and playne, alas! 71. Supply soothly; sene.
My woful houre and my disaventure,
That dolefully stonde in the same cas 73. doulfully; caas.
So fer behyndë, from al helth and cure. 74. ferre.
My wounde abydeth lyk a sursanure; 75. lyke.
For me Fortune so felly list dispose, 76. lyste.
My harm is hid, that I dar not disclose. 77. harme; dare.
For I my herte have set in suche a place
Wher I am never lykly for to spede; 79. lykely.
So fer I am hindred from her grace 80. ferre.
That, save daunger, I have non other mede. 81. none.
And thus, alas! I not who shal me rede
Ne for myn helpe shape remedye, 83. myne.
For Male-bouche, and for false Envye:
The whiche twayne ay stondeth in my wey 85. aye.
Maliciously; and Fals Suspeccioun 86. false suspection.
Is very causë also that I dey,
Ginning and rote of my distruccioun; 88. distruction.
So that I fele, [as] in conclusioun, 89. Supply as; conclusyon.
With hir traynes that they wol me shende,
Of my labour that deth mot make an ende! 91. dethe mote.
Yet, or I dye, with herte, wil, and thought
To god of lovë this avowe I make,
(As I best can, how dere that it be bought, 94. howe.
Wher-so it be, that I slepe or wake, 95. Where so.
Whyl Boreas doth the leves shake) 96. Whyle; dothe; leaues.
As I have hight, playnly, til I sterve,
For wele or wo, that I shal [ay] her serve. 98. wel; supply ay.
And, for her sake, now this holy tyme, 99. nowe.
Saint Valentyne! somwhat shal I wryte
Al-though so be that I can not ryme,
Nor curiously by no crafte endyte,
Yet lever I have, that she putte the wyte 103. put.
In unconning than in negligence,
What-ever I sayë of her excellence.
What-ever I saye, it is of duëtee, 106. say; dute (read duetee).
In sothfastnesse and no presumpcioun; 107. presumpcion.
This I ensure to you that shal it see, 108. se.
That it is al under correccioun; 109. correction.
What I reherce in commendacioun 110. commendacion.
Of herë that I shal to you, as blyve, 111. her (read here).
So as I can, her vertues here discryve.—
¶ Right by example as the somer-sonne
Passeth the sterre with his bemes shene, 114. beames.
And Lucifer among the skyës donne 115. amonge.
A-morowe sheweth to voyde nightes tene,
So verily, withouten any wene,
My lady passeth (who-so taketh hede)
Al tho alyve, to speke of womanhede.
And as the ruby hath the soveraintè
Of riche stones and the regalyë;
And [as] the rose, of swetnesse and beautè, 122. Supply as; swetenesse.
Of fresshe floures, withouten any lyë; 123. without.
Right so, in sothe, with her goodly yë, 124. eye.
She passeth al in bountee and fairnesse, 125. bountie; fayrenesse.
Of maner ekë, and of gentilnesse.
For she is bothe the fairest and the beste,
To reken al in very sothfastnesse; 128. reken (read reknen?).
For every vertue is in her at reste;
And furthermore, to speke of stedfastnesse,
She is the rotë; and of seemlinesse 131. seme∣lynesse.
The very mirrour; and of governaunce
To al example, withouten variaunce.
Of port benigne, and wonder glad of chere,
Having evermore her trewe advertence
Alway to reson; so that her desyre 136. reason.
Is brydeled ay by witte and providence; 137. aye.
Thereto, of wittë and of hy prudence 138. hye.
She is the wellë, ay devoide of pryde, 139. aye.
That unto vertue her-selven is the gyde!
And over this, in her daliaunce
Lowly she is, discret. wyse, [and secree], 142. dis∣crete and wyse (read discret wyse; and supply secree for the rime).
And goodly gladde by attemperaunce,
That every wight, of high and low degree, 144. lowe.
Are gladde in herte with her for to be; 145. glad.
Só that, shortly, if I shal not lye,
She named is 'The Flour of Curtesye.' 147. Floure.
And there, to speke of femininitee, 148. femynyte (!).
The leste mannish in comparisoun, 149. mannyshe; com∣parison.
Goodly abasshed, having ay pitee 150. aye pyte.
Of hem that been in tribulacioun; 151. ben; trybulacion.
For she aloon is consolacioun 152. alone; -cion.
To al that arn in mischeef and in nede, 153. arne; mischefe.
To comforte hem, of her womanhede.
And ay in vertue is her besy charge, 155. aye.
Sadde and demure, and but of wordes fewe;
Dredful also of tonges that ben large, 157. Dredeful.
Eschewing ay hem that listen to hewe 158. aye.
Above hir heed, hir wordes for to shewe, 159. her (twice.)
Dishonestly to speke of any wight;
She deedly hateth of hem to have a sight.
The herte of whom so honest is and clene,
And her entent so faithful and entere
That she ne may, for al the world, sustene 164. worlde.
To suffre her eres any word to here, 165. eeres; worde.
Of frend nor fo, neither fer ne nere, 166. frende; foe; ferre.
Amis resowning, that hinder shulde his name; 167. Amysse.
And if she do, she wexeth reed for shame.
So trewëly in mening she is set, 169. trewly; is in sette (om. in).
Without chaunging or any doublenesse;
For bountee and beautee ar togider knot 171. bountie; beautie are togyther knette.
In her personë, under faithfulnesse;
For void she is of newëfangelnesse; 173. voyde; newfanglenesse (or read voide and new∣fangelnesse).
In herte ay oon, for ever to perséver 174. aye one.
Ther she is set, and never to dissever. 175. There; sette.
I am to rude her vertues everichoon 176. euerychone.
Cunningly [for] to discryve and wryte; 177. Supply for.
For wel ye wot, colour[es] have I noon 178. colour; none.
Lyk her discrecioun craftely t'endyte; 179. Lyke; to endyte.
For what I sayë, al it is to lyte. 180. say.
Whérfor to you thus I me excuse, 181. Wherfore.
That I aqueynted am not with no muse!
By rethoryke my style to governe,
In her preyse and commendacioun, 184. commendacion.
I am to blind, so hyly to discerne, 185. blynde; hylye.
Of her goodnesse to make discripcioun, 186. discrypcion.
Save thus I sayë, in conclusioun, 187. say; conclusyon.
If that I shal shortly [her] commende, 188. Supply her.
In her is naught that Nature can amende.
For good she is, lyk to Policene, 190. lyke.
And, in fairnesse, to the quene Helayne; 191. fayrenesse.
Stedfast of herte, as was Dorigene,
And wyfly trouthë, if I shal not fayne: 193. wyfely.
In constaunce eke and faith, she may attayne 194. faythe.
To Cleopatre; and therto as †secree 195. setrone (!); read secree (see note).
As was of Troye the whyte Antigone;
As Hester meke; lyk Judith of prudence; 197. lyke.
Kynde as Alceste or Marcia Catoun; 198. Alcest.
And to Grisilde lyk in pacience, 199. lyke.
And Ariadne, of discrecioun;
And to Lucrece, that was of Rome toun,
She may be lykned, as for honestè; 202. lykened.
And, for her faith, unto Penelope. 203. faythe.
To faire Phyllis and to Hipsiphilee,
For innocencë and for womanhede;
For seemlinessë, unto Canacee; 206. semelynesse; Canace.
And over this, to speke of goodlihede,
She passeth alle that I can of rede; 208. al.
For worde and dede, that she naught ne falle,
Acorde in vertue, and her werkes alle. 209, 210. fal, al.
For though that Dydo, with [her] witte sage, 211. Supply her.
Was in her tyme stedfast to Enee,
Of hastinesse yet she did outrage;
And so for Jason did also Medee.
But my lady is so avisee
That, bountee and beautee bothe in her demeyne, 216. bountie; beautie.
She maketh bountee alway soverayne. 217. bountie.
This is to mene, bountee goth afore, 218. meane bountie gothe.
Lady by prudence, and hath the soveraintee;
And beautee folweth, ruled by her lore, 220. beautie foloweth.
That she †n'offendë her in no degree; 221. ne fende (!); degre.
So that, in one, this goodly fresshe free 222. fre.
Surmounting al, withouten any were,
Is good and fair, in oon persone y-fere. 224. fayre; one.
And though that I, for very ignoraunce,
Ne may discryve her vertues by and by,
Yet on this day, for a rémembraunce,
Only supported under her mercy, 228. Onely.
With quaking hondë, I shal ful humbly
To her hynesse, my rudenes for to quyte, 230. rudenesse.
A litel balade here bineth endyte,
Ever as I can suppryse in my herte,
Alway with fere, betwixe drede and shame, 233. feare; betwyxt.
Lest out of lose any word asterte 234. Leste; worde.
In this metre, to make it seme lame;
Chaucer is deed, that hadde suche a name 236. had.
Of fair making, that [was], withoute wene, 237. fayre; supply was; without.
Fairest in our tonge, as the laurer grene.
We may assaye for to counterfete 239. assay.
His gaye style, but it wil not be; 240. gay.
The welle is drye, with the licour swete, 241. lycoure.
Bothe of Clio and of Caliopè; 242. Clye (!).
And first of al, I wol excuse me
To her, that is [the] ground of goodlihede; 244. Supply the; grounde.
And thus I saye until hir womanhede:— 245. say.
¶ 'With al my mightë, and my beste entente, 246. might; best entent.
With al the faith that mighty god of kynde 247. faythe.
Me yaf, sith he me soule and knowing sente, 248. yaue; sent.
I chese, and to this bonde ever I me bynde,
To love you best, whyl I have lyf and mynde':— 250. whyle; lyfe.
Thus herde I foules in the dawëninge 251. daunynge.
Upon the day of saint Valentyne singe.
'Yet chese I, at the ginning, in this entente, 253. begynnyng (read ginning); entent.
To love you, though I no mercy fynde;
And if you liste I dyed, I wolde assente, 255. assent.
As ever twinne I quik out of this lynde! 256. quicke; lyne (misprint).
Suffyseth me to seen your fetheres ynde':— 257. sene; fethers.
Thus herde I foules in the morweninge 258. mornynge (for morweninge).
Upon the day of saint Valentyne singe. 252,259. saynte Valentyne (? om. saynte).
'And over this, myn hertes lust to-bente, 260. myne; luste.
In honour only of the wodëbynde, 261. onely; wodde bynde.
Hoolly I yeve, never to repente 262. Holy.
In joye or wo, wher-so that I wynde 263. where so.
Tofore Cupyde, with his eyën blynde':—
The foules alle, whan Tytan did springe, 265. al.
With dévout herte, me thoughte I herde singe! 266. deuoute hert; thought.
¶ Princesse of beautee, to you I represente 267. Lenvoye. beautie; represent.
This simple dytè, rude as in makinge,
Of herte and wil faithful in myn entente, 269. entent.
Lyk as, this day, [the] foules herde I singe. 270. Lyke; supply the.

DIV1.TRAILER: Here endeth the Flour of Curtesye. COLOPHON: Floure; Curtesy.

DIV1.HEAD: X. A BALADE; IN COMMENDATION OF OUR LADY. From Th.; collated with A. (Ashmole 59); and Sl. (Sloane 1212).
DIV1.BYLINE: (A devoute balade by Lidegate of Bury, made at the reverence of oure lady, Qwene of mercy.—A.)

LG.L: A THOUSAND stories coude I mo reherce 1. A. I kouþe to you.
Of olde poetes, touching this matere, 2. A. clerkis (for poetes); the (for this).
How that Cupyde the hertes gan so perce 3. A. cane mens hertes presse (!).
Of his servauntes, setting hem on fere; 4. Th. hem; A. þeire hertes. Th. in fere; A. a fuyre.
Lo, here the fyn of th'errour and the were! 5. A. With ful daunger payeþe his subgettes hyre. Sl. weere; Th. fere.
Lo, here of love the guerdon and grevaunce
That ever with wo his servaunts doth avaunce! 7. Th. Sl. euer; A. aye. Sl. A. his.. doth; Th. her.. do.

Of one to speke, at nede that wol nat fayle;
Alas! for dole, I ne can ne may expresse 10. A. Ellas I ne can ne may not ful expresse.

To love suche oon, al women surmounting, 16. Sl. on; Th. A. one.

That is of pitè the welle and eek the spring! 18. A. Whiche of pytee is welle.

Right thus I say, kneling tofore her face:—
