Chosen of Joseph, whom he took to wyve, 138. Th. toke. A. Chosen of god, whome Joseph gaf (!) to wyve.
Unknowing him, childing by greet mirácle, 139. Th. Sl. childyng; A. bare Cryste. Th. Sl. om. greet.
And of our manhode trewe tabernacle! 140. Th. And of our manly figure the; Sl. And of oure mar (!) figure; A. And of Ihesus manhode truwe.

DIV1.HEAD: XI. TO MY SOVERAIN LADY. From Th. (Thynné, ed. 1532); I note rejected spellings.

LG.L: I HAVE non English convenient and digne 1. none englysshe.
Myn hertes hele, lady, thee with t'honoure, 2. heale; the; to honour.
Ivorie clene; therfore I wol resigne 3. cleane.
In-to thyn hand, til thou list socoure 4. thyne hande; socoure.
To help my making bothe florisshe and floure; 5. helpe; flour.
Than shulde I shewe, in lovë how I brende, 6. howe.
In songes making, thy name to commende.
For if I coude before thyn excellence 8. thyne.
Singen in love, I wolde, what I fele,
And ever standen, lady, in thy presence,
To shewe in open how I love you wele; 11. howe.
And sith, although your herte be mad of stele, 12. made.
To you, withoute any disseveraunce, 13. withouten; disceueraunce.

L.HI: J'ay en vous toute ma fiaunce.

LG.L: Wher might I love ever better besette 15. Where; beset.
Than in this lilie, lyking to beholde?
The lace of love, the bond so wel thou knette, 17. bonde; knyt.
That I may see thee or myn herte colde, 18. se the; myne.
And or I passe out of my dayes olde,
Tofore singing evermore utterly—
'Your eyën two wol slee me sodainly.'
For love I langour, blissed be such seknesse, 22. sicknesse.
Sith it is for you, my hertely suffisaunce; 23. Sythe.
I can not elles saye, in my distresse, 24. els say.
So fair oon hath myn herte in governaunce; 25. fayre one; myne.
And after that I †ginne on esperaunce 26. begynne; read ginne.
With feble entune, though it thyn herte perce, 27. thyne.
Yet for thy sake this lettre I do reherce. 28. letter.
God wot, on musike I can not, but I gesse,
(Alas! why so?) that I might say or singe, 30. wote.
So love I you, myn own soverain maistresse, 31. owne; maistres.
And ever shal, withouten départinge. 32. without.
Mirrour of beautè, for you out shuld I ringe,
In rémembraunce eke of your eyen clere,
Thus fer from you, my soverain lady dere! 35. ferre.
So wolde god your love wold me slo, 36. wolde (twice).
Sith, for your sake, I singe day by day; 37. Sythe.
Herte, why nilt thou [never] breke a-two, 38. nylte; I supply never; breake.
Sith with my lady dwellen I ne may? 39. Sythe; dwel.
Thus many a roundel and many a virelay
In fresshe Englisshe, whan I me layser finde,
I do recorde, on you to have minde!
Now, lady myn! sith I you love and drede, 43. Nowe; myne sithe.
And you unchaunged finde, in o degree, 44. euer fynde (om. euer).
Whos grace ne may flye fro your womanhede, 45. Whose.
Disdayneth not for to remembre on me!
Myn herte bledeth, for I may nat you see; 47. Myne; se.
And sith ye wot my mening désirous, 48. sithe; wotte; meanyng.

L.HI: Pleurez pur moi, si vous plaist amorous!

LG.L: What marveyle is, though I in payne be?
I am departed from you, my soveraine;
Fortune, alas! dont vient la destenee, 52. destenie.
That in no wyse I can ne may attayne 53. canne.
To see the beautè of your eyën twayne. 54. se.
Wherfore I say, for tristesse doth me grame, 55. dothe.

L.HI: Tant me fait mal departir de ma dame!

LG.L: Why nere my wisshing brought to suche esploit
That I might say, for joye of your presence, 58. ioye.

L.HI: 'Ore a mon cuer ce quil veuilloit,

LG.L: Ore a mon cuer the highest excellence
That ever had wight;' and sith myn advertence 61. sithe myne.
Is in you, reweth on my paynes smerte,
I am so sore wounded to the herte.
To live wel mery, two lovers were y-fere,
So may I say withouten any blame;
If any man [per cas] to wilde were, 66. Short line; I insert per cas.
I coude him [sonë] teche to be tame; 67. Short line; I insert sone. for to; I omit for.
Let him go love, and see wher it be game! 68. Lette; se where.
For I am brydled unto sobernesse
For her, that is of women cheef princesse. 70. chefe.
But ever, whan thought shulde my herte embrace, 71. my hert shuld.
Than unto me is beste remedye, 72. best remedy.
Whan I loke on your goodly fresshe face;
So mery a mirrour coude I never espye; 74. espy.
And, if I coude, I wolde it magnifye.
For never non was [here] so faire y-founde, 76. none; I insert here.
To reken hem al, and also Rosamounde.
And fynally, with mouthe and wil present
Of double eye, withoute repentaunce, 79. without.
Myn herte I yeve you, lady, in this entent,
That ye shal hoolly therof have governaunce; 81. holy.
Taking my leve with hertes obeysaunce, 82. leaue.
'Salve, regina!' singing laste of al,
To be our helpe, whan we to thee cal! 84. the.
Al our lovë is but ydelnesse
Save your aloon; who might therto attayne? 86. your loue alone; om. loue.
Who-so wol have a name of gentillesse,
I counsayle him in love that he not fayne.
Thou swete lady! refut in every payne, 89. refute.
Whos [pitous] mercy most to me avayleth 90. Whose; I insert pitous.
To gye by grace, whan that fortune fayleth.
Nought may be told, withouten any fable, 92. tolde.
Your high renome, your womanly beautè;
Your governaunce, to al worship able,
Putteth every herte in ese in his degree. 95. ease.
O violet, O flour desiree, 96. floure.
Sith I am for you so amorous, 97. Sythe; amerous.
Estreynez moy, [lady,] de cuer joyous! 98. Estreynes; I insert lady to fill out the line.
With fervent herte my brest hath broste on fyre; 99. brost.

L.HI: L'ardant espoir que mon cuer poynt, est mort,
D'avoir l'amour de celle que je desyre,

LG.L: I mene you, swete, most plesaunt of port, 102. meane; porte.

L.HI: Et je sai bien que ceo n'est pas mon tort

LG.L: That for you singe, so as I may, for mone
For your departing; alone I live, alone.
Though I mighte, I wolde non other chese; 106. myght; none.
In your servyce, I wolde be founden sad; 107. sadde.
Therfore I love no labour that ye lese,
Whan, in longing, sorest ye be stad; 109. stadde.
Loke up, ye lovers [alle], and be right glad 110. I supply alle; gladde.
Ayeines sëynt Valentynes day, 111. Ayenst saynt.
For I have chose that never forsake I may! 112. chese (read chose).

DIV1.HEAD: XII. BALLAD OF GOOD COUNSEL. From Th. (Thynne's edition, 1532); collated with Ff. (MS. Ff. 1. 6, Camb. Univ. Library). Another copy in H. (Harl. 2251).

LG.L: CONSIDER wel, with every circumstaunce, 1. H. with; Ff. wiht; Th. om.
Of what estat so-ever that thou be— 2. Ff. H. estat; Th. estate. Th. om. that.
Riche, strong, or mighty of puissaunce, 3. Th. stronge.
Prudent or wyse, discrete or avisee, 4. Ff. avisee; H. avice; Th. besy.
The doom of folke in soth thou mayst nat flee; 5. Th. Ff. dome; H. doome. Th. sothe. H. mayst; Th. Ff. may. Th. Ff. flye; H. flee.
What-ever that thou do, trust right wel this, 6. H. that; rest om. Ff. H. do; Th. doste. Th. om. right.
A wikked tonge wol alway deme amis. 7. H. Ff. deme; Th. say.
For in thy port or in thyn apparayle 8. Ff. port; Th. porte. Th. thyne.
If thou be clad or honestly be-seyn, 9. All cladde. Ff. H. or; Th. and. Ff. beseyn; Th. be sayne.
Anon the people, of malice, wol nat fayle, 10. Ff. Anon; Th. Anone (and so in other places I correct the spelling by the MSS.).
Without advyce or reson, for to sayn
That thyn array is mad and wrought in vayn; 12. All made.
What! suffre hem spekë!—and trust right wel this, 13. Th. H. om. right.
A wikked tonge wol alway deme amis. 14. Ff. H. deme; Th. say.
Thou wilt to kinges be equipolent. 15. Ff. H. wylt; Th. wolde. Ff. H. equipolent; Th. equiuolent.
With gretë lordes even and peregal; 16. Ff. H. grete; Th. great.
And, if thou be to-torn and al to-rent, 17. Ff. to∣torn; Th. H. torn.
Than wol they say, and jangle over-al,
Thou art a slogard, that never thryvë shal; 19. Ff. H. Thou; Th. That thou.
Yet suffre hem spekë!—and trust right wel this, 20. Th. H. om. right.
A wikked tonge wol alway deme amis. 21. Ff. H deme; Th. say.
If thou be fayr, excelling of beautee,
Than wol they say, that thou art amorous; 23. Ff. H. Than; Th. Yet. All amerous.
If thou be foul and ugly on to see, 24. All foule.
They wol afferme that thou art vicious,
The peple of langage is so dispitous; 26. Ff. H. peple of; Th. peoples.
Suffre hem spekë, and trust right wel this, 27. So Ff.; Th. H. Suffre al their speche and truste (H. deme) wel this.
A wikked tonge wol alway deme amis. 21-28. and 28. Ff. H. deme; Th. say.
And if it fallë that thou take a wyf, 29. Ff. And yif hit falle; Th. If it befal.
[Than] they wol falsly say, in hir entent, 30. Insert Than; see l. 23.
That thou art lykly ever to live in stryf, 31. Ff. Thou art euer lykkely to lyue in stryve.
Voyd of al rest, without alegëment; 32. Ff. alleggement.
Wyves be maistres, this is hir jugëment; 33. Ff. H. be maistres; Th. hem maystren.
Yet suffre hem spekë—and trust right wel this, 34. So Ff.; Th. suffren their speche; om. right.
A wikked tonge wol alway deme amis. 22-35. So in H.; Th. Ff. transpose ll. 29-35. Th. fayre and; Ff. H. om. and. H. excellyng; Ff. Th. excellent. 35. Ff. H. deme; Th. say.
And if it so be that, of parfitnesse, 36. H. And if; Ff. And yif; Th. If. H. it; Th. Ff. om. Th. that thou: Ff. H. om. thou.
Thou hast avowed to live in chastitee, 37. Ff. H. Thou hast; Th. Haue.
Thán wol folk of thy persone expresse
Say thou art impotent t'engendre in thy degree; 39. Ff. H. Say; Th. That. Th. tengendre; Ff. to gendre.
And thus, whether thou be chast or deslavee, 40. Ff. Th. chaste. Ff. dyslave (better deslavee); Th. delauie.
Suffre hem spekë—and trust right wel this, 41. Th. H. om. right.
A wikked tonge wel alway deme amis. 42. Ff. H. deme; Th. say.
And if that thou be fat or corpulent, 43. Th. om. And.
Than wol they say that thou art a glotoun, 44. Th. H. om. that.
A devourour, or ellës vinolent; 45. Th. H. deuourer; Ff. devowrer (better devourour).
If thou be lene or megre of fassioun, 46. Ff. H. lene or megre; Th. megre or leane.
Cal thee a nigard, in hir opinioun; 47. Ff. H. her; Th. H. their.
Yet suffre hem spekë—and trust right wel this, 48. Th. H. om. right.
A wikked tonge wol alway deme amis. 49. Ff. H. deme; Th. say.
If thou be richë, som wol yeve thee laud, 50. All the. Th. laude; Ff. H. lawde.
And say, it cometh of prudent governaunce;
And som wol sayen, that it cometh of fraud, 52. Ff. Th. say; H. sayne. H. that; Th. Ff. om.
Outher by sleight, or by fals chevisaunce; 53. Ff. Outher; Th. H. Or.
To say the worst, folk have so gret plesaunce;
Yet suffre hem sayë—and trust right wel this, 55. Th. What; Ff. H. Yit. Ff. Th. say. Th. H. om. right.
A wikked tonge wol alway deme amis. 56. Ff. H. deme; Th. say.
If thou be sad or sobre of countenaunce, 57. All sadde.
Men wol say—thou thinkest som tresoun; 58. Ff. tresone; Th. H. treason.
And if [that] thou be glad of daliaunce, 59. I supply that.
Men wol deme it dissolucioun, 60. Ff. it is; Th. H. om. is.
And calle thy fair speche, adulacioun; 61. Th. Callyng; Ff. H. And calle. Th. om. thy.
Yet let hem spekë—and trust right wel this, 62. Th. H. om. right.
A wikked tonge wol alway deme amis. 63. Ff. H. deme; Th. say.
Who that is holy by perfeccioun, 64. Ff. H. Who; Th. And who.
Men, of malyce, wol calle him ipocryte; 65. Th. him an; Ff. H. om. an.
And who is mery, of clene entencioun, 66. Th. who that; Ff. H. om. that.
Men say, in ryot he doth him delyte;
Som mourne in blak; som laughe in clothes whyte;
What! suffre them spekë—and trust right wel this, 69. Ff. speke; Th. say. Th. H. om. right.
A wikked tonge wol alway deme amis. 70. Ff. H. deme; Th. say.
Honest array, men deme, †is pompe and pryde, 71. H. in; read is.
And who goth poore, men calle him a wastour; 72. H. vastour.
And who goth [mene], men marke him on every syde, 73. I insert mene; see note.
And saye that he is a spye or a gylour;
Who wasteth, men seyn [that] he hath tresour; 75. H. wastith; I insert that.
Wherfore conclude, and trust [right] wel this, 76. H. coclude (!); H. om. right.
A wikked tonge wil alway deme amis. 71-77. In H. only.
Who speketh mochë, men calle him prudent; 78. Ff. H. men calle him; Th. is holden.
And who debateth, men say, he is hardy; 79. Th. And who; Ff. H. Who that. Th. H. say that; Ff. om. that.
And who saith litel with gret sentiment, 80. Th. who that; Ff. H. om. that.
Som men yet wol edwyte him of foly; 81. Th. men yet; Ff. folke. Ff. H. edwyte; Th. wyte.
Trouth is put down, and up goth flatery; 82. Ff. H. vp; Th. nowe.
And who list plainly know the cause of this, 83. H. who; Ff. ho (=who); Th. who that. Ff. H. cause; Th. trouth.
A wikked tonge wol alway deme amis. 84. So H. Ff.; Th. It is a wicked tonge that alway saythe amys.
For though a man were al-so pacient 85. Ff. also; Th. H. as.
As was David, through his humilitee, 86. Th. om. his.
Or with Salamon in wysdom as prudent, 87. H. wisdom; Th. wisedome; Ff. wysdome.
Or in knighthode egal with Josuë, 88. Ff. to; Th. H. with.
Or manly proved as Judas Machabee,
Yet, for al that—trust right wel this,
A wicked tonge wol alway deme amis. 91. So Ff. H.; Th. Some wycked tonge of hym wol say amys.
And though a man hadde the high prowesse 92. Ff. om. a. All had. Ff. H. om. high.
Of worthy Hector, Troyes champioun,
The love of Troilus or the kindenesse, 94. Ff. H. kyndenes; Th. kyndnesse.
Or of Cesar the famous high renoun,
With Alisaundres dominacioun, 96. Th. Wyth al; Ff. H. om. al.
Yet, for al that—trust right wel this,
A wikked tonge wol alway deme amis. 98. So Ff.; Th. Some wycked tonge of hym wol say amys.
And though a man of high or low degree 99. Ff. H. And; Th. Or.
Of Tullius hadde the sugred eloquence,
Or of Senek the greet moralitee, 101. H. Senek; Ff. Senec; Th. Seneca. Th. great; Ff. H. om.
Or of Catoun the foresight or prudence, 102. Ff. or prudence; Th. H. and prouidence.
Conquest of Charles, Arthurs magnificence, 103. Th. The conquest; Ff. om. The. Ff. Arthurs; Th. H. Arturs.
Yet, for al that—trust right wel this,
A wikked tonge wol alway deme amis. 105. See note to 96.
Touching of women the parfit innocence, 106. H. of; Ff. to.
Thogh they had of Hestre the mekenes,
Or of Griseldes [the] humble pacience, 108. Ff. grecildes; H. Gresieldis; I supply the.
Or of Judith the proved stablenes,
Or Policenes virginal clennes, 110. H. Polycenes; Ff. Penilops.
Yit dar I say and truste right wel this,
A wikked tonge wol alway deme amis. 106-112. Not in Thynne; from Ff. H.
The wyfly trouthë of Penelope, 113. H. wyfly; Th. wyfely; Ff. wylfulle (!). Th. H. trouth; Ff. trowth; read trouthe.
Though they it hadde in hir possessioun, 114. Th. had; Ff. H. hadde. Th. her; Ff. thaire; H. theyr.
Eleynes beautè, the kindnes of Medee, 115. H. Eleynes; Ff. Eleyons; Th. Holynesse (for Heleynes). Th. kyndenesse; Ff. kyndnes.
The love unfeyned of Marcia Catoun, 116. Ff. H. loue; Th. lyfe (!). Th. Mertia; Ff. H. Marcia. Th. Caton; Ff. H. and catoun.
Or of Alcest the trewe affeccioun, 117. Ff. H. Alcestys (om. the).
Yit dar I say and truste right wel this,
A wikked tonge wol alway deme amis. 119. So Ff.; Th. A wycked tonge wol say of her amys.
Than sith it is, that no man may eschewe 120. Ff. suyth; H. sith; Th. sythen. H. it is; Ff. it; Th. it is so (om. that).
The swerde of tonge, but it wol kerve and byte, 121. Ff. wyll (=wol); H. wil; Th. om.
Ful hard it is, a man for to remewe 122. Ff. H. om. for.
Out of hir daunger, so they hem delyte 123. H. hir; Ff. ar; Th. theyr. Ff. so them hem delyte; Th. him for to aquyte.
To hindre or slaundre, and also to bakbyte; 124. Ff. Tho (for To) hindre sclaunder, and also to bacbyte; Th. Wo to the tonges that hem so delyte.
For [this] hir study fynally it is 125. Ff. For thayre study fynaly it ys; Th. To hynder or sclaunder, and set theyr study in this (cf. l. 124).
And hir plesaunce, alwey to deme amis. 126. Th. And theyr pleasaunces to do and say amis; H. And theyr plesaunce alwey to deme amys; Ff. has (as usual) A wicked tonge wol alway deme amis.
Most noble princes, cherisshers of vertue, 127. Ff. princesse; Th. princes.
Remembreth you of high discrecioun,
The first vertue, most plesing to Jesu, 129. Th. and most; Ff. H. om. and. Ff. plesing; Th. pleasyng.
(By the wryting and sentence of Catoun),
Is a good tonge, in his opinioun;
Chastyse the révers, and of wysdom do this, 132. H. revers; Th. reuerse; Ff. reuerce. H. wisdom; Th. Ff. wysdome.
Withdraw your hering from al that deme amis. 133. H. Voydeth (for Withdraw). Ff. deme; Th. saine.

DIV1.HEAD: XIII. BEWARE OF DOUBLENESS.

LG.L: THIS world is ful of variaunce 1. From F. (Fairfax 16); collated with Ed. (ed. 1561). Also in A. (Ash∣mole 59), in which it is much altered; other copies in Ha. (Harl. 7578), and Ad. (Addit. 16165).
In every thing, who taketh hede, 2. F. whoo.
That faith and trust, and al constaunce,
Exyled ben, this is no drede;
And, save only in womanhede,
I can [nat] see no sikernesse; 6. I suþþly nat.
But for al that, yet, as I rede,
Be-war alway of doublenesse.
Also these fresshe somer-floures 9. F. A. these; Ed. that.
Whyte and rede, blewe and grene,
Ben sodainly, with winter-shoures,
Mad feinte and fade, withoute wene; 12. F. feynt; Ha. Ed. feinte.
That trust is non, as ye may seen, 13. F. Ed. sene.
In no-thing, nor no stedfastnesse,
Except in women, thus I mene;
Yet ay be-war of doublenesse.
The croked mone, this is no tale,
Som whyle is shene and bright of hewe, 18. F. A. Ad. is shene; Ed. ishene.
And after that ful derk and pale,
And every moneth chaungeth newe;
That, who the verray sothe knewe, 21. F. A. who so; Ha. Ad. Ed. who.
Al thing is bilt on brotelnesse,
Save that these women ay be trewe; 23. Ad. these; rest om.
Yet ay be-war of doublenesse.
The lusty fresshe somers day,
And Phebus with his bemes clere,
Towardes night, they drawe away,
And no lenger liste appere; 28. Ha. Ad. no; F. Ed. non.
That, in this present lyf now here 29. F. So; rest That.
Nothing abit in his fairnesse, 30. F. abytte; Ed. abieth; Ad. abydeth.
Save women ay be founde intere
And devoid of doublenesse. 32. In the margin of F. Ad.—Per Antifrasim.
The see eke, with his sterne wawes,
Ech day floweth newe again,
And, by concours of his lawes,
The ebbe foloweth, in certain; 36. F. Ad. Ha. foloweth; Ed. repeats floweth from l. 34. A. Soone affter that comthe thebbe certeyne.
After gret drought ther comth a rain,
That farewel here al stabelnesse, 38. F. Ha. farewel al her; Ed. Ad. farewel here al.
Save that women be hole and plain;
Yet ay be-war of doublenesse.
Fortunes wheel goth round aboute
A thousand tymes, day and night:
Whos cours standeth ever in doute
For to transmew; she is so light.
For which adverteth in your sight
Th'untrust of worldly fikelnesse,
Save women, which of kindly right
Ne have no tache of doublenesse. 48. F. Ad. Ha. haue; Ed. hath. F. tachche; Ed. teche.
What man may the wind restraine
Or holde a snake by the tail,
Or a sliper eel constraine 51. F. slepur; Ha. sleper; Ed. Ad. slipper.
That it nil voide, withouten fail; 52. A. nyl; Ad. nil; Ha. wol; F. wil; Ed. will.
Or who can dryve so a nail 53. A. dryve so depe a.
To make sure new-fangelnesse, 54. Ed. suere.
Save women, that can gye hir sail
To rowe hir boot with doublenesse. 55,56. Ad. hir; Ha. F. her; Ed. their.
At every haven they can aryve
Wher-as they wote is good passage;
Of innocence, they can not stryve
With wawes nor no rokkes rage;
So happy is hir lodemanage, 61. F. happe; Ha. Ed. happy. F. her (=hir); Ed. their.
With nelde and stoon hir cours to dresse, 62. F. nelde; Ed. Ha. nedle. F. Ha. her; Ed. their.
That Salamon was not so sage
To find in hem no doublenesse. 64. F. Ha. hem; Ed. them.
Therfor who-so hem accuse 65. F. Wherfor; Ed. Ha. Ad. Therefore. MSS. hem; Ed. them.
Of any double entencioun,
To speke, rowne, other to muse, 67. Ed. rowme (!).
To pinche at hir condicioun; 68. F. hyr; Ad. hir; Ha. her; Ed. their.
Al is but fals collusioun, 69. A. Ad. nys (for is).
I dar right wel the sothe expresse;
They have no better proteccioun 71. Ed. better; F. bette; Ha. Ad. bet.
But shroude hem under doublenesse. 72. MSS. hem; Ed. them.
So wel fortúned is hir chaunce 73. Ad. Ed. their.
The dys to turnen up-so-doun, 74. F. Ed. turne; Ad. Ha. turnen.
With sys and sink they can avaunce,
And than, by revolucioun,
They sette a fel conclusioun
Of ambes as, in sothfastnesse; 78. F. Ambes ase; Ad. Ha. aumbes as; Ed. lombes, as (!)
Though clerkes make mencioun
Hir kind is fret with doublenesse.
Sampsoun had experience
That women were ful trewe founde, 82. F. weren; Ed. A. were. MSS. founde; Ed. ifound.
Whan Dalida, of innocence,
With sheres gan his heer to rounde; 84. A. heres; Ad. here; Ed. heere; F. hede.
To speke also of Rosamounde
And Cleopatras feithfulnesse,
The stories plainly wil confounde 87. F. Ad. Ed. The; A. Hir.
Men that apeche hir doublenesse. 88. MSS. hir, her; Ed. their.
Sengle thing ne is not preised,
Nor oo-fold is of no renoun; 90. F. oo folde; A. oone folde; Ed. ofolde.
In balaunce whan they be peised,
For lakke of weght they be bore doun;
And for this cause of just resoun, 92. F. A. Ad. weght; Ha. wight; Ed. waighte. A. borne.
These women alle, of rightwisnesse,
Of chois and free eleccioun
Most love eschaunge and doublenesse. 96. A. Ad. Haue stuffed hem with doublenesse.
O ye women, which been enclyned, 97. A. that (for which).
By influence of your nature,
To been as pure as gold y-fyned
In your trouth for to endure, 100. A. In alle youre touches for. Ad. trouthe for tendure.
Arm your-self in strong armure 101. For Arm read Armeth?
Lest men assaile your sikernesse: 102. Ha. assaye.
Set on your brest, your-self t'assure, 103. F. A. Ad. tassure; Ed. Ha. to assure.
A mighty sheld of doublenesse. 104. F. Ed. shelde; A sheelde.

DIV1.HEAD: XIV. A BALADE: WARNING MEN TO BEWARE OF DECEITFUL WOMEN. From Trin. (Trin. Coll. Cam. R. 3. 19), printed in Ed. (ed. 1561); T. (Trin. Coll. O. 9. 38); H. (Harl. 2251).

LG.L: LOKE wel aboute, ye that lovers be; 1. Trin. welle. T. abowte; Trin. about.
Lat nat your lustes lede you to dotage; 2. Trin. leede.
Be nat enamoured on al thing that ye see. 3. Trin. se.
Sampson the fort, and Salamon the sage 4. T. H. Salamon; Trin. Salomon.
Deceived were, for al hir gret corage; 5. T. here (read hir)); Trin. H. theyr (and elsewhere).
Men deme hit is right as they see at y; 6. So T.; Trin. H. hit right that they se with. T. eye; Trin. ey; H. ye; (read y).
Bewar therfore; the blinde et many a fly. 7. T. ette, alt. to ettyth; Trin. H. eteth (read et, and so elsewhere).
I mene, in women, for al hir cheres queinte, 8. H. T. in; Trin. of. Trin. wemen; queynt.
Trust nat to moche; hir trouthë is but geson; 9. Trin. H. hem nat (T. om. hem). Trin. trowth; geason (T. geson).
The fairest outward ful wel can they peinte, 10. T. fulle; Trin. H. om. Trin. peynt.
Hir stedfastnes endureth but a seson;
For they feyn frendlines and worchen treson. 12. Trin. feyne.
And for they be chaungeáble naturally, 13. T. be; Trin. ar; H. are. Trin. chaungeabylle.
Bewar therfore; the blinde et many a fly.
Though al the world do his besy cure
To make women stonde in stablenes, 16. Trin. wemen stond; stabylnes.
Hit may nat be, hit is agayn nature; 17. T. H. may; Trin. wolle.
The world is do whan they lak doublenes; 18. Trin. doubylnes.
For they can laughe and love nat; this is expres. 19. Trin. lawgh; expresse. H. om. nat.
To trust in hem, hit is but fantasy; 20. H. T. in; Trin. on. Trin. theym.
Bewar therfore; the blind et many a fly.
What wight on-lyve trusteth in hir cheres 22. T. yn; Trin. on. Trin. cherys.
Shal haue at last his guerdon and his mede;
They can shave nerer then rasóurs or sheres; 24. T. They; Trin. For wemen.
Al is nat gold that shyneth! Men, take hede; 25. Trin. shynyth.
Hir galle is hid under a sugred wede. 26. Trin. sugryd.
Hit is ful hard hir fantasy t'aspy; 27. T. harde; Trin. H. queynt. Trin. to aspy.
Bewar therfore; the blinde et many a fly. 15-28. So T. H.; Trin transposes 15-21 and 22-28.
Women, of kinde, have condicions three; 29. T. has the note: Fallere flere nere tria sunt hec in muliere. Trin. thre.
The first is, that they be fulle of deceit; 30. T. that; Trin. H. om.
To spinne also hit is hir propertee; 31. T. hyt; Trin. om. T. properte; Trin. propurte.
And women have a wonderful conceit, 32. H. haue; T. hath; Trin. om. Trin. conseyte.
They wepen ofte, and al is but a sleight, 33. Trin. H. For they; T. om. For. T. wepyth (read wepen); Trin. wepe. T. H. but; Trin. om. H. a sleight; T. deceyt; Trin. asteyte; Ed. a sleite.
And whan they list, the tere is in the y; 34. Trin. teere; ey.
Bewar therfore; the blinde et many a fly.
What thing than eyr is lighter and meveable?
The light, men say, that passeth in a throw; 37. T. passyth.
Al if the light be nat so variable 38. T. All yff; waryabylle.
As is the wind that every wey [can] blow; 39. T. wynde; ys blow (alt. to blowth; read can blow).
And yet, of reson, som men deme and trow 40. T. yut; summen.
Women be lightest of hir company; 41. T. ther (for hir).
Bewar therfore; the blind et many a fly. 36-42. In T. only.
In short to say, though al the erth so wan 43. T. schorte; Trin. sothe. Trin. erthe; wanne.
Were parchëmyn smothe, whyte and scribable, 44. Trin. parchemyne; scrybabylle.
And the gret see, cleped the occian, 45. T. H. that clepyd is; Trin. that callyd ys (read cleped). H. om. the. Trin. occiane.
Were torned in inke, blakker then is sable, 46. T. yn; Trin. into; H. to. T. H. is; Trin. om.
Ech stik a penne, ech man a scriveyn able, 47. T. H. Eche; Trin. Euery. Trin. yche; abylle. H. scryven; T. Trin. scriuener.
They coud nat wryte wommannes traitory; 48. T. They cowde not; Trin. Nat cowde then (!). T. wymmenys; Trin. womans; H. wommans. T. treytorye; Trin. H. trechery
Bewar therfore; the blinde et many a fly.

DIV1.HEAD: XVI. LA BELLE DAME SANS MERCY. From Th. (Thynne, ed. 1532); collated with F. (Fairfax 16); and H. (Harl. 372). Also in Ff. (Camb. Univ. Lib. Ff. 1. 6). Bad spellings of Th. are cor∣rected by the MSS. TITLE. Th. H. La . . mercy; F. Balade de la Bele Dame sanz mercy. H. adds—Translatid . . Ros.
DIV1.BYLINE: TRANSLATED OUT OF FRENCH BY SIR RICHARD ROS.

LG.L: HALF in a dreme, not fully wel awaked, 1. Th. F. Halfe; H. Half.
The golden sleep me wrapped under his wing; 2. F. H. Ff. wrapt.
Yet nat for-thy I roos, and wel nigh naked, 3. All rose.
Al sodaynly my-selve rémembring 4. Th. Ef. -selfe; H. F. self.
Of a matér, leving al other thing 5. F. matere; H. matier. Th. leuynge.
Which I shold do, with-outen more delay, 6. Th. must; F. sholde; H. shold.
For hem to whom I durst nat disobey. 7. H. to whom; F. the which; Th. whiche. Th. F. dysobey; H. sey nay.
My charge was this, to translate by and by,
(Al thing forgive), as part of my penaunce, 9. Th. thynge. Ef. part; rest parte.
A book called Belle Dame sans Mercy 10. Th. F. boke; H. book. Th. La bel; F. la bele; H. om. La. H. F. sanz; Th. sauns.
Which mayster Aleyn made of rémembraunce, 11. Th. Whiche.
Cheef secretarie with the king of Fraunce. 12. Th. secratairie; F. secretare; H. secretarie.
And ther-upon a whyle I stood musing, 13. H. ther-; Th. F. her-. Th. F. stode; H. stood.
And in my-self gretly imagening 14. Th. greatly ymagenynge.
What wyse I shuld performe the sayd processe, 15. Th. shulde; F. H. sholde; Ff. shuld. Th. the; F. H. this.
Considering by good avysement 16. Ff. avyse∣ment; rest adv.
Myn unconning and my gret simplenesse, 17. F. H. Ff. Myn; Th. My. F. H. Ff. symplesse.
And ayenward the strait commaundement 18. Th.-warde; strayte.
Which that I had; and thus, in myn entent, 19. Th. myne.
I was vexed and tourned up and doun; 20. Th. downe.
And yet at last, as in conclusioun, 21. Th. conclusyon.
I cast my clothes on, and went my way,
This foresayd charge having in rémembraunce,
Til I cam to a lusty green valey 24. H. in-to. H. green; Th. F. grene.
Ful of floures, to see, a gret plesaunce; 25. Th. se; gret.
And so bolded, with their benygn suffraunce 26. F. H. Ff. bolded; Th. boldly. F. benyng; Th. benygne; H. benyngne.
That rede this book, touching this sayd matere, 27. F. H. Ff. That; Th. Whiche. Th. F. boke; H. booke. H. F. the; Th. Ff. this. Th. om. seid.
Thus I began, if it plese you to here. 28. F. H. begynne. Th. please. (From this point I silently correct the spelling of Th.)
NAT long ago, ryding an esy paas,
I fel in thought, of joy ful desperate
With greet disese and payne, so that I was
Of al lovers the most unfortunate,
Sith by his dart most cruel, ful of hate, 33. Th. Ff. by; F. H. with.
The deeth hath take my lady and maistresse,
And left me sole, thus discomfit and mate, 35. Ff. soleyne (for sole thus); perhaps better.
Sore languisshing, and in way of distresse.
Than sayd I thus, 'it falleth me to cesse
Eyther to ryme or ditees for to make,
And I, surely, to make a ful promesse
To laugh no more, but wepe in clothes blake.
My joyful tyme, alas! now is it slake, 41. F. H. Ff. is; Th. doth.
For in my-self I fele no maner ese; 42. F. felde. Th. maner of ease.
Let it be written, such fortune I take, 43. F. H. I; Th. as I.
Which neither me, nor non other doth plese. 44. F. H. Ff. nor doth noon other.
If it were so, my wil or myn entent
Constrayned were a joyful thing to wryte, 46. F. H. Ff. Were constreyned.
Myn pen coud never have knowlege what it ment; 47. H. Myn eyen; F. Myn eyn; Th. My penne; Ff. My pen. Ff. neuer haue knolege; H. haue knowlege (!); Th. neuer knowe; F. haue no knowlych.
To speke therof my tonge hath no delyte.
And with my mouth if I laugh moche or lyte, 49. F. H. Ff. And; Th. Tho. Th. om. if.
Myn eyen shold make a countenaunce untrewe;
My hert also wold have therof despyte,
The weping teres have so large issewe.
These seke lovers, I leve that to hem longes, 53. F. H. Ff. seke; Th. sicke.
Which lede their lyf in hope of alegeaunce, 54. Th. Ff. theyr; H. F. her (often).
That is to say, to make balades and songes, 55. F. H. balade or.
Every of hem, as they fele their grevaunce.
For she that was my joy and my plesaunce,
Whos soule I pray god of his mercy save,
She hath my wil, myn hertes ordinaunce,
Which lyeth here, within this tombe y-grave. 60. F. H. Ff. lyth with hir vndir hir tumbe in graue (Ff. I-graue).
Fro this tyme forth, tyme is to hold my pees;
It werieth me this mater for to trete;
Let other lovers put hem-self in prees;
Their seson is, my tyme is now forgete.
Fortune by strength the forcer hath unshet 65. Th. Ff. by; F. H. with. F. hath the forser vnschete.
Wherin was sperd al my worldly richesse, 66. Th. sperde; Ff. spred; F. sprad; H. spradde (!).
And al the goodes which that I have gete
In my best tyme of youthe and lustinesse.
Love hath me kept under his governaunce;
If I misdid, god graunt me forgifnesse!
If I did wel, yet felte I no plesaunce;
It caused neither joy nor hevinesse.
For whan she dyed, that was my good maistresse, 73. Th. H. om. good.
Al my welfare than made the same purchas; 74. Th. om. Al. H. made than.
The deeth hath set my boundes, of witnes, 75. F. Ff. set; H. sette; Th. shette. F. H. Ff. boundes; Th. bondes.
Which for no-thing myn hert shal never pas.'
In this gret thought, sore troubled in my mynde, 77. F. H. thoughtes. Th. om. my.
Aloon thus rood I al the morow-tyde,
Til at the last it happed me to fynde 79. F. I (for it).
The place wherin I cast me to abyde 80. H. I purposid me to bide.
Whan that I had no further for to ryde. 81. H. forth to.
And as I went my logging to purvey,
Right sone I herde, but litel me besyde, 83. F. H. Ff. but; Th. a.
In a gardeyn, wher minstrels gan to play. 84. F. H. gardeyn; Th. garden.
With that anon I went me bakker-more;
My-self and I, me thought, we were y-now;
But twayn that were my frendes here-before
Had me espyed, and yet I wot nat how. 88. F. om. yet I; H. om. yet.
They come for me; awayward I me drow, 89. F. H. come; Th. came.
Somwhat by force, somwhat by their request, 90. Th. her; F. H. Ff. their.
That in no wyse I coud my-self rescow,
But nede I must come in, and see the feest. 92. F. H. nede; Th. nedes.
At my coming, the ladies everichoon
Bad me welcome, god wot, right gentilly,
And made me chere, everich by oon and oon, 95. H. F. Ff. eueryche by one and one; Th. euery one by one.
A gret del better than I was worthy;
And, of their grace, shewed me gret curtesy
With good disport, bicause I shuld nat mourne.
That day I bood stille in their company,
Which was to me a gracious sojourne.
The bordes were spred in right litel space;
The ladies sat, ech as hem semed best.
Were non that did servyce within that place 103. So Ff.; H. F. Were none that serued in that place (!); Th. Ther were no deedly seruaunts in the place.
But chosen men, right of the goodliest:
And som ther were, peravénture most fresshest, 105. Ff. peraunter. H. om. most.
That sawe their juges, sitting ful demure, 106. Th. om. sitting.
Without semblaunt either to most or lest,
Notwithstanding they had hem under cure.
Among al other, oon I gan espy
Which in gret thought ful often com and went 110. F. com; H. come; Th. came.
As man that had ben ravished utterly, 111. H. F. man; Th. one; Ff. on.
In his langage nat gretly diligent;
His countenaunce he kept with greet tourment,
But his desyr fer passed his resoun;
For ever his eye went after his entent 115. Th. F. Ff. went; H. yode.
Ful many a tyme, whan it was no sesoun. 116. Th. F. Ff. Ful; H. At.
To make good chere, right sore him-self he payned, 117. Th. om. good and right.
And outwardly he fayned greet gladnesse;
To singe also by force he was constrayned
For no plesaunce, but very shamfastnesse;
For the complaynt of his most hevinesse
Com to his voice alwey without request, 122. F. H. Come; Th. Came.
Lyk as the sowne of birdes doth expresse
Whan they sing loude, in frith or in forest. 124. F. H. om. 2nd in.
Other ther were, that served in the hal,
But non lyk him, as after myn advyse;
For he was pale, and somwhat lene with-al;
His speche also trembled in fereful wyse;
And ever aloon, but when he did servyse.
Al blak he ware, and no devyce but playn.
Me thought by him, as my wit coud suffyse,
His hert was no-thing in his own demeyn.
To feste hem al he did his diligence, 133. F. H. feste; Th. feest.
And wel he couth, right as it semed me. 134. Th. coude; rest couth. F. H. om. it.
But evermore, whan he was in presence,
His chere was don; it wold non other be.
His scole-maister had suche auctoritè
That, al the whyle he bood stille in the place, 138. Th. H. bode.
Speke coude he nat, but upon her beautè
He loked stil, with right a pitous face.
With that, his heed he tourned at the last
For to behold the ladies everichon;
But ever in oon he set his ey stedfast 143. F. eey; H. yee; Th. eye. Th. F. Ff. stedfast; H. faste.
On her, the which his thought was most upon. 144. Th. om. the.
And of his eyen the shot I knew anon 145. F. H. And; Th. For. Th. Ff. shot; H. sight; F. seght.
Which federed was with right humble requestes. 146. H. fedired; F. fedred; Ff. federid; Th. fereful.
Than to my-self I sayd, 'By god aloon,
Suche oon was I, or that I saw these gestes.' 148. Th. I, or that; F. ther that; H. I that there. Th. iestes.
Out of the prees he went ful esely
To make stable his hevy countenaunce;
And, wit ye wel, he syghed tenderly 151. F. H. tendirly; Th. wonderly.
For his sorowes and woful remembraunce.
That in him-self he made his ordinaunce,
And forth-withal com to bringe in the mes; 154. F. H. come; Th. came.
But, for to juge his most ruful semblaunce, 155. F. H. om. most. F. H. ruful; Ff. rewfull; Th. woful. F. H. Ff. semblaunce; Th. penaunce.
God wot, it was a pitous entremes!
After diner, anon they hem avaunced
To daunce about, these folkes everichoon; 158. F. H. these; Th. the.
And forth-withal this hevy lover daunced 159. F. H. louer; Th. man he.
Somtyme with twayn, and somtyme but with oon. 160. Th. om. but.
Unto hem al his chere was after oon,
Now here, now there, as fel by aventure;
But ever among, he drew to her aloon
Which he most dredde of living creature.
To myn advyse, good was his purveyaunce
Whan he her chase to his maistresse aloon, 166. All chase.
If that her hert were set to his plesaunce
As moche as was her beauteous persone. 168. F. H. beautevous.
For who that ever set his trust upon 169. F. H. that; Th. so. F. H. set; Th. setteth. H. trist.
The réport of the eyen, withouten more, 170. Th. the (rightly); H. there; F. Ff. their.
He might be deed and graven under stoon 171. F. vndir a.
Or ever he shulde his hertes ese restore.
In her fayled nothing, as I coud gesse, 173. F. H. as; Th. that.
O wyse nor other, prevy nor apert; 174. F. Ff. O; H. On; Th. One. F. H. vice.(!). H. ner (for 1st nor). Th. Ff. nor; H. or; F. ne. Ff. apert; Th. H. perte; F. pert.
A garnison she was of al goodnesse 175. Th. garyson. Th. goodlynesse.
To make a frounter for a lovers hert; 176. All frounter.
Right yong and fresshe, a woman ful covert;
Assured wel her port and eke her chere, 178. F. H. Ff. her; Th. of (twice).
Wel at her ese, withouten wo or smert,
Al underneth the standard of Daungere. 180. Th. standerde: F. standarte; H. standart.
To see the feest, it weried me ful sore;
For hevy joy doth sore the hert travayle.
Out of the prees I me withdrew therfore, 183. Th. -drawe; H. -drewh.
And set me down aloon, behynd a trayle 184. Th. Ff. alone; F.H. om.
Ful of leves, to see, a greet mervayle,
With grene withies y-bounden wonderly; 186. F. withes; H. Ff. wythyes; Th. wrethes.
The leves were so thik, withouten fayle,
That thorough-out might no man me espy. 188. H. Ff. thorughe; Th. through; F. thorgh. Th. no man might.
To this lady he com ful curteisly 189. Th. this; H. his. F. H. come; Th. came.
Whan he thought tyme to daunce with her a trace;
Sith in an herber made ful pleasauntly 191. Th. Set (for Sith). H. herbier.
They rested hem, fro thens but litel space. 192. H. them. Th. but a.
Nigh hem were none, a certayn of compace, 193. Th. of a certayne.
But only they, as fer as I coud see;
And save the trayle, ther I had chose my place, 195. Th. om. And.
Ther was no more betwix hem tweyne and me. 196. So F. H.; Th. bytwene hem two.
I herd the lover syghing wonder sore;
For ay the neer, the sorer it him sought.
His inward payne he coud not kepe in store,
Nor for to speke, so hardy was he nought.
His leche was neer, the gretter was his thought; 201. Th. more; H. Ff. neer.
He mused sore, to conquere his desyre;
For no man may to more penaunce be brought
Than, in his hete, to bringe him to the fyre. 204. Ff. hete; Th. heate; F. H. hert.
The hert began to swel within his chest,
So sore strayned for anguish and for payne
That al to peces almost it to-brest,
Whan bothe at ones so sore it did constrayne;
Desyr was bold, but shame it gan refrayne; 209. Th. Ff. gan; F. H. can.
That oon was large, the other was ful cloos; 210. F. H. The toon.
No litel charge was layd on him, certayn,
To kepe suche werre, and have so many foos.
Ful often-tymes to speke him-self he peyned,
But shamfastnesse and drede sayd ever 'nay';
Yet at the last so sore he was constrayned,
Whan he ful long had put it in delay,
To his lady right thus than gan he say
With dredful voice, weping, half in a rage:—
'For me was purveyd an unhappy day
Whan I first had a sight of your visage! 213-220. F. omits.
I suffre payne, god wot, ful hoot brenning,
To cause my deeth, al for my trew servyse;
And I see wel, ye rekke therof nothing,
Nor take no hede of it, in no kins wyse. 224. F. H. Ff. kyns; Th. kynde.
But whan I speke after my best avyse, 225. H. Ff. avise; Th. aduyse.
Ye set it nought, but make ther-of a game; 226. Th. it at; F. H. om. at.
And though I sewe so greet an entrepryse, 227. H. enterprise.
It peyreth not your worship nor your fame. 228. F. H. It; Th. Yet.
Alas! what shulde be to you prejudyce 229. Th. it be; F. H. om. it.
If that a man do love you faithfully
To your worship, eschewing every vyce? 231. Th. Ff. eschewynge; F. H. escusyng.
So am I yours, and wil be verily;
I chalenge nought of right, and reson why,
For I am hool submit to your servyse; 234. F. H. to; Th. vnto.
Right as ye liste it be, right so wil I, 235. All ye. Th. Ff. right; F. even; H. euyn.
To bynde my-self, where I was in fraunchyse!
Though it be so, that I can nat deserve 237. H. om. that.
To have your grace, but alway live in drede, 238. Th. alway; F. H. ay to.
Yet suffre me you for to love and serve 239. F. H. om. for.
Without maugrè of your most goodlihede; 240. Th. Withouten; F. Without.
Both faith and trouth I give your womanhede, 241. H. gif; F. geve.
And my servyse, withoute ayein-calling. 242. F. H. ayein; Th. any (!).
Love hath me bounde, withouten wage or mede, 243. F. withouten; H. withoughtyn; Th. withoute.
To be your man, and leve al other thing.'
Whan this lady had herd al this langage,
She yaf answere ful softe and demurely,
Without chaunging of colour or corage,
No-thing in haste, but mesurabelly:— 248. F. Ff. mesurabely; Th. H. mesurably.
'Me thinketh, sir, your thought is greet foly! 249. Th. Ff. your thought is; F. H. ye do ful.
Purpose ye not your labour for to cese?
For thinketh not, whyl that ye live and I, 251. Th. thynketh; F. H. think ye. Th. whyles; H. whil that; Ff. whils that.
In this matére to set your hert in pees!' 252. F. matere; H. matier; Th. mater.
'Ther may non make the pees, but only ye,
Which ar the ground and cause of al this werre;
For with your eyen the letters written be,
By which I am defyed and put a-fer.
Your plesaunt look, my verray lode-sterre,
Was made heraud of thilk same défyaunce 258. F. Ff. dyffiaunce.
Which utterly behight me to forbarre 259. F. H. Ff. to forbarre; Th. for to barre.
My faithful trust and al myn affyaunce.'
'To live in wo he hath gret fantasy
And of his hert also hath slipper holde, 262. Th. om. hath.
That, only for beholding of an y, 263. Th. eye; F. eeye; H. yee; (read y).
Can nat abyde in pees, as reson wolde!
Other or me if ye list to beholde, 265. F. if that ye lyst to beholde; H. Ff. if ye liste to biholde; Th. if ye list ye may beholde.
Our eyen are made to loke; why shuld we spare?
I take no kepe, neither of yong nor olde; 267. H. nor; Th. F. Ff. ne.
Who feleth smert, I counsayle him be ware!'
'If it be so, oon hurte another sore,
In his defaut that feleth the grevaunce,
Of very right a man may do no more;
Yet reson wolde it were in remembraunce.
And, sith Fortune not only, by her chaunce, 273. Th. om. not. Th. her; F. H. Ff. his.
Hath caused me to suffre al this payn,
But your beautè, with al the circumstaunce, 275. F. H. Ff. But; Th. By (!).
Why list ye have me in so greet disdayn?'
'To your persone ne have I no disdayn,
Nor ever had, trewly! ne nought wil have, 278. H. om. trewly. Th. Ff. nought; F. H. neuer.
Nor right gret love, nor hatred, in certayn;
Nor your counsayl to know, so god me save!
If such beleve be in your mynde y-grave 281. F. beleue; H. bileue; Th. loue (!).
That litel thing may do you greet plesaunce, 282. So Ff.; H. F. om. greet (Th. you dyspleasaunce!).
You to begyle, or make you for to rave,
I wil nat cause no suche encomberaunce!' 284. So F. Th.; H. encombrance.
'What ever it be that me hath thus purchased,
Wening hath nat disceyved me, certayn,
But fervent love so sore hath me y-chased
That I, unware, am casten in your chayne;
And sith so is, as Fortune list ordayne,
Al my welfare is in your handes falle, 290. F. I-falle; H. y-falle; Ff. falle; Th. fal.
In eschewing of more mischévous payn;
Who sonest dyeth, his care is leest of alle.'
'This sicknesse is right esy to endure,
But fewe people it causeth for to dy;
But what they mene, I know it very sure,
Of more comfort to draw the remedy.
Such be there now, playning ful pitously, 297. Th. F. Ff. now; H. nought.
That fele, god wot, nat alther-grettest payne;
And if so be, love hurt so grevously,
Lesse harm it were, oon sorowful, than twayne!'
'Alas, madame! if that it might you plese,
Moche better were, by way of gentilnesse, 302. Th. it were; F. H. om. it.
Of one sory, to make twayn wel at ese, 303. F. sorow; H. sorwe; Th. Ff. sory.
Than him to stroy that liveth in distresse! 304. F. H. stroye; Th. destroye.
For my desyr is neither more nor lesse
But my servyce to do, for your plesaunce,
In eschewing al maner doublenesse,
To make two joyes in stede of oo grevaunce!' 308. F. H. oo; Th. one.
'Of love I seke neither plesaunce nor ese, 309. Th. Ff. nor; F. H. ne.
Nor greet desyr, nor right gret affyaunce; 310. F. H. grete desire nor; Th. haue therin no. Th. om. right.
Though ye be seke, it doth me nothing plese; 311. F. H. seke; Th. sicke.
Also, I take no hede to your plesaunce. 312. Th. of; F. H. Ff. to.
Chese who-so wil, their hertes to avaunce, 313. F. H. their; Th. her.
Free am I now, and free wil I endure;
To be ruled by mannes governaunce
For erthely good, nay! that I you ensure!'
'Love, which that joy and sorowe doth departe, 317. Th. that ioy; F. H. om. that.
Hath set the ladies out of al servage, 318. F. H. om. al.
And largëly doth graunt hem, for their parte, 319. F. H. their; Th. her.
Lordship and rule of every maner age. 320. Th. maner of age.
The poor servaunt nought hath of avauntage
But what he may get only of purchase; 322. Th. by; F. H. Ff. of. Th. purchesse; F. H. purchace.
And he that ones to love doth his homage,
Ful often tyme dere bought is the rechace.' 324. Th. tymes. F. om. the. H. dere his richesse bought has. Ff. rechace; rest richesse.
'Ladies be nat so simple, thus I mene,
So dul of wit, so sotted of foly, 326. Th. in (for 2nd of).
That, for wordes which sayd ben of the splene, 327. F. ben; Th. be; H. are.
In fayre langage, paynted ful plesauntly,
Which ye and mo holde scoles of dayly, 329. H. scoolys holden dieuly.
To make hem of gret wonders to suppose; 330. F. H. of; Th. al.
But sone they can away their hedes wrye, 331. F. H. their hedes away.
And to fair speche lightly their eres close.'
'Ther is no man that jangleth busily,
And set his hert and al his mynd therfore, 334. F. set; Ff. sette; Th. H. setteth.
That by resoun may playne so pitously
As he that hath moche hevinesse in store.
Whos heed is hool, and sayth that it is sore, 337. F. H. om. that.
His fayned chere is hard to kepe in mewe;
But thought, which is unfayned evermore,
The wordes preveth, as the workes sewe. 340. Th. shewe; F. sue; H. Ff. sewe.
'Love is subtel, and hath a greet awayt, 341. Th. Ff. awayte; F. H. abayte.
Sharp in worching, in gabbing greet plesaunce, 342. F. worching; H. worsching; Th. workyng.
And can him venge of suche as by disceyt
Wold fele and knowe his secret governaunce; 344. F. H. know and fele.
And maketh hem to obey his ordinaunce
By chereful wayes, as in hem is supposed; 346. F. H. him; Th. Ff. hem.
But whan they fallen in-to repentaunce, 347. F. H. when that; Th. om. that.
Than, in a rage, their counsail is disclosed.' 348. F. H. their; Th. her.
'Sith for-as-moche as god and eke nature
Hath †love avaunced to so hye degrè, 350. All avaunced loue.
Moch sharper is the point, this am I sure, 351. Th. sharpe. F. H. this; Th. thus.
Yet greveth more the faute, wher-ever it be. 352. F. H. It; Th. Ff. Yet.
Who hath no cold, of hete hath no deyntè,
The toon for the tother asked is expresse; 354. F. ton; H. toon; Th. one. F. H. the tother; Th. that other.
And of plesaunce knoweth non the certeyntè 355. Th. om. the. Th. certeyne (!).
But it be wonne with thought and hevinesse.' 356. F. wonne; H. wonnen; Th. one (!). F. H. with; Th. in.
'As for plesaunce, it is nat alway oon;
That you is swete, I thinke it bitter payne. 358. F. H. is; Th. thinke.
Ye may nat me constrayne, nor yet right non,
After your lust, to love that is but vayne.
To chalenge love by right was never seyn,
But herte assent, before bond and promyse;
For strength nor force may not atteyne, certayn, 363. F. nor; H. ner; Th. and. Th. om. certayn.
A wil that stant enfeffed in fraunchyse!' 364. F. H. stant; Th. standeth. F. enfeoffed.
'Right fayr lady, god mote I never plese,
If I seke other right, as in this case, 366. Th. om. as.
But for to shewe you playnly my disese
And your mercy to abyde, and eke your grace.
If I purpose your honour to deface,
Or ever did, god and fortune me shende!
And that I never rightwysly purchace 371. F. H. rightwysly; Th. vnryghtfully (!).
Oon only joy, unto my lyves ende!'
'Ye and other, that swere suche othes faste,
And so condempne and cursen to and fro,
Ful sikerly, ye wene your othes laste
No lenger than the wordes ben ago!
And god, and eke his sayntes, laughe also.
In such swering ther is no stedfastnesse,
And these wrecches, that have ful trust therto,
After, they wepe and waylen in distresse.'
'He hath no corage of a man, trewly,
That secheth plesaunce, worship to despyse;
Nor to be called forth is not worthy
The erthe to touch the ayre in no-kins wyse. 384. Th. Ff. ayre; F. eir; H. heire.
A trusty hert, a mouth without feyntyse,
These ben the strength of every man of name; 386. Th. Thus be. F. H. Ff. man of; Th. maner.
And who that layth his faith for litel pryse, 387. F. layth; Th. layeth; H. latith.
He leseth bothe his worship and his fame.' 388. H. losith.
'A currish herte, a mouth that is curteys, 389. F. Ff. currisch; H. kurressh; Th. cursed.
Ful wel ye wot, they be not according;
Yet feyned chere right sone may hem apeyse 391. Th. F. right; H. ful.
Where of malyce is set al their worching; 392. F. H. their; Th. her. F. worchyng; H. werchyng; Th. workynge.
Ful fals semblant they bere and trew mening; 393. Th. and; F. H. a. F. Th. Ff. semyng; H. menyng.
Their name, their fame, their tonges be but fayned; 394. F. H. Their; Th. Her (thrice). Th. om. be. Th. but; F. H. not.
Worship in hem is put in forgetting,
Nought repented, nor in no wyse complayned.'
'Who thinketh il, no good may him befal;
God, of his grace, graunt ech man his desert!
But, for his love, among your thoughtes al,
As think upon my woful sorowes smert; 400. H. sorowe.
For of my payne, wheder your tender hert 401. Th. wheder; Ff. whedre; F. H. wher.
Of swete pitè be not therwith agreved,
And if your grace to me were discovert, 403. F. H. Ff. if; Th. of.
Than, by your mene, sone shulde I be releved.' 404. F. Ff. Then; H. Thanne; Th. That.
'A lightsom herte, a folly of plesaunce
Are moch better, the lesse whyl they abyde;
They make you thinke, and bring you in a traunce;
But that seknesse wil sone be remedyed. 408. Th. sicknesse.
Respite your thought, and put al this asyde;
Ful good disportes werieth men al-day; 410. Th. disporte. Th. me.
To help nor hurt, my wil is not aplyed; 411. Th. Ff. nor; F. H. ne.
Who troweth me not, I lete it passe away.' 412. F. H. Ff. it; Th. hem.
'Who hath a brid, a faucon, or a hound, 413. Th. Ff. byrde; F. bride; H. bridde.
That foloweth him, for love, in every place,
He cherissheth him, and kepeth him ful sound; 415. H. om. 2nd him.
Out of his sight he wil not him enchace. 416. F. H. om. 2nd him.
And I, that set my wittes, in this cace,
On you alone, withouten any chaunge,
Am put under, moch ferther out of grace, 419. Th. farther.
And lesse set by, than other that be straunge.' 420. F. H. sett lesse.
'Though I make chere to every man aboute
For my worship, and of myn own fraunchyse, 422. F. H. Ff. of; Th. for.
To you I nil do so, withouten doute,
In eschewing al maner prejudyse. 424. F. H. of all; Th. Ff. om. of.
For wit ye wel, love is so litel wyse, 425. Th. wote; F. H. wytt.
And in beleve so lightly wil be brought,
That he taketh al at his own devyse,
Of thing, god wot, that serveth him of nought.'
'If I, by love and by my trew servyse, 429. (Th.)=669 (F. H.). F. om. 2nd by.
Lese the good chere that straungers have alway,
Wherof shuld serve my trouth in any wise 431. F. There-of. F. H. shulde; Th. shal.
Lesse than to hem that come and go al-day, 432. Th. him that cometh and goth.
Which holde of you nothing, that is no nay? 433. Th. holdeth.
Also in you is lost, to my seming, 434. Th. as to; F. H. Ff. om. as.
Al curtesy, which of resoun wold say 435. F. H. wolde; Th. Ff. wyl.
That love for love were lawful deserving.' 436. Th. desyringe (!).
'Curtesy is alyed wonder nere
To Worship, which him loveth tenderly; 438. Th. To; F. H. With. F. H. best and tendyrly; Th. Ff. om. best and.
And he wil nat be bounde, for no prayere,
Nor for no gift, I say you verily, 440. F. H. om. no. F. H. Ff. yift; Th. gyftes.
But his good chere depart ful largely
Where him lyketh, as his conceit wil fal; 442. F. Wheryn hym.
Guerdon constrayned, a gift don thankfully, 443. F. H. Ff. constreynte.
These twayn may not accord, ne never shal.' 444. F. H. Ff. may not; Th. can neuer. F. H. ne; Th. Ff. nor.
'As for guerdon, I seke non in this cace; 445. H. seche; F. beseche.
For that desert, to me it is to hy; 446. F. H. om. it.
Wherfore I ask your pardon and your grace,
Sith me behoveth deeth, or your mercy.
To give the good where it wanteth, trewly,
That were resoun and a curteys maner; 450. Th. a curtyse; Ff. a corteys; F. H. curteysy.
And to your own moch better were worthy
Than to straungers, to shewe hem lovely chere.'
'What cal ye good? Fayn wolde I that I wist!
That pleseth oon, another smerteth sore;
But of his own to large is he that list
Give moche, and lese al his good fame therfore. 456. Th. om. al.
Oon shulde nat make a graunt, litel ne more,
But the request were right wel according;
If worship be not kept and set before,
Al that is left is but a litel thing.' 460. H. loste (for left).
'In-to this world was never formed non, 461. F. H. Ff. neuer formed (fourmed); Th. founded neuer.
Nor under heven crëature y-bore,
Nor never shal, save only your persone,
To whom your worship toucheth half so sore,
But me, which have no seson, lesse ne more,
Of youth ne age, but still in your service;
I have non eyen, no wit, nor mouth in store, 467. Th. no (for non). F. eeyn; H. yeen.
But al be given to the same office.' 468. H. That ne alle ar.
'A ful gret charge hath he, withouten fayle,
That his worship kepeth in sikernesse;
But in daunger he setteth his travayle
That feffeth it with others businesse. 472. F. feoffeth.
To him that longeth honour and noblesse,
Upon non other shulde nat he awayte; 474. Th. be (for he).
For of his own so moche hath he the lesse 475. F. H. om. his.
That of other moch folweth the conceyt.'
'Your eyen hath set the print which that I fele 477 (Th.)=525 (F. H.).
Within my hert, that, where-so-ever I go, 478. Th. Ff. so; H. sum; F. some.
If I do thing that sowneth unto wele, 479. H. sowndith.
Nedes must it come from you, and fro no mo.
Fortune wil thus, that I, for wele or wo, 481. H. Ff. thus; Th. this.
My lyf endure, your mercy abyding;
And very right wil that I thinke also
Of your worship, above al other thing.'
'To your worship see wel, for that is nede,
That ye spend nat your seson al in vayne; 486. F. om. ye. H. F. your sesoun spende not.
As touching myn, I rede you take no hede,
By your foly to put your-self in payne. 488. H. Ff. foly; Th. folly.
To overcome is good, and to restrayne 489. Th. H. herte. H. F. folyly; Th. follyly.
An hert which is disceyved folily.
For worse it is to breke than bowe, certayn,
And better bowe than fal to sodaynly!' 492. H. F. And; Th. om. Th. to fal.
'Now, fair lady, think, sith it first began 493. H. Th. faire.
That love hath set myn hert under his cure, 494. H. Ff. had (for hath). H. F. your; Th. Ff. his.
I never might, ne truly I ne can 495. F. H. I neuer; Th. Ff. It neuer.
Non other serve, whyle I shal here endure; 496. F. H. whiles.
In most free wyse therof I make you sure,
Which may not be withdrawe; this is no nay.
I must abyde al maner aventure;
For I may not put to, nor take away.' 500. H. F. not; Ff. nought; Th. neyther.
'I holde it for no gift, in sothfastnesse, 501. Th. gyfte; H. yifte.
That oon offreth, where that it is forsake; 502. Th. om. that.
For suche gift is abandoning expresse 503. Th. a gifte; H. F. Ff. om. a.
That with worship ayein may not be take.
He hath an hert ful fel that list to make 505. H. F. om. an. H. hurte ful fele (!).
A gift lightly, that put is in refuse; 506. H. F. Ff. in; Th. to.
But he is wyse that such conceyt wil slake,
So that him nede never to study ne muse.' 508. H. F. neuer; Th. neyther.
'He shuld nat muse, that hath his service spent 509. H. F. Who; Th. Ff. He.
On her which is a lady honourable;
And if I spende my tyme to that entent,
Yet at the leest I am not reprevable 512. F. om. the. Th. reproveable.
Of feyled hert; to thinke I am unable, 513. F. H. feyled; Th. fayned.
Or me mistook whan I made this request, 514. Th. I mystoke; H. F. Ff. me mystoke.
By which love hath, of entreprise notable, 515. F. entrepris.
So many hertes gotten by conquest.' 516. H. F. goten.
'If that ye list do after my counsayl, 517. H. Th. liste.
Secheth fairer, and of more higher fame, 518. F. H. Secheth; Th. Seche a.
Whiche in servyce of love wil you prevayl 519. Th. preuayle.
After your thought, according to the same.
He hurteth both his worship and his name
That folily for twayne him-self wil trouble;
And he also leseth his after-game 523. H. hosithe (for leseth).
That surely can not sette his poyntes double.' 477-524. Follows 572 in F. H. 477 (Th.)=525 (F. H.).
'This your counsayl, by ought that I can see,
Is better sayd than don, to myn advyse;
Though I beleve it not, forgive it me,
Myn herte is suche, so hool without feyntyse, 528. H. hoole; Th. hole.
That it ne may give credence, in no wyse, 529. H. F. it; Th. I. H. F. om. ne.
To thing which is not sowning unto trouthe; 530. H. soundyng.
Other counsayl, it ar but fantasyes, 531. H. F. it ar; Th. I se be. Th. Ff. fantasise; F. fantasyse; H. fantaisise.
Save of your grace to shewe pitè and routhe.'
'I holde him wyse that worketh folily 533. H. F. Ff. folily; Th. no foly (!).
And, whan him list, can leve and part therfro; 534. H. Th. parte.
But in conning he is to lerne, trewly,
That wolde him-self conduite, and can not so. 536. F. condyte.
And he that wil not after counsayl do,
His sute he putteth in desesperaunce; 538. Th. Ff. sute; H. F. suerte. H. F. in; Th. in to.
And al the good, which that shulde falle him to, 539. Th. om. which. H. F. om. that.
Is left as deed, clene out of rémembraunce.' 540. H. F. Ff. left as; Th. lost and. F. dethe (!).
'Yet wil I sewe this mater faithfully
Whyls I may live, what-ever be my chaunce; 542. H. Ff. Whils; Th. Whyles. Th. om. may.
And if it hap that in my trouthe I dy,
That deeth shal not do me no displesaunce. 544. Th. Than; H. F. Ff. That. H. not; Th. F. om.
But whan that I, by your ful hard suffraunce, 545. Ff. full; rest om. Th. H. harde.
Shal dy so trew, and with so greet a payne, 546. H. triew; Th. true. H. grete; Th. great. F. Ff. om. a.
Yet shal it do me moche the lesse grevaunce 547. F. H. om. the; read mochel less?
Than for to live a fals lover, certayne.'
'Of me get ye right nought, this is no fable,
I nil to you be neither hard nor strayt; 550. H. F. nyl; Th. wyl. H. Th. harde.
And right wil not, nor maner customable, 551. Th. no man (for nor maner).
To think ye shulde be sure of my conceyt.
Who secheth sorowe, his be the receyt!
Other counsayl can I not fele nor see,
Nor for to lerne I cast not to awayte; 555. Th. cast me not.
Who wil therto, let him assay, for me!' 556. H. F. ther-to; Th. therof.
'Ones must it be assayd, that is no nay,
With such as be of reputacioun, 558. H. F. beth.
And of trew love the right devoir to pay 559. H. trewe; Th. true. Ff. devoyr; H. duetes; F. dewtis; Th. honour.
Of free hertes, geten by due raunsoun; 560. Th. gotten. H. F. due; Th. dewe.
For free wil holdeth this opinioun,
That it is greet duresse and discomfort 562. H. grete; Th. great. H. Th.-forte.
To kepe a herte in so strayt a prisoun,
That hath but oon body for his disport.' 564. H. F. oo; Ff. on; Th. one. H. Th.-porte.
'I know so many cases mervaylous 565. Ff. H. cases; rest causes.
That I must nede, of resoun, think certayn, 566. H. F. Which; Th. Ff. That.
That such entree is wonder perilous, 567. H. F. Ff. entre; Th. auenture (!).
And yet wel more, the coming bak agayn.
Good or worship therof is seldom seyn;
Wherefore I wil not make no suche aray 570. Th. Where I ne wyl make suche.
As for to fynde a plesaunce but barayn, 571. Th. but a; H. F. om. a.
Whan it shal cost so dere, the first assay.' 525-572. Follows 716 in F. H.
'Ye have no cause to doute of this matere, 573. F. matere; Th. mater.
Nor you to meve with no such fantasyes 574. Th. fantasyse; F. fantasise; H. fantesye.
To put me ferre al-out, as a straungere;
For your goodnesse can think and wel avyse, 576. F. Ff. avyse; Th. H. aduyse.
That I have made a prefe in every wyse 577. H. Ff. prefe; F. preue; Th. prise.
By which my trouth sheweth open evidence; 578. H. trouthe; Th. truthe.
My long abyding and my trew servyse 579. H. Th. trewe.
May wel be knowen by playn experience.'
'Of very right he may be called trew, 581. H. Th. trewe.
And so must he be take in every place,
That can deserve, and let as he ne knew, 583. H. Ff. deserue; Th. discerne (!). H. Th. knewe.
And kepe the good, if he it may purchace.
For who that prayeth or sueth in any case, 585. H. Ff. sueth; F. seweth; Th. swereth.
Right wel ye wot, in that no trouth is preved;
Suche hath ther ben, and are, that geten grace, 587. Th. geten; H. F. getith.
And lese it sone, whan they it have acheved.' 588. H. F. Ff. it haue; Th. haue it.
'If trouth me cause, by vertue soverayne,
To shew good love, and alway fynd contráry, 590. Th. H. shewe; fynde.
And cherish that which sleeth me with the payne,
This is to me a lovely adversary!
Whan that pitè, which long a-slepe doth tary,
Hath set the fyne of al myn hevinesse,
Yet her comfort, to me most necessary, 595. Th. H. comforte.
Shuld set my wil more sure in stablenesse.' 596. Ff. Shuld; H. F. Shulde; Th. Shal.
'The woful wight, what may he thinke or say?
The contrary of al joy and gladnesse.
A sick body, his thought is al away 599. Th. sycke; H. F. seke. F. om. his. H. F. Ff. al awaye; Th. alway.
From hem that fele no sorowe nor siknesse. 600. H. Ff. fele; Th. felen. H. sorwe; F. Ff. sorowe; Th. sore.
Thus hurtes ben of dyvers businesse
Which love hath put to right gret hinderaunce, 602. Th. om. right. Th. hindraunce.
And trouthe also put in forgetfulnesse
Whan they so sore begin to sighe askaunce.' 604. H. Ff. so; Th. ful; F. om.
'Now god defend but he be havëlesse 605. H. Th. defende. H. F. haueles; Th. harmlesse (!).
Of al worship or good that may befal,
That to the werst tourneth, by his lewdnesse, 607. Th. om. the.

In hem that kepe it long for wele or wo. 632. F. H. Ff. for; Th. in.

They be so wel reclaymed to the lure,

The feble socour of desesperaunce.'
'Resoun, counsayl, wisdom, and good avyse 653. F. Ff. avyse; Th. H. aduyse.
Ben under love arested everichoon,

And therwith bounden with so strong a cheyne

The lesse ye gete, as of your hertes rest,

'Ye say as falleth most for your plesaunce,
And your power is greet; al this I see; 686. Th. great.
But hope shal never out of my rémembraunce,
By whiche I felt so greet adversitè. 688. F. H. Ff. felt; Th. fele. Th. great.
For whan nature hath set in you plentè
Of al goodnesse, by vertue and by grace,
He never assembled hem, as semeth me, 691. H. F. semeth: Th. semed.
To put Pitè out of his dwelling-place.'
'Pitè of right ought to be resonable,
And to no wight of greet disavantage; 694. H. F. of; Th. do no.
There-as is nede, it shuld be profitable
And to the pitous shewing no damage. 696. F. damage; H. dammage; Th. Ff. domage.
If a lady wil do so greet out-rage 697. H. F. om. wil.

'To comforte hem that live al comfortlesse,

'What-ever he be that sayth he loveth me,

Of my pore lyfe, ful of adversitè!'

But he no more was in his ladies thought,

And afterward, oon tolde me thus expresse, 809. Th. Ff. thus; H. it; F. om.
He rente his heer, for anguissh and for payne,
And in him-self took so gret hevinesse 811. Th. great. TITLE; in. Th.
That he was deed, within a day or twayne.
Ye trew lovers, this I beseche you al, 813. H. F. Ff. Ye; Th. The. F. trew; H. trewe; Th. true. Th. thus; H. Ff. this.
Such †avantours, flee hem in every wyse, 814. Ff. aventours; rest aventures (see note). Th. flie; H. F. fle.
And as people defamed ye hem cal;
For they, trewly, do you gret prejudyse. 816. Th. great.
Refus hath mad for al such flateryes 817. Th. omits this line; from H. F. Ff. H. F. made. H. F. Ff. flaterise.
His castelles strong, stuffed with ordinaunce,
For they have had long tyme, by their offyce,
The hool countrè of Love in obeysaunce.
And ye, ladyes, or what estat ye be, 821. Th. H. estate; Ff. astate.
In whom Worship hath chose his dwelling-place, 822. H. F. Ff. In; Th. Of.
For goddes love, do no such crueltè,
Namely, to hem that have deserved grace. 824. Ff. haue; F. hath; H. om. Th. omits the line.
Nor in no wyse ne folowe not the trace 825. H. folwe ye not; F. folowe ye not; Ff. folowe not; Th. foule not.
Of her, that here is named rightwisly,
Which by resoun, me semeth, in this case
May be called LA BELLE DAME SANS MERCY. After 828, F. has—Explicit la bele dame sanz mercy; H. F. Verba translatoris.

DIV2.HEAD: Verba Translatoris.

LG.L: Go, litel book! god sende thee good passage! 829. Th. H. Ff. the.
Chese wel thy way; be simple of manere;
Loke thy clothing be lyke thy pilgrimage,
And specially, let this be thy prayere
Un-to hem al that thee wil rede or here, 833. H. F. om. al. All the.
Wher thou art wrong, after their help to cal 834. Th. hir (for their).
Thee to correcte in any part or al. 835. Th. H. The.
Pray hem also, with thyn humble servyce,
Thy boldënesse to pardon in this case; 837. Th. cace; H. caas.
For els thou art not able, in no wyse, 838. H. elles.
To make thy-self appere in any place.
And furthermore, beseche hem, of their grace,
By their favour and supportacioun, 840,841. Th. her (for their).
To take in gree this rude translacioun,
The which, god wot, standeth ful destitute 843. Th. H. wote.
Of eloquence, of metre, and of coloures, 844. Th. om. and.
Wild as a beest, naked, without refute, 845. H. F. Wilde; Th. Ff. Lyke.
Upon a playne to byde al maner shoures. 846. Ff. tabyde; Th. to abyde.
I can no more, but aske of hem socoures 847. H. axe.
At whos request thou mad were in this wyse, 848. Th. Ff. were made; F. was made; H. made was.
Commaunding me with body and servyse.
Right thus I make an ende of this processe, 850. H. F. Ff. processe; Th. prosses.
Beseching him that al hath in balaunce
That no trew man be vexed, causëlesse, 852. Th. H. trewe.
As this man was, which is of rémembraunce;
And al that doon their faythful observaunce, 854. Th. done her; Ff. do thair; H. dothe here; F. doth thair.
And in their trouth purpose hem to endure, 855. Th. her (for their).
I pray god sende hem better aventure.

DIV1.HEAD: XVIII. THE CUCKOO AND THE NIGHTINGALE; OR THE BOOK OF CUPID, GOD OF LOVE. From Th. (Thynne, ed. 1532); collated with F. (Fairfax 16); B. (Bodley 638); S. (Arch. Selden, B. 24); T. (Tanner 346); also in Ff. (Camb. Univ. Ff. 1. 6). TITLE: Th. Of the C. and the N.; F. B. The boke of Cupide, god of loue.

LG.L: THE god of love, a! benedicite! 1. Th. ah; F. a; S. a. a.
How mighty and how greet a lord is he! 2. Th. Howe; gret; lorde.
For he can make of lowe hertes hye,
And of hye lowe, and lyke for to dye, 4. Th. of his; Ff. S. of hye; F. B. high hertis.
And harde hertes he can maken free.
And he can make, within a litel stounde 6. F. B. S. Ff. And he; Th. om. And.
Of seke folk ful hole, fresshe and sounde, 7. Th. folke; om. ful.
And of [the] hole, he can make seke; 8. I supply the. S. hole folke.
And he can binden and unbinden eke 9. S. And he; rest om. And. Th. F. B. bynde; read binden.
What he wol have bounden or unbounde. 10. Th. T. That; F. B. Ff. What; S. Quhom.
To telle his might my wit may not suffyse; 11. Th. tel; wytte.
For he may do al that he wol devyse. 12. Th. Ff. wol; rest can.
For he can make of wyse folk ful nyce, 12, 13. Th. T. transpose these lines. 13. Th. folke.
And [eke] in lyther folk distroyen vyce; 14. I supply eke. Th. T. om. in (S. has in-to). F. lyther; S. lidder; Th. Ff. lythy; T. leþi. Th. folke. Th. T. to distroyen; rest om. to.
And proude hertes he can make agryse.
Shortly, al that ever he wol he may;
Ageines him ther dar no wight sey nay. 17. Ff. T. Ageynes; S. Ageynest; Th. Agaynst; F. B. Ayenst. Th. Ff. T. om. ther.
For he can gladde and greve whom him lyketh; 18. Th. glad; rest glade.
And, who that he wol, he laugheth or he syketh; 19. Th. loweth. S. has 2nd he; rest omit. F. B. don hym laugh or siketh.
And most his might he sheweth ever in May. 20. Th. T. shedeth.
For every trewe gentil herte free 21. Th. fre.
That with him is, or thinketh for to be, 22. F. B. om. for.
Ageines May now shal have som steringe 23. S. Ff. Aȝeynes; F. B. Ayenst; Th. T. Agayne. Th. nowe.
Other to joye, or elles to morninge, 24. F. B. Other; S. Outhir; Th. T. Ff. Or. Th. ioy. F. B. S. T. ellis; Th. els. Th. T. Ff. some mournyng; rest om. some.
In no sesoun so greet, as thinketh me. 25. F. B. grette; Ff. S. grete; Th. moche.
For whan they mowe here the briddes singe, 26. F. then; rest whan (when). Th. may; T. mai; F. B. S. mow; Ff. mowe. Th. byrdes; S. foulis; rest briddes.
And see the floures and the leves springe, 27. Th. leaues.
That bringeth into hertes rémembraunce 28. Th. T. her (for hertes).
A maner ese, medled with grevaunce, 29. Th. T. ease; S. ess; F. B. case (!). Ff. y-medled.
And lusty thoughtes fulle of greet longinge. 30. Th. ful; Ff. fulle. Th. great.
And of that longing cometh hevinesse,
And therof groweth ofte greet seknesse, 32. Th. great sicknesse.
And al for lak of that that they desyre; 33. S. all; rest om. Th. lacke.
And thus in May ben hertes sette on fyre,
So that they brennen forth in greet distresse. 35. Th. forthe; great.
I speke this of feling, trewely; 36. S. trewely; Th. trewly.

DIV1.HEAD: XX. THE FLOWER AND THE LEAF. From Speght's edition (1598); I note rejected readings.

LG.L: WHEN that Phebus his chaire of gold so hy 1. hie.
Had whirled up the sterry sky aloft,
And in the Bole was entred certainly; 3. Boole.
Whan shoures swete of rain discended †soft, 4. sweet; raine; oft (!).
Causing the ground, felë tymes and oft,
Up for to give many an hoolsom air, 6. wholesome aire.
And every plain was [eek y-]clothed fair 7. plaine was clothed faire.
With newe grene, and maketh smalë floures 8. new greene. small flours.
To springen here and there in feld and mede; 9. field and in mede.
So very good and hoolsom be the shoures 10. wholsome.
That it reneweth, that was old and deede 11. renueth.
In winter-tyme; and out of every seede
Springeth the herbë, so that every wight 13. hearbe.
Of this sesoun wexeth [ful] glad and light. 14. season; I supply ful.
And I, só glad of the seson swete, 15. season.
Was happed thus upon a certain night; 16. certaine.
As I lay in my bed, sleep ful unmete 17. sleepe.
Was unto me; but, why that I ne might
Rest, I ne wist; for there nas erthly wight, 19. earthly.
As I suppose, had more hertës ese 20. hearts ease.
Than I, for I n'ad siknesse nor disese. 21. Then; nad sicknesse; disease.
Wherfore I mervail gretly of my-selve, 22. meruaile greatly; selfe.
That I so long withouten sleepë lay;
And up I roos, three houres after twelve, 24. rose; twelfe.
About the [very] springing of the day, 25. I supply very.
And on I put my gere and myn array; 26. geare; mine.
And to a plesaunt grovë I gan passe, 27. pleasaunt.
Long or the brightë sonne uprisen was, 28. bright.
In which were okës grete, streight as a lyne, 29. great.
Under the which the gras, so fresh of hew, 30. grasse.
Was newly spronge; and an eight foot or nyne 31. sprong.
Every tree wel fro his felawe grew, 32. well; fellow.
With braunches brode, laden with leves new, 33. lade.
That sprongen out ayein the sonnë shene, 34. ayen.
Som very rede, and som a glad light grene; 35. Some; red; some.
Which, as me thought, was right a plesaunt sight. 36. song (read songes); fort (sic).
And eek the briddes song[ës] for to here
Would have rejoised any erthly wight. 38. earthly.
Here the nightingale of al the yere, 40. Heare; all.
Ful busily herkned, with herte and ere, 41. Full; herkened; hart and with eare.
If I her voice perceive coud any-where.
And at the last, a path of litel brede 43. litle breade.
I found, that gretly had not used be, 44. greatly.
For it forgrowen was with gras and weede, 45. grasse.
That wel unneth a wight [ther] might it see. 46. well; I supply ther.
Thought I, this path som whider goth, pardè, 47. some
And so I folowèd, til it me brought 48. followed till.
To right a plesaunt herber, wel y-wrought, 49. pleasaunt; well.
That benched was, and [al] with turves new 50. I supply al; turfes.
Freshly turved, wherof the grenë gras
So small, so thik, so short, so fresh of hew, 52. thicke.
That most lyk to grene †wol, wot I, it was. 53. lyke vnto (read to); wel (!; read wol).
The hegge also that yede [as] in compas 54. I supply as.
And closed in al the grene herbere, 55. (Perhaps imperfect); all; green.
With sicamour was set and eglantere, 56. eglatere; see l. 80.
Writhen in-fere so wel and cunningly 57. Wrethen.
That every braunch and leef grew by mesure, 58. branch; leafe.
Plain as a bord, of on height, by and by, 59. an (better on).
[That] I sy never thing, I you ensure,
So wel [y-]don; for he that took the cure
It [for] to make, I trow, did al his peyn
To make it passe al tho that men have seyn. 63. all; seyne.
And shapen was this herber, roof and al, 64. roofe.
As [is] a prety parlour, and also 65. I supply is.
The hegge as thik as [is] a castle-wal, 66. thicke; I supply is; wall.
That, who that list without to stond or go, 67. would all.
Though he wold al-day pryen to and fro,
He shuld not see if there were any wight 69. should.
Within or no; but oon within wel might 70. one; well.
Perceive al tho that yeden there-without 71. all.
In the feld, that was on every syde 72. field.
Covered with corn and gras, that, out of dout, 73. corne; grasse; doubt.
Though oon wold seeken al the world wyde, 74. one would seeke all.
So rich a feld [ne] coud not be espyed 75. field; I supply ne; espide.
[Up]on no cost, as of the quantitee, 76. On; coast; quantity.
For of al good thing ther was [greet] plentee. 77. all; I supply greet; plenty.
And I, that al this plesaunt sight [than] sy, 78. all; pleasaunt sight sie.
Thought sodainly I felt so sweet an air 79. aire.
[Come] of the eglantere, that certainly, 80. I supply Come; eglentere.
Ther is no hert, I deme, in such despair, 81. heart; dispaire.
Ne with [no] thoughtës froward and contrair 82. with thoughts; contraire.
So overlaid, but it shuld soone have bote, 83. should.
If it had onës felt this savour sote. 84. soote.
And as I stood and cast asyde myn y, 85. mine eie.
I was ware of the fairest medle-tree
That ever yet in al my lyf I sy, 87. all; life; sie.
As full of blossomës as it might be. 88. blosomes.
Therin a goldfinch leping pretily 89. leaping pretile.
Fro bough to bough, and, as him list, he eet
Here and there, of buddes and floures sweet. 91. buds.
And to the herber-sydë was joining
This fairë tree, of which I have you told;
And, at the last, the brid began to sing,
Whan he had eten what he etë wold. 95. eaten; eat.
So passing sweetly, that, by manifold,
It was more plesaunt than I coud devyse; 97. pleasaunt then.
And whan his song was ended in this wyse, 98. when.
The nightingale with so mery a note 99. merry.
Answéred him, that al the wodë rong 100. all; wood.
So sodainly, that, as it were a sot, 101. sote.
I stood astonied; so was I with the song
Through ravishèd, that, [un]til late and long 103. Thorow; till.
Ne wist I in what place I was, ne where; 104. I ne wist (better Ne wist I).
And †ay, me thought, she song even by myn ere. 105. ayen (!).
Wherfore about I waited busily 106. I waited about.
On every syde, if I her mightë see; 107. might.
And, at the last, I gan ful wel aspy 108. full well.
Wher she sat in a fresh green laurer-tree 109. greene laurey (error for laurer); see l. 158.
On the further syde, even right by me,
That gave so passing a delicious smel 111. smell.
According to the eglantere ful wel. 112. eglentere full well.
Wherof I had so inly greet plesyr 113. great pleasure.
That, as me thought, I surely ravished was
Into Paradyse, where my desyr 115. desire.
Was for to be, and no ferther [to] passe 116. I supply to.
As for that day, and on the sotë gras 117. grasse.
I sat me doun; for, as for myn entent, 118. downe; mine.
The birdës song was more convenient, 119. birds.
And more plesaunt to me, by many fold, 120. pleasaunt.
Than mete or drink, or any other thing; 121. meat; drinke.
Thereto the herber was so fresh and cold,
The hoolsom savours eek so comforting 123. wholsome; eke.
That, as I demed, sith the beginning
Of the world, was never seen, or than,
So plesaunt a ground of non erthly man. 126. pleasaunt; none earthly.
And as I sat, the briddës herkning thus, 127. birds harkening.
Me thought that I herd voices sodainly, 128. heard.
The most sweetest and most delicious
That ever any wight, I trow trewly,
Herde in †his lyf, for [that] the armony 131. Heard; their (error for his); I supply that.
And sweet accord was in so good musyk, 132. musike.
Thát the voice to angels most was lyk. 133. like.
At the last, out of a grove even by, The Leaf.
That was right goodly and plesaunt to sight, 135. pleasant.
I sy where there cam singing lustily 136. sie; came.
A world of ladies; but to tell aright
Their greet beautè, it lyth not in my might, 138. great beauty; lieth.
Ne their array; nevertheless, I shal 139. shall.
Tell you a part, though I speke not of al. 140. speake; all.
†In surcotes whyte, of veluet wel sitting, 141. The (!; read In); wele.
They were [y-]clad; and the semes echoon, 142. were clad; echone.
As it were a maner garnishing,
Was set with emeraudës, oon and oon, 144. Emerauds one and one.
By and by; but many a richë stoon 145. rich.
Was set [up-]on the purfils, out of dout, 146. on; purfiles.
Of colors, sleves, and trainës round about;
As gret[e] perlës, round and orient, 148. great pearles.
Diamondës fyne and rubies rede, 149. Diamonds; red.
And many another stoon, of which I †want 150. stone; went (for want).
The namës now; and everich on her hede 151. head.
A richë fret of gold, which, without drede, 152. rich; dread.
Was ful of statly richë stonës set; 153. stately rich.
And every lady had a chapëlet
On her hede, of [leves] fresh and grene, 155. head; I supply leves.
So wel [y-]wrought, and so mervéilously, 156. wele wrought; meruelously.
Thát it was a noble sight to sene;
Some of laurer, and some ful plesauntly 158. pleasantly.
Had chapëlets of woodbind, and sadly
Some of agnus-castus ware also 160. were; read ware, as in 335.
Chápëlets fresh; but there were many tho 161. of tho (om. of).
That daunced and eek song ful soberly; 162. eke.
But al they yede in maner of compas. 163. all; compace.
But oon ther yede in-mid the company 164. one.
Sole by her-self; but al folowed the pace 165. Soole; selfe; all followed.
[Which] that she kept, whos hevenly-figured face 166. I supply Which; whose heauenly.
So plesaunt was, and her wel-shape persòn, 167. pleasaunt; wele.
That of beautè she past hem everichon. 168. beauty; -one.
And more richly beseen, by manifold, 169. beseene.
She was also, in every maner thing;
On her heed, ful plesaunt to behold, 171. head; pleasaunt.
A crowne of gold, rich for any king; 172. goldë (?).
A braunch of agnus-castus eek bering 173. eke bearing.
In her hand; and, to my sight, trewly,
She lady was of [al] the company. 175. I supply al.
And she began a roundel lustily, 176. roundell lustely.
That Sus le foyl de vert moy men call, 177. Suse; foyle.
