LG.L: And than the company answéred all
With voice[s] swete entuned and so small, 180. voice sweet.
That me thought it the sweetest melody
That ever I herdë in my lyf, soothly. 182. heard.
And thus they came[n], dauncing and singing, 183. came.
Into the middes of the mede echone,
Before the herber, where I was sitting,
And, god wot, me thought I was wel bigon; 186. bigone.
For than I might avyse hem, on by on, 187. one by one.
Who fairest was, who coud best dance or sing,
Or who most womanly was in al thing. 189. all.
They had not daunced but a litel throw 190. little.
When that I herd, not fer of, sodainly 191. heard.
So greet a noise of thundring trumpës blow, 192. great; thunder∣ing trumps.
As though it shuld have départed the sky; 193. skie.
And, after that, within a whyle I sy 194. sie.
From the same grove, where the ladyes come out,
Of men of armës coming such a rout 196. comming.
As al the men on erth had been assembled 197. all.
In that place, wel horsed for the nones, 198. wele.
Stering so fast, that al the erth[ë] trembled; 199. all; earth.
But for to speke of riches and [of] stones, 200. speake; I supply of.
And men and hors, I trow, the largë wones 201. horse.
Of Prester John, ne al his tresory 202. Pretir (!); all.
Might not unneth have bought the tenth party!
Of their array who-so list herë more, 204. their (read hir?); heare.
I shal reherse, so as I can, a lyte. 205. rehearse.
Out of the grove, that I spak of before, 206. spake.
I sy come first, al in their clokes whyte, 207. sie; all; their (read hir?).
A company, that ware, for their delyt, 208. were: read ware (as in 329); delite.
Chapëlets fresh of okës cereal 209. seriall (for cereal).
Newly spronge, and trumpets they were al. 210. sprong; all.
On every trumpe hanging a brood banere 211. broad.
Of fyn tartarium, were ful richly bete; 212. fine; richely.
Every trumpet his lordës armës †bere; 213. lords; here (read bere); see
About their nekkës, with gret perlës set, 214. (and often): their (for hir). neckes; great pearles.
Colers brode; for cost they would not lete,
As it would seme; for their scochones echoon 216. echone.
Were set about with many a precious stoon. 217. stone.
Their hors-harneys was al whyte also; 218. horse; all.
And after hem next, in on company, 219. them (for hem); one.
Cámë kingës of armës, and no mo, 220. kings.
In clokës of whyte cloth of gold, richly;
Chapelets of greene on their hedes on hy, 222. heads; hye.
The crownës that they on their scochones bere 223. crowns.
Were set with perlë, ruby, and saphere, 224. pearle.
And eek gret diamondës many on; 225. eke great Diamonds; one.
But al their hors-harneys and other gere 226. all; horse; geare.
Was in a sute according, everichon, 227. euerichone.
As ye have herd the foresayd trumpets were; 228. heard.
And, by seeming, they were nothing to lere;
And their gyding they did so manerly. 230. there guiding.
And after hem cam a greet company 231. great.
Of heraudës and pursevauntës eke 232. herauds; pur∣seuaunts.
Arrayed in clothës of whyt veluët; 233. white.
And hardily, they were nothing to seke
How they [up]on hem shuld the harneys set; 235. on; should.
And every man had on a chapëlet;
Scóchones and eke hors-harneys, indede, 237. horse.
They had in sute of hem that before hem yede. 238. him (for 2nd hem).
Next after hem, came in armour bright,

And every clasp and nail, as to my sight, 241. claspe; naile.
Of their harneys, were of red gold fyne; 242. their (for hir?); so in 214, 216, 218, 222, 223, 230 (there), 240; &c.
With cloth of gold, and furred with ermyne
Were the trappurës of their stedës strong, 244. their (for hir?); so in 248, &c.
Wyde and large, that to the ground did hong;
And every bosse of brydel and peitrel 246. boose (!); bridle; paitrell.
That they had, was worth, as I would wene,
A thousand pound; and on their hedës, wel 248. heads well.
Dressed, were crownës [al] of laurer grene, 249. I supply al.
The best [y-]mad that ever I had seen; 250. made; sene.
And every knight had after him ryding
Three henshmen, [up]on him awaiting; 252. on.
Of whiche †the first, upon a short tronchoun, 253. whiche euery on a.
His lordës helme[t] bar, so richly dight, 254. lords helme bare.
That the worst was worth[y] the raunsoun 255. worth.
Of a[ny] king; the second a sheld bright 256. a (read any); shield.

And after hem, on many a fresh co[u]rsere,

And al they ware[n], after their degrees, 267. were; read waren.
Chapëlets new, made of laurer grene,
Some of oke, and some of other trees;
Some in their handës berë boughës shene, 270. honds bare.
Some of laurer, and some of okës kene,
Some of hawthorn, and some of woodbind, 272. hauthorne.
And many mo, which I had not in mind.
And so they came, their hors freshly stering 274. horses.
With bloody sownës of hir trompës loud;
Ther sy I many an uncouth disgysing 276. sie; disguising.
In the array of these knightës proud; 277. knights.
And at the last, as evenly as they coud,
They took their places in-middes of the mede, 279. their (for hir? see 275); so in 286, &c.
And every knight turned his horse[s] hede 280. horse.
To his felawe, and lightly laid a spere 281. fellow; speare.
In the [a]rest, and so justës began 282. rest.
On every part about[en], here and there; 283. about.

Toward the ladies on the grenë plain, 297. green.
That song and daunced, as I sayd now right.

They breke[n] of both the song and dance, 300. brake; they (error for the).

With levës lade, the boughës of gret brede; 305. great.
And to my dome, there never was, indede,
[A] man that had seen half so fair a tree; 307. I supply A; halfe; faire.
For underneth it there might wel have be 308. underneath.
An hundred persons, at their own plesaunce, 309. their (for hir?); plesance.

So that they shuld have felt no [greet] grevaunce 311. should; I supply greet.
Of rain, ne hail, that hem hurt[ë] might. 312. raine; haile; hurt.
The savour eek rejoice would any wight 313. eke.
That had be sick or melancolious, 314. sicke; melancolius.

DIV1.HEAD: XXI. THE ASSEMBLY OF LADIES. From Th. (Thynne, ed. 1532); compared with A. (Addit. 34360); and T. (Trin. R. 3. 19). TITLE. Th. The assemble of ladies; T. the Boke callyd Assemble de Damys.

I am redy, that may be to your ese." 448. ease.
We folowed her unto the chambre-dore,
"Sisters," quod she, "come ye in after me."
But wite ye wel, there was a paved flore, 451. A. wite; Th. wete; T. wote.
The goodliest that any wight might see; 452. se.
And furthermore, about than loked we 453. aboute.
On eche corner, and upon every wal, 454. A. eche a corner.
The which was mad of berel and cristal; 455. A. The; Th. T. om. made. A. berel; Th. Burel; T. byralle.
Wherein was graven of stories many oon; 456. one.
First how Phyllis, of womanly pitè, 457. howe.
Deyd pitously, for love of Demophoon. 458. A. Deyd; Th. Dyed. Demophone.
Nexte after was the story of Tisbee, 459. Th. Tysbe; A. T. Thesbe.
How she slew her-self under a tree. 460. slowe; -selfe.
Yet saw I more, how in right pitous cas 461. sawe; howe. Th. T. a right; A. om. a.
For Antony was slayn Cleopatras. 462. slayne.
That other syde was, how Hawes the shene 463. Th. T. was Hawes the shene; A. was how Enclusene (? error for Melusine).
Untrewly was disceyved in her bayn. 464. A. Vntriewly was; Th. T. Ful vntrewly. bayne.
There was also Annelida the quene,
Upon Arcyte how sore she did complayn. 466. howe; complayne.
Al these stories were graved there, certayn; 467. certayne.
And many mo than I reherce you here;
It were to long to tel you al in-fere. 469. longe.
And, bicause the wallës shone so bright, 470. shone (=shoon).
With fyne umple they were al over-sprad, 471. Th. A. vmple; T. vmpylle.
To that intent, folk shuld nat hurte hir sight; 472. folke shulde.
And thorugh it the stories might be rad. 473. Th. through; A. thurgh (=thorugh; see 436).
Than furthermore I went, as I was lad;
And there I saw, without[en] any fayl, 475. sawe. All without. fayle.
A chayrë set, with ful riche aparayl. 476. aparayle.
And fyve stages it was set fro the ground, 477. grounde.
Of cassidony ful curiously wrought;
With four pomelles of golde, and very round, 479. rounde.
Set with saphyrs, as good as coud be thought; 480. coude.
That, wot ye what, if it were thorugh sought, 481. wote. T. thorow; A. thurgh (=thorugh; Th. through (see 473).
As I suppose, fro this countrey til Inde, 482. A. til; Th. T. to.
Another suche it were right fer to finde! 483. farre.
For, wite ye wel, I was right nere that, 484. A. wite; Th. wete; T. wot.
So as I durst, beholding by and by;
Above ther was a riche cloth of estate,
Wrought with the nedle ful straungëly, 487. T. nedylle.
Her word thereon; and thus it said trewly, 488. worde.
A endurer, to tel you in wordës few, 489. A. endurer; Th. T. endure. All you.
With grete letters, the better I hem knew. 490. great; knewe.
Thus as we stode, a dore opened anon; 491. anone.
A gentilwoman, semely of stature,
Beringe a mace, cam out, her-selfe aloon; 493. came; alone.
Sothly, me thought, a goodly crëature! 494. Sothely.
She spak nothing to lowde, I you ensure, 495. spake nothynge.
Nor hastily, but with goodly warning: 496. A. T. hastily; Th. hastely. warnynge.
"Mak room," quod she, "my lady is coming!" 497. A. roome; Th. T. rome. comynge.
With that anon I saw Perséveraunce, 498. sawe.
How she held up the tapet in her hand. 499. helde; hande.
I saw also, in right good ordinaunce, 500. sawe. A. goode; Th. T. goodly.
This greet lady within the tapet stand, 501. great; stande.
Coming outward, I wol ye understand; 502. -stande.
And after her a noble company,
I coud nat tel the nombre sikerly. 504. coude.
Of their namës I wold nothing enquere 505. (above): T. Attemperaunce chaunclere. wolde.
Further than suche as we wold sewe unto, 506. wolde. T. sew; A. sue.
Sauf oo lady, which was the chauncellere, 507. A. Sauf oo; Th. Saue a.
Attemperaunce; sothly her name was so. 508. sothely.
For us nedeth with her have moch to do 509. moche.
In our maters, and alway more and more. 510. A. matiers. alwaye.
And, so forth, to tel you furthermore, 511. forthe.
Of this lady her beautè to discryve,
My conning is to simple, verely; 513. connynge.
For never yet, the dayës of my lyve, 514. A. dayes of al my.
So inly fair I have non seen, trewly. 515. fayre. A. none sene; Th. sene none; T. noon seen.
In her estate, assured utterly,
There wanted naught, I dare you wel assure, 517. A. you; Th. T. om.
That longed to a goodly crëature.
And furthermore, to speke of her aray,
I shal you tel the maner of her gown; 520. gowne.
Of clothe of gold ful riche, it is no nay;
The colour blew, of a right good fasoun; 522. coloure blewe. T. good; Th. goodly. facyoun.
In tabard-wyse the slevës hanging doun; 523. Th. taberde; T. taberd. T. doun; Th. adowne.
And what purfyl there was, and in what wyse,
So as I can, I shal it you devyse.
After a sort the coller and the vent, 526. sorte; vente (T. vent).
Lyk as ermyne is mad in purfeling; 527. T. ermyn; Th. Armyne. made; purfelynge.
With grete perlës, ful fyne and orient, 528. Th. great; T. gret.
They were couchèd, al after oon worching, 529. one worchynge.
With dyamonds in stede of powdering; 530. Th. diamondes; T. dyamondes. powderynge.
The slevës and purfilles of assyse; 531. T. purfyllys; Th. purfel (!).
They were [y-]mad [ful] lyke, in every wyse. 519-532. Missing in A. 532. Both made lyke (!).
Aboute her nekke a sort of fair rubyes, 533. sorte.
In whyte floures of right fyne enamayl; 534. enamayle.
Upon her heed, set in the freshest wyse, 535. A. fresshest; Th. T. fayrest.
A cercle with gret balays of entayl; 536. A. with; Th. T. of. great; entayle.
That, in ernest to speke, withouten fayl, 537. A. withouten; Th. T. without. fayle.
For yonge and olde, and every maner age,
It was a world to loke on her visage. 539. worlde. A. T. loke; Th. loken.
Thus coming forth, to sit in her estat, 540. comynge forthe; estate.
In her presence we kneled down echon, 541. downe. A. eche on; Th. T. euerychone.
Presentinge up our billes, and, wot ye what, 542. A. T. vp; Th. om. wote.
Ful humb[el]ly she took hem, by on and on; 543. toke; one and one.
When we had don, than cam they al anon, 544. done; came; anone.
And did the same, eche after her manere,
Knelinge at ones, and rysinge al in-fere.
Whan this was don, and she set in her place, 547. A. Whan; Th. T. And whan. done.
The chamberlayn she did unto her cal; 548. -layne.
And she, goodly coming til her a-pace, 549. A. til; T. to; Th. vnto.
Of her entent knowing nothing at al,
"Voyd bak the prees," quod she, "up to the wal; 551. Voyde backe; preace.
Mak larger roum, but look ye do not tary, 552. Make. A. larger; Th. T. large. roume; loke.
And tak these billës to the secretary." 553. take; secretarye.
The chamberlayn did her commaundëment, 554. -layne.
And cam agayn, as she was bid to do; 555. came agayne.
The secretary there being present, 556. -tarye.
The billës were delivered her also, 558. onely.
Not only ours, but many other mo. 559. agayne.
Than the lady, with good advyce, agayn 560. -layne.
Anon withal called her chamberlayn.
"We wol," quod she, "the first thing that ye do,
The secretary, make her come anon 562. Th. secretarye ye do make come; A. T. secretary make hir come.
With her billës; and thus we wil also,
In our presence she rede hem everichon,
That we may takë good advyce theron 565. maye. A. avise; T. auyse.
Of the ladyes, that been of our counsayl; 566. counsayle.
Look this be don, withouten any fayl." 567. Loke; done; fayle.
The chamberlayn, whan she wiste her entent, 568. A. The chambrelayn whan she wist; Th. T. Whan the chamberlayne wyste of.
Anon she did the secretary cal: 569. -tarye.
"Let your billës," quod she, "be here present,
My lady it wil." "Madame," quod she, "I shal." 571. A. om. it.
"And in presence she wil ye rede hem al." 572. A. ye rede hem al; T. yow there cal (!); Th. ye hem cal (!); Th. ye hem cal (!).
"With good wil; I am redy," quod she, 573. A. gode.
"At her plesure, whan she commaundeth me."
And upon that was mad an ordinaunce,
They that cam first, hir billës shuld be red. 576. came. Th. shuld; A. T. to. T. red; A. Th. redde.
Ful gentelly than sayd Perséveraunce,
"Resoun it wold that they were sonest sped." 578. Rayson. A. T. wold that; Th. wyl. spedde.
Anon withal, upon a tapet spred, 579. spredde.
The secretary layde hem doun echon; 580. -tarie; downe echone.
Our billës first she redde hem on by on. 581. T. rad. T. theym (=hem); Th. A. om. one by one.
The first lady, bering in her devyse 582. bearyng.
Sans que jamais, thus wroot she in her bil; 583. A. T. in; Th. on.
Complayning sore and in ful pitous wyse
Of promesse mad with faithful hert and wil 585. made.
And so broken, ayenst al maner skil,
Without desert alwayes on her party; 587. deserte; partye.
In this mater desyring remedy. 588. A. matier. Th. T. a remedy; A. om. a.
Her next felawës word was in this wyse, 589. A. next felawes word; Th. T. next folowing her word.
Une sanz chaungier; and thus she did complayn, 590. A. Une; Th. T. Vng. T. saunz chaunger. complayne.
Though she had been guerdoned for her servyce,
Yet nothing lyke as she that took the payn; 592. toke; payne.
Wherfore she coude in no wyse her restrayn, 593. restrayne.
But in this cas sewe until her presence, 594. case.
As reson woldë, to have recompence. 595. reason.
So furthermore, to speke of other twayn, 596. twayne.
Oon of hem wroot, after her fantasy, 597. wrote.
Oncques puis lever; and, for to tel you plain, 598. A. Oncques; Th. Vncques; T. Vnques. playne.
Her complaynt was ful pitous, verely, 599. A. grevous (for pitous).
For, as she sayd, ther was gret reson why; 600. great reason.
And, as I can remembre this matere, 601. A. And; Th. T. om.
I shal you tel the proces, al in-fere. 602. processe.
Her bil was mad, complayninge in her gyse, 603. made.
That of her joy, her comfort and gladnesse 604. comforte.
Was no suretee; for in no maner wyse 605. Th. surete; A. suerte; T. seurte.
She fond therin no point of stablenesse, 606. A. fonde; Th. T. sayd (!).
Now il, now wel, out of al sikernesse; 607. Nowe; wele.
Ful humbelly desyringe, of her grace, 608. Th. humbly; A. humble (!); read humbelly. her high grace; A. om. high.
Som remedy to shewe her in this cace. 609. A. Som remedy to chewe (!); in; Th. T. Soone to shewe her remedy in.
Her felawe made her bil, and thus she sayd, 610. sayde.
In playning wyse; there-as she loved best, 611. playnynge.
Whether she were wroth or wel apayd 612. wrothe. wele apayde.
She might nat see, whan [that] she wold faynest; 613. se; wolde. I supply that.
And wroth she was, in very ernest; 614. wrothe.
To tel her word, as ferforth as I wot, 615. worde; wote.
Entierment vostre, right thus she wroot. 616. wrote.
And upon that she made a greet request 617. great.
With herte and wil, and al that might be don 618. done.
As until her that might redresse it best;
For in her mind thus might she finde it sone, 620. mynde. A. thus; Th. T. there.
The remedy of that, which was her boon; 621. whiche; boone.
Rehersing [that] that she had sayd before, 622. Rehersynge. I supply that.
Beseching her it might be so no more. 623. Besechynge.
And in lyk wyse as they had don before, 624. lyke; done.
The gentilwomen of our company
Put up hir billës; and, for to tel you more, 626. A. vp; Th. T. om.
Oon of hem wroot cest sanz dire, verily; 627. One; wrote.
And her matere hool to specify, 628. hole. A. Of hir compleynt also the cause why; T. om. this line.
With-in her bil she put it in wryting; 629. writinge.
And what it sayd, ye shal have knowleching. 630. A. knowlachyng; Th. T. knowynge.
It sayd, god wot, and that ful pitously, 631. wote.
Lyke as she was disposed in her hert, 632. herte.
No misfortune that she took grevously; 633. toke.
Al oon to her it was, the joy and smert, 634. one. A. til. A. it; Th. T. om. smerte.
Somtyme no thank for al her good desert. 635. thanke; deserte.
Other comfort she wanted non coming, 636. comforte. A. wayted; Th. T. wanted. comynge.
And so used, it greved her nothing. 637. -thynge.
Desyringe her, and lowly béseching, 638. besechynge.
That she for her wold seke a better way, 639. A. T. for her wold; Th. wolde for her.
As she that had ben, al her dayes living, 640. A. al; Th. T. om. lyuynge.
Stedfast and trew, and so wil be alway. 641. trewe. A. so; Th. T. om.
Of her felawe somwhat I shal you say, 642. saye.
Whos bil was red next after forth, withal; 643. nexte. A. after; Th. T. om. forthe.
And what it ment rehersen you I shal.
En dieu est, she wroot in her devyse; 645. diu; wrote.
And thus she sayd, withouten any fayl, 646. A. any; Th. T. om. fayle.
Her trouthë might be taken in no wyse 647. T. takyn; Th. A. take.
Lyke as she thought, wherfore she had mervayl; 648. meruaile.
For trouth somtyme was wont to take avayl 649. auayle.
In every matere; but al that is ago;
The more pitè, that it is suffred so.
Moch more there was, wherof she shuld complayn, 652. shulde.
But she thought it to greet encomb[e]raunce 653. great. All encombraunce.
So moch to wryte; and therfore, in certayn, 654. moche.
In god and her she put her affiaunce 655. Th. T. al her; A. om. al.
As in her worde is mad a remembraunce; 656. made.
Beseching her that she wolde, in this cace,
Shewe unto her the favour of her grace.
The third, she wroot, rehersing her grevaunce, 659. wrote.
Ye! wot ye what, a pitous thing to here; 660. thinge.
For, as me thought, she felt gret displesaunce, 661. felte great.
Oon might right wel perceyve it by her chere, 662. A. om. right.
And no wonder; it sat her passing nere. 663. sate; passynge.
Yet loth she was to put it in wryting, 664. lothe; wrytynge.
But nede wol have his cours in every thing. 665. A. his; T. a; Th. om. thinge.
Soyes en sure, this was her word, certayn, 666. A. Se iour (for Soyes). worde certayne.
And thus she wroot, but in a litel space; 667. wrote. A. but; Th. T. om.
There she lovëd, her labour was in vayn, 668. vayne.
For he was set al in another place;
Ful humblely desyring, in that cace, 670. Th. T. humbly; A. humble (!); see 607. desyrynge.
Som good comfort, her sorow to appese, 671. comforte; sorowe.
That she might livë more at hertes ese. 672. ease.
The fourth surely, me thought, she liked wele,
As in her porte and in her behaving;
And Bien moneste, as fer as I coud fele, 675. Th. moneste; T. A. monest. farre; coude.
That was her word, til her wel belonging. 676. worde.
Wherfore to her she prayed, above al thing,
Ful hertely (to say you in substaunce) 678. T. tell (for say).
That she wold sende her good continuaunce. 679. wolde.
"Ye have rehersed me these billës al,
But now, let see somwhat of your entent." 681. lete se.
"It may so hap, paraventure, ye shal.
Now I pray you, whyle I am here present, 683. Nowe.
Ye shal, pardè, have knowlege, what I ment. 684. A. T. parde have knowlache; Th. haue knowlege parde.
But thus I say in trouthe, and make no fable,
The case itself is inly lamentable. 686. selfe.
And wel I wot, that ye wol think the same, 687. wote. A. that; Th. T. om. thinke.
Lyke as I say, whan ye have herd my bil." 688. herde.
"Now good, tel on, I hate you, by saynt Jame!" 689. Nowe. All hate (=hote).
"Abyde a whyle; it is nat yet my wil.
Yet must ye wite, by reson and by skil, 691. A. wite; Th. T. wete. reason.
Sith ye know al that hath be don before:—" 692. A. knowe al that hath be done afore; Th. T. haue knowledge of that was done before.
And thus it sayd, without[en] wordes more. 693. A. it; Th. T. it is (om. is). All without. A. any (for wordes).
"Nothing so leef as deth to come to me 694. Nothynge. A. lief; T. leef; Th. lefe. dethe.
For fynal ende of my sorowes and payn; 695. payne.
What shulde I more desyre, as semë ye?
And ye knewe al aforn it for certayn, 697. aforne; certayne.
I wot ye wolde; and, for to tel you playn, 698. wote.
Without her help that hath al thing in cure 699. helpe; thinge.
I can nat think that I may longe endure. 700. thinke. T. I; Th. A. it.
As for my trouthe, it hath be proved wele,
To say the sothe, I can [you] say no more, 702. I supply you.
Of ful long tyme, and suffred every dele 703. longe.
In pacience, and kepe it al in store;
Of her goodnesse besechinge her therfore
That I might have my thank in suche [a] wyse 706. thanke. I supply a.
As my desert deserveth of justyse." 707. deserte. A. deservith; Th. T. serueth.
Whan these billës were rad everichon, 708. -one.
This lady took a good advysement; 709. A. This lady; Th. T. The ladyes. toke.
And hem to answere, ech by on and on, 710. A. ech; Th. T. om.
She thought it was to moche in her entent;
Wherfore she yaf hem in commaundëment, 712. A. yaf; Th. T. yaue. T. in; Th. A. om.
In her presence to come, bothe oon and al, 713. one.
To yeve hem there her answer general. 714. A. hem there hir answere; Th. T. hem her answere in.
What did she than, suppose ye verely?
She spak herself, and sayd in this manere, 716. spake; -selfe.
"We have wel seen your billës by and by, 717. sene.
And some of hem ful pitous for to here. 718. A. T. ful; Th. om.
We wol therfore ye knowe al this in-fere,
Within short tyme our court of parliment 720. shorte; courte.
Here shal be holde, in our palays present; 721. A. T. paleys.
And in al this wherin ye find you greved, 722. fynde.
Ther shal ye finde an open remedy
In suche [a] wyse, as ye shul be releved 724. I supply a. A. shul; Th. T. shal.
Of al that ye reherce here, thoroughly. 725. T. thoroughly; Th. throughly; A. triewly.
As for the date, ye shul know verily, 726. shal (see 724); knowe.
That ye may have a space in your coming;
For Diligence shal it tel you by wryting." 728. So Th.; A. shal bryng it yow bi; T. shall hyt yow tell by.
We thanked her in our most humble wyse, 729. moste.
Our felauship, echon by oon assent, 730. eche one by one.
Submitting us lowly til her servyse.
For, as we thought, we had our travayl spent 732. A. vs(for 1st we). trauayle.
In suche [a] wyse as we helde us content. 733. I supply a.
Than eche of us took other by the sleve, 734. toke.
And forth withal, as we shuld take our leve. 735. forthe; shulde.
Al sodainly the water sprang anon 736. sprange anone.
In my visage, and therwithal I wook:— 737. woke.
"Where am I now?" thought I; "al this is gon;" 738. nowe; gone.
And al amased, up I gan to look. 739. A. Al amased vp; Th. T. Al mased and vp (read And al amased up). loke.
With that, anon I went and made this book, 740. boke.
Thus simplely rehersing the substaunce, 741. All simply.
Bicause it shuld not out of remembraunce.'— 742. shulde. Th. T. be out; A. out (om. be).
'Now verily, your dreem is passing good, 743. Nowe; dreame.
And worthy to be had in rémembraunce;
For, though I stande here as longe as I stood, 745. stode.
It shuld to me be non encomb[e]raunce; 746. shulde; none. All encombraunce.
I took therin so inly greet plesaunce. 747. toke; great.
But tel me now, what ye the book do cal? 748. nowe; boke.
For I must wite.' 'With right good wil ye shal: 749. A. wite; Th. T. wete.
As for this book, to say you very right, 750. boke.
And of the name to tel the certeyntè, 751. So A.; Th. T. Of the name to tel you in certaynte (T. certayn).
L'ASSEMBLÈ DE DAMES, thus it hight; 752. A. La semble; T. Lassembyll.
How think ye?' 'That the name is good, pardè!' 753. Howe thynke. A. the; Th. T. om.
'Now go, farwel! for they cal after me, 754. Nowe.
My felawes al, and I must after sone;
Rede wel my dreem; for now my tale is doon.' 756. dreme; done.

DIV1.TRAILER: Here endeth the Book of Assemble de Damys. COLOPHON: in T.only.

DIV1.HEAD: XXVI. PROSPERITY. XXVI. From MS. Arch. Seld. B. 24, fol. 119; I give rejected spellings.

LG.L: RICHT as povert causith sobirnes,
And febilnes enforcith contenence,
Richt so prosperitee and gret riches 3. Rycht; grete.
The moder is of vice and negligence;
And powere also causith insolence;
And honour oftsiss chaungith gude thewis;
Thare is no more perilous pestilence 7. perilouss.
Than hie estate geven unto schrewis.

DIV1.HEAD: XXVII. LEAULTE VAULT RICHESSE. XXVII. From MS. Arch. Seld. B. 24, fol. 138; I give rejected spellings.

LG.L: THIS warldly joy is only fantasy, 1. Ioy; onely.
Of quhich non erdly wicht can be content;
Quho most has wit, lest suld in it affy, 3. leste.
Quho taistis it most, most sall him repent;
Quhat valis all this richess and this rent,
Sen no man wat quho sall his tresour have? 6. wate.
Presume nocht gevin that god has don but lent, 7. done.
Within schort tyme the quhiche he thinkis to crave.

DIV1.HEAD: XXVIII. SAYINGS PRINTED BY CAXTON. XXVIII. From Caxton's print of Chaucer's Anelida, &c.; see vol. i. p. 46. Also in ed. 1542, in later spelling.

LG.L: WHAN feyth failleth in prestes sawes,
And lordes hestes ar holden for lawes,
And robbery is holden purchas,
And lechery is holden solas,
Than shal the lond of Albyon
Be brought to grete confusioun.
Hit falleth for every gentilman 7. Cx. euery.
To saye the best that he can
In [every] mannes absence, 9. I supply every.
And the soth in his presence.
Hit cometh by kynde of gentil blode
To cast away al hevines, 12. Cx. heuynes.
And gadre to-gidre wordes good;
The werk of wisdom berith witnes. 14. Cx. wisedom.

DIV1.HEAD: XXIX. BALADE IN PRAISE OF CHAUCER. XXIX. From MS. Trin. R. 3. 19, fol. 25; also in Stowe (ed. 1561).

LG.L: MASTER Geffray Chauser, that now lyth in grave, 1. MS. Chausers; Stowe, Chauser.
The nobyll rethoricien, and poet of Gret Bretayne, 2. Rethoricion (!).
That worthy was the lawrer of poetry have
For thys hys labour, and the palme attayne;
Whych furst made to dystyll and reyne
The gold dew-dropys of speche and eloquence 6. elloquence.
In-to Englyssh tong, thorow hys excellence.
